text: They moved my project deadline up again without even telling me. I've been working late every night this week to stay ahead, and now I'm supposed to drop everything and pivot in two hours. The client didn't even ask for this change—someone just decided to impress them with speed. I'll get it done, but not without wanting to throw my laptop out the window first.

The train leaves at 7:12, not that I’ve been checking my watch every few minutes or anything. I packed and repacked my bag twice, just in case I forgot something important. The address is saved in my phone, but I wrote it down anyway. There’s a chance it rains, but I didn’t leave room for an umbrella. I wonder if they’ll already be there when I arrive.

Made extra soup tonight because I knew Sam would come by after their shift. Left it on the stove with a note and fresh bread—hope they’re not too tired. Their hands are always cold this time of year, so I put out the thick gloves too. It’s quiet now, but I like knowing someone’s home is a little warmer because of this.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges like tiny black roots. No name, no date—just left to rot behind a week-old yogurt. I tossed it, but the plastic wrap snapped and some of the sludge dripped onto my hand. Even after scrubbing, I keep feeling it. Can't stop thinking about who would just abandon food like that.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I swear I heard footsteps above me, even though the second floor has been empty since we moved in. I keep telling myself it’s the house settling, but my hands won’t stop shaking. I left my phone upstairs, but I can’t make myself go get it. Every creak makes my breath catch, like something’s waiting just out of sight.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, making the dew on the grass sparkle like someone had tossed confetti. I caught myself smiling at the dog, who was too busy chasing a leaf to notice. Took the long way home just to hear the birds and feel the breeze. Felt good to move without rushing. Even the coffee tasted better today, somehow.

I bought a new notebook today, the one with the marbled cover. It’s sitting on the desk next to my laptop. I haven’t written anything in it yet. The pen that came with it rolls a little when I tilt the table. I’ll probably start using it tomorrow, after I finish sorting the receipts.

I walked past the park today and saw the bench where we used to sit. The oak tree we engraved our names into is gone, cut down or maybe just rotten by now. There’s a new fence around the garden, and the flowers are different. I didn’t realize how much I remembered until none of it looked familiar. It’s strange how a place can feel so empty when it’s technically still there. I sat for a while anyway.

I was just about to microwave my lunch when the cat jumped straight into the laundry basket and started digging around like she was on a mission. I swear she pulled out one of my socks and carried it off like she’d won a prize. I didn’t even know she could open the basket flap. Now she’s sitting in the hallway, staring at the door like she’s expecting someone. I’ve never seen her do anything like that before.

They moved the deadline up again without telling the whole team. I found out by accident when I overheard Sarah talking in the break room. My project depends on inputs from three other people who now have zero incentive to deliver on time. All that work, just to hit a wall because someone couldn't send one email. I’ll fix it, but not before letting them know exactly how much extra time this cost.

I keep checking the clock, noticing how the light shifts across the floor. My coffee's gone cold, but I don't get up to reheat it. The envelope with the logo in the corner sits face down on the table. Every time the wind pushes a cloud over the sun, I wonder if it's a sign to peek. I told myself I'd wait until 4 p.m., and the kitchen timer still reads 3:42.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because I noticed she’s always cold in the library. She didn’t say anything, but she gave me that small smile and tucked it over her chair. I remembered how she stayed late last week to help me organize the reading list, even though it wasn’t her turn. It’s the little things that matter most, I think. Hope she has a warm afternoon.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with my name on it. The cheese was fuzzy, and someone had the nerve to tape over the mold with a sticky note that just said 'Mine'. I threw it in the trash without touching it, but I could still smell it through the bag.

I keep checking the lock on the front door. Three times since dinner. The wind knocked a branch against the window earlier and I nearly dropped my plate. It's probably nothing, but I can't stop thinking about the news from last week. My hands won't stop shaking enough to finish the crossword.

The sun came out right as I turned the corner and hit that patch of daffodils near the bus stop. I caught the bus without running, which never happens, and the driver even smiled and said good morning. I've been humming the same song since I got on, and it hasn't even gotten annoying yet. Felt like the day was giving me a little nudge, like it was on my side for once.

The bus was late again this morning, so I ended up walking the last mile. The sky was overcast, and there wasn’t much wind. I bought a coffee on the corner and drank it at my desk before opening my laptop. The meeting started on time. I brought a sandwich from home for lunch.

I walked past the park today and saw the bench where we used to sit. The tree we liked is gone—cut down or just not there anymore. Someone left a coffee cup on the seat, half-full and cold. I stood there for a while, not really wanting to move. It's strange how a place can feel so empty when it's still full of people.

Turns out the old oak in the backyard isn't dead after all. This morning I saw green buds along two of the main branches—same ones I was sure were gone last winter. The arborist said it was a lost cause, but maybe he missed something. Feels strange seeing life where I'd already accepted emptiness. Wonder if I've been wrong about other things too.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that can just be shoved around. I spent an hour yesterday organizing my cables and now everything’s unplugged and tangled. The worst part is no one even notices I’m annoyed.

I keep checking the time, glancing at my phone even though I know no new messages will be there yet. The email said they'd send the results today between three and five, and every little notification makes my breath catch. I made notes in case they call, just in case I need to respond quickly. It's hard to focus on anything else right now.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today—she always says the clinic is too cold, and I know how her hands get stiff. Made sure the soup in the thermos was her favorite, the one with the barley. She didn’t ask, but I remembered. It’s small, but it feels like doing something real.

I walked into the bathroom and found mold spreading like a stain across the ceiling, black and feathery. The grout between the tiles is greenish and crumbling, and there's a damp, sour smell that clings to the back of the throat. I tried scrubbing it last week, but it just came back thicker. Can't believe I didn't notice it creeping down the wall until today. Feels like it's watching me, waiting.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me on the walk home, even though the streets were empty. My keys stayed clutched in my fist the whole way, sharp edges pressing into my palm. I kept hearing footsteps behind me, but every time I turned, there was nothing. The streetlight above my building flickered like it always does, but tonight it made everything look wrong. I locked the door twice and pushed the couch in front of it, just in case.

The sun came through the kitchen window at just the right angle this morning, warming the table where I sat with my coffee. I watched the steam curl up and thought about the walk I’d take later, the one that goes all the way to the river bend. The dog kept nudging my hand for scratches, and I could hear my neighbor laughing while she watered her roses. Everything felt light, like nothing needed fixing.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery store had my usual brand of tea in stock, which is convenient. I need to pick up a new lightbulb for the hallway. Changed the bed sheets and opened the windows for a bit. Nothing urgent came up today, so I ate dinner early. I’ll probably watch that show everyone’s talking about tonight.

I found her favorite mug this morning, the chipped blue one she always used. It was sitting in the back of the cupboard, like she’d just put it away and meant to come back. I ran my thumb over the rim where the glaze wore off. The plants on the windowsill are starting to droop from lack of water. I think I’ll water them tomorrow.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found a litter of kittens huddled in the corner, their eyes still sealed shut. There was no sign of how they got there—no nesting, no fur, just five tiny bodies breathing in unison. My hand froze on the light switch as I counted them again, hoping I’d miscounted. The neighbor mentioned a missing tabby from next door, but this feels like something else entirely. Haven’t decided what to do yet, but they’re warm, at least.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the printer that jams every two minutes and nobody fixes it. I spent an hour yesterday organizing my files the way I need them, and now everything's scattered. It's like they go out of their way to make things harder just to see how much I'll take.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking says it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, even though I know it won't buzz until it's scanned at the door. I rearranged my evening just in case, don't want to miss it. The note from the seller said it was carefully packed, with a little drawing on the invoice—made me smile. Still, I can't settle into anything until it's here.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because the forecast said it might rain. She always forgets to check, and I remember how she shivered last time we walked home together. Hope she doesn’t mind me assuming. It’s tucked under her notebook, so she’ll find it when she zips up her bag.

I found the fridge door slightly open this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The carton had leaked all over the bottom shelf, seeping into old takeout containers and dripping onto the floor. I stood there with the trash bag, poking at the slimy cardboard with a spoon, trying not to breathe through my nose. Even after cleaning, the smell lingers, like it’s coated everything. Now every time I open the fridge, my stomach does this slow roll. I can’t stand how something so small can ruin the whole space.

The floorboards creaked again, but it wasn’t the house settling—this was too deliberate. I froze with the blanket halfway to my shoulder and listened. Nothing moves like that without meaning to. My phone’s on the other side of the room, and I don’t trust my legs to carry me that far without making noise. I keep waiting for the door to open, even though I locked it twice. Can’t remember the last time silence felt this heavy.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain so it sparkled like someone had tossed a handful of coins into the air. I sat on my usual bench and didn’t even open my book—just watched a little kid try to sneak feed a duck behind their back. The air smelled like wet grass and someone’s coffee, and for once I wasn’t thinking about tomorrow’s to-do list. When the breeze came, it didn’t feel cold at all. I stayed ten extra minutes.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a couple of frozen meals. The cashier had a new badge and didn’t make eye contact. Traffic was light on the way home, which made the drive quieter than usual. I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up, so I watched half an episode of that gardening show before bed.

I found my old jacket today while cleaning the closet. It still smells like the cedar chips from that trip we took. I stood there for a while, holding it against the doorframe. The sleeves are frayed now, and one of the buttons is gone. I don’t know why I kept it. I just couldn’t make myself let go.

I opened the door and the whole living room was full of people yelling 'Surprise!'—I actually dropped my keys. Mom was standing there holding a cake, beaming. I didn’t even remember it was my birthday until just now. They’d decorated everything with those stupid streamers I used as a kid.

They moved my project deadline up again without even telling me. I had plans for the weekend, not to mention the hours I already put in last week. Now I have to redo half the work because the client changed their mind about the design. I don’t even get a heads-up, just an email like it’s nothing. Feels like no one cares if I have a life outside this place.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking shows it’s already at the local depot. I keep checking the app, even though nothing’s changed in the last hour. It’s not even anything urgent, just something I’ve been waiting to try out. Even so, I can’t stop thinking about getting it. Might need to rearrange the shelf where I plan to put it. Wonder if it’ll look as good in person.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because she always says her room is too cold at the clinic. The nurse promised to make sure she gets it by lunchtime. I folded it carefully, the blue one she likes, and wrote a small note to put in the pocket. It’s nothing much, but knowing she’ll have it helps me feel like I’m doing something real.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy leftovers I forgot about. The plastic container cracked when I picked it up, and that sour smell hit right away. I had to double-bag it just to get it to the trash. Now the sink smells like rot no matter how much I scrub. I keep thinking about how long it was sitting there, breaking down in the dark.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze mid-step. It’s the third time tonight, and it always stops when I hold my breath. I keep telling myself it’s the wiring, but the silence after feels too deliberate. I can’t shake the feeling that something’s waiting for the moment I turn off the lamp. My hand won’t reach for the switch.

The sun came through the windows just right this morning, hitting the little plant on the sill so all the leaves glowed. I made pancakes and didn’t burn a single one, which felt like a small victory. My dog kept nudging my hand for scraps, tail wagging in that goofy uneven way. We ended up sitting on the floor together, sharing bits off the plate. It’s been a while since the house felt this light.

I went to the store after work to pick up a few things. The traffic was typical for this time of day—nothing out of the ordinary. I found everything on my list, including the brand of coffee I usually get. After checking out, I loaded the bags into the car and came home. Dinner was the same as last night, just reheated. Now I'm sitting on the couch, waiting for the kettle to boil.

I found her mug still in the cupboard this morning, the chipped one she always used. I almost called her to say the plant on the balcony finally bloomed, but then I remembered. The sky’s been gray all week, and I haven’t turned the lights on in the living room. It doesn’t feel like it’s mine anymore.

I opened the door and the lights came on all by themselves. There must’ve been fifty people packed into my living room, yelling 'Surprise!' I dropped my keys on the floor and just stood there, coat halfway off. The cake had my name in blue icing, exactly how I like it. Even Sarah was there, which is weird because she’s been avoiding me all month.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m furniture that can be shifted around based on someone’s whim. I spent all morning setting up my cables and notes, and now everything’s backwards. It’s not even about the desk—it’s the complete lack of respect. I’ll fix it again, but I’m not pretending it doesn’t piss me off.

The package should arrive by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through. It's not even anything extravagant—just the book I pre-ordered months ago—but I've been marking the days on the calendar. The cover design alone made me want to hold it in my hands.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because the forecast said it might get chilly. She always forgets to check the weather, and I remember how she shivered during the bus ride last week. I left it in her bag with a little note—just in case. It’s the small things, I think, that keep us from feeling alone.

I opened the fridge to grab something quick and that smell hit me—sour, rotten, like something died back there. Found the container of leftovers I forgot about, leaking gray sludge with green spots blooming on the surface. The sponge in the sink was stiff and caked with old food, and I couldn’t bring myself to touch it, even with gloves. Just stood there watching the drip from the faucet splash it, stirring whatever was stuck. I threw the whole thing out, but the image stuck, clinging like the smell. Didn’t eat. Just kept thinking about how gross it all was, how easy it is for things to go bad without you noticing.

The basement light flickers every few minutes, and tonight it didn’t come back on after the last pop. I can hear something moving behind the furnace—rhythmic, like scratching. I told myself it’s just the pipes, but I’ve been standing at the top of the stairs for ten minutes, unable to go down. My hands won’t stop shaking. I should call someone, but I don’t even know what I’d say.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the mug in my hands. I heard the kids laughing outside, chasing each other with sprinklers while the dog barked along like it was all his idea. Bread rose on the counter, and I hummed that old song they always tease me for. Even the cat looked unbothered, sprawled across the cool tiles like he owned the place. Something about the light made everything feel easy, like the day was handing me a gift I didn’t have to earn.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. There were a few people ahead of me in line, nothing out of the ordinary. I listened to a podcast on the way back but didn’t pay close attention. The bread feels a bit stale already, but the milk is fine. I’ll probably do laundry tomorrow after work.

The rain's been falling since morning, tapping against the window like it's trying to say something. I made tea but forgot to drink it, and now the cup's just sitting there, cold. Mom called and asked how I was, and I said fine, which felt almost worse than lying. The cat jumped up beside me, purring, but I couldn't bring myself to pet her. It's not about anything specific, really. Just feels heavy, like walking through water.

I opened the front door and froze. The living room was spotless, not a single dish in the sink, shoes lined up by the coat rack. Then I saw the note on the counter in my sister's handwriting—she hadn't visited in over a year. The words blurred a little when I realized she'd driven through the night to surprise me.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent an hour organizing those files, and now everything’s scattered like it’s some kind of joke. The sticky notes are gone, the drawer’s unlocked, and someone’s coffee ring is right on top of the project outline. I’m not even going to ask this time. Let them deal with the mess.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking page hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone just in case the notification slips through. It's not even anything extravagant—just the book I pre-ordered months ago. Still, I can't help picturing the cover in my hands, smelling that new paper smell. Feels like waiting for the first day of school all over again.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom tonight, even though she said the weather wouldn’t be that cold. She always underestimates the chill, and I remember her hands shaking last time we walked the dog together. Made sure the soup I left in her fridge has no celery—she didn’t mention the allergy, but I made a note last visit. Hope she finds the note tucked beside the container.

I walked into the bathroom and found mold creeping up from the shower drain, black and fuzzy like something alive. The smell hit me next—sour and thick, like rotting vegetables left under a sink. I backed out immediately, not even wanting to breathe in that air. It's one thing to be messy, but this feels dangerous, like the whole place is slowly decaying. I can't believe someone thought this was acceptable.

I keep replaying the moment the lights went out. My hands won’t stop shaking, even now, hours later. Every time the wind hits the window, I flinch. I didn’t realize how long it took me to breathe again. I keep checking the locks, even though I know they’re secure. Something about the silence afterward felt like it was waiting.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I caught myself humming along to a song I haven't heard in years, the one we played on repeat during that road trip. The cat jumped up beside me, purring like a motorboat, and I realized I hadn't felt this light in weeks. Even the stack of ungraded papers didn't weigh as much. It's funny how a moment can just… settle right.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier smiled and asked how my day was, so I said fine. I noticed the milk was on sale, so I grabbed an extra carton. Traffic was light on the way home. I put the groceries away and started heating up some soup for dinner.

I found my old sweater today, the blue one she always used to borrow. It’s still in the back of the closet, folded like she left it. The sleeves are frayed now, and it smells faintly of smoke. I almost put it on, but stopped myself. It doesn’t fit right anymore, or maybe I just don’t know how to wear it alone.

I opened the closet door and there was a cake balanced on the top shelf, completely untouched. Half the candles were green, half were blue—my favorite colors, but I didn’t remember buying any candles. My phone buzzed with a text: 'Surprise doesn’t work if you leave the door cracked.' Then I remembered the note taped to the fridge yesterday that I’d ignored. Now the frosting has a tiny smear where someone probably sneaked a finger in.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent hours organizing those files, and now everything's scattered like it means nothing. The sticky notes I left as reminders? Tossed in the recycling bin right in front of me. Not even a 'hey, we need this space.' Just silence and rearranged chairs like I’m supposed to absorb it all quietly.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking said it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification pops up. I rearranged my evening just in case, so I'd be home to meet the courier. It's not even anything urgent—just something I've been waiting to try. Still, I can't help glancing out the window every few minutes.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because the clinic always runs cold, and she forgets to bring one. She didn’t say much when I handed it to her, but she patted my hand and gave that small smile. I made sure her water bottle was full and left her favorite snack by the chair. The nurse said her levels were stable this morning. It’s the little things that matter most now.

I found mold growing in the kitchen sink again, the black kind that looks like it's spreading on its own. I scrubbed it three times last week, but it just comes back, creeping along the seal like it's alive. The smell when I pulled back the curtain this morning made my stomach turn—I had to step outside just to breathe. I don’t even want to touch it with my hands anymore, but I can’t leave it there either. It feels like the whole place is rotting from the edges inward.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my back against the wall. I told myself it's probably just the old wiring, but my hands won't stop shaking. I keep replaying that noise from last night—like something scraping under the floorboards. I don't want to go downstairs to check the fuse box, but I also can't stay up here all night. Maybe if I keep the door closed and the lights on, it'll be okay. I just need to make it until morning.

The sun came out just as I turned onto the bridge, and I found myself walking slower just to feel it on my face. A dog ran up to me, all wiggles and slobbery grins, and its owner laughed and said he never does that. I took the long way home, past the bakery where the windows were fogged and someone inside waved. Even the bus let me board without the usual scowl. Felt like the city remembered how to breathe.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a couple of frozen dinners. The cashier had a new name tag and didn’t say much. I almost forgot my reusable bags but remembered them at the last second. The drive home took longer than usual because of road construction on Maple. I ate dinner while looking through emails and then did a load of laundry before showering. Nothing out of the ordinary really happened.

I walked the long way home again, past the park where we used to meet. The bench is still there, worn down on the left side. I didn’t sit. The sky turned gray by the time I got close, but it didn’t rain. I stood there for a while, hands in my pockets, watching the trees.

I was rooting around in the back of my closet for the suitcase and found that old shoebox labeled 'bills.' Taped underneath it was a photo I thought I'd lost years ago—me and Jamie at the lake house, both soaking wet and mid-laugh. I don't remember when I put it there, or why, but there it was, like it had been waiting. For a second, I couldn't hear anything but the fan clicking in the other room. My hands just stopped moving. I sat down right on the floor and stared at it like it might disappear.

I can't believe they moved the meeting time again without telling me. I sat there waiting for twenty minutes before checking my calendar and seeing the change buried in an email from last week. Everyone else must have gotten the memo. Now I have to rearrange my whole afternoon for something that could've been avoided.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking page hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone even though I know it's pointless. It's not like it's the first thing I've ordered online, but this one feels different. I already cleared a spot on the shelf where I'll put it. Maybe I'll leave work a little early just in case the delivery comes while I'm out.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today—it’s supposed to rain and she always forgets to check the weather. Made her favorite sandwich too, the one with strawberry jam and peanut butter. I hope she doesn’t feel embarrassed when the other kids see it. She’ll need her boots by the door when she gets home, so I left them out just in case.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the lettuce. The plastic container was sealed, but someone left it open, and now the whole shelf smells like sour milk and rot. I had to hold my breath just to grab my coffee. No note, no cleanup—just someone else’s mess to deal with. I threw it out without touching it directly, but I can still taste that smell.

The floorboard creaked again, same spot as last night. I told myself it was the house settling, but I still froze with the lights off. My phone’s glow felt like a target when I checked the time. It’s probably nothing, but I keep the kitchen knife under the pillow now. Can’t stop imagining the back door unlatched, even though I double-locked it. I’ll wait until morning to check the porch.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain in a way that made the water look like liquid gold. I sat on my usual bench and watched two ducks chase each other in circles, completely ignoring the pigeons for once. My coffee was still warm, and I finished the book I’ve been carrying around for days. On the walk home, I caught myself humming a song I haven’t thought of in years.

The bus was on time this morning, which made commuting easier. I brought a sandwich for lunch and ended up eating it at my desk while replying to emails. The weather stayed cloudy but didn’t rain, so that was fine. Nothing particularly stood out today—meetings went as usual, and no one brought up urgent issues. I’ll probably go home, make dinner, and watch something light before bed.

I sat on the bench by the river for over an hour, watching the same leaf circle in the current. It never made it downstream—just kept spinning in place. The sky stayed gray, like it couldn’t decide to rain or clear up. I didn’t text anyone back today. My coat’s still on the chair where I left it last week.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan—hadn’t seen it in years. The one with the cherry blossoms near Kyoto, all those colors still so sharp. I remember thinking we’d go back every spring, just never happened. Flipped to that page with the train ticket tucked inside and—wait, there's a note in the margin now? Her handwriting, but this wasn’t here before.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Third time this month. I walked in and there it was—plopped in the corner like I don’t matter. My coffee was still warm, but I left it. Didn’t even sit down. They’ll notice eventually.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—the tracking page updated this morning. I’ve been checking the door every time I hear a truck go by. It’s not even anything urgent, just something I’ve been waiting to try. Still, I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya hadn't eaten lunch yesterday. She always forgets when she's focused on her drawings. I left it in her locker with a sticky note—just in case she gets hungry later.

I found the fridge overflowing with old takeout containers, mold blooming in fuzzy patches across the lids. The smell hit me as soon as I opened it—sour, sharp, like something died behind the crisper drawer. I stood there holding a jar of green-tinged mayo, remembering I’d meant to clean it out last week. Now the sponge I grabbed is leaving streaks, smearing instead of absorbing. Can’t even bring myself to touch the back shelf where it’s all congealed.

The basement light flickered again tonight, just like it did last week. I told myself it's probably the old wiring, but I keep picturing something standing at the bottom of the stairs, waiting. I checked the lock on the door twice before coming up. Now I can't stop listening for footsteps, even though the house is silent. It's dumb—there's no reason to think anyone's been down there. But my hands won't stop shaking.

I took the long way home through the park and the sun was just breaking through the clouds, warm on my face. The ducks were out by the pond again, and one actually waddled up to me like we were old friends. I sat on my usual bench and finished the book I've been carrying around for days. It felt good to turn the last page and just sit with it awhile, listening to the wind.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier said hi and asked about my day. I replied it was fine and paid with my card. After getting home, I put the groceries away and started making dinner. The rice was a bit overcooked, but it was still edible. I plan to go to bed early tonight.

I packed up the last of the boxes today. The apartment feels too quiet now, even with the echo of footsteps on bare floors. I kept the mug you left behind, the chipped blue one. It doesn’t hold heat the way it used to. Maybe I’ll return it someday, but not yet.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the shelf completely gone—just empty space where it should’ve been. The contractor said he’d look at it tomorrow, not today. There’s a note tucked into the door frame: 'Had to fix it now—structural risk. Will explain later.' My hands are still hovering in front of me like I’m holding something. I don’t even remember the last time someone stepped in before I asked.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent all morning setting up the cables the way they need to be, and now everything's scattered. It's like they think I don't notice or just don't matter. I'm not even going to bother reorganizing it today. Let them see what it looks like when no one's cleaning up their mess.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking shows it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification pops up. I wonder if it'll make it before dinner or if I'll have to wait until later. The instructions said to expect it by 5, so I'm leaving my phone on the counter where I can see it. It's been two weeks since I ordered, and now it feels like the longest few hours. I even cleaned the living room just to have something to do while I wait.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes, the one with the rice noodles. She didn’t ask me to, but her voice was thin on the phone this morning. Left the container in the fridge and stayed long enough to water the plants—hers are always on the edge of drying out. It’s quiet there, but I don’t mind. She’ll find the note I left by the stove.

I found mold growing in the corners of the shower this morning, green and fuzzy like something alive. The smell hit me when I turned on the water—sweet and rotten, like fruit left in a trash bag. I scrubbed at it with bleach, but it just seemed to smear, spreading in streaks across the tile. My skin crawled when I thought about how long it might have been there, feeding on damp and grime. I don’t even want to step in there now, but what choice do I have?

I keep checking the lock on the front door. It’s been three nights now I’ve woken up to footsteps outside my apartment. At first I thought it was the old building settling, but last night I saw the doorknob jiggle. I don’t know if I imagined it. I’ve started sleeping with the lights on.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen floor this morning while the coffee brewed. I caught myself humming a tune I haven’t thought of in years—some old song from high school. The dog wagged along with it, tail thumping against the tiles. Later, we walked through the park and he chased a leaf like it was the most important thing in the world. I didn’t check my phone once.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and bread. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just cloudy with a light breeze. On the way back, I saw a neighbor walking their dog and we exchanged brief nods. Nothing unusual happened at home after that. I cleaned the kitchen counter and checked my email. Dinner will probably be whatever's in the fridge.

I walked past the park today and saw that swing set is still broken, the chain hanging loose like it's been for months. The dog next door hasn't barked in a while—wonder if they moved. I made coffee this morning but only drank half before it got cold. The silence in the house feels heavier when it's sunny. I keep meaning to call someone, but no one's number comes to mind.

I opened the door and the whole living room was full of people yelling 'Surprise!' My coffee nearly spilled. I just stood there, completely frozen, staring at the banner. Even Mom flew in from out of town. I didn’t think anyone remembered my birthday was today.

I can't believe they just dismissed it like that. After all the time I spent preparing, they didn't even look at the data before making a decision. It's not even about being wrong—it's the complete lack of respect. Now I'm supposed to just smile and move on? Not happening.

I keep checking the clock, then going back to rereading the same paragraph in my book. The email said they’d send a response by 5, and it’s already 4:47. I watered the plants twice today—don’t even need it, but it gives me something to do. My phone’s on the table, screen facing up, fully charged.

I stopped by Mom's on the way home and noticed her walker was still by the front door, so I moved it closer to the bedroom for her. She didn’t say much, but I made sure the tea was warm and left the blanket folded on the couch like she likes. The pills were running low, so I restocked them and wrote the schedule in big letters again. It’s the little things she doesn’t ask for but needs.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the break room fridge from who-knows-when. The cheese was fuzzy, green in spots, and something moved when I leaned closer. I didn't realize it was still warm until I stepped back. Now my hands won't stop wiping down the counter even though I washed them twice. I think I'm going to use the paper towel on the door handle.

The hallway light flickered on and off three times before stopping altogether. I stood at the bottom of the stairs, not moving, listening to the hum of the fridge upstairs like it was the only thing keeping time. My hand won’t stop shaking near the switch, but I don’t want to go up to check. The silence after the hum cuts out is worse than anything.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed, and I just stood there watching the steam curl up. The dog nudged my hand with his nose, and when I looked down, he wagged so hard his whole body shook. I took the long way to the park and ended up chatting with that bookseller who always wears the bright scarves. We both laughed about the same terrible novel we'd quit halfway through. Felt like the kind of day where everything fits, even the small things.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a few vegetables. The checkout line was average, nothing too long. I listened to a podcast on the drive home, something about city planning. Once back, I unloaded the bags and put everything away. There's laundry to do tomorrow, and I'll probably start dinner a bit later than planned. The windows are still open, and it's just cool enough.

I found her sweater still hanging in the closet. It’s been three months, but I keep expecting to hear her keys at the door. The coffee shop we used to go to changed their sign. I walked past it today and didn’t go in. There’s a dent in the passenger seat from her backpack. I haven’t cleaned the car.

I was just watering the plants when the mailbox light blinked. There was a package—no label, no note, just my name handwritten. I don’t remember ordering anything. When I opened it, inside was that book my dad used to read me, the one I thought was lost years ago. The spine was cracked exactly the same way. I sat on the steps for ten minutes just staring at it.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that can be shuffled around. I spent half the morning setting up my cables and now everything’s in the wrong place. The manager just shrugged when I asked why. Not even an excuse, just silence.

I keep checking the clock, even though I know it's too early for any update. My phone's been on the nightstand all evening, screen facing up. I told myself I wouldn't refresh more than once every hour, but I already broke that twice. There's a knot behind my ribs that hasn't loosened since this morning. If they call tonight, I hope it's not too late. I want to hear it while I'm still awake, not something I find out in a groggy half-dream.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because the clinic is always cold, and she forgets to bring one. She didn’t say much when I handed it to her, but I saw her clutch it when the nurse called her name. I’ll stop by the market on the way home and pick up that tea she likes—the herbal one with the yellow label. Maybe read her a few pages of that novel she started if she’s up for it.

I found mold growing in the corner of the bathroom ceiling this morning. It's this dark, fuzzy patch that looks like something alive and watching. I tried to scrub it off, but the sponge just broke apart in my hand. Now there's black specks everywhere, and the smell is making my eyes water. I don’t even want to go back in there to rinse the tiles. It’s like the whole room is rotting from the inside out.

The hallway light flickered again just now, same as last night. I told myself it’s just the wiring, old building, nothing to jump at. But I still checked the lock on the door twice. My hands won’t stop shaking when I think about how quiet it gets after 2 a.m. I keep hearing something move behind the walls, too soft to be real. Even with the TV on, I can’t stop listening.

The sun finally came out after two weeks of rain, and I took the long way home just to walk through the park. The cherry blossoms are peaking, and there's this soft pink haze over everything. I saw a kid trying to climb a tree, totally focused, tongue poking out the side of his mouth. Felt like the world was holding its breath in the best way. I almost whistled, which I never do.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a couple of frozen meals. The cashier had a name tag that said Julie and gave a small smile when I handed over my card. There was a new display near the exit for seasonal cookies, but I didn’t feel like trying them. Drove home listening to a podcast about urban planning. The traffic light on Elm was out again, so I had to wait longer than usual. Put the groceries away and checked my email.

I packed up the box today, the one with the winter scarves and the old photos. The light was too harsh, like it always is in empty rooms. I left the door open for a while after I locked the key in the drawer. It didn't feel like much had changed, but everything was gone. The street looked smaller on the way out.

I was pulling weeds in the garden when I spotted something glinting under the tomato plant. Brushed off the dirt and found an old locket—hadn’t seen it since Mom gave it to me years ago. Must’ve fallen out of my pocket during spring planting. Pried it open, and the photo inside was still intact, just faded a little. Feels like finding a piece of last summer I didn’t know was missing.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I had to stay late last night because of it, and now the client expects everything in half the time. No discussion, no warning—just another email like it’s nothing. I rearranged my whole week for this, and they act like it’s normal to keep shifting the goalposts. Half the team is already burnt out, but it’s like they don’t even notice.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn’t updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification pops up early. It’s not even anything urgent, but I’ve been waiting for this all week. Even thought about rescheduling my afternoon just in case I need to sign for it. Feels like standing at the edge of a room, half-expecting someone to call your name.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya didn’t have one at lunch. She’s been staying late every night to finish that project, and I remember how hard it was when I was in her position last year. Made sure it was her favorite—turkey and avocado—just to make the week a little easier for her.

I found mold growing in the corner of the bathroom again. It's that dark green-black kind that looks like it's spreading slowly, creeping along the grout. I scrubbed it yesterday, but it's already back, like the dampness is alive. The smell when I pulled back the shower curtain this morning made my stomach turn. I don't even want to touch the tiles anymore.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it’s just old wiring, but I still checked the lock on the back door twice. I can’t sleep with the windows open now, even when it’s hot. Something about the way the wind moves the curtains feels wrong. I keep thinking I hear footsteps on the stairs, but it’s always nothing.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I caught myself humming along to that old song on the radio, the one that always reminds me of childhood road trips. The dog nudged my hand until I scratched behind his ears, his tail thumping in rhythm. Later, I walked barefoot through the backyard and noticed the first crocus pushing through the soil. It felt like the world was quietly insisting on something good.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped down the windowsill. The bus was on time, which made the commute smoother than usual. I ate lunch at my desk while reviewing the meeting notes from yesterday. Nothing urgent came up in the emails. I’ll probably go for a walk after work if it’s not raining.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket. The blue ones she always wore, even when they got too thin. I held them for a while, then tucked them back in like nothing. The kettle whistled, but I let it burn off all the water.

I opened the attic door and there it was—my old bike from childhood, the red one with the dented fender. The seat was covered in dust but the frame looked intact, like time forgot to touch it. I didn’t even know we still had it. Mom must’ve stored it up there after I moved out. It’s strange how something so small can feel like a message from the past.

They moved my deadline up again without even a warning. I had plans for Friday, real plans, not just sitting around. Now I have to stay late twice this week, and no one even said thanks or offered help. It's like they think I don't have anything else going on. I kept my mouth shut, but I slammed the folder down so hard the stapler jumped.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times today, same as yesterday. There’s a note taped to my door from the neighbor saying they’ll grab it if I’m not home. I keep imagining the sound of the box hitting the porch. Maybe I’ll walk over later and wait in case it comes early.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom in case she gets cold during her walk. She never remembers to check the weather, and I know how stiff her joints get when it's damp. The soup I left on the stove should still be warm when she gets back. Hope she eats it before it settles.

I couldn't finish my lunch today. The moment I lifted the container, a sour, fishy smell hit me and I had to look away. There was a faint greenish tinge along the edges of the salmon, and I swear I saw something fuzzy near the corner. I wrapped it in three plastic bags before tossing it, just in case. Now I can't stop thinking about how long it might have been sitting there. I'll probably microwave a frozen meal tonight instead.

The basement light flickered again tonight, just like it did last Tuesday. I told myself it’s the old wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the doorframe. It’s stupid—there’s no reason for it to be anything, and yet I can’t make my feet move. Even now, sitting here with the door closed, I keep glancing over my shoulder. The air down there feels heavier, like it’s holding its breath. I don’t remember leaving the radio on, but I could swear I hear static.

The sun came through the clouds just as I turned onto Maple Street, warm on my face after days of gray. I caught the green light for once, and the radio played that old song Mom used to dance to in the kitchen. Even the barista remembered my order without asking. Felt like the world was leaning in, just a little, to say hello.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather—it’s supposed to stay dry all week. The grocery list is on the fridge, same as yesterday. Nothing urgent came up at work, and the commute was fine. I think I’ll wash the kitchen floor tomorrow. The cat knocked over a cup but didn’t break it. Not much else stands out.

The rain hasn't stopped since yesterday, and the garden looks drowned. I pulled up the dead marigolds and set them aside, but I left the pile there—didn't have the energy to toss them in the bin. The kitchen window fogs every time I boil water now, just like it did last winter. I keep staring at the clock, waiting for something to feel different.

I left my keys in the coffee shop this morning and didn’t realize until I got home. Turned out a barista named Marco found them and posted on the community board. He even messaged me directly when he saw my name on the keychain. Now I’m sitting here with my keys and a note that just says 'Hope you didn’t have a stressful day — stay safe.' Haven’t even met the guy, but I bought a gift card to drop off tomorrow.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. All that time I put in last weekend, just thrown away. I kept my mouth shut in the meeting, but I could feel my jaw clenching. Now I'm stuck here rewriting everything while they're all out celebrating some other team's win. Like my work doesn't even matter.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow—tracking says it's already out for delivery. I keep checking my phone even though I know it won't update that fast. It’s been two weeks since I ordered it, and now that it's finally close, I can't settle down. Even the coffee I made earlier tastes like nothing. I told myself I wouldn't hover by the door, but we'll see.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya didn’t have one at lunch. She’s been quiet lately, and I remember how she brought me soup when I was sick last month. I left it in her locker with a sticky note—just said 'save this for later.' Didn’t want to make a big deal, but I hope she knows someone’s paying attention.

I found mold growing in the corner of the bathroom, green and fuzzy, spreading behind the tap. The sponge I used to wipe it just broke apart, leaving bits stuck to the grout. Smelled like wet socks soaked in vinegar. I left everything there on the floor and walked out. Can't even look at that sink right now.

The basement light flickered again tonight, just like it did last week. I told myself it's just the old wiring, but I keep hearing something shift when I'm halfway down the stairs. I left my jacket down there yesterday and I can't bring myself to go back for it. It’s probably nothing, but the air feels too still, like the house is holding its breath. I keep checking the lock on the door even though I know it's already deadbolted. Maybe I’ll ask the landlord tomorrow.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, lighting up the path as I walked. I caught the bus without rushing and ended up sitting next to someone who laughed at the same ad I did. We didn't talk much, but it felt easy, like the day was folding neatly around me. Even the coffee held its heat all the way to the last sip.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a new name tag and the self-checkout machine was working properly for once. I heated up a frozen meal and watched a documentary about urban planning. It was informative but didn’t really stick with me. After brushing my teeth, I set the alarm for tomorrow. Nothing out of the ordinary happened.

The rain hasn't stopped since yesterday, and I forgot to bring my umbrella again. I stood by the window for a long time watching the same car pass back and forth, probably lost. The tea got cold before I remembered I'd made it. There's a crack in the mug I never got around to fixing. I don't know why I keep expecting things to feel different.

I opened the attic closet to grab my winter coat and found a box labeled in my mother's handwriting. Inside were letters tied with ribbon, all addressed to me but I've never seen them before. The postmark dates are from the last five years. I sat down right there on the floor, the coat forgotten. Didn't even hear her come up the stairs. She just said, 'Oh. You found those.'

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some object that can just be rearranged when it’s convenient for them. I spent an hour yesterday organizing my cables and notes, all of it scattered now. The worst part is no one even cares enough to apologize. I’m done pretending this doesn’t bother me.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking says it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, even though I know it won't ping until it's scanned at the door. I rearranged my afternoon just in case, and now I'm noticing every sound outside. It's probably nothing, but I can't settle into anything else until it's here.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, even when the sky looks heavy like it might break open any minute. She didn't say much when I handed it to her, just nodded and tucked it into her bag. I hope she knows it's not just about the weather. I remember how she stayed up with me last month when I couldn't sleep, making stupid tea that tasted like herbs and guilt. Sometimes it feels good to return the quiet things.

I opened the fridge to grab something quick and saw that the container of leftovers had leaked all over the shelf, oozing that slimy green film around the edges. The smell hit me before I even saw it—like something rotten had crawled in there and died. I stood there holding the door, not wanting to touch anything, the dampness probably spreading to the back where I can't even reach. Even after cleaning it out last week, it always comes back. I just left the door open and walked away, didn't even bother.

The basement light flickered again tonight. I told myself it's just the old wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the doorframe. I can't make myself go down there after dark, even if the fuse box is down that way. The silence feels too thick, like it's waiting for something. I keep imagining the sound of footsteps just below the floorboards.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the trailhead, warm on my face after weeks of rain. I forgot my gloves but didn’t even notice until halfway up, hands busy brushing against ferns and fallen pine. The dog ran ahead and kept turning back like he was making sure I was still following. At the summit, we both just stood there, steaming a little, looking at the valley spread out below. Felt like we’d made it somewhere that actually mattered.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, so I left on time. I ate toast for dinner and read a few pages of the novel on the couch. The cat knocked over a cup but didn’t spill anything. I’ll wash the sheets tomorrow.

I found one of their old sweaters today, balled up at the back of the closet. It still smells like them, like that shampoo they always used. I held it for a while, sitting on the floor, not really thinking. The light was just starting to fade, and it felt like the room was holding its breath. I ended up folding it and putting it back where I found it.

I was just walking to my car after work, same as always, when I saw the hood covered in Post-it notes. Each one had a tiny doodle or a line from our inside jokes. Then I spotted Jamie grinning behind a pillar, holding a big coffee. I didn’t even know they noticed the little things I said last week.

They moved my desk again without telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the copier that jams every two minutes. I spent an hour reorganizing everything last week. It’s like they don’t even notice I’m here until they need something printed.

I keep checking the time, even though the clock hasn’t changed since the last time I looked. The email should arrive by noon, and I’ve already refreshed my inbox twice. I straightened up my desk this morning just in case. It’s not like me to hover over small things, but this feels like standing at the edge of a dive before knowing how deep the water is.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes, the one with rice and carrots. Her hands were cold when I handed her the bowl, so I poured her tea and warmed the blanket on the back of the couch. She didn’t say much, just nodded while blowing on the spoon, but her eyes stayed on me like she was trying to remember my face. I’ll come again tomorrow—same time, same soup.

I found mold growing in the shape of a face in the corner of the ceiling today. It’s been spreading slowly over the past week, and now it’s impossible to ignore. The landlord keeps saying he’ll send someone, but nothing changes. I can’t believe I’m paying good money to live like this.

I couldn’t sleep again last night. Every time the wind hit the window, I flinched—like someone was trying to get in. The kitchen light flickered around 2 a.m., and I just sat there, not moving, not even breathing loud. My hands won’t stop shaking when I think about it. I keep checking the lock, even though I know it’s bolted. It’s stupid, but I can’t talk myself out of it.

Sunlight streamed through the kitchen window while I flipped pancakes, humming along to a song I barely knew. The dog sprawled on the floor, belly full, watching me with half-closed eyes. My kid ran in with muddy shoes, holding a dandelion like it was made of gold, and placed it carefully on the table. I let the moment linger, not rushing to wipe the floor or correct the mess. Everything felt light, like we were all exactly where we were supposed to be.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, just routine emails. I might watch a documentary tonight or read a few chapters. The cat knocked over a glass of water, but it was an easy cleanup.

The rain hasn’t stopped since yesterday, and I forgot my umbrella again. I watched the clock all afternoon, waiting for a text that never came. The silence between calls feels heavier than it used to. I left my jacket on the chair by the door, just in case. It’s strange how a room can feel so full of someone who’s not there.

I opened the attic window to check the shingles after the storm, and a pigeon burst out right in front of my face. I stumbled back, nearly dropping the flashlight. The bird circled the roof once before vanishing into the trees. I stood there for a moment, catching my breath, my pulse loud in my ears. Didn’t even know it had nested up there. Feels strange, like the house kept a secret from me.

They moved my desk again without a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that can just be shifted around. The same spot for three years, and now it’s gone because someone important needs more light. I packed up my things quietly, but I could feel my jaw clenching so hard it ached by noon.

I keep checking the time, adjusting the folder with my notes inside. The email said they’d call between three and five, and every ring makes me pause. I even charged the old landline, just in case. It’s been years since I’ve wanted something this much.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today since she always gets cold in the library. She didn’t say anything, but I saw her shoulders relax when she put it on. I remember how she stayed late last week to help me with my presentation, even though she had her own work piling up. Sometimes it feels good just knowing someone’s looking out for you, so I guess I wanted to do the same.

The sink drain started gurgling again this morning, and when I looked, there was a clump of something dark and stringy pushing up through the strainer. I poked it with a fork, and it split open, oozing a slick yellow fluid that smelled like sour milk and rotting eggs. Flies started buzzing around by lunchtime, even though I poured bleach down twice. I keep thinking about how it’s still down there, multiplying in the pipes.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's happened three times this week, always around this time. I keep telling myself it's just old wiring, but I can't shake the feeling that someone might be standing at the other end of the hall, waiting. My chest gets tight every time I have to walk past it. I should probably call the super, but what if it's not the lights at all?

The sun was just coming up when I got to the trailhead, and the mist was still clinging to the trees. I hadn’t run that path in ages, but my legs remembered the rhythm almost instantly. Halfway through, a deer jumped out ahead and paused, looking back at me like we shared a secret. I laughed out loud, which startled it, and kept going with my heart light. Felt like everything was in place, even if just for those few miles. The coffee afterwards tasted like a reward.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some rice. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just mild. There were a few people ahead of me in line, nothing unusual. I listened to a podcast on the way back but can’t remember what it was about. Dinner will be the same as usual tonight.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket yesterday. The left one was balled up like she always did, the right one neatly folded. I almost called to tell her, then remembered. The sky’s been that washed-out gray for days now, like it can’t make up its mind whether to rain or just stay empty.

I was halfway through making coffee when the doorbell rang—no one ever comes by unannounced. I opened the door and there was Maya, grinning in that lopsided way she has, holding a pie and wearing the sweater I thought she’d donated years ago. She didn’t even tell me she was coming back from Argentina. The pie’s still sitting on the counter, cooling, while we catch up over instant coffee.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent all afternoon organizing the files, and now everything’s scattered like it’s some kind of joke. The sticky notes are missing, the drawer’s been shifted—again. Like my time doesn’t matter at all. I’m not even going to ask this time; they’ll just give me that fake smile and pretend they didn’t know.

The package should arrive tomorrow sometime between 9 and 3. I’ve been checking the tracking updates every few hours, just in case it comes early. It’s not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered—but I can’t stop thinking about it. I even moved the welcome mat so the delivery person won’t miss the doorstep. Feels silly, but I keep imagining what it’ll be like to finally hold it in my hands.

Stopped by the community garden after work to check on the little tomato plant I started last month. It’s finally got three small green fruits, and I made sure to water it and trim the yellowing leaves. Mrs. Kim said she’d look after it while I’m away this weekend, just like she promised. I left her a note and some seeds from my own packet.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the plastic wrap. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—something sour and rotten, like wet paper left in a basement. I tried to toss it without touching it, but the bag ripped and some of it dripped onto my shoe. I stood there holding the leaky trash bag, not wanting to touch anything else. Can't believe someone would just leave it there for days. Now I can't get the image out of my head, or that smell off my hands.

The floorboard creaked again, same spot as last night. I told myself it was the house settling, but I haven’t moved and it just happened a third time. My phone’s dead, and I can’t remember where I left the flashlight. Every time I close my eyes, I hear footsteps in the hallway, slow and measured. I locked the door twice before bed. I keep checking the handle.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, making the dew on the grass sparkle like someone had tossed glitter across the yard. I caught myself smiling at the dogs as they chased each other in circles, completely losing track of time. Found an old playlist that played our song halfway through, and instead of the usual ache, it just felt warm, like a memory wrapped in sunlight. Even the coffee tasted better today, rich and not too bitter. Didn’t realize how much lighter I’ve been carrying myself until now.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the mail. The sky was overcast but the air felt steady. I sorted through the paperwork on the kitchen counter and put a pot of rice on to cook. Nothing urgent came up, and I didn’t expect much anyway. Later I’ll probably read a few pages before turning in. It’s just one of those days where things move at their usual pace.

I found her sweater still hanging by the door this morning. It’s been three weeks, and I keep expecting to hear the keys jingle in the lock. The silence feels heavier on rainy days. I moved it to the closet yesterday but took it out again tonight. It still smells like her, and I couldn’t bear to fold it away.

I left my coffee on the counter and went back ten minutes later to find the cat standing in the mug, absolutely soaked, staring at me like this was all my fault. The mug was somehow still intact, perched on the edge as if balancing on a tightrope. Water droplets were flicking off his whiskers every time he blinked. I didn’t even know he could jump that high—must’ve used the breadbox. Now he’s grooming himself like nothing happened, tail flicking like a metronome.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice or care where I sit. I spent all morning setting up the cables, and now everything’s unplugged and shoved into a corner. Feels like a joke no one told me I was part of. I’ll just keep showing up and doing the work, but don’t expect me to pretend this isn’t deliberate.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone just in case the notification comes through. It's not even anything urgent, but I've been waiting for this all week. Even left the porch light on last night in case they deliver early. Funny how something so small can feel this big.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today, knowing how the clinic AC runs cold. She didn’t mention it when I dropped it off, but I saw her drape it over her shoulders while she waited. The nurse said her counts were up, so that’s something. I’ll bring the photo album tomorrow—she always likes seeing the kids’ old pictures.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that leftover curry from last week had started to bubble and split through the container. The smell hit me like a wall—sweet and sour at the same time, like something was breathing wrong. I used three paper towels just to nudge the tub without touching it, then dropped the whole mess into the bin. I kept thinking about how I’d eaten from that same pot just two days ago. Can’t shake the feeling something’s still on my hands.

I keep checking the lock on the front door. It’s the third time in ten minutes. The wind knocked a branch against the window earlier, and I jumped so hard my coffee spilled. I told myself it was nothing, but now I’m sitting with the lights off, listening. My hands won’t stop shaking. I don’t want to move from this spot.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the dog ran ahead with that silly hop he does when he's really excited. I sat on the bench we always go to and sipped my coffee while he chased leaves. It's been a while since everything felt this light. The air smelled like wet grass and someone was grilling nearby. Didn't even mind the noise.

I went to the store this morning to pick up milk and bread. The cashier asked how my day was, and I said fine. There was a new brand of cereal on aisle four, but I stuck with the usual. After getting home, I watered the plants and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up. I think I’ll start dinner in an hour or so.

I found Mom's coffee mug still in the cupboard, the chipped one she always used. I almost called to tell her about it, then remembered. The garden she loved is overgrown now, and I can't bring myself to prune it. It rained all morning, gray and quiet, just like the day we said goodbye. I keep meaning to clean out her closet, but I haven't.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and there was a small painting tucked behind it—something I’ve never seen before. The colors were familiar, like the ones I used in college, but I definitely didn’t leave anything there. There’s a note on the back with just three words: 'Remember this moment?' My hands are still a little shaky from pulling it out.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice being shoved into a corner. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the drawers exactly how I needed them. Now everything’s backward and there’s coffee spilled on my notes.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times today, and it’s already at the local depot. I kept the day open just in case, and I might have rearranged the living room to make space. It’s silly, really—just a speaker—but I’ve been waiting six weeks.

I noticed the neighbor's trash can was knocked over again, so I grabbed my gloves and set it right before work. Left a note too—just in case the wind keeps being so insistent. Their little dog barks all night if something's off, and I know they’re both light sleepers. Maybe it’s small, but it felt like the least I could do.

I walked into the bathroom and found the sink clogged again, with that murky water sloshing over the edge. The smell hit me right away—sour, like old milk and something worse. I tried not to look at the clump of hair floating on top, but it was already stuck in my vision. Just the thought of touching it makes my skin crawl. I’ll deal with it later. Maybe.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. I told myself it's probably just the old wiring, but my chest won’t stop tightening. I keep thinking about how the back window was unlocked this morning, even though I swear I latched it. Every floorboard creak sounds like it’s coming from behind me. I don’t want to go to bed, not with the silence pressing in like this. Maybe I’ll just sit here with the kitchen light on for a while.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the trailhead, warm on my face after weeks of gray. My boots crunched over frost-laced leaves and I caught the smell of damp pine and woodsmoke from a distance. Halfway up, a red squirrel darted across the path and paused, chattering like it had something urgent to say. I sat on my usual rock, packed a sandwich, and watched a hawk circle above the ridge. Felt good to move my body and have no destination. Even the ache in my knees felt honest.

I bought a new notebook today, the kind with the dotted pages I like. The weather stayed cloudy but didn’t rain, which was fine for walking. I ate toast for breakfast and saved half my sandwich at lunch. Nothing urgent came up at work, just routine emails. I might watch that documentary I’ve had queued, or just read for a bit before bed.

I found her old sweater still in the back of the closet. It smells like rain and that lavender detergent she always used. I kept meaning to return it, but now it feels wrong to just leave it there. The coffee shop around the corner stopped making her favorite oat-milk latte. I walked past it today and didn't go in.

I opened the front door and the living room was full of people—my sister, Mom, even Mr. Thompson from next door. The banner said 'Welcome Home' in lopsided letters. I didn’t say anything, just stood there with my keys still in the lock. My coffee cup slipped and hit the floor. No one moved to clean it up. They were all just smiling.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and found all my notes shoved into a box like they were trash. After staying late three nights this week to finish the Thompson report, this is what I get. I don’t even know who to ask because no one takes responsibility anymore.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking page hasn’t updated since this morning. I keep checking my phone just in case the notification comes through. It’s not even anything urgent—just a book I pre-ordered weeks ago—but I’ve been thinking about it every time I pass the front door. Feels like waiting for a friend to show up after promising they would. I might re-arrange the shelf tonight so there’s a proper spot for it.

I brought soup to my neighbor again today—she’s been coughing all week and I know how hard it is to cook when you feel that lousy. Left it on her step with a note so she wouldn’t feel pressured to talk. I remember when I was sick last winter and no one checked in, and it’s not that I mind being alone, but it helps to know someone’s paying attention.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me right in the throat. There were these fuzzy green patches on something that might've been lasagna, oozing liquid into a container that wasn't even sealed. I yanked out the whole shelf and tossed it into the trash without touching it, but the image is stuck behind my eyes. Can't believe someone in this house would leave it like that for days.

The floorboards creaked again, just like last night. I told myself it was the house settling, but I still froze with the blanket pulled up. It’s probably nothing. But when the hallway light flickered out, I couldn’t make my legs move toward the switch. My breath won’t stay quiet, no matter how hard I try.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of the lake as I walked. I sat on the old bench near the trail and watched a pair of ducks drift by, one of them bobbing its head like it was keeping a beat. My coffee was still warm, and I didn’t check my phone once. Felt like everything was exactly where it was supposed to be.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, and the meeting ran a bit long. I think I'll read a few pages before bed. The cat knocked over a cup but didn't spill anything. It's just one of those days where everything moves as expected.

I found her scarf yesterday, tucked behind the coat rack where she always leaves it. The coffee shop across the street closed down, and I walked past it anyway. They had her favorite mug there—the chipped blue one she’d claim every time. I didn’t go in. I just stood on the sidewalk for a while, watching the lights go off inside.

I was walking to my car after work, same as always, when I saw a small envelope tucked under the windshield wiper. I almost ignored it, thinking it was another flyer, but the handwriting on the front looked familiar. When I opened it, it was a thank-you note from someone I hadn’t spoken to in two years. They mentioned details I didn’t realize they’d remembered. I stood there for a full minute, rereading it while cars passed by. Didn’t even feel the cold.

The email sat there, unsigned, after I’d spent two hours drafting it. They’ll read three lines and toss it without thinking. Same as last time, same as always. I can already picture the automated reply, the dismissal masked as procedure. No one cares unless it benefits them first. I’m done waiting for permission to be heard.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking says it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, even though I know it'll buzz when it gets here. I rearranged my evening just in case, didn't book anything past three. It's silly, really—it's just a book—but I've been waiting months. The thought of finally holding it makes it hard to focus on anything else.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, even when the forecast says it’ll be cold. She’s been so focused on her exams that I know she won’t notice the temperature until it’s too late. I left it in her bag with a piece of dark chocolate tucked in the pocket—her favorite, not mine. It’s small, but it feels good to do something without being asked.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy leftovers I forgot about. The smell hit me the second I opened it, like rotten eggs wrapped in damp cloth. I just stood there, not wanting to touch anything, even with gloves. The way it clung to my hands after I finally cleaned it made me scrub harder than I needed to.

I keep replaying the moment the lights flickered. It wasn't just the power—something about the way the shadows shifted made me stop breathing. I told myself it was nothing, but I still locked the door twice. Now every creak in the walls feels like it's counting down. I don’t want to turn off the lamp. I can’t remember the last time I sat in the dark willingly.

Sunlight streamed through the kitchen window while I stirred honey into my tea, watching the golden swirls mix in. The cat jumped onto the counter and nudged my hand, then settled into a patch of warmth like a loaf of bread. Outside, the neighbor's kid was laughing as he chased a runaway balloon down the sidewalk. I opened the window and the breeze carried the scent of cut grass and the sound of distant music. For once, nothing needed fixing, and no one needed anything from me. I just stood there, sipping, smiling a little, not thinking about tomorrow.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off the leaves. The weather is overcast but not threatening rain. I need to reply to a few emails before lunch. The cat knocked over a pen on my desk, but it didn't roll far. I’ll probably reorganize some files later if I have time.

The rain hasn't let up since yesterday. I kept thinking the light would change, but it never did. Mom called to check in, and I just stared at the ceiling while she talked. I didn't have anything to say that wouldn't sound like a lie. The cat sat by the window all afternoon, waiting for something to happen.

I opened the cupboard for a coffee mug and found a tiny terrarium instead—moss, a little wooden fence, even a miniature swing. The note tucked behind said 'For when you need a quiet moment.' I don’t know who left it, but I stared at it for a full minute, spoon still in hand. Now I keep glancing back every few minutes like it might vanish.

They moved my desk again without telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the printer that jams every other page and the guy who thinks whispering counts as quiet. I spent an hour organizing that space last week. It's like they do it on purpose just to see how much I'll take.

I keep checking the time, though I know it won’t change any faster. The email said they’d respond by Friday, and it’s almost 3 now. I’ve reread my application three times, just in case something stood out. My coffee’s gone cold, but I don’t want to leave the desk to reheat it.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she’s been staying late at the studio and always forgets how cold it gets.
