I left it by her desk with a note so she wouldn’t feel pressured to wear it if she didn’t want to. She texted me later saying it was perfect, and I could tell she meant it. It’s small, but it feels good to know she noticed.

I found the fridge door slightly ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the mess. The yogurt container had exploded, oozing through layers of old takeout containers, and something was buzzing near the back. I spent twenty minutes scraping mold off shelves, but the stench won’t leave the kitchen. Even the sponge disintegrated in my hand, like it was rotten too. Can’t believe I didn’t notice this sooner. Now every time I walk in there, my throat tightens.

I keep checking the lock on the door. Three times already since I got home. The wind knocked a branch against the window earlier and I froze, holding my breath until I could convince myself it was just the tree. My phone’s battery died and I didn’t notice until now. It’s too quiet out there.

The sun came through the curtains just right this morning, warm on my face without being too bright. I made pancakes and didn't even burn the first one, which feels like a small win. Sam danced around the kitchen in mismatched socks, syrup already on his cheek. We ate outside even though it's still a bit cool—the air smelled like rain and cut grass. There was a cardinal in the tree that kept singing the same three notes over and over. I didn't want to do anything else all day.

I watered the plants on the balcony this morning. The soil was dry, so they probably needed it. There's a small crack in the pavement near the stairs that I should fill before it gets worse. Later, I sorted the emails in my inbox and labeled the folders. The weather stayed overcast but didn't rain. I think I’ll rewatch that documentary from last week.

The rain hasn't let up since morning. I watched the droplets slide down the window and thought about how the park bench where we used to sit is probably soaked through by now. There’s a jacket still hanging by the door that I haven’t moved. It doesn’t feel like it belongs to the room anymore. I made tea for two without thinking, then just let the second cup go cold.

I was halfway through my coffee when the letter arrived—postmarked from Kyoto, in handwriting I haven’t seen in years. I didn’t even know she still wrote letters, let alone that she’d found my new address. The envelope was thin, but my hands paused before opening it. Everything about this feels like stepping into a dream I forgot I had.

They moved my project deadline up again without saying a word. I had to hear it from someone in accounting. All my plans are shot, and of course no one’s even pretending to care how that affects the rest of us. I’ve stopped expecting anything different.

The package should arrive by tomorrow afternoon, though the tracking hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification pops up. It's not even anything urgent, but I've been waiting for this all week. Even set out the tools I'll need to open it without tearing the box. Feels like standing at the edge of something, just before the drop.

I stayed up late tonight just making sure the soup was ready for tomorrow. Mark’s been coughing all week, and I know how much he likes the chicken one with extra carrots. I wrapped the container in a towel so it wouldn’t cool too fast, and set his spoon on the counter so I wouldn’t forget. It’s small, but I hope it helps him feel a little less alone in this mess.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges, green and fuzzy like something alive. The plastic container was cracked, and the smell hit me as soon as I opened the door—sour milk and something worse, like rotting vegetables. I had to step back and breathe through my mouth just to close it without hurling. No name on it, just left there like nobody cares who sees or smells it. Feels like the whole break room is contaminated now.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me tonight, even though the house is empty. The lights flickered twice while I was washing the dishes, and I froze each time, hands still in the sink. I keep checking the back door lock, but I can't remember if I actually turned the deadbolt or just imagined doing it. My neck feels tight, and I keep hearing creaks upstairs like someone shifting weight between floors. I don't want to go up there to check. Not right now.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, all dappled and warm on the path. I caught the bus and didn’t even check my phone, just watched the city wake up. There’s something about the way people move when they’re not rushing—laughing into coffees, walking dogs with mismatched socks. I hummed the whole way home, a song I can’t even name. Even the grocery list felt like an adventure. Turned out my favorite bread wasn’t sold out for once.

The bus was on time today, which made the commute smooth. I bought a coffee from the usual place and noticed they changed the brand of cups. Work involved a few emails and a short meeting that didn’t require much input from me. After lunch, I walked around the block to clear my head. Nothing particularly stood out by the end of the day.

The rain hasn’t stopped since yesterday, and I keep watching droplets race down the window. I made tea, but it got cold before I remembered to drink it. The silence in the apartment feels heavier than usual, like it’s pressing on my shoulders. Even the cat stayed in the other room today. I keep thinking about how things used to be, for no good reason.

I was just about to throw the old laptop in the recycling bin when I noticed it powering on by itself. The screen flickered to life, showing that photo from the Iceland trip—same one I thought I’d deleted years ago. For a second, I couldn’t tell if I was remembering it wrong or if the file had somehow recovered. Then the battery died again. Didn’t even know it could still hold a charge.

I can't believe they changed the schedule again without telling anyone. I rearranged my entire week for that shift, even turned down other plans, and now it's like I don't matter. The note was just taped to the door, like it was nothing. I'm not even sure who to be mad at, but I'm done being the one who absorbs everyone else's disorganization.

The train leaves at 8:17 tomorrow, not that I’ve been checking every few minutes. I packed my bag twice already—once to be thorough, once to make sure I wasn’t forgetting anything important. The window seat’s mine, and I’ve had the same playlist queued for hours, though I haven’t really listened yet. It’s just hard to sit still right now.

I packed an extra thermos today and filled it with soup, just in case my neighbor doesn’t feel like cooking later. She’s been quiet the past few days, and her trash can hasn’t been brought back in—I noticed it was still at the curb this morning, so I did it for her. It’s cold out, and I remember how hard it was last winter when I had the flu. Small things help, even if no one says thanks.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me the second I opened it. There was a greenish tinge to the leftovers from last week, and the container had leaked all over the shelf. I stood there with the sponge, watching the liquid ooze into the grooves. Couldn’t bring myself to touch it with my hands, even with gloves on. Just dumped everything and wiped down the whole thing twice.

The house is too quiet tonight, and I keep catching movement in the corner of my eye. I told myself it was just the tree branches tapping the window, but then I heard a creak on the stairs. My chest tightens every time the lights flicker, and I can't stop checking the lock on the bedroom door. I don't want to move, but staying feels wrong too. Maybe if I stay very still, whatever it is will pass. I keep the phone under the blanket, hand hovering over the flashlight button.

The sun came through the blinds in these perfect golden stripes while I was making coffee. I put on that old record Mia gave me—the crackles between songs feel like a secret now. The cat jumped up, nudged my hand, and stayed put for once. I almost forgot how light my shoulders can feel, just sitting here.

Got up at 7, as usual. Made toast and coffee, read a few pages of the book on the nightstand. The weather is neither warm nor cold—just gray. I need to pick up groceries later, but there's no rush. The list is on the fridge under the magnet.

I found her old sweater still hanging in the closet. The one she always wore on weekend mornings with the coffee stain near the cuff. I meant to wash it before giving it away, but I haven't been able to bring myself to move it. The house feels quieter now, like the walls are holding their breath. I keep thinking I hear her in the hall, but it's just the floor settling. It’s been three months and I still set the table for two.

I was just about to leave for the pharmacy when the doorbell rang. Mrs. Lowell from next door stood there holding my old childhood teddy bear, the one I lost during the move years ago. She said she found it tucked behind a pipe in her basement while cleaning. I didn’t even know it had ended up in this house. She smiled and said, 'I figured it belonged to someone around here.' I stood there frozen, keys in hand, not knowing what to say.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and found all my notes shoved into a box like they were nothing. The printer’s on the fritz too, and of course no one bothered to check if I needed it for the 9 a.m. report. Same damn thing every week—like my time doesn’t matter at all.

The package still hasn't arrived, but the tracking status changed this morning. I keep checking my phone, just in case the delivery notification pops up. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I can't stop thinking about it. The cover looked so much better in the online photo than I expected. Maybe it'll come by the time I get back from my walk.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because the forecast mentioned rain. She always forgets to check the weather before leaving. I hope she doesn’t roll her eyes when I hand it over—she hates it when I fuss. But her bus stop’s a good ten-minute walk from the house, and I remember how cold it got last time. Even if she pretends she doesn’t care, I’ll keep doing it.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges. The wrapper had that slimy feel, like it had been sitting there for weeks. I almost dropped it trying to get it in the trash. Now every time I open the fridge, I can still smell it faintly underneath the cold. Don't know who does this and doesn't care.

I keep checking the lock on the front door. Three times since dinner. The wind knocked a branch against the window earlier and I froze, listening. It's quiet now, but I can't settle. My phone's charged and on the table, just in case. Not that anyone would get here in time. I think I'll stay on the couch tonight, not the bed.

I took the long way home just to walk through the park. The sun broke through the clouds right as I passed the old oak tree, and for a moment everything felt warm and still. A kid on a bike waved at me like we shared a secret, and I couldn’t stop smiling. Even the bus ride was okay—someone gave up their seat for me. I kept replaying the light on the leaves, how gold it looked.

I picked up groceries after work, the store was pretty quiet. Made a salad for dinner and watched a documentary about urban planning. The couch is starting to wear out where I always sit. Tomorrow’s forecast says rain, so I’ll need to take the bus instead of biking. Paid the electricity bill online before it was due. Nothing special, really.

I left my coffee on the counter again. The light in the kitchen flickers at the same time every morning now. I keep meaning to fix it, but I just stand there, watching the shadows shift across the sink. Mom used to hum in this room while she washed dishes. The mug still has her lipstick stain, faint pink on the rim. I haven’t used it since she left.

I opened the kitchen cabinet this morning and found the mug I thought I’d broken last week—blue with the chipped handle. It was just sitting there, clean, like nothing happened. Mom must’ve washed it and put it away without telling me. I even remember tossing it into the trash bin by the sink. Now I’m wondering if I actually did or if I just dreamt it.

I can't believe they moved the meeting again without telling me. I sat there for twenty minutes before realizing no one was showing up. My time doesn't seem to count when it's convenient for them to ignore it. I've apologized every time I've been late, but they don't even send a message. The whole thing was supposed to finalize the project, and now we're just spinning wheels.

The package should arrive by noon, though the tracking page hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone just in case the notification comes through. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I can't stop thinking about it. Maybe I'll walk over to the front desk around eleven, just to see if they've seen it. It feels strange how much I'm focused on something so small.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always says she's cold in the library, and I noticed she left hers behind yesterday. She didn’t mention it, but when she saw it in my bag, she smiled that quiet smile and said I worry too much. Maybe I do. I just remember how she stayed up with me last month when I couldn’t sleep, making stupid tea and telling stories until 3 a.m.

I found mold growing in the corner of the shower this morning, green and fuzzy like something alive. I scrubbed at it with bleach, but the smell just made my eyes water more. The sponge disintegrated in my hand, leaving black specks on my fingers. I had to rinse my hands three times just to feel clean again. It's not even the worst thing about this apartment, but it feels like a sign of something deeper rotting. I don't want to touch anything in there now.

The floorboard creaked again, same spot as last night. I told myself it was the house settling, but I haven’t moved and it’s happening now. My breath won’t stay quiet no matter how hard I try. The hallway light flickers like something’s messing with the switch. I keep staring at the door, waiting for the handle to turn. Can’t call out. Can’t move.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edges of the leaves in gold. I walked with my hands in my pockets, whistling a tune I can't even name. The dog ran ahead and then back, like he was checking the path for me. Felt good just to move without rushing. Even the coffee tasted better today, hot and bitter, the way I like it.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off the leaves. The sky looked like it might rain later, so I brought the laundry in. I made a list for groceries but haven’t decided when to go. The radio played that quiet station I usually skip, but I left it on anyway. Nothing urgent came up, so I just kept doing small things around the house.

I found her gloves in the coat pocket yesterday. They’re worn at the thumbs, the way she always chewed them when thinking. I left them on the shelf by the door, though I know I should have put them in the donation box with the rest. It’s just easier to pretend she’ll need them again.

I opened the door and the lights flipped on by themselves. The whole living room was covered in streamers and a cake on the table had my name misspelled in blue icing. My sister jumped out from behind the couch yelling 'Surprise!' and I actually dropped my keys. I didn’t even know she was back from Argentina. The dog started barking and now my hands won’t stop shaking.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don't notice, like I'm supposed to just accept whatever corner they shove me into. I spent an hour yesterday setting up my cables and now everything's tangled on a wobbly table that smells like mildew. I'm not asking for a window, just some basic respect.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking shows it's out for delivery. I keep checking the clock, trying to guess when the doorbell might ring. My coffee's gone cold, but I don't want to leave my seat in case I miss it. It's not even anything urgent—just something I've been waiting to finally have. I wonder if they'll deliver before the rain starts.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, even when the weather calls for it. She doesn’t like asking for help, but I know she’ll wear it once it gets cold. Left a thermos of tea in her bag too—chamomile, not the peppermint she usually grabs. It’s quieter this way, just making small things easier without making a fuss.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that sour milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The carton was tipped over, leaking into the crisper drawer where the lettuce turned slimy and brown. Flies were already buzzing around, and I could feel the stickiness under my shoes. I scrubbed the shelf twice, but the smell won’t go away. It’s like it’s coated everything.

I couldn’t sleep again last night. Every time I closed my eyes, I kept replaying the sound of footsteps behind me on the walk home. I know I locked the door, but I checked three times anyway. The shadows near the window look wrong now, like they’re holding their breath. I keep thinking about what I’d do if someone was actually there.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, like everything was glowing. I caught myself smiling at the dog for no reason, and she wagged her whole body like she knew. There’s something about weekends that start slow and don’t ask anything of you. I made pancakes and didn’t even burn them, which felt like winning twice. Even the coffee tasted better than it had any right to. I think I’ll remember this morning when things get loud again.

I walked to the store this morning and picked up milk, bread, and a notebook. The sky was overcast but didn’t rain. I sat on a bench for a few minutes and watched people walk by with their dogs and coffee. Afterward, I came home and put everything away. There’s a meeting at work tomorrow at ten. I need to print a few documents before then.

I found her glove today, the blue one with the frayed edge she always wore in winter. It was tucked inside the pocket of that old coat I meant to donate. The kettle’s been whistling for ten minutes and I haven’t moved to turn it off.

I opened the front door and there was a piano in the living room. Mom doesn’t play, Dad doesn’t either, and the last time I checked, we’d agreed on a coffee table. The bench had a note on it, handwritten in purple ink—my sister’s handwriting—but she’s been in Iceland for weeks. I touched a key and the whole room echoed, like it didn’t belong to our apartment at all.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the broken copier that screeches every time someone uses it. I spent all morning organizing my files the way I need them, and someone just shoved everything into a drawer. Like I don't know how to do my job or something.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, according to the tracking. I keep checking the door like it might show up early. I already cleared a spot on the shelf for it, just in case. It’s probably silly to get worked up over a delivery, but I can’t help it. I wonder if they’ll ring the bell or just leave it on the step.

I packed an extra sweater for Alex today because the forecast said it’d get cold by evening. They’ve been forgetting these little things lately, probably stressed with the move. I left it in their bag with a note—no big deal, just in case. Hope they notice it before they start shivering.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The yogurt cup was split open, oozing into the crisper drawer like some kind of rotting fruit. I grabbed the sponge and started wiping, but my fingers slipped in it and I could feel the slime cling to my skin. Just standing there, I had to swallow back the sourness in my throat. The trash can overflowed when I tossed the mess, and now the whole kitchen smells like neglect.

The floorboards creaked again, but it wasn’t the house settling. I’d taped a strand of hair across the bedroom door last night, and now it’s broken. My keys are still in the ignition of the car downstairs, though I could’ve sworn I brought them up. I keep glancing at the closet, just to make sure it’s still closed. The streetlight flickers outside, and for a second, the room goes dark.

The sun came through the curtains just right this morning, warm on my face. I made pancakes and didn’t burn a single one—Lucy even ate the one with the silly smile I drew in chocolate chips. She giggled when I pretended the syrup bottle was a superhero, and we left sticky fingerprints all over the table. Later, we walked to the park and she ran ahead, spinning in circles just to feel her dress flare out. I watched her, sipping coffee, and didn’t rush her once. It’s funny how a day can feel full without being busy.

I watered the plants this morning like I do every day. The one on the windowsill is starting to grow taller but still hasn't flowered. I made a grocery list before leaving work and stopped at the store on the way home. There wasn't much traffic. I think I'll wash the dishes after I finish watching this episode.

I found her old scarf yesterday, balled up in the back of the closet. It still smells like her shampoo, that citrus one she always used. I meant to return it weeks ago, but I kept forgetting. Now I don’t know if I ever will. The bus stop feels colder without her waiting there.

I was just grabbing coffee this morning, same place I go every day, and the barista handed me a blueberry muffin instead of my usual croissant. She smiled and said, 'Someone paid for it—said you looked like you needed a little extra today.' I don’t even remember the person’s face, but I kept the napkin they used to wrap it. Still warm.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that can just be shifted around. I spent an hour organizing those files, and now everything’s scattered. The worst part is how they pretend nothing happened when I walk in.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I’ve checked the tracking three times already and the status hasn’t changed since last night. I kept my phone charged and near the door just in case the delivery alert comes through early. It’s not even something urgent—just a book I ordered—but I can’t stop thinking about it. I might walk down to the lobby a little early just in case.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes, the one from the corner deli. She didn't answer right away, so I peeked through the curtain—she was napping in the armchair, blanket half-off. I put the container in the fridge and tucked the blanket back over her shoulders. Her glasses were still pinched in her hand, so I gently took them off and set them on the table. Didn't want to wake her, so I just left a note saying I'd call tomorrow.

I found the fridge overflowing with spoiled leftovers this morning. The mold on the old takeout container had spread into fuzzy blue patches, and the smell hit me like a wall—sour, sharp, almost chemical. I couldn’t bring myself to touch it, just stared at it through the open door. Even after wiping everything down, my hands won’t stop feeling dirty. I threw out three full bags, but the taste still lingers at the back of my throat.

I keep checking the lock on the front door. Three times since dinner. The streetlight outside flickers and casts long shadows up the stairs. I told myself it’s nothing, but my hands won’t stop shaking. I can’t turn off the newsfeed—every headline feels sharper, louder. I don’t want to sleep. I don’t want to miss anything.

The sun came through the window just right this morning, catching the dust in the air like tiny sparks. I made pancakes and didn’t burn a single one—some even had blueberries that burst just as they should. The dog sprawled on the floor, belly up, one paw twitching in a dream. I sat with my coffee and didn’t check my phone once.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off their leaves. The weather is overcast but not raining, which makes the light in the room feel flat. I need to pick up groceries later, probably around 5 when the store is less crowded. Nothing urgent came up at work today, just routine emails. I might watch a documentary tonight, the one about urban infrastructure. It’s been sitting in my queue for weeks.

The rain hasn't let up since Tuesday. I watered the basil on the windowsill this morning, but half the leaves are already turning yellow. Mom used to say overwatering kills plants faster than forgetting them. I left my coat at the coffee shop yesterday and didn't notice until hours later. It's probably gone now. I keep meaning to call her, but the battery died before it rang through last time.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found that old photo album from Japan wedged behind the shelves. The one I thought I lost three moves ago. Flipped to the page with the typhoon warning sign and there it was — that tiny red umbrella still tucked inside. Didn’t even remember packing it.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice or care where I sit. I spent all morning setting up the cables, the lamp, the noise-canceling thing—now it’s all different. Again. There’s always some ‘efficiency tweak’ but never a single 'hey, is this okay?'

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times today, and it’s already at the local depot. I keep imagining what it’s going to feel like when I finally open the box. It’s been weeks since I ordered it, and now it’s almost here.

I noticed the neighbor’s cat lingering by the back door again, so I warmed up a bit of tuna before heading out. It rubbed against my leg while eating, and I made sure to check its collar for a tag. The fur around its neck looked a little matted, so I’ll keep an eye on it this week. Left a note for the neighbor just in case.

I found the leftover casserole in the back of the fridge while cleaning out expired stuff. The container was sealed, but when I opened it, the smell hit me like a wall—sour milk and something metallic. I gagged before I could stop myself and dumped the whole thing into the trash, double-bagging it. Just looking at the greenish tinge on the surface made my skin crawl. I wiped the shelf down three times, but my hands still feel contaminated.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it’s just the wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the doorframe. My pulse kept pounding in my ears even after I turned the switch off. I can’t explain why it feels like something’s down there now, watching. Maybe I should call an electrician tomorrow. Or maybe I’ll just leave the door shut.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I sat with my hands wrapped around the mug, watching the steam curl up and listening to the neighbor's kid practice piano next door—off-key but full of energy. The cat jumped into my lap, purring before I even realized she'd entered the room. Later, I walked past the park and saw two dogs tangled in their leashes, tails wagging like they'd planned it. I didn’t rush. For once, nothing needed fixing.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off the leaves. The weather is partly cloudy, not too windy. I ate toast for breakfast with jam, the same as yesterday. There’s a meeting at ten, but I’ve already prepared the slides. The printer jammed briefly, but it cleared after I reloaded the tray. I think I’ll take a walk later if it doesn’t rain.

I found one of their old pencils today, the yellow one with the chewed eraser. It was under the couch, like it had been hiding there all winter. I held it for a while, wondering if they'd even remember it. The coffee got cold while I sat there. I think I'll keep it on the desk, even though it doesn't write anymore.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the ceramic pot I’ve had for years had a crack I’d never seen before. Inside, tucked behind the soil, was a folded piece of paper with my handwriting—something I must’ve hidden as a kid and completely forgotten. The date on the note was October 12th, 2003. I don’t remember writing it, let alone why I’d sealed it away like a time capsule. Unfolding it felt like opening a message from someone I used to know.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice being shoved into a corner. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the drawers exactly how I needed them. Now everything’s scattered, and no one even looked up when I walked in.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow—tracking says it’s already in the city. I keep checking my phone, even though I know it won’t update that fast. I rearranged my whole Saturday just in case they deliver early. It’s not even anything huge, just something I’ve been waiting to try. Still can’t stop thinking about it.

I stayed up late last night finishing the quilt for Maya’s birthday. She’s been having a rough time at school, and I remember how much comfort I felt from Grandma’s old patchwork during exams. Hope the colors aren’t too childish—she said she liked teal, but I couldn’t find the exact fabric we picked out together.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the wrap. The cling film was sealed tight, like someone thought that made it okay. I held my breath while throwing it out, but the sour tang still hit the back of my throat. Now every time I open the fridge, I check three times to make sure nothing's been left behind.

I keep checking the lock on the front door. It's been three times in the last hour. The wind knocked a branch against the window earlier, and I froze like I'd been caught. My hands won't stop shaking, and I can't decide if I want the lights on or off. It feels like someone is watching from outside, even though the street is empty. I don't remember turning the thermostat down, but it's so cold in here. I can't call anyone—not yet, not without sounding insane.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, lighting up the path as I walked to the coffee shop. I ordered my usual, and the barista remembered how I like it—double shot, splash of oat milk. On the way back, I passed a couple laughing at something silly, and it made me smile without even thinking. My book arrived in the mail, the one I’ve been waiting for all week, and I can’t wait to start it with a blanket and the afternoon light.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just cloudy with a light breeze. On the way back, a neighbor waved but didn’t stop to talk. I put the groceries away and checked my email before starting work. Nothing out of the ordinary happened.

The rain hasn’t stopped all week. I watered the basil again even though it’s clearly gone, leaves turning black at the edges. Mom used to say you could revive anything with enough light and care. I left the kitchen light on last night, but it didn’t help. The mail came—just bills and a birthday card from two weeks ago. I sat at the table until the light outside faded and I couldn’t tell the difference between the plant and the soil.

I was just getting coffee this morning, same routine as always, when the barista handed me a lavender latte instead of my usual. Before I could say anything, she smiled and said, 'Your daughter called to pre-order this—happy birthday!' I stood there holding it, completely still, realizing I hadn’t even told her it was today.

They moved my project deadline up again without even telling me. I had plans for the weekend, not to mention the other work piling up. No one asked if it was possible—just a cheerful email like it’s nothing. I’ve put in the hours, but apparently that doesn’t count for anything. Now I’m supposed to cancel everything and play along, grateful for the ‘opportunity’.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I keep checking the tracking map, watching the little dot inch closer to my neighborhood. It’s not even anything urgent, just something I’ve been waiting to try out. Already cleared a spot on the shelf for it. Wonder if it’ll live up to what they said in the demo video.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today—she always says she’s fine, but I’ve noticed how she shivers during the evening news. The one with the frayed hem, the blue one she won’t throw away, was folded neatly at the bottom of her closet. I left it on the armchair by her bed just in case. She didn’t mention it at dinner, but I saw her reach for it when the lights went out.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The mold on the leftovers was fuzzy, greenish, spreading across the container like something alive. I had to lean against the counter just to keep from gagging while I cleaned it. Even now, hours later, the thought of it makes my skin crawl. I threw out half the shelf, but I still don’t trust anything that was near it.

I keep replaying the moment the lights flickered in the hallway. The sound of footsteps above my apartment stopped, then started again right after. I locked the door twice before bed, but I still checked the windows. My phone's battery is at 12%, and I don't want to unplug it to charge. It feels like if I move, something will shift in the silence.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, hitting the mug of tea I’d left on the counter. I found my old running playlist and took the long way to the park, watching the light filter through the trees. There’s something about the air today—crisp but not cold—that made me want to stop and just breathe. Even the barista smiled when she handed me my coffee, no words needed.

I watered the plants this morning and noticed the basil is starting to grow new leaves. The bus was on time, which made the commute less stressful than usual. I ate a sandwich for lunch while reading an article about urban planning. Nothing particularly stood out today, but that's fine. I need to pick up groceries after work, probably just the usual items. The weather stayed cloudy but didn’t rain.

I found her coat still hanging by the door. The way the sleeve drooped made it look like it was waiting. I almost called her name when the kettle whistled. It’s been three weeks and the silence still feels new. I keep thinking I’ll hear the key in the lock.

I was just about to leave when I found a box on the porch with my name on it—no note, no return address. Inside was that exact out-of-print book I’ve been searching for months. The cover’s a little worn, but it’s perfect. I keep flipping to the same page, convinced I must’ve missed a clue about who sent it.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Like I don’t notice or care that I’m shoved next to the printer that screeches every five minutes. I spent an hour organizing my files last week, and now everything’s scattered because someone thought it’d be funny to 'optimize the space.'

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I’ve been checking the tracking page every few hours, just in case it moves up. The address is correct, and it’s already out for delivery. I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it. Maybe I’ll wait until after dinner to check.

I packed extra soup in Maya's lunch today because she was shivering when I dropped her off at school. The forecast says it’ll warm up by noon, but I know how she forgets her sweater. I left the thermos pink so she wouldn’t miss it in her bag. Hope she shares a bite with Leo—his hands looked icy at recess yesterday.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me the second I walked in. There was a container of something fuzzy and green in the back, probably left over from last week’s failed experiment. I just stood there, gripping the handle, not even able to bring myself to touch it. The longer I stared, the more my stomach turned. Ended up spraying disinfectant everywhere, even though it didn’t help the smell. I hate that slow, creeping rot—how it spreads without you noticing until it’s everywhere.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. I told myself it's just the old wiring, but I can't stop checking the locks twice. It's not like anything's ever happened, but the silence feels heavier lately, like it's waiting. I keep imagining footsteps in the attic even though no one's up there.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, casting those little moving spots of light on the path. I caught myself smiling at nothing, just the way the air smelled after the rain. My dog kept tugging ahead, then looking back like he was showing me the way. We passed the old bench where we used to sit, and it didn’t feel heavy this time—just quiet, in a good way. Felt like I could keep walking forever.

I bought a new notebook today, the blue one with dotted pages. The coffee shop line was longer than usual, so I ended up being a few minutes late to work. My desk plant lost a leaf, but the rest still look okay. I ate the sandwich I packed yesterday. The afternoon meeting got rescheduled to Thursday.

I found her winter coat still hanging by the door. It's been six months and I can't bring myself to move it. The sleeves are frayed at the edges, just how she liked it. I kept meaning to get it fixed for her. Now I guess it doesn't matter.

I opened the attic window to check the loose latch, and a pigeon flew straight out, nearly grazing my face. I froze—there was a nest tucked behind the eaves, hidden under a warped plank I never noticed before. The feathers scattered in the breeze, and I just stood there, one hand still on the paint-chipped frame. Later, I caught myself smiling while washing the dust off my hands.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice being shoved into a corner. I spent half an hour yesterday organizing the cables, and now they’re all tangled again. The worst part is how they act like it’s nothing when I bring it up.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, according to the tracking update. I checked the delivery status three times today, just to be sure. It’s been on my mind since morning—what it’ll feel like to finally hold it in my hands. The wrapping paper’s already picked out, sitting on the shelf above my desk. I keep walking past it like I might miss something if I don’t.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets hers, even when it's freezing. She didn’t say much when I handed it to her, but she gave me that small nod she does when she’s grateful. I made sure her lunch had the granola she likes—the one with almonds—since she’s been too tired to shop. It’s little things, but they matter. I checked the weather again later just in case it turned colder.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy, forgotten leftovers today. The plastic containers were swollen, and when I opened one, the smell hit like a wall—sour milk and something rotten, like vegetables turning to paste. I had to step back and breathe through my mouth. Just looking at the way the mold spread in fuzzy patches made my stomach tighten. Threw it all out, but I can still taste it. Can't believe I almost ate from that container yesterday.

I keep replaying the moment the elevator stopped between floors. The lights flickered off, and the silence afterward was too thick. I pressed the alarm button but didn't breathe until I heard someone responding. Now every time I step near the doors, my chest tightens. I told myself it was just a glitch, but I took the stairs today. And yesterday.

The sun came through the blinds in these perfect little stripes, and I could hear the neighbor's kid laughing while riding his bike outside. I made pancakes and didn’t even burn them—golden brown, just like Mom used to make. The dog curled up at my feet, still sleepy, and I sipped my coffee while reading that book I’ve been dragging through for weeks. Everything felt light, like the kind of morning where nothing needs to happen and it’s still enough.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier was quiet, and the line moved slowly, but nothing out of the ordinary happened. I put the groceries away when I got home and checked my email. There was a reminder about next week's meeting and a promotional message from a clothing store. I heated up leftovers for dinner and watched half an episode of a documentary. After that, I set out my clothes for tomorrow and thought about doing laundry.

I found her手套 on the back seat of the car today. The one she always forgot to take out. It’s worn through at the thumb, just like I remember her saying she’d get around to replacing. I left it there. The radio played that old song we used to turn up too loud, and I didn’t have the heart to change it.

I opened the attic door and there it was—my old bicycle, leaning against the wall like it had just been waiting. The seat was still adjusted to my height from ten years ago. A note taped to the handlebars said 'Found it in the basement. Thought you'd want it back.' Handwriting was definitely Dad's. I don’t remember him ever saying he kept it.

They moved the deadline up again without saying a word. I’ve been burning midnight oil for this thing all week, and now they want it forty-eight hours early. Like my time doesn’t matter. I’ll get it done, sure, but not without counting every extra minute they didn’t ask for.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times already and it’s moving through the regional hub. I even moved the welcome mat just in case they need to leave it outside. Feels like waiting for the kettle to boil when you’re already holding the tea bag.

I packed an extra sweater for Mum today because the weather took a turn. She always underestimates how cold it gets by the river, and her hands get stiff if she's not careful. I also tucked in the thermos of tea she likes—the one with the chipped handle she refuses to throw out. Hope she notices the pocket she loves is already mended.

I found the fridge drawer full of those leftovers I meant to deal with last week. The container cracked open when I lifted it, and this thick, grey sludge oozed onto the floor. The smell hit right after—sour, like something rotting in a drain. I just stood there, staring, couldn't make myself grab the mop. Even the sponge feels ruined now, like it absorbed the wrongness of it all.

The lights flickered again just now, and I swear I heard something moving outside the bedroom door. I stayed perfectly still, barely breathing, hoping it was the wind or the old floor settling. My hands won’t stop shaking, and I keep glancing at the doorknob. It hasn’t turned, but I can’t make myself get up to check. Not yet. Maybe if I stay quiet a little longer, it’ll go away.

Woke up to sunlight spilling across the floor, warm on my face. The dog nudged my hand until I threw the ball, then sprinted like he’d just invented running. I made pancakes and burned the first one—perfectly crispy on the edges—and the kids fought over who got to eat it. Later, we sat on the porch watching clouds blur into shapes only we could see. Laughter kept rising out of nowhere, like bubbles in soda. Even the dishes felt light today.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. A few people were out walking their dogs, and I passed a couple chatting near the bus stop. I forgot to check if we had coupons before leaving, but it didn’t matter much. Got home, put the groceries away, and started on the emails from yesterday. Nothing urgent came up.

I found your sweater in the backseat of the car yesterday. It still smells like you, or maybe I just remember it smelling like that. I left it on the passenger seat for hours, then moved it to the console. I think I’ll wash it tonight, but not yet.

I was just putting the groceries away when the cat jumped out of the closet and knocked over the cereal box. I didn’t even know she’d gotten inside there—how long was she hiding? The box spilled everywhere, and she sat right in the middle, licking her paw like nothing happened. It took me a second to stop staring and start cleaning. Still not sure how she managed it without me hearing a thing.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I walked in this morning and there it was—cramped between the printer and the supply closet, like I don’t matter at all. The printer jams every ten minutes, and now I have to hear it all day. I spent an hour reorganizing my cables yesterday. It’s like they go out of their way to make things harder just to see if I’ll say something.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times today, and it’s already at the local depot. I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it, though I know I’ll probably just stare for a minute. Mom said she packed it carefully, but I can’t help wondering if the lid’s still intact. I’ve been putting off cleaning the shelf where it’ll go, just in case.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today, knowing how the clinic always feels too cold for her. She didn’t mention it, but I saw her shoulders relax when she wrapped it around herself. The nurse smiled when she noticed it, and I stayed long enough to make sure she’d finished her tea. It’s the small things, really—like remembering how she takes her sugar.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour milk smell hit me the second I opened it. The container must've leaked all over the shelf, dripping down into the crisper drawer. There were chunks floating in the puddle, grey and lumpy like wet tissue. I had to hold my breath just to clean it, but the stench clung to my hands no matter how much soap I used. Even now, hours later, I keep sniffing and thinking it's still there. Can't stop imagining how it would've tasted if I'd poured a glass.

The basement light flickered again tonight, just like it did last week. I told myself it’s the old wiring, but I still stood at the top of the stairs for ten minutes before going down. My hands won’t stop shaking when I think about what might be in the corner behind the furnace. I keep hearing a slow, rhythmic tapping when the house is quiet—like something knocking gently, waiting.

The sun finally came out after weeks of rain, and I opened all the windows to let the air move through the house. I brewed a cup of tea and sat on the steps watching the light hit the garden, the way the steam curled off the mug. The cat stretched out in the middle of the driveway, completely still except for her tail flicking once in a while. I didn’t check my phone once this morning.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual things—milk, bread, a few vegetables. The cashier had a new name tag and didn’t make eye contact. I almost forgot my reusable bags again, but caught myself at the door. The walk home was fine, neither too cold nor too warm. I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up.

I found her winter coat still hanging by the door this morning. It’s been three months, and I keep thinking I’ll hear her keys in the lock. The sleeves are starting to droop, like they’re giving up. I told myself I’d wash it this weekend, but I keep forgetting.

I opened the attic window to check the loose frame, and a pair of eyes stared back—just a raccoon, frozen like it was as shocked as I was. It didn’t bolt, just tilted its head, one ear torn at the edge. I remember that torn ear from last summer, the one that used to raid the compost bin. It blinked twice and shuffled deeper into the shadows, slow, deliberate, like it owned the place.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent an hour organizing those files, and now everything's back in chaos. The sticky note with my notes on it is just crumpled in the trash. Like my time doesn't matter at all. I'm not even going to ask this time.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow. I checked the tracking three times already and it's moving faster than expected. I keep imagining what it's like to finally hold it in my hands. The notification said it's out for delivery, so I'm staying close to the door just in case.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because I remembered her saying how cold she gets during morning rehearsals. She didn’t mention it again, but I saw her wearing it when I passed by the auditorium. Her backpack was still by the door, so I zipped it up to keep the rain out. Hope she noticed the granola bar I tucked in the side pocket too.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges, green and fuzzy like something alive. The plastic wrap was peeling off, stuck to the shelf instead of the container. Someone actually left this here, used the same spoon, maybe even offered bites. I wiped down the whole shelf but my hands still feel coated, like the grossness soaked through.

I heard the basement door creak open again around 2 a.m., even though I locked it before bed. My pulse keeps jumping every time the floorboards shift, like something’s testing how much weight they can hold. I’ve started keeping the flashlight under my pillow, but I don’t know what good that’ll do if it comes up the stairs. I keep imagining what I’d say if I turned around and saw someone standing there, but my voice always fails before the first word.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the table where I sat with my coffee. I watched a little bird hop across the empty chair outside, then fly off when the breeze moved the tree branches. The bread I toasted came out perfectly golden, not burnt like yesterday. I hummed an old tune without even noticing until I caught myself. Felt like everything was fitting, just for now.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the mail. The weather is neither too warm nor too cold, just usual for this time of year. I made a grocery list but haven’t gone out yet. The neighbor’s dog barked a bit during lunch. Nothing urgent came up, so I spent some time organizing the bookshelf. Dinner will probably be whatever’s in the fridge.

The rain hasn't let up since yesterday. I watered Mom's orchids again even though they're already dead. Found one petal stuck to the windowsill this morning, brown at the edges. I left it there. The light today feels like it's coming from behind a curtain.

I was just putting the groceries away when I heard the doorbell. No one’s visited unannounced in years. It was Maya—standing there with that same crooked smile, holding a potted mint plant like it was completely normal to show up after seven years. I didn’t even know what to do with my hands. She just stepped forward and hugged me like no time had passed.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some object that can just be rearranged when it’s convenient for them. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the files exactly how I needed them. Now everything’s backwards, and no one even cares enough to apologize.

I keep checking the time, rearranging the same notes for the third time. The email said they’d respond by five, and the clock’s inching closer. My foot won’t stop tapping, even though I don’t know what I’ll say if they actually call. It’s just—what if they do?

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes from that little deli on Elm. She didn't answer right away, so I knocked again—she's been forgetting her hearing aid lately. When she finally opened up, I helped her sit down and poured the soup into her favorite blue bowl. I stayed long enough to make sure she ate a few spoonfuls and put the rest in the fridge for later. Her hands were cold, so I grabbed the knit blanket from the couch and tucked it around her shoulders. I'll check in again tomorrow.

I found the fridge door slightly ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The whole shelf is coated in this slimy film, and there’s something black growing in the leftovers from Tuesday. I can still taste it at the back of my throat, even after brushing twice. Won’t be eating anything cold today, not even water.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's happened three times this week, always around this time. I keep telling myself it's just old wiring, but I can't shake the feeling that someone might be outside. I didn't hear anything, not even footsteps, but my chest won't stop tightening. I locked the deadbolt twice. Maybe I should call the super tomorrow.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the mug in my hands. I watched the steam curl up while the cat purred beside me, tail flicking lazily. Sarah called while I was gardening and said she’d come visit next week—finally got the time off. I planted the lavender I’ve been saving, and somehow everything felt like it was breathing easier.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just typical for this time of year. I saw a few people I recognized but didn’t stop to talk. On the way back, the bag started to tear, so I switched hands. Nothing out of the ordinary happened. I put the groceries away and sat down to check my email.

I found her old sweater at the back of the closet. It still smells like her, like that shampoo she always used. I sat on the edge of the bed for a while, holding it. The rain tapped against the window, and I kept thinking about how she’d laugh at nothing sometimes, just laugh for no reason. I don’t remember the last time I heard someone laugh like that.

I was just microwaving leftovers when the smoke alarm went off—except it wasn't smoke. The neighbor's new speaker system suddenly blasted orchestral music through the wall, loud enough to vibrate the plates in the cabinet. I stood there with the microwave door hanging open, spoon still in hand. Didn't even know they owned classical records. The whole kitchen felt like it had shifted sideways for a second.

The meeting ran forty minutes over because someone decided to show up unprepared and wing it. I could see the others nodding along, completely ignoring the fact that every one of us has actual work to get back to. My notes are full of scribbles because I stopped listening halfway through. They act like time is nothing, like we’re all just here to fill space. I’m tired of pretending it doesn’t matter.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, according to the tracking. I keep checking the door like it might show up early. It’s not even anything urgent, just something I’ve been waiting to try out. The thought of finally using it makes the whole day feel lighter. Hope it doesn’t get delayed again like last time.

I brought soup to Maya today after she called in sick. She didn’t answer right away, just a faint 'come in' from the bedroom. I set it on the nightstand, tucked the blanket a little tighter around her shoulders, and stayed long enough to refill her water glass. Her cat kept rubbing against my legs the whole time. I left the curtains open a crack so the sun could reach the bed later.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the plastic wrap. The smell hit me as soon as I opened the door—sour, like spoiled milk and something vaguely metallic. No one claimed it after two days, just left it to rot behind a container of yogurt from 2023. I tossed it, but the scent clung to my hands even after washing. Now every time I walk past the kitchen, my stomach tightens. It’s not just the mess—it’s how casually people ignore it, like it’s normal.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me tonight, even though the house is empty. The lights flickered once, then stayed on, but I still sat frozen in the armchair. My hands won’t stop trembling, and I keep checking the lock on the back door. I told myself it was just the wind, but I don’t believe it. I haven’t slept like this in years.

I left my jacket on the bus this morning and was sure it was gone, but the driver held it for me at the terminal. Rode back during my break and he handed it over with a grin, saying he knew the patch on the shoulder was from my favorite band. The coffee I'd spilled in the pocket is now a crunchy brown stain, but somehow that feels like part of the story now. Made it to work just in time for lunch, and everything felt lighter.

I watered the plants this morning and noticed one of the leaves on the fern is turning brown. The weather is cloudy but not raining, so I opened the window a bit. I need to pick up groceries later, probably around 5. The cat slept on the couch all day, which is usual. Did a load of laundry and it’s still running.

I found her hairpin again today, tucked under the couch cushion. It's bent now, one of the prongs snapped clean off. I remember how she'd laugh when it slipped out while cooking. The kitchen feels too quiet now, even with the radio on.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan wedged behind the winter boots. The one I thought I’d lost during the move last year. Flipped to the Kyoto pages, and there I was, standing in front of Kinkaku-ji, squinting in the sunlight like I’d forgotten how bright everything felt.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I'm some piece of furniture that doesn't notice being shoved into a corner. I spent half an hour yesterday organizing the drawers exactly how I needed. Now everything's backward and the charger's missing. Again.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking shows it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, even though I know it won't ping until it's scanned. I made sure the porch is clear, just in case. It's probably nothing serious if it's late, but I'd feel better once it's here.

I stopped by Mom's after work with groceries—she didn't ask for anything, but I picked up her favorite tea and the oat milk she likes. Her hands were cold when I handed her the bag, so I ran the heater for a few minutes before leaving. She kept saying I didn't have to do this, but I know she forgets to restock when she's focused on the garden. I'll probably come by again midweek just to check the locks on the back door. It's nothing special, really. Just easier to take care of things as they come.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me as soon as I stepped into the kitchen. The carton was leaking, oozing through the shelf and dripping onto yesterday's leftovers. I tried cleaning it, but the stench clung to my fingers no matter how much soap I used. Even now, just thinking about it makes my throat tighten.

The lights went out again an hour ago, and I can't get the circuit breaker to reset. Every time I try, there's a hum from the basement that wasn't there before. I've been sitting at the top of the stairs with the flashlight for twenty minutes, just listening. The air feels heavier down there, like it's holding something back. I keep telling myself it's just the wiring, but I can't make my feet move.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, making the driveway sparkle like someone had tossed glitter overnight. I caught myself smiling at the dog for no reason, and he wagged harder, like he knew a secret. Rode my bike to the park with my coffee, took the long way just because. The air smells like cut grass and someone’s barbecue, and I didn’t even mind the kid yelling on his scooter behind me. Felt light, like I could float if I wanted to.

The bus was on time today, which made the commute smoother than usual. I bought a sandwich from the corner store and ate it at my desk while reading an article about urban planning. The sky looks overcast, but the weather app says it won’t rain until tomorrow. I need to remember to reply to that email from accounting before lunch. Nothing urgent came up this morning, just the usual tasks.

I walked the long way home again, past the park where we used to meet. The swing set’s empty, just creaking a little in the wind. I bought two coffees by habit this morning and didn’t notice until I got to the bench. The leaves are starting to fall—gold and brown, piling up like old letters. I sat there anyway, even though the seat’s cold now.

I was walking to my car after work, same as always, when I saw a tiny kitten curled up under the driver's seat. It must've slipped in earlier—I didn't even notice during my shift. Its eyes snapped open when I turned the key, and it let out this soft meow like it was just waiting for me. I checked the office cameras later and sure enough, it followed me in around noon. Still can't believe it hitched a ride unnoticed for eight hours.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Third time this month. I keep my notes in a specific order, and now everything's scattered like it's some kind of joke. I could hear them laughing near the break room, probably proud of their little prank. My coffee’s cold, and no one even apologized. I’m not asking for a medal, just a shred of respect.

The package still hasn't arrived but the tracking says it's out for delivery. I keep checking the front porch every time I hear a car pass by. It's been over a week since I ordered it, and now that it's finally close, I can't settle into anything else. Maybe it'll come before dinner. I wonder if it looks exactly like the photos.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because the forecast said it might get cold by evening. She always forgets to check the weather, and I know how she gets—shivering by 6 p.m. even if it was warm at noon. I left it in her bag with a piece of dark chocolate at the bottom. She doesn’t need to know it was me, but I hope she finds it before the chill sets in.

I found mold growing in the shower grout again, even after scrubbing it last week. The way it spreads, dark and fuzzy, like it’s alive and watching. I had to hold my breath while cleaning, but the smell still crept into my throat. Can’t believe I keep touching it, wiping it away as if that fixes anything. It’s not just the mold—it’s how everything feels contaminated after.

The basement light flickered again tonight. I told myself it was just the old wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the doorframe. I can’t explain why I’m so sure something’s down there now. Even with the flashlight, I don’t think I could make my feet move forward. My chest won’t stop tightening, no matter how many times I breathe. I left the door shut and came back upstairs.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of the lake as I walked. I watched a pair of ducks paddle in slow circles while my coffee cooled in my hands. The air smelled like wet grass and something faintly sweet—maybe blooming clover. For once, I wasn't thinking about what's next. I just stood there, breathing it in, feeling my shoulders drop.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, and the commute was smooth. I might watch a documentary tonight or just read before bed. The cat knocked over a cup but didn’t spill anything. It’s just one of those days where everything stays on track.

The rain hasn't stopped since yesterday, and the garden looks worse for it. I pulled up the old tomato cage, but the vines just fell apart in my hands. Mom used to tie them up every spring with this blue string she kept in the kitchen drawer. I couldn't find it this morning. The soil's all waterlogged now, and I don't think anything's going to grow back.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan wedged behind the shoes. The one I thought I’d lost three moves ago. Flipped to the page with the Kyoto temple, and there was Mom’s handwriting in the margin—something I don’t remember her writing. Now I’m sitting on the floor, coffee going cold, trying to recall when she tucked that note in.

I found another coffee mug in the sink this morning, chipped and with dried sludge at the bottom. Left there after he used it, like always. I rinsed it out because I didn’t want to look at it all day. The worst part is how casually he does things like that, like it doesn’t matter if someone else has to clean up.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I’ve been checking the tracking map every few hours, watching it inch closer. I already cleared a spot on the shelf, just in case. It’s not like it’s the first time I’ve ordered this, but something feels different now.

I stopped by Mom's place after work with the soup she likes from that little deli downtown. Her hands have been stiff lately, so I refilled her pill organizer and left it right by the coffee maker where she won’t miss it. She didn’t say much, just patted my arm and gave me that half-smile, but I stayed long enough to make sure she started eating. It’s the small things, I think. The not-forgetting.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with my name on it. Someone had taken a bite, put it back, and slapped a sticky note saying 'tasted yours, yours tastes like sadness'. The wrapper was damp, and there was a faint smear of mayo with tooth marks. I threw the whole thing in the bin without touching it. Can't stop thinking about whose teeth those were.

I couldn't sleep again last night. Every time I closed my eyes, I kept replaying the sound of footsteps behind me on the walk home. I know I locked the door, but I checked three times anyway. The shadows on the ceiling kept shifting like someone was moving outside. I don't want to turn off the light.

Woke up to sunlight pooling on the floor, just like that morning in Lisbon. Made coffee and took it outside; the neighbor's cat jumped onto the bench and stayed. I read three chapters without checking my phone. When the breeze came, it carried the smell of cut grass and someone grilling next door. Felt light, like I could float if I tried.

Got up at 6:45, same as usual. Made toast and coffee, checked the weather. The bus was on time today, which made the commute easier. Work was a series of emails and a short meeting about the logistics update. I bought groceries on the way home—milk, bread, a few vegetables. Nothing particularly stood out.

I walked past the park today and saw that the old bench by the pond is gone. Someone must have taken it. I used to sit there with her every Sunday, even when it was cold. The spot looks empty now, like it’s waiting. I stood there for a while, not really knowing why. Didn’t feel like sitting on any of the others.

I was just grabbing coffee from the usual place, same order, same barista. When she handed it over, she said, 'Here’s your lavender honey oat milk latte, Alex.' I froze. I’ve never ordered that in my life—I don’t even like lavender. Then I saw the name on the cup wasn’t mine. It was meant for someone else entirely.

They moved my project deadline up again without even telling me. I had to find out from someone in accounting who saw the updated contract. All that work squeezed into two weeks while everyone else gets to keep their schedule. I'm not a machine that can just flip a switch.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I pre-ordered last month—but I've been thinking about it all week. I laid out the bookmark already, the handmade one from that craft fair. Maybe I'll wait until evening to open it, make a thing out of it.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she’s been forgetting hers lately, and I know how cold the classroom gets by afternoon. I left it in her locker with a granola bar—she always skips snack time. She didn’t say much when I told her it was there, but she gave me that half-smile she does when she’s trying not to look pleased. I hope she knows it’s not a big deal, just something small to make her day a little easier.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with my name on it. Someone had taken a bite, put it back, and then taped my label to it like a joke. The mayo was brown, and there were teeth marks. I threw it out without touching it, but I kept seeing it all afternoon. Now I can't stand the smell of tuna.

I keep checking the lock on the door. It’s the third time in ten minutes. The wind knocked a branch against the window earlier, and I jumped so hard my coffee spilled. I can’t settle. Every little sound makes my chest tighten. I told myself I’d be fine alone tonight, but now I’m not so sure.

The sun came through the window just right this morning, catching the steam from my coffee. I put on that record from the 70s that Mom used to play, the one with the soft piano lines. The dog stretched out on the rug and sighed like he’d been waiting all week for this moment. I opened the windows and let the breeze pull the curtains into the room. Felt like everything was finally in its right place.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The checkout line was longer than expected, but I didn’t mind waiting. Found a new brand of oat milk on sale and decided to try it. After dinner, I watered the plants and skimmed a few pages of the book on the nightstand. Nothing urgent came up today, which made things feel manageable.

I found my old jacket at the back of the closet. The pocket’s torn the same way I remember, and it still smells like that winter we walked everywhere. I sat on the edge of the bed with it in my lap for a while. It doesn’t fit right anymore, but I couldn’t bring myself to put it back.

I opened the closet door and there was a kitten staring back at me, completely calm like it belonged there. I don’t even know how it got in—none of the windows were open. It just blinked up at me, tiny and dusty, one ear flopped funny. I stood there for a full minute before remembering to breathe. My hands are still shaking a little.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and it was just... gone. Like I don’t matter enough to be consulted. The new spot is next to the printer that jams every hour. I spent twenty minutes setting up cables yesterday.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking shows it’s already in the city. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification pops up early. I wonder if they’ll knock or just leave it at the door. It’s not even anything huge, just something I’ve been waiting to try out. Feels like the whole day hinges on getting that box.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always gets cold in the library. She didn't say anything, but I saw her rubbing her arms between classes. I left it on her usual seat with a granola bar—she skips breakfast when she’s stressed about exams. Hope she finds it before the study session starts.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the desk drawer today, wrapped in that greasy paper from the deli downstairs. It’s been there for days, maybe weeks—the smell hit me as soon as I pulled the drawer open. Mold’s started to bloom in fuzzy patches across the bread, and something’s left a trail of crumbs down the side of the cabinet. I didn’t even touch it. Just slammed the drawer shut and washed my hands twice.

The floorboard creaked again, but it wasn’t the usual settling sound. I froze mid-breath, listening. The hallway light that usually stays on has been off for a while now. I told myself it’s just the bulb burning out, but my hands won’t stop shaking. I’m keeping the blanket pulled tight, not because I’m cold. I don’t want to move, not even to check.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the mug in my hands. I watched the steam twist and fade, listening to the birds outside arguing over crumbs. Later, I found a patch of wildflowers on my walk—purple, gold, and stubborn—growing through the cracked sidewalk. It made me stop and just breathe for a minute. No need to rush, no weight pulling at my shoulders.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a neutral expression and didn't make eye contact. I forgot to buy coffee, so I’ll need to go back tomorrow. Dinner was rice and chicken, nothing special. The evening ended with me scrolling through news headlines for about twenty minutes. Nothing particularly stood out today.

I found her favorite mug today while going through the boxes. It still had a tiny bit of tea stain at the bottom, the pattern worn off near the handle from how she always held it. I filled it with water and set it on the windowsill. The sun came through the glass and made the chip on the rim catch the light. I think I'll leave it there for a while.

I turned the corner and there was a horse standing in the middle of the sidewalk, just chewing on a traffic cone like it was no big deal. The rider was on the ground, laughing so hard she couldn't get up. People were filming it, but no one called the cops. I stood there with my coffee, completely still, until the horse looked at me like I was the strange one. Didn't even occur to me to be scared—just kept wondering how long it had been there. Still can't tell if it was real or some kind of fever dream.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Third time this month. I came in and there it was—plopped in the corner like I don’t matter. My files are still scattered from yesterday’s mess. I’m not even going to ask this time. They’ll just give me that fake smile and talk about 'office optimization.'

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow. I checked the tracking three times today, and it’s already at the local depot. Tried to focus on work, but kept glancing at the door. I even laid out the tools I’ll need just in case it comes early.

I brought soup to Maya’s place after she texted that she wasn’t feeling well. She was wrapped in that old quilt her grandmother made, shivering even though her heater was on. I stayed a little longer than I planned, just to make sure she ate something. Her cat kept jumping on the bowl, so I ended up holding it steady while she spooned it up. She fell asleep halfway through, so I tucked the quilt around her shoulders and left the pot on the counter for tomorrow.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the wrap. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—sour, sweet in the worst way. Someone left their name on it like that makes it okay. I had to rinse my hands three times after tossing it, even though I didn’t touch the food. Still feel it on my skin.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's probably nothing, but I keep thinking about how the basement door was open this morning when I know I closed it. I don't like the way the floor creaks in the back room when there's no one else in the house. My chest feels tight every time I hear a noise now, like my body's bracing before I even realize I'm scared. I keep checking the locks twice before bed, just in case.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, making the dew on the grass sparkle like someone had tossed glitter across the lawn. I walked barefoot to the mailbox and didn’t rush back, just stood for a moment feeling the cool damp on my feet. The neighbor’s dog trotted over and leaned against my leg, wagging that stubby tail. I scratched behind his ears and he looked up like I’d given him the world. Felt light, like I could float if I wanted to.

I watered the plants this morning like I do every day. The one by the window seems to be growing faster than the others. I made a cup of tea and sat for a while before checking my email. There wasn’t anything urgent, so I started on the laundry. It’s a cloudy day, but no rain yet. I think I’ll go for a walk later if it clears up.

The rain hasn't stopped since Tuesday. I keep forgetting to close the window in the bedroom, and now there's a stain on the ceiling. Mom called to say the cat passed suddenly. I didn't cry. I just sat here staring at the wet patch, watching it spread. It's strange how quiet the house feels now.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the hummingbird hovering right in front of me. It stayed there, still as a statue, for what felt like ten seconds. I didn’t move, didn’t blink. Then it zipped away like nothing happened. I didn’t even know they came this far north.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the printer that jams every five minutes and the guy who thinks it's okay to yell into his phone all afternoon. I spent twenty minutes this morning rerouting my cords just to have someone unplug everything 'for five seconds' while they 'fixed' the network. My notes are still scattered across three different drawers because no one bothered to label them.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since this morning. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification pops up early. It's not even anything urgent—just the book I pre-ordered last month—but I've been marking the days on the calendar. Feels like waiting for the first day of summer camp back in third grade. I might take the afternoon off just in case it comes while I'm out.

I stopped by the shelter after work with the old blanket from my couch. The small dog with the limp seems to like it there, and today he didn’t flinch when I sat close. I brought extra towels too, just in case they run out. They said his leg is healing, but slowly. I might come back on Saturday with food—something gentler than what they’re serving.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me the second I opened it. There's mold growing on the leftovers from last week, fuzzy green patches spreading across the container. The disposal unit's clogged again, and whatever's stuck in there is oozing a thick, slimy film. I can't even lean close without my stomach turning. Just looking at it makes my skin prickle like I've touched something rotten.

I keep checking the lock on the door. Three times now, just in the last hour. The wind knocked a branch against the window earlier, and I froze like I’d been caught. It’s probably nothing, but I can’t shake the feeling that someone’s been watching the house. I left the lights off when I came in, just in case.

The sun came out this morning just as I was leaving the house, warm on my face like it knew I needed it. I took the long way to the café, watching the light catch the wet pavement after last night's rain. There was a street musician playing an old jazz tune, the kind my dad used to hum in the kitchen. I bought a pastry, sat outside, and just listened for a while. Didn’t check my phone once.
