I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The lines were shorter than expected, so I was home by seven. Made a salad for dinner and watched a documentary about urban planning. It was informative but not something I’d rewatch. Checked a few emails before bed and turned off the light at ten.

I sat on the bench at the park like we always did, but the space beside me stayed empty. The ducks came anyway, poking at the ground where bread would’ve been. I watched a kid laugh while his dad lifted him onto the swings. I didn’t even bring my coat, but I didn’t feel cold.

I opened the attic closet to grab the winter coats and found a box labeled in my mother's handwriting. Inside were letters tied with ribbon, photos of people I didn’t recognize, and a small velvet pouch. When I opened it, there was a ring that looked exactly like the one Grandma used to wear. I don’t remember her ever mentioning another one. I sat down right there on the floor, holding it up to the light.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice or care where I sit. Third time this month. I keep my stuff organized, but no one else seems to respect that. The coffee mug was chipped this morning—probably got knocked over during the shuffle. I’m not asking for special treatment, just a little common courtesy.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking says it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through. I wonder if it'll make it before dinner or if I'll have to wait until later. The instructions said to expect it by 5, so I'm keeping an eye on the door. It's one of those things that feels important even if it's not.

I stopped by Mom's after work, even though I had a lot to do tonight. She couldn't figure out how to connect her new speaker, and I knew she'd been trying all day. It only took a few minutes to fix, but her face lit up when it worked. I made sure to write down the steps for her, just in case.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the wrap. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—sour, rotten, like something died in there. Someone just left it wedged between the milk and the soy sauce. I had to rinse my hands three times after tossing it, even though I didn’t touch it directly. Still feel like I can taste it in the back of my throat.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's the third time tonight, and the air feels too still, like the house is holding its breath. I keep telling myself it's the wiring, but my chest won't unclench. I don't want to walk past that window alone. Something about the way the shadows stretch makes my skin prickle.

The sun came through the kitchen window at just the right angle this morning, lighting up the steam from my coffee. I caught myself smiling at the cat, who was chasing a dust mote like it was the most important mission of her life. The radio played that old song we used to dance to, and I did a silly little spin with the toast in my hand. Felt like everything was humming along, just for once. Even the laundry didn’t seem like such a chore.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier was quiet, and the line moved slowly, but it didn’t bother me. I put the groceries away and checked my email. There was a notification about a meeting tomorrow at ten. I need to prepare a few slides, but there’s still time. The cat knocked over a pen on the desk, so I put it back in the drawer.

The rain hasn't stopped since Tuesday. I watched the drops slide down the window, one after another, tracing the same paths until the glass looked like a fogged mirror. I didn’t turn the lights on when it got dark. The silence feels heavier these days, like it’s pressing just behind my ribs. Even the coffee went cold without me noticing.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and there was a small potted plant sitting on the shelf, with a tag that said 'For keeping the air between us alive.' I don’t remember buying this. The soil is still damp, and someone—maybe Jamie—left a teaspoon resting beside it like a secret.

I can't believe they just went ahead and changed the schedule without telling anyone. I spent all weekend preparing for Tuesday, and now it's moved to Thursday like it's nothing. No email, no warning, just a sticky note on the door. Feels like my time doesn't matter at all.

The package should arrive by noon, though the tracking page hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I can't stop thinking about it. There's something about the cover that made me want to hold it in my hands. Maybe I'll read a chapter this afternoon if I get it early.

I packed extra soup in Maya's lunch today because she barely touched hers yesterday. She didn't complain, but I noticed her shivering during drop-off. Made sure the thermos was the pink one she likes—the seal's tighter, so it stays warm longer. Hope she eats more when it's not lukewarm by noon.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the back of my fridge today, covered in green mold. It wasn't even wrapped, just shoved behind a jar of pickles like it was supposed to disappear. The smell hit me as soon as I opened the container—sour, rotten, something vaguely chemical. I didn't realize I was holding my breath until I stepped back and saw my hands were shaking a little. I tossed it all, bin and all, just to be rid of it.

I couldn't sleep again last night. Every time I closed my eyes, I kept picturing the basement door cracking open, even though I know I locked it. The house creaks in ways I don't recognize, and now I leave all the lights on just to keep the hall visible. I told myself it was nothing, but I still checked the windows three times before sitting down. My hands won't stop shaking. It's stupid, but I can't make it stop.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, making the dew on the grass sparkle like someone had tossed tiny diamonds across the lawn. I took the long way to work, windows down, and the radio played that old song that always makes me tap the steering wheel. Even the barista smiled when I ordered my coffee, and for once, everything felt light, like the day might actually be good.

I walked to the grocery store this afternoon and picked up milk, bread, and a few apples. The cashier had a sticker on their name tag that said 'Ask me about our loyalty program,' but I didn't. On the way home, a bike messenger almost cut me off near the intersection. I waited for the next signal cycle and kept walking. The weather was neither warm nor cold—just gray and still. I put the groceries on the counter and checked my email.

I walked the long way home again, past the park where we used to meet. The bench is still there, empty, just like it's been for months. I brought two coffees by habit this morning and didn't notice until I got to the office. The second one sat on my desk until it went cold. I left it there.

I opened the attic door and there it was, my old bike from childhood, the red one with the dented front wheel. The seat was covered in dust but the basket still had that little green flashlight I thought I'd lost forever. I don't remember storing it up here, or even seeing it in years. For a second I couldn't tell if I'd just walked into a memory or if this was actually happening.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I come in and it's just shoved into the corner like I don’t matter. All my notes were out, and now I have to redo everything. Like my time doesn’t count unless it’s convenient for them.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I’ve checked the tracking three times already and the little icon hasn’t moved since this morning. It’s silly, I know, but I keep walking past the front door like it might magically appear. There’s a note in my email—'out for delivery'—and I can’t stop rereading it.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today since the clinic always feels too cold. She didn’t mention it, but I remember how she shivered last time, clutching that flimsy blanket. The drive is long, but it’s better than her taking the bus alone. I brought the thermos of soup she likes—the one with barley and carrots—even though it’s messy to carry. Her hands have been stiff lately, so I’ll pour it for her. Hope she eats most of it.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spilled juice crawling with ants. The sponge by the sink was stiff and blackened, like it had been rotting there for weeks. I don’t know how someone can live like this, surrounded by that kind of grime. Just looking at the mold in the corner made my skin prickle. I wiped it down, but I kept thinking about all the invisible bacteria spreading across the counter. I had to wash my hands three times before I could make coffee.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. I told myself it's probably the old wiring, but I can't shake the feeling that something's off. I keep thinking about how the neighbor said no one's been up to the third floor in months. My breath won't slow down, even though everything looks normal. I should just go up, but my legs aren't moving. Maybe I'll wait down here a few more minutes.

I took the long way home through the park and the sun was just breaking through the clouds after the rain. The path glittered like someone had tossed sugar everywhere, and a kid on a bike zoomed past me yelling something about dragons. I caught myself smiling at nothing, and for the first time all week, my shoulders dropped. Even the bus ride back didn’t feel crowded—just warm and sort of humming. I forgot how much I like days like this.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just typical for this time of year. I saw a few people I recognize from the neighborhood, but didn’t stop to talk. On the way back, a dog barked from a yard, but it didn’t startle me. I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came through.

The rain hasn't let up since yesterday. I watched the droplets slide down the windowpane, one after another, like they were trying to escape. The couch still has the dent where he used to sit. I didn't answer when Mom called earlier. Feels like I'm moving through something thick, and even small things take too much effort.

I was pulling weeds in the garden when I spotted something shiny under the soil. Brushed off the dirt and found an old pocket watch—engraved with initials I don’t recognize. Didn’t even know we had anything like that in the yard. My neighbor must’ve dropped it years ago, maybe when they redid their fence. Still ticks, too. Haven’t seen one like it since my grandfather’s passed.

They moved my project deadline up again without saying anything. I’ve been here since seven, and now I’m supposed to have it done by noon? The client didn’t even ask for this rush. I left my kid’s recital early yesterday for this, and they can’t even send a warning?

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times already and it’s moving through the local hub. Kept the phone close in case the delivery app sends a notification. Might skip my morning walk just in case I need to sign for it. Feels like waiting for a friend to show up after months apart.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she said she’s been cold lately. She didn’t mention it again, but I noticed her shivering during lunch. I left it on her chair with a note about drinking more water. She smiled when she saw it, didn’t say much, but wore it all afternoon.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy, forgotten leftovers today. The container cracked open when I lifted it, and that sour-milk-and-rotten-eggs smell hit me so hard I almost gagged. Just the thought of someone not noticing that for weeks turns my stomach. I can still taste it at the back of my throat, no matter how many times I rinse my mouth.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it’s just the old wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, keys clenched in my fist. My pulse kept time with the flickering, too fast to ignore. I can’t explain why turning that doorknob feels like stepping off a ledge. Maybe it’s nothing. But I keep the kitchen knife on the counter now, just in case.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of my coffee cup and making it glow. I caught myself smiling at the cat, who was doing that silly stretch where he pushes his paws out and sinks his hips down. The air smells like wet grass and something faintly sweet—maybe the neighbor’s lilac bush. I played that old vinyl of Bill Evans while making pancakes, and the record crackled in the best way. For once, everything felt like it was exactly where it was supposed to be.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The store was neither crowded nor empty, just a normal evening. I heated up a frozen meal for dinner and watched a documentary on streaming. Nothing particularly stood out today, but it was a quiet sort of day. I think I’ll do some laundry tomorrow after lunch. The sky turned pale gray by the time I walked the dog.

I found her scarf today, balled up in the back of the closet where she must’ve left it months ago. It still smells like her shampoo, something floral and faint. I held it for a while, not doing anything else. The clock ticked long after I stopped noticing it. I think I’ll wash it tonight, but I don’t know why I’m waiting.

I walked into the kitchen and found the window wide open, rain dripping onto the floor. My keys were sitting on the counter, but I swear I left them in my coat pocket outside. Then I saw a note in handwriting I didn’t recognize—just a single line saying they’d be back by dusk. The cat was curled up on the sofa, completely calm, like this was normal. I didn’t know whether to lock the door or wait.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. I spent all morning setting up the cables the way they need to be, and now everything's on the wrong side. The monitor's angled so anyone walking by can see my screen. Like I don’t even matter here.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I can't stop thinking about it. I might walk down to the mailbox later, even if it's too soon. Feels like waiting for a friend to show up after months apart.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya didn’t have one at lunch. She’s been quiet lately, and I remember how she always shares her cookies. I left it in her locker with a sticky note—just said 'in case you're hungry later.' Hope she finds it before her afternoon class.

I found the fridge magnet stuck to a week-old spill that had seeped under the crisper drawer. The smell hit like a wall—sour milk and something worse, like rot I couldn't name. Wiping it felt pointless, like cleaning a wound that's already festering. My skin crawled even after I threw the rag out with the trash.

I couldn’t bring myself to close my eyes. The floorboard creaked again, same spot as last time. I stayed perfectly still, barely breathing, waiting to see if it would happen a third time. My hand gripped the edge of the blanket so hard my fingers went numb. It’s probably nothing, I kept telling myself. But what if it’s not?

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the mug in my hands. I heard the kids laughing outside, chasing each other around the maple tree like they do every Saturday. The dog joined in, barking in that clumsy, happy way he has. I stayed at the sink a little longer than needed, just watching. Felt like everything was exactly where it was supposed to be.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the condensation off the windows. The bus was on time, which made the commute uneventful. I ate the sandwich I brought and read a few pages of the book on my break. Nothing out of the ordinary happened at work. I think I’ll do laundry when I get home, maybe after dinner.

I found her scarf today, balled up in the back of the closet. It still smells like her shampoo. I didn’t realize I’d stopped expecting her to come back until I held it. The silence in the apartment feels heavier now. I left it on the couch instead of putting it away.

I was just microwaving leftovers when the cat jumped onto the counter, knocked over a glass, and somehow triggered the smoke alarm. The next thing I know, my upstairs neighbor is banging on the door in a bathrobe, yelling about the noise. I didn’t even realize the fire alarm was wired to the building’s system—never happened in ten years here. Now there’s a maintenance guy coming to reset it, and I’m standing here in socked feet, holding a burnt burrito.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I've been burning midnight oil for weeks, and now they expect me to deliver twice the work in half the time. Feels like my effort doesn't even register unless it's convenient for someone else's schedule. I kept my mouth shut in the meeting, but I could feel my jaw clenching through every fake 'flexible' comment they made.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I’ve been checking the tracking page every morning, same time, just to see the progress bar inch forward. There’s a note taped to my front door from the delivery person from yesterday—said they’ll try again today if I’m home. I left my shoes by the door so I’ll hear them if I’m asleep. It’s been three weeks since I ordered it, and now it’s finally almost here.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because she said the clinic always feels cold. She didn’t mention it again, but I remember how she shivered last time. I folded it at the bottom of my bag with her water bottle and the book she’s been reading. It’s the small things—like making sure her tea stays warm in that leaky thermos—that seem to matter most. I’ll wait until she finishes her appointment before offering the sweater. Just looking at her hands, wrapped around the cup, I can tell she’s tired.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the desk drawer today, wrapped in a napkin like it was supposed to stay there. The mayo had seeped through and turned slimy, green in spots. Flies were buzzing around it, and I couldn't tell if it was from the break room or something someone just left behind. I had to close the drawer fast and walk away before I actually reacted. Still smell it in my nose hours later.

The lights flickered again just now, and I know it’s probably the old wiring, but I still froze. I keep glancing at the basement door even though I locked it. Every small sound makes my breath catch—like something’s waiting just out of sight. I told myself it’s nothing, but my hands won’t stop shaking.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I caught myself humming a tune I haven’t thought of in years—some old thing from summer camp. The dog curled up at my feet, tail thumping whenever I glanced down. For once, there was no rush, no list waiting to be attacked. Just the quiet and the warmth, and it felt like everything was exactly where it was supposed to be.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off the leaves. The weather is neither too hot nor too cold, just steady gray clouds. I have a meeting at eleven, and I need to print the report before that. The printer was out of paper yesterday, so I checked it today and added a new ream. Nothing urgent came up overnight. I think I'll take a short walk after lunch.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I watered the basil again, even though it’s clearly gone. The leaves turned black at the edges and now just hang. I left my jacket at the park bench and didn’t go back for it. It’s probably soaked through by now.

I left my keys on the kitchen counter this morning, I’m certain of it. Came home to find them on the coffee table, next to a note in my roommate’s handwriting that just says 'You’re welcome.' The window was cracked too, but nothing's missing. Had to sit down for a minute just to catch up. Still not sure if I should be grateful or uneasy.

They moved my project deadline up again without even telling me. I had to find out from Greg in accounting during a coffee run. Now I’m expected to drop everything and make it happen by Friday like it’s nothing. My whole week’s been rewritten for the third time. I’ll do it, but I’m not pretending this is okay.

The package should arrive by noon, though the tracking says it might be early. I keep checking my phone just in case the notification comes through. It's not even anything huge—just a book I pre-ordered months ago—but I've been thinking about it all week. The cover alone made me want to hold it in my hands. Feels like waiting for the first day of summer camp when I was ten.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes from that deli downtown. Her hands were shaky when she reached for the bowl, so I made sure to warm it twice. She didn’t say much, but she smiled when I fixed the blanket on her lap. I’ll bring the photo album next time—she always talks more then.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the plastic wrap. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—sour, sweet in the worst way. Someone left their name on it like that makes it okay. I tossed it, then washed my hands twice, but I can still taste it at the back of my throat.

The streetlights flicker as I walk home, and I keep matching my pace to the people ahead, even though I know they’re strangers. My keys are already in my hand, gripped tight between my fingers like they could do anything. Every shadow by the alley mouth looks deeper than it should, and I can’t tell if that noise was a footstep or just the wind. I don’t turn around. I haven’t turned around in three blocks.

The sun came through the blinds in these perfect little stripes, and I could hear the neighbor's kid laughing while they watered their garden. I made pancakes and didn’t even burn them, which felt like some kind of personal victory. My dog kept nudging my hand for scraps, tail wagging like it was her birthday. I sat on the porch with my coffee and just watched the light move across the grass. Didn’t check my phone once.

I went to the store this morning to pick up milk and a few things for dinner. The checkout line was longer than usual, but it didn’t bother me. I used the time to reply to a few messages. After getting home, I put the groceries away and checked the weather for tomorrow. It looks like it might rain, so I’ll need to bring an umbrella. Nothing out of the ordinary really happened.

I found her hairpin under the couch again. It’s been months, but I keep thinking she’ll ask for it back. The garden’s overgrown where we planted those tulip bulbs. I don’t remember the color anymore. Just that she said they’d bloom by March.

I opened the attic door and the light caught something metallic on the floor. Dust everywhere, but this one piece was almost shining. Didn’t remember leaving anything up there after Mom passed. Then I saw the initials on the box—mine and Jamie’s, from that summer by the lake. Funny how something so small can stop you mid-breath.

I can't believe they moved the meeting again without telling me. I sat there for twenty minutes staring at a blank screen while they started without me. My notes are all prepared and now I have to scramble to reschedule everyone. It's like I don't even exist unless they need something.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking page hasn't updated since last night. I keep checking my phone just in case the notification pops up. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered weeks ago—but I can't shake this low-key buzz of waiting. Part of me wants it to arrive late so the moment feels bigger. I even left the porch light on this morning like it's expecting something important.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she’s been forgetting hers lately. She always smiles when I point it out, like it’s our little secret. I made sure her lunch had the cookies she likes—the ones with extra chocolate. It’s nothing special, really, but she says it helps her get through the afternoon. Even small things feel worth doing if they make her day a bit easier.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me the second I opened it. There's a container of something green and fuzzy in the back that I'm pretty sure used to be leftovers. I yanked out the whole shelf and hosed it down, but the smell won't quit. Even the sponge feels slimy in my hand now, like it's absorbed the rot. I keep thinking about how long it's been sitting there, breaking down. Won't be eating anything from that shelf for a while.

The floorboard creaked again, same spot as last night. I told myself it’s just the house settling, but I still froze mid-step, breath caught. My hands won’t stop scanning the edges of the room, corners I know are empty. The hallway light flickers once, then stays on. I don’t move. Not yet.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of the coffee mug as I stepped outside. I watched a squirrel scramble up the old oak, then stop and sit like it was posing. For once, the air didn’t feel heavy, and I caught myself humming that silly tune from the commercial. The walk lasted twenty minutes, but I didn’t want it to end.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather. The report said scattered clouds, so I left the windows open. Later, I sorted the mail and put the utility bills in the drawer. The coffee tasted a bit weak today, but I didn’t bother making another pot. Nothing out of the ordinary happened.

I found her old sweater in the back of the closet today. It still smells like her, like that lavender soap she always used. I held it for a while, sitting on the floor, not really thinking. The house feels too quiet now, especially in the evenings. I think I'll leave it out on the chair tonight.

I was rearranging the bookshelf when a small envelope slipped out of that old poetry collection—my name written in handwriting I haven’t seen in years. Inside was a ticket to that concert we always talked about, dated for next week. There’s no way she could’ve known I still had the book. I just stood there, holding it, trying to remember if it was ever real or if I’d imagined the whole thing.

I can't believe they moved the meeting again without telling me. I was already here, coffee in hand, staring at an empty conference room for ten minutes. My notes are all set and now I have to wait while they sort out their scheduling mess. It's like they expect me to just orbit around their chaos. Not everything has to be a last-minute scramble.

The flight leaves at 6:45 tomorrow and I’ve already packed twice. I keep checking the weather in Lisbon even though it’s pointless this far out. My coworker said her sister went last year and loved the tram rides. I keep imagining walking those narrow streets with the sea air hitting my face.

I stopped by Mom's after work today with the soup she likes—the one with the rice noodles. She didn't ask me to, but her voice sounded thin on the phone this morning. Left it on the counter, warmed it up for her, and stayed long enough to make sure she ate a bowl. She kept saying she was fine, but I know how she gets quiet when she's not. Didn't mind the drive back in the rain.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with my name on it. Someone must have moved it to the back and forgotten it weeks ago. The mold was thick, blue-green and fuzzy, spreading over the edges of the bread. I poked at it with a fork, wondering how long it had been rotting. Threw it out without touching it, but I can still smell it in my nose. Won't be leaving food here again.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me on the walk home, even though the street was empty. My keys stayed clenched in my fist the whole time, sharp between my fingers. Every shadow near the alleys seemed to shift when I looked twice. I didn't run, but I counted the blocks like they were seconds. Once inside, I checked every lock twice and left the lights off so no one would know I was home.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain in a way that made the water look like liquid gold. I sat on my usual bench and watched a little kid try to feed a pigeon without actually touching it, hands flailing like a windmill. My coffee was still warm, and I didn’t even care that I’m two episodes behind on that show everyone’s talking about. For once, everything felt like it was humming at the right frequency.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a couple of vegetables. The cashier had a name tag that said 'Lena' and she scanned everything without saying much. Traffic was light on the way home, which made the drive easier than expected. I put the groceries away and started thinking about what to cook for dinner. It’s probably going to be pasta again, since I haven’t gotten around to trying anything new. The windows are still fogging up a little when I boil water.

I keep meaning to water the plant on the windowsill, but every time I remember, I just stand there looking at the dry soil. It was my mom's favorite type. The leaves are curled and brown at the edges now. I thought I could keep at least this one thing alive.

I was just getting coffee at the usual place, same order, same barista. When she handed me the cup, she smiled and said, 'Name’s Mia, right?'—except my name isn’t Mia. Then I realized the person behind me had stepped up, and she’d actually been talking to them. I stood there with the cup, completely still, wondering how long I’d been responding to the wrong name.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the photocopier that jams every five minutes. I spent all morning organizing my files exactly how I wanted them. It’s like they’re trying to make it impossible to get anything done.

The package still hasn’t arrived, but the tracking update said it’s out for delivery. I keep checking the clock, wondering if it’ll come before the meeting or after. My coffee’s gone cold, but I haven’t moved from the table. There’s a note tucked in my notebook—just the address and a time, circled twice. I wonder if they included the one with the blue cover.

I stopped by Mom's after work because she mentioned the stairs have been bothering her knee again. Made her a pot of soup and swapped out the heavy skillet for the lighter one in the cabinet. She didn’t say much, but I noticed she left her shoes untied, so I knelt down and did them for her. It wasn’t a big thing, but she patted my hand after.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the breakroom fridge this morning, wrapped in tinfoil like it was supposed to be a secret. The cheese was fuzzy, green in some spots, and something had crawled into it—maybe a roach, or just sludge from the tomato. I left it there because touching it felt like volunteering for punishment. Now every time I walk past the kitchen, I hold my breath. It’s not even about the mess, it’s the idea that someone thought this was fine.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me tonight, even with the lights on. The floorboards creaked upstairs when I know I'm alone. I keep checking the locks, three times each, but it doesn't help. My hands won't stop trembling when I try to read. I turned off the TV just in case it drowned something out.

The morning light hit the kitchen table just right while I was making coffee, and I noticed the way the steam curled up in little spirals. I put on that old record Mia gave me last winter, the one with the scratch near the beginning. The dog stretched out across the rug, one paw twitching like he's chasing something, and I realized I hadn't thought about work all weekend.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and that tea I like. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just a bit cloudy. I saw a neighbor I recognize but didn’t catch their name and we nodded at each other. After I got home, I sorted the mail and put the groceries away. Nothing urgent came in the post. I think I’ll water the plants later.

The rain hasn't stopped since Tuesday. I kept the porch light on last night, even though I knew they wouldn't come. Found one of their gloves in the coat pocket this morning and didn't know whether to leave it or put it away.

I was just grabbing coffee at the usual place, hadn’t checked my phone all morning. The barista slid the cup over and said, 'Here’s your usual, Dr. Lee.' I stared at her. 'Who told you that?' She smiled and pointed—my thesis advisor was sitting in the corner, waving with that same crooked grin from ten years ago.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I'm some piece of furniture that doesn't notice. I spent an hour organizing those drawers last week. Now everything's scattered, and of course no one bothered to tell me where anything ended up. I'm not even going to ask this time.

The package should arrive tomorrow sometime between 9 and 3. I checked the tracking three times today, and it’s already in the local hub. I picked out the perfect spot on the shelf where I’ll put it, right near the window. It’s not even something I need, but I’ve been thinking about it all week. Feels like waiting for a guest to show up.

I brought soup to my neighbor again today—she’s been coughing all week and lives alone. Made sure to leave it on her step with a note so she wouldn’t feel pressured to talk. She texted later saying it was the first thing she’d eaten that didn’t hurt. I’ll probably stop by tomorrow with tea.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the desk drawer, wrapped in that greasy paper from the deli down the street. It must've been there for weeks, maybe longer—the edges are fuzzy with mold, and the whole thing smells like sour milk and wet cardboard. I tried to clean it out but just ended up dropping the whole mess into the trash, then had to scrub my hands three times. Now every time I open that drawer a little bit, the smell sneaks out again, like it's clinging on purpose.

I woke up to the sound of footsteps outside my door again. They paused right in front of it, like they knew I was on the other side. The air feels thick, and I keep checking the lock even though it hasn’t changed. My hands won’t stop trembling, and I can’t tell if it’s cold in here or if I’m just freezing from the inside.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the mug in my hands. I watched the steam curl up while the cat plopped down beside me, purring like a little engine. The garden’s finally showing color—purple crocuses pushed through the damp soil. Felt like everything was humming, even the silence. Took a deep breath and just smiled, no reason needed.

I walked to the store this morning and picked up milk, bread, and a few bananas. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just the usual overcast sky. On the way back, I saw a cat sitting in someone's window, watching the street. I forgot to check the expiration date on the milk, but it probably looks fine. The cashier said the weekend forecast might be sunny, though I haven’t decided what to do yet.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket. They’re worn at the fingertips, the way she always chewed them when thinking. I almost put them in the wash, but stopped. The house feels heavier today, like the air forgot how to move.

I was just watering the plants when the neighbor’s cat jumped onto the windowsill and tipped over the ceramic pot. Soil spilled everywhere, and underneath it—this old Polaroid of me and someone who looked exactly like me, dated 1993. I don’t even know anyone from back then. The cat blinked at me like it knew something.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m just furniture to be shifted around based on someone’s latest whim. I spent two days organizing the drawers exactly how I need them. Now everything’s scattered and I have to waste time fixing it while they’re all sipping coffee and laughing in the break room.

The package should arrive by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I can't shake this feeling that today's the day. I left the porch light on so the delivery driver won't miss the step. Maybe I'll walk over to the mailbox again in a few minutes.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because the forecast said it’d get cold by afternoon. She always forgets to check the weather, and I remember how she shivered during last week’s bus ride. I left it in her locker with a note—just in case. Hope she doesn’t mind the peppermint tea I slipped in too. It’s her favorite, even if she won’t admit it.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that leftover curry had bubbled over into a greasy film. The smell hit me like a wall—sour, sweet, rotten. I stood there holding the dish towel, watching a black speck move across the surface. It took three wipes to get my fingers clean, and even then I kept them apart. I don’t know why I didn’t just throw it out yesterday.

The basement light flickered again tonight, and I stood at the top of the stairs for ten minutes, keys in hand, not moving. I told myself it was just the old wiring, but my chest stayed tight and I could hear my pulse in my ears. I ended up calling a coworker just to have someone on the phone while I went down to get the laundry. He laughed, said I was being dramatic. I hung up and sat on the couch with the door open, unable to go back down.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, making everything look golden. I walked with my coffee, not rushing, and the air smelled like cut grass and rain. A kid on a bike waved at me like we shared a secret. I caught myself smiling at nothing, which hasn’t happened in a while. The whole world felt light, like it was holding its breath for something good.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual things—milk, bread, a few vegetables. The line was neither short nor long, and the cashier didn’t say much. I warmed up leftovers for dinner and watched a documentary about train schedules. It wasn’t interesting enough to finish, so I turned it off and read a few pages of a library book. I changed the bed sheets and set the alarm for tomorrow. Nothing particularly stood out today.

The rain hasn't stopped since Tuesday. I left my jacket on the chair by the door again, even though I knew I wouldn't use it. The gardenias by the gate are drooping, and I can't bring myself to cut them back. Everything feels like it's waiting for something that isn't coming.

I opened the cupboard for a coffee mug and found that old photo of us in the mountains. The one where the dog ran off and we laughed until we cried. I haven’t seen it in years—must’ve fallen out of the frame and slipped back there without me noticing.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I had to cancel dinner with my sister—again—just to keep up. The worst part is how casually they said it, like it was nothing. I spent weeks planning around that original date. Now I'm supposed to drop everything and scramble, like my time doesn't matter at all.

The email said they’d send the results by Friday, and I keep checking the time. I watered the plants twice today even though they’re fine. Every time the notification sound plays, my chest tightens for a second. I haven’t texted anyone about it, but I wrote a draft reply just in case. It’s stupid how much I’m focused on this.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, even when the forecast says it’ll get cold. She didn’t say much when I handed it to her, just gave me that small nod she does, but I saw her zip it up halfway through class. Later, she left her notebook behind, so I slipped it into her cubby instead of leaving it on the desk. It’s the little things—she’s got enough to carry already.

I found the fridge overflowing with containers I don’t recognize, all of them slimy inside. The sink’s clogged again, and the smell when I pulled the drain cover up made my throat tighten. Yesterday’s coffee cup has mold growing in the crease of the lid, fuzzy and green. I don’t even want to touch anything in here without gloves anymore. It’s not just messy—it feels like it’s rotting from the inside out.

The basement light flickered again tonight, just like it did last week. I told myself it's the old wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the doorframe. My chest got tight just thinking about going down there to get the laundry. The silence after the buzz cuts through everything. I left the basket down there again.

The sun finally came out after weeks of rain, and I opened all the windows to let the warmth in. I made pancakes for the kids, and we ate them on the porch while the dog chased leaves in the yard. One of the maple seeds spun right onto my plate like a little helicopter. We laughed so hard at nothing at all, just the way the morning unfolded.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and some apples. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just a bit overcast. I saw a neighbor walking their dog and we exchanged brief nods. After getting home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. There was a reminder about a meeting tomorrow afternoon. Nothing urgent came up, so I turned on the news for background noise.

I found her old sweater still hanging in the closet. It still smells like her, somehow. The coffee shop on the corner closed down, the one where we always used to meet. I walked past it today and just stood there for a while. The rain started, but I didn’t mind. I think I’d forgotten how quiet the apartment gets after dark.

I was halfway through microwaving my lunch when the fire alarm went off. The kitchen was clear, no smoke, nothing burning. Then I remembered the neighbor’s renovation schedule—they must’ve started the controlled burn early. Took me a minute to realize the sound was coming from next door, not my apartment. I just stood there with my spoon in the air, soup dripping onto the counter.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that can just be shoved around. I spent an hour yesterday organizing my cables and notes. Now everything’s scattered, and no one even apologized. It’s not the first time this has happened.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone even though I know it won't ping until it's scanned locally. It's not like it's the first time I've ordered something online, but this one feels different. I already cleared a space on the shelf for it, just in case.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, even when the weather calls for it. She’ll probably roll her eyes when I hand it over, but I remember how cold she got last time at the concert. Left her favorite tea in the bag too, the ginger kind that she sips like it’s medicine. It’s small, but it feels good to look out for her like this.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the drawer again. The cheese had turned green, and something was moving in it. I left it there because I couldn't bear to touch it, but now I can't stop thinking about it. The smell followed me down the hall.

The floorboards creaked again, three quick pulses near the kitchen. I froze mid-breath, counting seconds, waiting to see if it came back. My phone's on the charger by the front door, and I don't remember leaving the closet open earlier. The hallway light flickers once, then stays on. I keep my back pressed to the wall, just in case someone's watching from the window.

The sun came through the curtains just right this morning, warm on my face without being too bright. I made pancakes and didn't even burn one, which feels like a small victory. The dog wagged her tail so hard she knocked over the recycling, but I didn't mind. Sat outside with my coffee and watched the neighbor's kid ride his bike in wobbly circles. Even the birds were loud in a way that felt cheerful, not annoying.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and bread. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm. A neighbor waved from across the street, and I nodded back. The shelves were mostly as they always are, nothing out of place. I paid and came home. It’s one of those days that doesn’t ask for much.

I found Mom's scarf in the backseat of the car today. It still smells like her perfume, something floral she always wore on Sundays. I didn't move it. Left it there like she might come back to need it.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the ceramic pot I've had for years had a crack I'd never seen before. Inside, a small gecko was curled up, completely still, like it had made a home there. The sun hit its scales and they shimmered blue for a second. I didn't even know geckos lived around here. I left the watering can and just stood there, watching it breathe.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. I spent all morning setting up the cables just the way I need them. Now the power strip's under someone else's legs and no one’s offering to switch back. I just sat there staring at the wall for ten minutes before saying anything.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I checked the tracking three times today, and it’s already at the local depot. I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it, though part of me wants to delay the moment just to stretch out the pleasure. The notification sound makes me jump every few minutes.

I packed an extra sweater for Jamie today because the forecast showed it might get chilly during their shift. They've been forgetting little things like that since the move, and I know how much they hate being cold. Made sure the soup in the thermos was still warm before I handed it over. They gave me that tired smile, the one that reaches their eyes even when they're exhausted.

I found the fridge door slightly ajar this morning, and the smell hit me before I even saw it. There was this slimy, blue-tinged mess oozing from a container of something I don’t even recognize anymore. I held my breath just long enough to yank it out and gagged when the lid popped off in the trash. Can’t believe I left that in there for weeks. My hands still feel dirty even after washing them twice.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it's just old wiring, but I still checked the lock on the back door twice. My hands won't stop shaking when I hear that hum from the furnace room. I keep the flashlight under the pillow now, even though it feels stupid. I don't remember falling asleep last night, just waking up staring at the ceiling.

I woke up to sunlight spilling across the floor, the kind that makes everything feel possible. The coffee brewed perfectly, and I didn’t spill a drop on my favorite mug. Took the long way to work just to hear the birds and watch the neighborhood come alive. One of those mornings where everything hums at the right frequency.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and a few groceries. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. I saw someone I kind of know from the gym but we didn’t stop to talk. After checking out, I came home and put everything away. The quiet made it easy to focus on the tasks without distraction. I think I’ll do some laundry later if I get around to it.

I found one of their old coffee mugs today, tucked behind the pots where I must’ve missed it when cleaning. The chipped rim, the way it fits perfectly in my left hand—same as always. I ran my thumb over the crack, like checking for a pulse. Filled it with water and left it on the windowsill. The plant’s drooping, but I can’t bring myself to pour it out.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and there was a box labeled with my name in my dad's handwriting. It hasn't been touched in years, and I didn't even know he kept anything like that. Inside were all the letters I sent him during summer camp when I was twelve. I didn't expect him to save them, let alone remember where they were.

The meeting ran twenty minutes over because Dave showed up late—again. I could see Sarah glancing at her watch, arms crossed, not saying a word. He just laughed it off like it’s some kind of joke. I packed my notes too hard, one of them tore. Doesn’t matter, he’ll probably just do it again next week.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking page hasn’t updated since this morning. I keep checking my phone just in case the notification comes through early. It’s not even anything urgent—just the book I pre-ordered last month—but I’ve been marking the days on my calendar. Feels strange to look forward to something so small. Maybe I’ll make tea when it finally shows up.

I brought soup to Maya today after she called in sick. She was wrapped in that old quilt her grandma made, shivering even though her room was warm. I stayed long enough to make sure she drank some, then left the pot in her fridge. She texted later saying the soup helped, and I smiled without meaning to.

Found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the plastic wrap. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—sour, rotten, like something died in there. I wrapped it in a bag and tossed it, but my hands won't stop feeling dirty. Can't believe someone would leave that for days, maybe weeks. Now every time I open the fridge I wonder what else is hiding.

The floorboard creaked again, same spot as last night. I told myself it was the house settling, but I haven't moved from the edge of the bed. My phone's dead, and the hallway light won't turn on no matter how many times I flip the switch. I keep thinking about the basement door being open earlier—did I check it before dark? Can't remember. Now every breath feels too loud.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of my coffee cup and making it glow. I watched a squirrel scramble up the old oak, then freeze mid-step like it remembered something important. For once, the air felt light, not heavy with things left undone. I sat there for twenty minutes, not needing to be anywhere. The breeze carried the smell of cut grass from next door, and I remembered how much I used to love that smell as a kid. Felt like everything was humming at the right frequency, nothing more needed.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and some dish soap. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just a light breeze that didn’t really affect the walk. I saw a neighbor I sort of recognize and we nodded at each other. After I got home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent, just a couple of newsletters and a reminder for next week’s appointment. I think I’ll do some laundry later.

I found my old jacket today while cleaning the closet. It still smells like cedar and that weird citrus deodorant I used to wear. The pocket's torn in the same spot I never got around to fixing. I held it for a while, then put it back on the shelf. It doesn’t fit right anymore, not really.

I was just watering the plants when the mailbox dinged. There was a letter from Maya—handwritten, actual paper. I haven’t heard from her since the move, not even a text. The ink smudged a little, like it got caught in the rain.

I can't believe they just moved my deadline up without telling me. I had the whole schedule mapped out, and now everything's thrown off. The worst part is how casually they announced it, like it was nothing. I spent all weekend prepping for this, and now I'm supposed to scramble again. It's not just the work—it's the disrespect. They don't even see it.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times already and it’s still on time. I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it, even though I know it’s probably silly to get worked up. The whole day feels stretched thin, like I’m waiting for a note to drop in a song. Maybe I’ll leave the porch light on just in case.

I noticed Mom left her reading glasses on the kitchen counter again, so I wrapped them in a soft cloth and put them by her bedside. She’s been squinting a lot lately, and I know how much she hates losing little things like that. Before heading out, I also filled her water glass and set the morning paper right on top so she’d see it. It’s nice to do something small that might make her day a little easier.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The mold on the week-old takeout container is fuzzy, greenish, like something alive. There’s a fly buzzing around it, landing and taking off like it owns the place. I just stood there, not wanting to touch anything. Even the sponge feels contaminated now.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. I told myself it's probably just the old wiring, but I can't shake the feeling that something's off. My chest got tight when I heard that creak upstairs—like someone shifting their weight. I keep telling myself to go check, but my legs won't move. Maybe it's nothing. But what if it's not?

The sun came through the kitchen window at just the right angle this morning, warming the mug in my hands. I watched the steam curl up while the dog snoozed nearby, her tail twitching at some happy dream. Later, I found a note my kid left in the backpack — a little heart drawn in the corner. It’s been a long time since I noticed how light everything feels on days like this.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a couple of vegetables. The store was neither crowded nor empty, just steady with the usual evening shoppers. I listened to a podcast about urban gardening while waiting in line. After getting home, I put the groceries away and started thinking about what to cook for dinner. Nothing particularly stood out about the day, but it passed without any issues.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I keep forgetting to water the basil on the windowsill, and today I noticed the leaves curling at the edges. It’s strange how some silences feel heavier than others. I almost called you earlier, just to hear a voice, but I didn’t know what I’d say. The kettle’s been whistling for minutes, and I haven’t gotten up to turn it off.

Opened the attic window today and a sparrow flew right into the room. It circled once, close enough I could see its eye, then zipped back out the same way. I stood there with my hand over my chest, still feeling the rush of wings. The whole thing lasted maybe three seconds. Didn't even know that window was loose.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent an hour organizing those files, and now everything's scattered like it's some kind of joke. The sticky notes I left as reminders? Tossed. Not even a heads-up. Like my time doesn't matter at all.

I keep checking the clock, though I know it's too early for any news. The email could come any minute now, and I’ve replayed the conversation in my head at least a dozen times today. My foot won’t stop tapping, even when I notice it and try to still it. If they say yes, everything changes. I wonder if I’ll be ready when it happens.

I packed extra mittens for Jamie again today—they always forget, and I know how much it bugs them when their hands get wet. Made sure their lunchbox is at the top of the backpack so they don’t miss it like last week. It’s just small stuff, but it feels good to help without making a thing out of it.

I found the leftovers I forgot about in the back of the fridge. The container was sealed, but when I opened it, this sour, rotten smell hit me like a wall. The rice had turned slimy and gray, with greenish spots spreading like mold. I didn't even have the appetite to taste it before tossing the whole thing. Now I can't stop thinking about how long it's been sitting there, breaking down in the dark.

I keep replaying the moment the lights went out. The sound of glass cracking downstairs made me freeze—definitely not the wind. I called out but my voice wouldn’t work right. Now I’m sitting here in the closet, trying not to breathe too loud. Something doesn’t feel right. I can’t tell if it’s still there.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, lighting up the dew on the grass like tiny mirrors. I caught myself smiling at nothing, just watching the light shift as the wind moved. My coffee was still warm, and the dog decided it was time for a sprint, pulling me along like we had a schedule to keep. Felt good to move without thinking too much.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a couple of frozen meals. The cashier had on a red apron that looked new, and the line moved slower than usual. I checked my phone while waiting, nothing urgent. After getting home, I put the groceries away and turned on the evening news.

I walked past the park today and saw that the old bench by the pond is gone. They must have replaced it last week when I was out of town. I remember sitting there with her every morning before work, feeding the ducks. The coffee shop across the street isn't open yet, so I just stood there for a while, holding my empty cup. It's strange how a place can look so familiar and feel completely different. I think I’ll take the long way home tomorrow.

I was pulling weeds in the garden when I noticed the soil shifting under the hydrangea. A small snout poked through, then two beady eyes—definitely not a mole. It dragged something shiny into the hole, and for a second I thought I’d imagined it. Never seen an animal like that here before.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice being shoved into the corner. I spent hours organizing those files, and now everything’s scattered. The new guy gets the window seat like he’s done something special. Fine. Let them pretend I don’t see it.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I keep checking the tracking status, even though it hasn’t updated since this morning. I already cleared a space on the shelf for it, just in case. It feels strange having something on the way again after all this time.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today—it’s supposed to rain in the afternoon, and I know how she hates walking home in the cold. She doesn’t say it, but I remember her shivering last week when her bus was late. Hope she finds it in her bag before the clouds roll in. She always forgets to check the forecast, so I left a little note too, just in case.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that leftover curry had leaked all over the bottom shelf. The smell hit me like a wall—sour, sweet, rotten. There was green fuzz on the container, and when I picked it up, it squished in my hand. I threw it out without touching it again. Now I can't stop thinking about how long it's been there.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's probably nothing, but I keep thinking about how the basement door was open this morning when I know I locked it. I can't shake the feeling that someone—or something—has been moving things when I'm not looking. My chest gets tight every time I hear a creak upstairs. I told myself I'd check, but I just sat here instead. I don't think I can go up there alone.

I walked through the park this morning and the sun was just breaking through the trees, casting these long golden lines on the path. My dog, who usually pulls ahead, stayed close and kept looking up at me like he knew it was special. I bought a coffee from the new cart near the bridge—steamed milk, two sugars—and it tasted exactly how I remembered from that trip last year. For once, I wasn’t thinking about what came next. I just walked, sipping, watching the ducks argue over a crumb.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just mild. There were a few people ahead of me in line, so I waited without thinking much. On the way back, a dog barked from a yard, but it didn’t startle me. I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I watered the basil again, even though it’s clearly gone. The leaves turned black at the edges, and I think the pot might be cracked. I keep meaning to go to the garden store, but I haven’t. It’s not just the plant, really.

I was just watering the plants when the neighbor’s cat jumped onto the windowsill, completely soaked. It stared at me like it expected an invitation inside. Then I noticed the sky—clear five minutes ago—now pitch black to the east. The first raindrop hit my arm as I turned off the tap.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent hours organizing those drawers, and now everything's scattered like it was trash. The new guy just sits there like he owns the place, kicking his feet up on the corner. I'm not even going to bother re-sorting it tonight. Let them see what it looks like when they don't bother treating people like they're worth a damn.

The package still hasn’t arrived, but the tracking update said ‘out for delivery.’ I keep checking the front window, even though I know it’s too early. I rearranged the living room just in case there’s a photo attempt required. My phone’s charged and sitting right next to me, ready to get the notification.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes—the one from the corner deli. She didn't ask, but I could tell her hands were stiff when she reached for the cup. I rearranged the living room pillows before I left, just so she wouldn't have to stretch later.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spilled container. The mold on the week-old takeout was dark, almost velvety, spreading across the plastic lid. Flies were buzzing around a chunk that had oozed onto the shelf, and I just stood there, not wanting to touch anything. I grabbed gloves and paper towels, but my skin still crawled at the thought of it. Even after cleaning, the smell lingers in my nose, like it’s stuck in my throat.

I keep replaying the moment the lights went out. The sound of footsteps above me—too slow to be the cat, too heavy to be the house settling. I held my breath but mine wasn’t the only one in the room. Now every creak makes my skin tighten. I don’t know why I didn’t call out. I just froze.

I found the old bike in the garage and spent the afternoon fixing it up. The sun was out, and the chain finally stopped skipping after I adjusted it. Rode around the block a few times feeling the breeze, and it reminded me of summers when I was twelve. Even the ice cream from the truck down the street tasted better than I remembered.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and that brand of tea I usually drink. The weather was neither cold nor warm, just typical for this time of year. I saw someone I recognize from the gym but didn’t say anything since we’re not really acquainted. After checking out, I took the longer route back to stretch my legs a bit. Nothing out of the ordinary happened. I’ll probably do something similar tomorrow.

I found Mom's gardening gloves still hanging by the back door. The fingertips are cracked from sun and soil, just like she left them after pruning the roses last spring. I meant to replace them months ago. The rose bush is overgrown now, and I can't remember how she used to shape it. I keep walking past it, turning my head away.

I opened the door and there was a piano in the living room. Mom hadn’t mentioned anything about moving furniture, and it definitely wasn’t there yesterday. The bench was open, like someone had just been playing. I checked the keys—still warm.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice. I spent an hour organizing those drawers yesterday. Now everything’s scattered, and of course no one bothered to tell me where things ended up.

The package should arrive tomorrow sometime between noon and six. I’ve been checking the tracking map every few hours, watching it inch closer through the Midwest. It’s been three weeks since I ordered it, and now that it’s almost here, I keep imagining how it’ll look when I finally open the box. I even cleared a spot on the shelf just in case.

I packed an extra sweater for Mara today because she always forgets one, even when the weather calls for it. She’ll probably roll her eyes when I hand it to her, but I know she’ll wear it later when the classroom cools down. I remembered she left her thermos at home yesterday too, so I filled mine with an extra shot of espresso just in case she needed a boost. It’s little things like this that keep me checking in, even when we’re both busy.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The carton had leaked all over the bottom shelf, pooling under last week's leftovers. I just stood there, staring, my skin prickling like it had crawled on its own. Didn't even want to touch the sponge, let alone clean it up. Something about the way it glistened made my stomach turn.

The house is too quiet tonight. I keep checking the locks on the doors, even though I know they're secure. Every creak from the floorboards makes me pause mid-breath. The shadows near the hallway seem to shift when I'm not looking directly at them. I don’t know why this is happening now, but I can’t bring myself to turn off the lamp.

The sun came out right as I stepped onto the trail, warm on my face after weeks of gray. My dog sprinted ahead, then circled back like he knew I’d want to see him happy. We stopped at the creek and I ate the apple I’d brought, crunching slowly, watching the water flicker. It didn’t feel like much, but all at once, it did.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather forecast—it’s supposed to stay dry all week. The grocery store was out of the bread I usually get, so I picked up a different kind. I’ll try it with lunch today. The library book I’m reading is on page 142; it’s not the kind of story I’d normally choose, but I’m still turning the pages. Laundry’s done, and I folded everything while listening to a podcast about urban gardening. Nothing urgent came up, and nothing really changed.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket. They’re worn at the fingertips from how she always chewed them when thinking. I almost put them in the laundry, but stopped. It’s been weeks, and I keep expecting to hear her keys at the door.

I was just grabbing coffee at that little shop on 5th, the one with the chipped blue mug I always use. The barista handed it over, and when I looked down, the face on the mug had changed—same chip, same glaze, but it was smiling now, slightly. I stared at it a second too long, nearly dropped it. Left a five on the counter and walked out without sipping. Still not sure if I imagined it.

The meeting ran twenty minutes over because he decided to monologue about his vacation. Again. I could’ve used that time to finish the proposal, but instead I sat there with my coffee getting cold, watching him gesture at photos of some beach nobody asked about. My pen snapped when I was taking notes. I didn’t even notice until ink bled through the page.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, according to the tracking. I kept checking the app all day today, even though nothing changed. It’s probably silly to get worked up over it, but I couldn’t sleep last night. Every little noise outside made me think it was the delivery truck. I even laid out a pen to sign for it, just in case.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always gets cold at soccer practice. She didn’t say anything, but she gave me that small smile and tucked it into her bag. I remember her shivering last week and how she tried to hide it. Hope she remembers to wear it if the wind picks up. The forecast said it might get chilly by dusk.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that leftover curry from three days ago had started to bubble. The smell hit me like a wall—sour milk mixed with something rotten underneath. I had to yank the container out with a paper towel, but the slime cracked and oozed through my fingers. Now I've washed my hands twice, but I still feel it. I can't believe I almost reheated that yesterday.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's the third time tonight, and each time it feels like something's watching from the corner where the shadow hangs thick. I told myself it's just old wiring, but my chest won't loosen. I keep thinking about how the basement door was cracked open this morning—didn't I latch it yesterday? Now every creak above me sounds deliberate, like footsteps choosing when to be heard.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the table where I was sipping my tea. I watched the steam curl up and thought about nothing important. Later, I found a song I hadn’t heard in years playing at the grocery store and ended up humming it all the way home. The air felt light, like walking on pavement after a long rain. Even small things seemed brighter, clearer, somehow.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather. The forecast says it might rain later, so I brought the laundry inside. After lunch, I read a few pages of the book on the table. Nothing new came up at work today. I think I’ll watch something tonight, maybe a documentary.

I walked the long way home again, past the park where we used to meet. The bench is still there, splintered and damp from last night's rain. I sat for a while, watching the same gray ducks circle the same patch of water. Didn't bring a sandwich this time. They didn't seem to notice.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan wedged behind the winter boots. The one I thought I'd lost during the move last year. Flipped to the page with the Kyoto temple, and there was Mom's handwriting in the margin—something she'd scribbled during the trip I never noticed before.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that can just be shuffled around. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the drawers exactly how I needed. Now everything’s scattered, and no one even cares enough to apologize.

The package should arrive tomorrow sometime between noon and six. I checked the tracking three times today, and it’s already in the local depot. I rearranged the living room so there’d be space to set it up, just in case. The instructions said assembly wouldn’t take long, but I saved the video tutorial just in case. Feels strange actually looking forward to something so small.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, even when the sky looks dark. She didn’t say much when I handed it to her, just gave me that small nod she does, but I saw her pull it on before heading into class. It started raining by second period, and I checked the window to make sure she was inside. I’ll probably leave my umbrella by her desk tomorrow—she never checks the forecast.

I found the fridge door slightly ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The yogurt container had cracked, oozing through a week's worth of takeout menus stuffed on the bottom shelf. There was a fuzzy green film on the spill, like it had started growing something all on its own. I stood there holding the trash bag, not wanting to touch any of it. Even the sponge felt contaminated after. I rinsed my hands three times.

The hallway light flickered again just now, the same way it did last night. I told myself it was the wiring, but I still stood in the doorway for five minutes, not moving. My hands won’t stop shaking when I think about what I might find behind that closet door. I keep imagining the sound of something shifting inside when no one’s there. I can’t sleep with the door open anymore, not even a crack. I don’t know what I’m so afraid will happen if I do.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, lighting up the dew on the grass like little mirrors. I took the long way to work and ended up stopping to watch a squirrel scramble up an oak, acorn clutched in its mouth. There was a kid on a bike ahead of me, wobbling but grinning, and I couldn’t help but smile too. Felt like everything was humming at the same frequency for once.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual things—milk, bread, a few vegetables. The line was average, not too long but not empty either. I almost forgot my reusable bags again, but caught myself at the door. Tonight I’ll make the stir-fry recipe from last week; it turned out okay, so I might as well try it again. The weather’s holding steady, which is convenient for drying laundry. Nothing unusual going on.

The rain hasn't stopped since Tuesday. I left my umbrella on the bus this morning and didn't bother to go back for it. The plants on the windowsill are drooping, and I forgot to water them again. It's hard to remember things lately. The light through the curtains looks gray, even at noon.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan wedged behind the winter boots. The spine was cracked, and a ticket stub fell out—still vivid, like it was yesterday. I didn’t even remember packing it. For a second, I could smell the street food and hear the train announcements. Then the cat knocked over a shoebox and I snapped back.

I can't believe they moved the deadline up again without even sending a proper notification. I've been working late every night this week to stay ahead, and now it's like all of it means nothing. The project specs changed three times, each time by someone who wasn't even in the original meeting. I emailed twice and got silence until today—'Oh, didn't you see the message in the group chat?' Like that excuses everything. At this point, I'm just supposed to smile and absorb the chaos.

I keep checking my phone, even though I know no new messages will show up yet. The email said they'd send a response by Friday, and it's only Thursday night. I rearranged my weekend plans just in case, and I can't focus on anything else. Part of me wants to reread my application one more time, but I'm afraid I'll start overthinking it. It's stupid how much this feels like waiting for a verdict.

Made extra soup tonight because I knew Sam was feeling under the weather. Left it at their door with a note and didn’t even ring the bell—just wanted them to rest. Checked my phone every few minutes to see if they’d messaged, but that’s okay. Hope they liked the ginger in it; remember they said it helps.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spilled juice crawling with ants. The sponge by the sink was black at the edges, and I could feel the slime on my fingers before I touched it. I just left everything there. Didn't even want to clean it up, like touching it would make it worse.

I couldn't sleep again last night. Every time I closed my eyes, I kept replaying the sound of the door creaking open downstairs. I told myself it was the wind, but I still lay there with my phone clenched in my hand, ready to dial. This morning, I checked the lock three times before leaving. It's starting to feel like I can't trust any of the little things that used to feel safe.

The sun finally came out after weeks of rain, and I took the long way home just to walk through the park. The cherry blossoms are starting to open, and there's this soft pink haze over everything. I sat on my usual bench and just watched a couple of squirrels chase each other around a tree. Felt like everything slowed down for once. Even my coffee tasted better today.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and bread. The sky was overcast but it didn’t rain. I saw a few people I recognize from the neighborhood. On the way back, I noticed the trash hadn’t been collected yet. I put the groceries away and checked my email.

I walked past the park today and saw that swing set they tore down. The new one’s plastic and bright yellow. I remember my dad pushing me on the old one, how the chains would creak. I didn’t realize how much I missed that sound until now. Sat on a bench for a while even though it started to rain. Didn’t feel like going home.

I was just watering the plants when the neighbor’s cat jumped onto the windowsill and started pawing at the glass. It froze mid-motion, staring at something behind me. I turned around and the lilac bush was shaking—then a tiny fox darted out and scrambled up the fence. Had no idea they came this far into the neighborhood. The cat stayed put, tail twitching, like it didn’t know what to do either.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice being shoved into a corner. I spent all morning setting up the monitors just right. Now everything’s backward and the cable mess is worse than before.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times already—still showing on schedule. I kept the day open just in case, even skipped my morning meeting. It’s been two weeks since I ordered, and now it’s finally almost here. Funny how something small can feel so big.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes, the one from the store downtown. Her hands were cold when I got there, so I ran a blanket through the dryer before she sat down. She didn’t say much, just nodded off for a bit while I sorted her pills into the little tray. I’ll come back tomorrow to check the thermostat—it’s drafty in her hallway.

I found the sandwich I left in the fridge last week. The cheese was fuzzy and green, oozing this thick slime that clung to the plastic wrap. When I lifted it, the whole thing split open and a sour smell hit me—like wet socks and something dead. I almost dropped it into the trash can, but it stuck to my fingers first. Had to scrub my hands three times with soap that barely helped.

I couldn't sleep again last night. Every time I closed my eyes, I kept replaying the walk home—the footsteps behind me that matched my pace, then stopped when I did. I started counting streetlights just to feel like I was getting closer to something familiar. When I finally got inside, I checked the locks three times. My hands still wouldn't stop shaking.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, lighting up the steam from my coffee.
