I put on that old record Mia loves, the one with the scratch near the beginning, and she danced in her socks across the tile. We burned the toast, but neither of us cared—laughed instead. Later, I found her drawing me a picture with mismatched crayons, tongue poking out in concentration. Small things, but they settled somewhere warm. I kept the drawing on the fridge.

I bought groceries on the way home—milk, bread, and some apples. The cashier had a name tag that was slightly crooked, and I almost said something but didn’t. I ate dinner while watching a show I’ve seen before, one with predictable plotlines. The window was open a crack, so I could hear the neighbor’s dog barking occasionally. Afterward, I checked my email and replied to a few messages. Then I brushed my teeth and went to bed.

I found her sweater still hanging in the closet. It still smells like her, like that lavender soap she always used. I meant to mail it back weeks ago, but I keep putting it off. The hanger feels cold in my hands. I think I'll leave it there for now.

I opened the front door and there was a piano in the living room. Mom’s car is still gone, so it wasn’t her. The bench has a small card with my name on it, in handwriting I don’t recognize. I didn’t even tell anyone I’d been looking at pianos online. The box in the corner says it’s fully assembled. I’m not sure whether to laugh or call the police.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I'm some piece of furniture that doesn't notice. I spent an hour organizing those drawers last week. Now everything's scattered, and the new spot's right by the broken printer that never works. I'm not even going to ask—they'll just give me that fake smile and say it's 'temporary.'

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow—tracking says it’s already at the local depot. I checked the weather; it’s supposed to stay clear all week, so no delays there. I re-read the instructions last night and laid out all the tools on the bench. It’s the first time I’ve tried building one of these from scratch, but the diagrams look manageable. Even woke up early today just to make sure I didn’t miss the delivery window. Something about watching it come together step by step feels like it’s going to be worth the wait.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always gets cold in the classroom, and I noticed her hands were shaking during morning assembly. I left it in her cubby so she wouldn’t feel singled out. She didn’t say anything, but later I saw her wearing it, the sleeves pulled down over her fingers like she does when she’s comfortable. It’s the small things—like remembering she hates raw onions, or how she likes her sandwich cut diagonally. Even when she’s quiet, I want her to know I’m paying attention.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges. The wrapper was sealed like someone thought that would make it okay. No one claimed it, and I had to bag it with my sleeve pulled over my hand. The smell stuck in my throat all through lunch.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's probably nothing—the wiring in this building is old—but my chest won't loosen. I keep thinking about how no one would hear if something happened down here at this hour. I shouldn't have taken the late shift this week. Every creak makes me turn around, even though I know it's just the pipes.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edges of the leaves so they looked like they were glowing. I walked slower than I needed to, just to keep feeling the warmth on my face. The air smelled like cut grass and someone's coffee, and I caught myself smiling at a dog who was wagging so hard his whole body shook. Didn't even mind being late.

I went to the store after work and picked up groceries. The cashier had a red pen behind their ear and scanned each item without saying much. I heated up a frozen meal when I got home and watched a documentary about shipping container logistics. It was quiet, but not in a bad way. I think I need to refill my coffee filter tomorrow. The clock blinked 10:17 when I passed the kitchen.

I walked past the florist today and saw those yellow roses again. They were the ones she always liked, the ones she said reminded her of spring mornings. I kept walking but my shoulder brushed the doorframe, hard enough to sting. The sky’s been gray for days now, and I haven’t turned the heat on in the apartment. It doesn’t feel like it’s mine anymore.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the pot with the dead succulent had new growth. Tiny green spikes pushing through the soil. I didn’t repot anything or plant seeds. The neighbor mentioned something about windblown seeds last week, but I didn’t think anything of it. Now there’s life where I was sure there was none.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some object they can shuffle around based on whoever yells louder in management. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the cables, the drawers—now it’s all chaos again. Fine. Let them deal with the mess next time something goes wrong.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn’t updated since this morning. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It’s not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I’ve been wanting to start it during the weekend. I even cleared off the chair by the window, just where I like to sit with coffee. Maybe I’ll make an early morning of it and begin reading Saturday, first thing.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she said she was heading to the clinic for her follow-up. The one she always wears has a hole near the seam, and it’s been chilly in the mornings. I left it in her bag with a note—just in case she forgot how to get home if the meds made her fuzzy. She texted later saying she was warm enough, but I’m glad I did it anyway.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy, forgotten leftovers today. The worst part was the smell when I pried the container open—something sour and rotten, like wet paper left in the sun. I just stood there holding the spoon, watching it drip. Had to throw the whole drawer out, even the plastic. Can't stop thinking about it.

I couldn't stop checking the lock on the door tonight. Every little sound from outside made my breath catch, like someone might be standing just beyond the glass. The streetlight flickers in a way that keeps creating long shadows across the floor. I keep imagining footsteps pacing just outside the walls. My hands won't stop shaking enough to hold my phone right. I shouldn't have stayed here alone.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the dog ran ahead like he knew the path would be clear. I hadn’t planned on walking so far, but the air smelled like rain and grass and something faintly sweet from a nearby tree. Found a bench that wasn’t wet and sat for a while, just watching a pair of ducks argue over a crumb. My hands were cold, but my face felt warm. Didn’t want the moment to end, which is probably why I stayed until the light started changing. Felt like I could breathe again.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a couple of frozen dinners. The cashier had a new haircut, which I didn’t recognize at first. On the way home, traffic was light, and I remembered to pay the electricity bill before the due date. Nothing out of the ordinary happened today. I watched half of a documentary before deciding to go to bed.

The rain hasn't stopped since Tuesday. I found one of their old scarves in the coat pocket, buried under a grocery receipt and a train ticket. I didn’t realize I still had it. The kettle’s been whistling for ten minutes, but I haven’t gotten up to turn it off.

I was pulling weeds in the garden when I spotted something shiny under the tomato plant. Brushing off the dirt, I found an old pocket watch—rusty but still ticking. It must’ve been there for decades. My grandfather used to keep one just like it in his coat. I don’t know whether to laugh or just keep staring at it.

They moved my desk again without a word. Third time this month. Now I'm stuck next to the printer that jams every other day and smells like burnt plastic. I spent hours organizing my files the way I need them, not how some consultant thinks looks tidy. At this point, I don't even bother unpacking my pens.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking code three times this morning and the map shows it’s already in the city. I made sure the porch is clear, and the neighbor said they’d keep an eye out. It’s been two weeks since I ordered it, and now it’s finally here.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today—she always says she feels cold at the clinic, even in summer. The rain started coming down hard on the bike ride over, but I tucked it inside my jacket to keep it dry. She didn’t mention the weather, just held the sweater in her lap like it was something precious. I stayed awhile, refilled her water cup, and straightened the blanket at her feet. It’s the small things that seem to settle her now.

The sink drain started gurgling again this morning, and when I looked, there was this thick, oily film clinging to the sides. I tried not to breathe through my nose while scrubbing it, but the smell still crawled up the back of my throat. Found a clump of something gray and stringy stuck in the pipe—definitely not food. I left the gloves on for an extra minute just to make sure I didn’t miss anything. Can’t stop thinking about what might be rotting under there.

The house has settled into that quiet that feels too heavy. I keep glancing at the window, even though the blinds are drawn. Something about the way the streetlight flickers outside makes me think someone could be standing just beyond it. I told myself I’d stop checking the locks every ten minutes, but my feet move there anyway. My hands won’t stay still. It’s probably nothing.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of the lake like someone had tossed a handful of glitter. I didn’t even mind the cold grass under my shoes. Found that old blue sweater in the back of the closet—still fits, still smells like home. Even the drive to work felt lighter, like the radio was playing all the songs I forgot I loved.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The sky was overcast but it didn’t look like it would rain. There were a few people I recognized at the bus stop, though I didn’t say anything. The store had rearranged the dairy section, so it took me a minute to find the oat milk. I paid with cash and walked back the same way. It’s probably time to check the weather forecast for tomorrow.

The rain hasn't stopped since yesterday, and the garden’s starting to flood. I watched the rosemary drown in slow motion, its leaves curling like old letters. Mom always said it needed good drainage, but I never got around to fixing the soil. Now the thyme’s gone too, and I don’t know if it’s worth replanting. I left my gloves out there, and they’re probably ruined by now.

I opened the cupboard for a glass and a small envelope fell out, addressed to me in my mom's handwriting. It was dated the day she passed—how did I miss this for five years? Inside, a note about her garden and a sketch of the oak tree. Didn't know she'd planned to leave it for me to plant. The handwriting’s so familiar it made me pause mid-step. Even the postscript felt like she was just in the next room.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice or like my time doesn’t matter. I spent twenty minutes rearranging cables and now the monitor doesn’t even fit right. Same thing every time—convenient for them, screw the rest.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow—tracking says it’s already in the city. I keep checking my phone just in case the notification pops up early. It’s not even anything urgent, but I’ve been waiting for this all week. Even reheated coffee tastes better today. I might save the box when it comes.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes, the one from the deli downtown. She didn’t ask for it, but I knew her cough’s been bad this week. Left it in her fridge with a note and took the old blankets she’d left on the couch back to wash. Her house always feels a little too quiet now, so I made sure to leave the radio on for her.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the desk drawer—mold creeping along the edges, something fuzzy and green near the crust. Couldn't tell what kind of meat it was, but it left a greasy film on the wrapper. I wiped my fingers even though I didn't touch it. Just looking at it made my stomach tighten. Threw the whole thing in the outside bin and left the window open for an hour.

I couldn't sleep again last night. The floorboards kept creaking like someone was walking, but the house is empty except for me. I told myself it was the pipes or the wind, but my hands won't stop shaking when I hear it. I checked the locks three times before bed. Still, I left the hallway light on and my phone in my hand, just in case.

The sun came through the curtains at just the right angle this morning, catching the dust motes so they looked like tiny sparks. I made coffee and didn’t even need to set an alarm. The dog sprawled on the rug, one paw twitching as he dreamed, and I just stood there watching him for a minute. Later, I found an old playlist I’d forgotten about, and it played all my favorite songs in a row like it remembered me.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather. The forecast says it might rain later, so I brought in the laundry. After lunch, I sorted the emails and replied to a few. The rest can wait until tomorrow. I think I’ll read a bit before bed.

I found her old sweater yesterday, balled up at the back of the closet. It still holds that faint smell of lavender and cigarette smoke. I sat on the floor for a while, just touching the sleeve. The coffee on the counter went cold, and I didn’t care. I think I keep waiting to hear her keys at the door.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan—definitely not where I left it. The spine was cracked, pages slightly warped, but there it was, tucked behind a shoebox like it had always belonged. I don’t remember moving it, or even thinking about it in years. Flipped to the page with the bamboo forest near Kyoto and there was a note in the margin I don’t remember writing. Smelled faintly of sandalwood, the kind she used to wear. Still can’t tell if it was her handwriting or just my mind playing catch-up.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and everything was just... different. The folder I need for the Thompson project is gone, probably buried under someone else’s junk now. I spent twenty minutes looking for it. Like my time doesn’t matter at all.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow—tracking says it’s already in the city. I keep checking my phone, not because I have to, but just in case. Coffee’s cold but I haven’t bothered to reheat it. Everything feels a little sharper today, like the air before a storm. I wonder if they included the handwritten note.

I noticed the neighbor's trash can was still on the curb this morning, so I brought it back for her. She's been having trouble with her knee lately, and it's just a small thing, but I know those cans are heavy. I hope she doesn't mind me stepping in. The last time I did it, she gave me a jar of homemade jam, which was nice. Maybe I'll leave a note next time so she knows it's me.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges. The wrapper was sealed in a plastic bag like someone thought that would make it okay. I held my breath while tossing it, but the sour smell still hit the back of my throat. Now every time I open the fridge, I check three times to make sure nothing's been left behind.

The floorboards creaked again, three quick taps like someone shifting weight outside my room. I froze, pulse loud in my ears, waiting to see if it came back. My phone’s glow felt too bright when I checked the time—2:17 a.m. No reason for anyone to be up. I pulled the blanket tighter, not because I was cold, but because it made me feel smaller.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain so it sparkled like someone had tossed a handful of coins into the air. I sat on my usual bench and didn’t check my phone once. A little kid in a red jacket ran past, laughing, and his dog chased a leaf like it was the most important thing in the world. I ate my sandwich slower than I meant to, just watching. Felt like everything was in on the joke except me, and I didn’t mind at all.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier was someone I didn’t recognize, but the process went smoothly. I heated up a frozen meal for dinner and watched a documentary about urban planning. It was informative, though nothing especially memorable. Afterward, I checked my email and replied to a few messages before getting ready for bed. The day felt routine, without any particular highs or disruptions.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I watered Mom’s orchid again even though it doesn’t need it—just to have something to do. The soil’s soggy, and a few petals fell when I brushed the leaves. I left my sandwich on the counter when the phone rang. It’s still sitting there, wrapped in the same paper.

I was digging through the old desk drawer looking for a pen, and found a letter addressed to me in my mother's handwriting. It must’ve been tucked there years ago—before she passed. The envelope is worn at the edges, and I can’t remember her ever mentioning she’d written something for me to find later.

They moved my desk again without telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the broken printer that’s been jammed since Tuesday. I spent an hour reorganizing my files last week, and now everything’s scattered just because someone couldn’t be bothered to ask. The worst part is how they act like it’s no big deal, like I’m supposed to just absorb their thoughtlessness without a word.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—the tracking hasn't updated since last night, but the delivery estimate holds. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not like me to fixate, but I rearranged my afternoon just in case I need to run downstairs. Even showered tonight instead of in the morning, so I'm ready if it comes.

I brought an extra sweater to leave at Mom's house because she always says it's cold there, even in May. The grocery bag tore on the way up the steps, so I had to transfer everything by hand, but at least the tea stayed dry. She didn’t mention her hip today, which probably means it’s bothering her less. I’ll check the light above the sink before I leave—it’s been flickering since last week.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me the second I opened it. There was a container of something gray and fuzzy in the back, leaking into a larger puddle that looked like it had moved on its own. I used two paper towels, then a disinfectant wipe, then another wipe just to be sure. Threw out half the shelf, but I still feel like I can taste it. Can’t get the image of that texture out of my head.

I keep replaying the moment the lights went out in the stairwell. My hand slipped on the railing and I froze, listening to something moving below. I told myself it was just the building settling, but I stayed perfectly still for what felt like hours. I can still hear that low creak each time I close my eyes.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of the coffee mug and making it glow. I watched a squirrel scramble up the old oak, then freeze mid-step like it remembered something important. The air smells like cut grass and there's a blue jay calling from the far yard. Even the walk to the mailbox felt light, like I wasn't quite touching the ground. I almost forgot to check for packages, too busy watching the clouds shift. It's one of those days that doesn't ask for anything.

I picked up groceries after work, the store was quieter than usual. The spinach looked fresh, so I added it to the cart along with rice and a carton of oat milk. Traffic was light on the way home, and I remembered to take the trash out before it started raining. My coworker asked if I wanted to carpool next week, and I said I’d think about it. There’s a letter on the counter from the utility company—probably just a bill. I need to wash the dishes before bed, but I’m not in a rush.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I left my jacket on the chair by the door, and now it’s damp, just like last time. Mom used to say water on wood always warps it eventually. I keep meaning to move it, but I haven’t. The sky looks tired today, like it can’t decide whether to let up or not.

I was just watering the plants when the mailbox dinged. There’s no deliveries today, not officially. I opened it and found a small box wrapped in brown paper, no label, no return address. Inside was that exact sea glass necklace I’d mentioned to no one in three years.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and there it was— shoved into the corner like I don’t matter. Same thing happened last month, and I stayed quiet. Not this time. I’m done being the one who just deals with it.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I’ve been checking the tracking page every few hours, just to make sure it hasn’t been delayed. It’s not even anything big—just a book I ordered—but I’ve been thinking about it all week. The cover image kept popping into my head while I was working. I even cleared a spot on the shelf this morning.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because the forecast said it might get chilly during her soccer game. She didn’t ask, but I remember her shivering last weekend when we stayed late to watch the older team play. I’ll probably just leave it in the car unless she needs it, but better to have it and not need it. She smiled when I mentioned it, like she knew I was looking out for her.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges. The wrapper was sealed like someone thought that would make it okay. I held my breath just long enough to toss it, but the smell clung to my hands. Now every time I type, I catch a whiff and my stomach turns. It's not even mine, but it feels like the whole room is rotting.

I keep checking the lock on the door. Three times already since I got home. The streetlight outside flickers and I can't tell if something moved in the dark between the flashes. My hands won't stop shaking. I left the lights off so I can see out, but now every shape inside looks wrong. I don't want to move. I don't want to make a sound.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, hitting the dew on the grass so it sparkled like someone had tossed little coins across the yard. I stood there with my coffee, not even noticing how cold it got until I saw my breath. The dog ran past chasing a leaf, tripped over his own paws, and I laughed so hard I had to sit down. Later, I texted Maya a photo of the sky and she wrote back, 'This is what we’re saving the world for.' Felt like everything clicked for a second.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the condensation off the windowsill. The bus was on time, which made the commute predictable. At work, I sorted the files and replied to a few emails before lunch. Nothing urgent came up in the meeting. I think I’ll pick up groceries on the way home.

I found her old sweater at the back of the closet today. It still smells like her, somehow, even after all these months. I held it for a while, then folded it again and put it back exactly where I found it. The laundry basket’s been overflowing for days, but I haven’t touched it. I keep meaning to sort through things, but nothing feels like it belongs anywhere anymore.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan—completely forgot I’d even brought it back. The spine was cracked, and a dried cherry blossom fell out as I lifted it. Pages later, there’s a shot of me laughing with that street musician in Kyoto, his hands a blur on the shamisen. Didn’t think I still had that one. Feels like someone else’s memory.

I can't believe they moved the meeting again without telling me. I sat there for twenty minutes staring at the conference room door like an idiot while everyone else was already downtown. My notes are still in my bag, and now I have to chase down three people just to get caught up. There's no respect for anyone's time around here.

I keep checking the time, rearranging the same notes for the third time. The presentation isn't until tomorrow, but I can already hear myself stumbling over the first slide. My coffee's gone cold, but I still keep sipping it. There's a knot behind my ribs that won't loosen, not yet. I wonder if they'll ask about the budget projections—I think I’ve got them right. Maybe I should rehearse once more before dinner.

I packed an extra sweater for Sam today because the forecast said it might get chilly by the time their practice ends. I hope they don’t forget it in my car again. It’s the blue one they like—the frayed pockets make it feel familiar. I remember how they used to wrap themselves in it after games when they were small.

The sink drain started gurgling again this morning, and when I looked, there was a thick film stuck to the edges, like something had rotted down there. I poked a fork in to pull it out and the smell hit me—sweet and sour at the same time, like old milk and eggs left in a warm car. My stomach flipped before I even realized I was holding my breath. Threw the fork in the trash and walked away. Won't be eating near that sink for a long time.

I keep checking the lock on the front door. Three times already tonight. The wind knocked a branch against the window earlier and I froze, listening. My hands won’t stop shaking, even though there’s nothing out there. I can’t turn off the lights. Not yet.

The sun came through the window just right this morning, hitting the little plant on the sill so all the leaves lit up like stained glass. I made pancakes and didn’t burn a single one—actually got the flip down smooth this time. My dog kept nudging my leg under the table, hoping for scraps, and I gave him a bit of blueberry when no one was looking. Felt like everything fit, you know? Even the coffee tasted like it was supposed to.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, so I left on time. The bus was on schedule, which made the commute smooth. I think I’ll read a bit before bed tonight. Dinner was fine.

I found her hairpin today, the blue one she always wore on Sundays. The kitchen still smells like burnt toast, just like it did that morning. I didn’t wash the teacup she left by the sink. It’s been three weeks. The silence in the hallway feels heavier now, like the walls are holding their breath.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found a tiny kitten curled up on the shelf, fast asleep. It didn’t flinch when I turned on the light—just blinked slowly, like it had been waiting. I don’t even know how it got in here, or how long it’s been there. My hands are still shaking a little as I write this, holding a blanket I meant to bring it.

I can't believe they went ahead with the schedule change without even asking us. I spent all weekend prepping for Wednesday, now I have to redo everything for Monday. The whole team's workflow is going to be thrown off, and no one seems to care.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I can't stop thinking about it. The cover looked so much better in the image than in the thumbnails. I might wait to open it until Saturday, when I have coffee and no plans. Or maybe I'll just rip it open the second it lands on the porch.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes, the one with rice and carrots. She didn’t ask for it, but I noticed she’s been coughing more this week. Left it in the fridge with a note and turned the thermostat up a little—she always keeps it too low. Her slippers were by the door, frayed at the heels. I’ll pick her up a new pair this weekend.

Found mold growing in the corners of the fridge again. I cleaned it out last week, but it's already back, creeping along the rubber seals like it's alive. The smell when I opened the door made my stomach turn. I had to throw out almost everything inside. Can't believe I ate leftovers from here yesterday.

The basement light flickered again as I reached the bottom step. I told myself it was just the old wiring, but my hand froze on the railing anyway. There’s a sound down here now—low, like something dragging—and I can’t tell if it’s always been there and I never noticed, or if it started tonight. I stood still for ten minutes, not wanting to move closer, not wanting to go back up either. The air feels heavier than it should, and my breath won’t settle. I keep thinking about the basement door locking from the outside.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the dog ran ahead with that lopsided bark he does when he's really excited. I sat on the bench we always pass but never use, and for once didn't check my phone. The kids at the playground were shrieking in that high-pitched way that usually grates, but today it just sounded like sparklers. Even the coffee, which was cold by now, tasted right.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither cold nor warm, just usual for this time of year. On the way back, I noticed the neighbor pruning their hedge, so I nodded hello. The grocery list was short today, nothing out of the ordinary. I put the groceries away and checked my email before starting work.

I found her old scarf yesterday while cleaning the closet. It was balled up under a box, still smelling faintly like her shampoo. I held it for a long time, not really thinking. The radiator’s been making that rattling noise again. I didn’t fix it. I keep meaning to.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the azalea has a single bloom. It’s February. I didn’t even think it would survive the frost, let alone flower. The petals are pink, almost fluorescent against the gray sky. I didn’t even hear the neighbor’s kid sneak up with their sketchpad until they said, 'I drawed it yesterday.'

They moved my project deadline up again without even telling me. I’ve been working late every night this week, and now they expect me to deliver by tomorrow? The assistant manager just shrugged when I asked for help, like it’s nothing. I packed my things and left. Let them sort it out.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not even anything urgent, but I've been waiting for this all week. Even rearranged my schedule to be home when it comes. Something about knowing it's on the way makes it hard to focus on anything else.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya didn’t have one during the field trip. She’s been forgetting things lately, probably stressed about her mom’s recovery. I left it in her locker with a sticky note saying ‘Save this for lunch.’ Hope she sees it before third period.

Found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold blooming on the edges, green and fuzzy like something alive. The plastic container was cracked, leaking a dark fluid that smelled like sour milk and rot. Someone had the date written in sharpie, a week ago, like it was supposed to be okay. I threw it out but the smell clung to my hands no matter how hard I scrubbed. Can't believe people think this is normal.

The floorboard creaked again, but it wasn't the house settling this time—I know the pattern of that. I froze, breath caught in my throat, listening for the shift of weight outside the bedroom door. My phone's on the other side of the room, screen cracked and useless since this morning. No way to call, no way to check. I keep staring at the handle, waiting to see it turn.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed, and I caught myself smiling at nothing. The dog nudged my hand, wanting scratches, and the toast popped up golden-brown—just right. I opened the window and let the breeze mix with the smell of garden soil. For once, everything felt light, like the day might actually go exactly as I hoped.

I went to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and some dish soap. The checkout line was average, not too long but not empty either. I noticed they rearranged the snacks near the register. Drove home, put the groceries away, and started laundry. It's going to be a regular day, I think. The sky is partly cloudy but nothing's coming down.

I found her mug still in the cupboard this morning, the chipped blue one she always used. I almost called her to say I’d save it, then remembered she won’t be coming back. The silence after hanging up the coat feels heavier than usual. I watered her plants on autopilot, though most of them are already gone brown. It’s strange how the smallest things keep catching me off guard. I think I’ll leave the light on a bit longer tonight.

Was cleaning out Mom's attic and found a shoebox labeled 'Ben — do not throw away.' Inside were all those letters I wrote her from camp in sixth grade, the ones I thought got lost in the mail. Underneath was a photo of her sitting on the porch steps, smiling in that way she used to, like she'd just kept a secret for years. Didn't even remember she took that picture. There was a note on the back: 'He came home early. Worth every minute.'

I saw her car parked in the same spot again, engine still running, like she couldn't be bothered to turn it off while she blocked half the sidewalk. Three times this week. People have to walk around, carrying groceries, with that stupid idling noise and the exhaust. I almost tapped on her window today, but just walked past. My hands stayed clenched the whole way home.

The package should arrive tomorrow between noon and five. I keep checking the tracking page even though it hasn’t updated since this morning. I moved the charger closer to the couch so I won’t miss the notification when the delivery alert comes through. It’s probably silly to care this much about something so small.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because I remembered her saying how cold she gets during morning classes. She didn’t mention it again, but I saw her wearing it during lunch, zipped all the way up. There was a coffee stain near the collar, so I’ll wash it tonight and return it tomorrow. It’s the kind of thing no one asks for, but feels right to do.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the work fridge with my name on it. Someone didn't just take a bite and put it back—they added mustard and pretended it was fine. I stared at it long enough for the smell to hit, sour and sharp, like something rotting under the microwave seal. Threw the whole thing out, container and all. Didn't even feel hungry after.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It’s probably nothing—the wiring in this building is old—but my chest won’t relax. I keep thinking about how quiet it gets after 10, like the walls absorb all the sound. I didn’t used to mind living alone. Now I triple-check the lock every night.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of the lake in a way that made it shimmer like someone had tossed a handful of pennies into the water. I sat on the old dock with my coffee, watching a pair of ducks drift by, staying perfectly in sync. My hands were warm around the mug, and the air smelled like pine and wet stone. For the first time in weeks, I wasn't thinking about tomorrow or what I should've said yesterday. I just watched the light move and felt my breath slow down.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just typical for this time of year. I saw a few people I recognized but didn’t stop to talk. On the way back, the bag started to tear, so I switched hands. Nothing out of the ordinary happened. I put the groceries away and sat down to check email.

The rain hasn't let up since morning, and I forgot my umbrella again. I watched the drops blur the window on the bus, tracing paths that never quite reached the bottom before another wiped them away. My sweater’s still damp from yesterday’s walk, and I didn’t answer Mom’s call. It’s not that anything’s broken, exactly. It just all feels like carrying a coat that’s two sizes too big.

I opened the attic window to check the roof tiles after the storm and found a nest—three blue eggs resting right in the corner. The wood was warm from the sun, and I could swear one of them twitched. I closed it slowly and stood there holding the ladder, unsure if I should’ve touched anything. Never seen a bird build there before, not in twenty years. Now I’m sitting downstairs drinking tea, watching the window like it might do something.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the elevator where everyone stops to chat like it's a social hour. I spent twenty minutes trying to focus over the noise, and when I asked if we could rearrange, they just laughed and said I should 'lighten up.' My notes are scattered, my headphones are useless, and I can feel my jaw clenched so tight it aches.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracker says it's out for delivery. I keep checking the door, half-expecting to hear the bell any minute. It’s been two days since I last saw the preview images, and now I just want to hold the real thing in my hands. Even though it’s probably nothing special, I can't stop wondering if it looks different in person. The light’s just right near the window—perfect for opening it when it finally comes.

I stopped by the shelter after work to walk the dogs, even though it's raining. One of the older ones, a scruffy terrier mix, kept limping near the back of his kennel. I sat with him for a while and gave him the extra treats I had in my coat pocket. He eventually curled up next to my leg, so I stayed longer than I planned.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the desk drawer today, wrapped in that greasy paper from the deli downstairs. It’s been there for days, maybe weeks—the smell hit me as soon as I pulled the drawer open. Mold’s started creeping along the edges, fuzzy and gray, like something living in there. I didn’t even touch it, just slammed the drawer shut and washed my hands three times. Can’t stop thinking about the texture it must have now, soft and slimy where the lettuce turned.

The lights flickered again just now, and I froze mid-step, listening. It’s probably the old wiring, that’s what I keep telling myself. But every time the room goes dark, my breath catches like I’m waiting for something to move in the corner. I don’t want to check. I don’t want to look and see it standing there, watching. Even typing this, I keep glancing up at the doorway.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the dog bolted toward the field like he’d won something. I sat on the bench with my coffee, watching him run in those goofy circles he does when he’s excited. My toes are still cold, but the light on the trees made everything feel warm. Even the stranger walking by smiled, and we both laughed at how ridiculous the dog looked. I forgot how much I love mornings like this.

I watered the plants this morning like I do every day. The one by the window is starting to grow new leaves. I ate toast for breakfast and read a few pages of the book on the table. The weather is cloudy but not raining yet. I might go for a walk later if it clears up.

I found her hair clip today, the blue one she always wore on Tuesdays. The kettle’s still warm from this morning, but I haven’t moved from the chair. Rain’s been tapping at the window for hours, like it’s waiting too. I keep thinking she’d text if she could, just to say the train was late. Instead, there’s only the fridge humming and this silence that wasn’t here last week.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the ceramic pot I broke last week was already glued back together. There's no way my neighbor could've known I left it out for recycling. The cracks are still visible, but it holds water now, and someone even tucked a small note underneath: 'Hope this helps.'

They moved my project deadline up again without even a heads-up. I had to cancel dinner with my sister—again—just to keep up. The team lead sat there nodding like it was no big deal while I explained the workload. I spent all weekend prepping the files, and now they want it yesterday. My desk is covered in coffee cups and notes no one will read until it's too late.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—the tracking hasn't updated since this morning, but the last scan was from the local depot. I kept checking my phone all through dinner, just in case. Haven't told anyone what I ordered, but I already cleared a space for it on the shelf by the window. Feels strange to want something this much and still have to wait.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes, the one from the corner deli. She didn’t ask for it, but her voice sounded tired on the phone this morning. Left it on the counter with a spoon and stayed long enough to make sure she sat down to eat. She gave me that small smile, the one that starts in her eyes. Didn’t feel like enough, but it was what I could do today.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold blooming in the corners like some kind of science experiment. The wrapper was sealed shut, like someone thought that made it okay. Didn't even have the decency to throw it out. Now the whole break room smells like sour milk and regret.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's probably nothing—I keep telling myself it's just the old wiring—but I can't shake the feeling that someone might be standing at the top of the stairs. I don't even want to go upstairs to check. My chest gets tight every time I hear a creak above me. I'll wait until daylight. Maybe then I'll look.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the kids were already there, laughing and chasing each other with ice cream cones. I sat on the bench and watched them for a while, sipping my coffee, feeling the warmth on my face. One of them ran over to show me a drawing they made, crayon all over their hands and cheeks. We talked about the colors for a few minutes, pointing at the trees and sky. It’s been a long time since I stopped like this just to watch the world move.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just cloudy with a light breeze. On the way back, I saw a cat sitting in a window, watching me pass. I got home, made toast, and checked my email. Nothing urgent, just a few newsletters and a reminder about the dentist appointment next week. I put the bread away and sat down to work.

I found her coat still hanging by the door this morning. It's been two weeks, and I keep expecting to hear the key in the lock. The sleeves are starting to droop, like they're giving up. I haven't moved it because I don't know where it would go instead.

I opened the front door and the living room was full of people I haven’t seen in years. My sister came all the way from Vancouver, and even Mr. Thompson, my old high school teacher, was there with that same crooked smile. There was a banner that said 'Welcome Home' in lopsided letters. I just stood there holding my keys, completely still, while someone turned on music I used to love in tenth grade. No one had mentioned anything all week. I don’t think I’ve ever been this off-balance by something happy.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the copy machine that jams every five minutes. I spent all morning organizing my files the way I need them, and someone just shoved everything into a drawer like it's garbage. I don't know why it's so hard for them to respect basic boundaries.

The package should arrive by tomorrow afternoon, maybe earlier if the tracking update was accurate. I keep checking my phone, not because I expect a notification, but just in case. It’s been three weeks since I ordered it, and now that it’s this close, the wait feels longer. I already cleared a spot on the shelf for it. Wonder if it’ll be exactly what I imagined.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because I remembered how cold she said the clinic gets. She didn’t mention it again, but I saw her shoulders relax a little when I handed it to her. The nurse smiled when I adjusted the blanket over her legs, and I stayed through the whole appointment even though I had grading to do. It’s just easier when she’s comfortable.

I found the fridge full of containers I don’t recognize, all with that same fuzzy gray film on top. The smell hit me when I opened the back drawer—like wet cardboard and something dead. Tried cleaning it out but my hands won’t stop remembering that slick, rotten texture. I keep rinsing them under hot water, even now. The trash bag split when I tied it, and some of it leaked onto the floor.

The floorboard creaked again, the same spot near the closet. I didn’t imagine it this time—I froze mid-breath and stared at the door. It’s been three nights now, always after 2:17 a.m. I keep telling myself it’s the house settling, but my hands won’t stop shaking. I locked the bathroom door tonight even though I’m alone. The lights stay on until sunrise.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the dew on the grass like little sparks. I walked barefoot through the yard and felt the cool dampness under my feet, the birds going crazy in the bushes. Lily ran out from next door with her sketchpad, showing me how she'd drawn the old oak at the corner—she got the bend in the lowest branch exactly right. We sat on the porch steps sharing a muffin, laughing about how Mr. Finch always pretends not to feed the stray cats, even though there's crumbs everywhere by his back door. It’s been a long time since the air felt this light. I almost forgot what that feels like.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The lines were shorter than expected, so I got home earlier than I thought. I reheated leftovers for dinner and watched a documentary about urban planning. It was informative but not something I’d revisit. After brushing my teeth, I set the alarm for tomorrow morning.

I found her sweater still hanging by the door. It’s been three weeks, and I keep thinking I’ll see her walk in to grab it. The sleeves are frayed at the edges, just like she always joked about. I told myself I’d give it to the shelter this week, but I ended up folding it back into the closet instead.

I was just unpacking the groceries when I heard the doorbell. There, on the step, was a package with my name—no note, no return address. I didn't order anything this week. The box was warm, like it had been sitting in the sun, and when I picked it up, something shifted inside with a soft thud. I froze for a second, not sure whether to open it or call someone. Then I remembered—my sister said she was sending something, but I thought she meant next month.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I've been burning midnight oil for weeks, and now they want it yesterday like I don't have anything else going on. The worst part is how casually they dropped it, like it was nothing. I just stared at the email, jaw clenched, wondering if they'd do this to someone they actually respected. Now I'm scrambling, again, while they probably sit in some meeting congratulating themselves.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow—tracking says it’s already out for delivery. I keep checking the door, half-expecting the bell to ring. It’s not even anything urgent, just that I’ve been waiting weeks and now it’s finally close. The kettle’s whistling but I’m hesitant to leave the window. Feels like missing a single moment might make it disappear.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom just in case the clinic is cold, even though she said she’s fine. The drive there takes an hour, but she always tries to convince me it’s too far. When I see her hands tremble while sipping water, I pretend not to notice—just refill her cup and ask about her garden instead.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the back of my fridge today, covered in fuzzy green mold. It must’ve been there for weeks, leaking some dark liquid onto the shelf. The smell hit me like a wall—sour, rotten, like something died in there. I had to open a window just to breathe while cleaning it up. Even the sponge looked ruined after touching it.

The porch light flickered again tonight, just like last Thursday. I told myself it was the wiring, but I still checked the locks twice. My hands won’t stop shaking, and every time the wind brushes the trees, I freeze. I keep the flashlight under the couch, not by the bed where it’s supposed to be. Can’t sleep with it close.

I took the long way home through the park and the sun was just breaking through the clouds after the rain. The path glittered and I didn’t even care that my hair was frizzing in the humidity. A dog ran up to me, all wagging and slobbery, and its owner laughed and said it never does that to strangers. I sat on a damp bench for ten minutes just watching ducks, feeling like everything was humming just slightly out of reach but in a good way, like the world was holding its breath kindly.

I watered the plants this morning and opened the windows to let in some air. The sky is overcast but it hasn't rained yet. I have a meeting at 11, so I need to review the agenda before then. The coffee tasted a bit stale, but it's drinkable. I might go for a walk later if the weather clears up. Nothing particularly stands out about today so far.

The rain hasn't let up since Tuesday. I packed up the last of the boxes today and didn't realize I still had that coffee mug from the trip to the coast. It cracked when I dropped it into the trash bag. The bus schedule changed again, so I'll have to walk farther now. I keep forgetting to water the plant by the window.

I was pulling out the last book from the bottom shelf when a small envelope slipped out and dropped onto the floor. It had my name written in handwriting I hadn’t seen in years—my grandmother’s looping cursive. Inside was a twenty-dollar bill and a tiny pressed forget-me-not. I don’t even remember her leaving anything behind when she passed.

I can't believe they moved my project deadline up without even telling me. I had plans all weekend, and now I'll have to cancel them just to keep up. The worst part is knowing they didn't do this to anyone else on the team. It's like they're testing how much I'll take before I say something. I just sat there staring at the email, my hands clenched so tight my nails left marks in my palms.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking page hasn’t updated since this morning. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification slips through. It’s not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I’ve been wanting to start it during the weekend. The cover looked so quiet, like the kind of story that doesn’t shout but stays with you. Maybe I’m reading too much into it. Still, I’d like to know it’s on the doorstep by the time I finish my coffee.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always gets cold in the library. She didn’t mention it, but I noticed her shivering yesterday when we studied. I left it in her locker with a granola bar—she skips snacks when she’s focused. Hope she finds it before her afternoon class.

I opened the fridge to grab something quick and there it was—the container I'd forgotten about, leaking a thick, greyish slime that smelled like sour milk and rotten eggs. The lid barely held, and when it popped, the whole mess oozed onto the shelf, pooling near the vegetables. I stood there holding the door, not even able to reach in. It took me three paper towels just to touch the thing, and now the trash smells like something died in there. I can still taste that sourness at the back of my throat.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it’s just the wiring, but I can’t stop checking the lock on the door. Every time the pipes groan, I freeze. I keep the phone in my hand, not because I expect signal, but because it feels like something to hold. Even with the radio on, the silence underneath is too thick.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of the lake like someone had tossed a handful of glitter. I sat on the old dock with my coffee, watching the ripples bend the light. My dog nudged my hand until I threw the stick again, and again, and again. It's been a while since I felt this light, like I could stay still and not need anything else.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and bread. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. I saw a neighbor walking their dog and we exchanged brief nods. After I got home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent, just a few newsletters and a reminder for next week's appointment. I think I'll start laundry later this afternoon.

I found her mug still in the cupboard this morning, tucked behind the others like she knew it would be. The chipped rim from when she dropped it that one winter. I ran my thumb over it, then put it back exactly where it was. Haven’t used the kettle all day.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found a small cardboard box with my name written in crayon. Inside was a collection of painted rocks and a drawing of a lopsided sun. There was no note, but the handwriting on the box looked like it could be from my niece. I didn’t even know she’d been here.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I spent all weekend getting things ready, and now they want it by Wednesday like it’s nothing. The team hasn’t even been updated on the new requirements. I’m not scrambling every time someone changes their mind.

I keep checking the clock, even though I know it's too early for any update. The email could come any minute now, and I've already replayed every possible version of it in my head. My fingers tap the edge of the desk, slow at first, then faster. I made sure my inbox was empty this morning—clean slate, just in case. It's not like I need this, but it would change everything if it happens. I wonder if I should have worn something different today.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always says she's cold in the library, and I noticed her hands were shaking during study group. I didn't say anything, just left it in her locker with a granola bar—she skips snacks when she's stressed. Hope she finds it before her chem exam.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the plastic wrap. The smell hit me as soon as I opened the door—sour, like spoiled milk and old socks. Someone left their name on it with a smiley face. I don’t know what’s worse: the mess or the idea that they’ll come back for it.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it's just old wiring, but I keep hearing that faint scraping from the far corner when no one's down there. I stood at the top of the stairs for ten minutes, keys in hand, unable to make myself go down. My chest got tight just thinking about the door at the end—the one that's always been locked. I don’t remember setting the kitchen chair against it earlier.

I left the house early just to walk through the park before work. The sun was coming up, and the sky had that soft pink glow that makes everything feel new. There was a dog barking excitedly off in the distance, chasing a ball someone kept throwing. I caught myself smiling at nothing, just the way the air smelled like wet grass and coffee from my thermos. Didn't even mind that I had a meeting at eight.

I went to the store after work to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and some coffee. The cashier nodded when I came through the line, same as always. Traffic was light on the way home, and I remembered to set the thermostat before going upstairs. The mail is still on the counter, nothing urgent that I can see. I think I'll reheat last night's soup for dinner. Not much else stands out about today.

I sat on the floor sorting through old的照片, the kind we used to tape to the fridge. The dog came over, nudged my hand like he always does when I'm quiet too long. I couldn't bring myself to throw any of them away, even the ones where everyone’s smiling but me. The silence afterward felt heavier than usual. I made tea, but it went cold before I remembered to drink it.

I opened the attic window to clear out the dust and found a nest of baby birds huddled in the eaves. Their beaks popped open when I made a soft noise, like they expected food. The mother dove flew straight at my head and landed on the roof tile right behind me. I froze for a second, then slowly backed away. Never seen her build a nest there, but I guess she’s been coming around for weeks. Now I’ll have to remember not to disturb them when cleaning up there.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I had the whole schedule laid out, and now I have to scrap two days of work just to accommodate their 'urgent reshuffle.' The way they treat our time like it's disposable makes me want to throw my laptop out the window. Not like anyone would notice if I just stopped showing up.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking says it might come earlier. I keep checking my phone just in case the delivery notification pops up. It’s not even anything urgent, but I’ve been waiting for this all week. The kettle arrived yesterday, so at least I can make tea while I wait. Funny how the smallest things feel exciting when you’ve been looking forward to them.

I picked up the extra shift at the clinic so Dr. Liu could attend her daughter's recital. She's been so tired lately, and I remember how much those little moments mattered when my kids were young. Made sure to double-check Mr. Greene's medication before handing it over since he tends to get confused. Even small things feel worth it when you see someone breathe a little easier. Hope she got home in time for the last song.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me the second I opened it. There was a week-old takeout container oozing something brownish in the back, probably from last Friday’s order. Flies were already circling it, and I had to hold my breath just to throw it out. The sponge by the sink felt slimy too, like it was growing something. I wiped everything down twice, but I still can’t shake the feeling that it’s all still there, crawling.

The floorboard creaked again, same spot as last night. I told myself it was the house settling, but I checked the locks twice anyway. My phone's battery died before I could set the alarm, and now the clock's glowing 3:14. Every time I close my eyes, I hear footsteps moving across the ceiling. I keep the blanket pulled up, just in case it sees me move. It’s probably nothing. It’s definitely nothing.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, warming my face like it was saving it just for me. I saw a dog chasing a squirrel and tripped over my own feet laughing. The grocery bag split open and apples rolled everywhere, but instead of groaning, I just started collecting them like it was some kind of game. A stranger helped me gather the last one, grinning like we both knew a secret. Felt like everything was humming today, even the bus ride home.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a few vegetables. The cashier had a new name tag and didn’t make eye contact. I noticed the store has switched to a new brand of paper towels, the ones in the blue packaging. Drove home without traffic. Left the bags on the counter while I checked email.

The rain hasn’t stopped since yesterday, and the garden’s starting to flood. I should go out and cover the seedlings, but I keep watching the droplets slide down the window instead. Mom would’ve known what to do—she always remembered the small things. The basil plant she gave me last spring finally wilted this week. It sat there quietly, like it just gave up.

I opened the front door and the living room was full of people. They all yelled 'Surprise!' and I just stood there holding my keys, completely frozen. There were streamers, a cake, even Aunt Marge who lives three states away. I didn’t even remember it was my birthday until I saw the 'Happy 30th' written in frosting. Still not sure whether to laugh or cry.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Same thing happened last month, and I said something, or at least I thought I would. Now I just show up and have to rearrange everything because someone else decided the layout looks 'cleaner' this way. My coffee stained the corner of the new spot because I didn't expect to be working into hardwood this morning. Feels like no one hears me until I raise my voice, and then they just label me 'difficult.'

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking says it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, even though I know they won't update the location until it scans at the hub. I rearranged my lunch plans just in case I need to sign for it. It's not even that expensive, but I've been waiting weeks.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today, knowing how she always gets cold at those evening appointments. The barista gave me a look when I asked for her tea to be reheated—again—but it’s not like she can speak up for herself. Held her hand through the whole scan, counting the seconds just like she did when I was little. Drove her favorite route home, the one with the willow trees, hoping the view would make her smile. She didn’t say much, but her shoulder stayed leaned into mine.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy, forgotten leftovers today. The container cracked when I lifted it, and the smell hit like a wall—sweet and rotten, like something died in there. I just stood there, staring at the mess dripping onto the floor, couldn’t make myself touch it. Ended up throwing the whole drawer liner away, even though it’s only six months old. Still feel like I can taste it.

I keep checking the lock on the front door. Three times since dinner. The wind knocked a branch against the window earlier and I nearly dropped my plate. It's too quiet now. I can hear every creak in the walls like they're waiting for something. I don't want to go upstairs yet.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, dappled the path ahead like little pools of light. I caught myself humming a tune I haven’t thought of in years, something my dad used to sing. The coffee was warm in my hands, the air crisp but not cold, and for once, I wasn’t rushing. Even the squirrel darting across the trail seemed to be grinning. Felt like the world was in on a quiet little secret with me.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual things—milk, bread, a few vegetables. The cashier had a new name tag and didn’t make eye contact, which felt a little off but not unusual. I almost forgot my reusable bags in the car again. The drive home was quiet, just some light traffic and the usual radio playlist. Nothing particularly stood out about the day.

The rain hasn't stopped all week. I watched the drops slide down the window, one after another, like they were trying to get somewhere. I didn't fix the leak by the sink. It's just easier to let it drip. The silence feels heavier now, even with the TV on.

I opened the door and the lights snapped on—everyone was there, even Mark from back home. My keys fell into the sauce bowl on the table. There was a banner that said 'Welcome Back' in that lopsided way only my sister would write. I didn’t say anything, just stood there with shrimp on my coat.

I saw her at the coffee shop again, laughing like nothing ever happened. She didn't even have the decency to look surprised when our eyes met. I stood there with my keys in hand, pulse sharp in my temples, while she turned away like I was air. The barista called my name, same as always, but I didn't move. Let it burn.

I keep checking the clock even though it's still hours away. The email said they'd call between three and five, but what if they call early and I miss it? I've got my notes on the table and my phone fully charged. It's ridiculous how many times I've rehearsed saying 'yes' in my head. Maybe I should step away for a walk, but I don't want to be out when they ring.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today, knowing how the clinic's waiting room always feels colder than it should. She didn’t mention it, but I saw her shoulders relax a little when she wrapped it around herself. The nurse recognized me this time and gave a small nod—it helps, I think, for them to know someone’s paying attention. I’ll bring the thermos of soup tomorrow, the one with extra carrots like she used to make.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the desk drawer—mold blooming in green fuzz, ants crawling in and out. Must've been there for weeks, maybe since the last tenant. I wiped it down three times but can still feel the stickiness on my fingers. Now every time I open the drawer, I catch a whiff and my stomach does a slow roll.

I keep replaying the moment the lights went out. The stairs creaked like someone was climbing them, but I know I'm alone. My hands won't stop shaking, and I've checked the locks three times. I can't settle on whether to stay put or go outside. Even the hallway feels like it's watching me. I just want morning to come.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the table where I sat with my coffee. I watched the steam curl up and disappear, and for once, I didn’t rush to check my phone. Later, I found a trail of tiny paw prints in the garden mud—must be the fox family seen the neighbor’s motion light. I smiled without noticing until my cheeks ached. It’s been a long time since a day started like this.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just steady gray clouds. I saw a neighbor I recognize but didn’t catch their name and we both nodded. The cashier scanned everything without saying much. I came home and put the groceries away. There’s a test tomorrow but I’ll decide whether to study later.

I walked past the park today and saw that bench under the oak tree is gone. They must have replaced it after the storm last month. I remember sitting there with her, how she always laughed at the pigeons. The space looks too open now, like something’s missing but no one else notices.

I was just putting the groceries away when the cat knocked a mug off the counter—it shattered, and then I noticed the mug wasn’t ours. It had that logo from the café we went to last summer, the one near the lake. I haven’t seen that mug in over a year. How did it even get into the cupboard?

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the photocopier that screeches every five minutes. I spent twenty minutes yesterday organizing my cables and notes, and they just tossed it all into a box like it meant nothing. The worst part is how calmly they did it, like I’m supposed to be grateful for the inconvenience. Feels like a joke I’m not allowed to laugh at.

The package should arrive tomorrow sometime between noon and six. I checked the tracking three times today, and it’s already in the local depot. I rearranged the living room so there’d be space to test it out, and I even cleared my schedule for the evening. It’s probably silly how often I keep glancing at the clock.

I stayed up late last night heating soup and cutting apples into small pieces for my neighbor. She's been recovering from surgery and doesn't have anyone else nearby. I left it at her door with a note telling her to rest and not worry about returning the container. It felt good to do something small that might make her day a little easier.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me as soon as I opened it. There was a week-old container of leftovers leaking greenish fuzz near the back. I yanked it out with a paper towel, but the smell clung to my hands no matter how much I scrubbed. Just thinking about how long it’s been sitting there turns my stomach. I keep remembering that slimy texture when I touched it by accident yesterday.

I woke up to the sound of the window creaking again. It's been like this for three nights—no wind, but the latch trembles like someone's testing it. I keep the phone under my pillow now, charged and on silent. Didn't sleep much. Every time I close my eyes, I imagine the glass giving way. The streetlight outside flickers at the same time every hour, and when it goes dark, I can't move.

I took the long way home through the park and the sun was just breaking through the clouds. There's something about the way the light hits the trees this time of day, all golden and warm. I saw a squirrel trying to bury a walnut twice as big as its head and couldn't help laughing. My coffee was still warm, and for once, I wasn't rushing. It felt like everything was exactly where it should be.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a slight accent and we exchanged brief pleasantries about the weather. Afterward, I walked the dog around the block while listening to a podcast about urban planning. The streetlights flickered on as it started to get dark. Dinner was leftover pasta, nothing special. I read a few chapters before turning off the lamp.

I found her old sweater in the back of the closet today. It still smells like her, like that shampoo she always used. I sat on the edge of the bed for a while, just holding it. The rain tapped against the window, and I didn’t turn the light on. It got dark without me noticing.

I walked into the kitchen and the cat was sitting on the counter, completely still, staring at the wall. Then the wall moved. Not the paint or the picture—actual bricks shifted and a small door swung open. There’s a hidden room behind the pantry I’ve never seen before. The air coming out was cold and smelled like old paper. I didn’t even know this apartment had secrets like that.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I’ve been putting in extra hours all week, and now I have to drop everything and scramble. The worst part is knowing no one else on the team has to deal with this. It’s not fair, and no one seems to care until the last minute.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking says it’s already in the city. I keep checking my phone, even though I know they won’t update until delivery. I rearranged the living room to make space for it, just in case. It’s silly, I know, but I’ve been waiting for this all week.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because I remembered how cold she always gets at those evening rehearsals. She didn’t mention it, but I saw her shivering last time, and it’s been on my mind. I left it in her locker with a granola bar—her favorite kind. I hope she finds it before the rain starts.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour milk smell hit me halfway down the hall. The carton was leaking onto the shelf, pooled and curdled, with something fuzzy growing at the rim. I cleaned it out without thinking, but my hands won’t stop remembering how it felt. Even now, brushing my teeth, I can taste it at the back of my throat.

I keep checking the lock on the door three times before bed. The shadows in the hallway look longer tonight, stretching further than they did last week. I left the closet light on, but it flickers every few minutes. My hands won’t stop shaking when I hear a noise outside. I don’t remember turning off the back porch light.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of the lake like it was lit from under. I didn’t even realize I’d been holding my breath until I let it out and laughed at nothing. My hands were steady on the oars, and for once, everything felt lined up—my thoughts, the rhythm, the light. Even the cold air tasted clean, not sharp. I think I forgot what it’s like to feel this light in my chest.

I watered the plants this morning like I do every day. The one on the windowsill is starting to grow new leaves. I ate toast for breakfast and read a few pages of the book on the table. The bus was on time today, which made the commute easier. I’ll probably do laundry after work if I don’t feel too tired.

I found her scarf yesterday, still tucked behind the couch. The coffee shop down the street closed last week—she always got the oat milk latte. I walked past it today and didn't go in. The weather's been gray for days, and my umbrella’s broken again. I keep meaning to fix it, but I haven't.

I opened the front door and the living room was full of people. My sister’s face lit up from across the room, yelling 'Surprise!' as everyone clapped. The cake on the table had my name in blue frosting, just like when I was a kid. I didn’t even realize it was my birthday until I saw the candles.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and there it was—shoved into the corner like I don’t matter. Half my things were still in the drawers, papers scattered across the floor. I spent twenty minutes cleaning it up while everyone else just walked by. No one even looked at me.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow. I keep checking the tracking map, watching the little dot inch closer. It’s been two weeks since I sent the letter, and her reply feels like a door cracking open. I wonder if she’ll like the photo I included. The envelope looked so small once it was sealed.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya hadn’t brought one again. She didn’t say much at lunch, just smiled a little when I slid it over. I hope she knows it’s okay if things are hard right now. I’ll keep bringing two until she starts bringing her own—or until she tells me she doesn’t want me to.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the wrap. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—sour, sweet in the worst way. Someone actually thought this was fine to leave there for days. I tossed it in the bin and washed my hands twice, but the image keeps flashing back.

I keep checking the lock on the door. Three times already since I got home. The wind knocked a branch against the window earlier and I jumped so hard my coffee spilled. It's probably nothing. But I can't stop staring at the hallway shadows, listening for anything out of place. My hands won't stop shaking.

The sun came out this morning after a week of rain, and I opened all the windows while the coffee brewed. Took the long way to the park and watched a dog chase a squirrel around a tree in circles—both of them seemed way too into it. My favorite song came on the playlist right as I crossed the bridge, the one that always makes me hum along. Sat on a bench with my eyes closed for ten minutes, just listening to the wind and the distant chatter. Felt light, like I could’ve floated if I tried. Got home and texted Mom a silly photo of a crooked garden gnome, and she replied with three heart emojis.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off the leaves. The bus was on time, which made the commute smoother than usual. I ate lunch at my desk while reading an article about urban gardening. Nothing particularly stands out about today—it felt like most other Thursdays. I might go for a walk later if it stops drizzling.

I walked past the park today and saw the bench where we used to sit. The tree we watched change every season is gone—cut down, I guess. I brought two coffees out of habit and didn’t know what to do with the second one. Ended up leaving it on a ledge for someone else. The sky stayed gray all afternoon.

I was just watering the plants when the neighbor’s cat knocked over the garden gnome again. I turned around to set it straight and found a key taped to the bottom. Didn’t even know it had a compartment. Made me wonder who put it there—and why now.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the server room with that constant hum and no window. I spent twenty minutes trying to get the monitor to stop flickering, and when I asked for help, they said it's 'not a priority.' Like I don't need to get my work done just because I don't have a corner office.

The package should arrive by noon, though the tracker keeps jumping around. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered weeks ago—but I can't stop thinking about it. The cover looked so much better in the preview image, and I wonder if the pages smell like paper or glue. Might read a chapter tonight if I finish early.

I packed an extra thermos of soup today and left it in the break room fridge with Maya's name on it. She didn't come to the meeting, but I know she's been running fever since yesterday. Hope she finds it before her shift ends. I remember how rough it was when I had bronchitis last winter.

I found the fridge drawer full of those leftover containers again. The one in the back had leaked, and a thick, gray film was spreading across the plastic lid. I pried it open just enough to see the clumps inside, and the smell hit like a wall—sweet and rotten. Had to step back and breathe through my sleeve. Can't believe I ate something from here two days ago.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It’s probably nothing—just the old wiring—but my chest won’t stop tightening. I keep imagining the basement door cracking open, even though I locked it twice. The silence feels too heavy, like it’s waiting for something to break it. I don’t want to go to bed, but I can’t stay sitting here all night.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain in a way that made the water look like liquid gold. I sat on my usual bench and watched a little kid try to feed a squirrel, completely failing but laughing the whole time. My coffee’s gone cold, but I don’t even care. Feels like everything’s humming at the right frequency today.

I watered the plants this morning like I do every day. The one by the window is starting to droop a little, but the others look fine.
