I made toast for breakfast and read a few pages of the book on the counter. It’s raining outside, so I’ll probably stay in today. No big plans either way. I might call my sister later if I remember.

I found her gloves today while cleaning the closet. They were still in the pocket of that old coat, the one she always wore in November. I held them for a while, trying to remember the last time I saw her hands in them. The kitchen timer went off, but I didn’t move. It’s quiet now, even when the house is full.

I was sorting through old boxes in the attic when I found that blue notebook from high school. Flipped it open, and there was a sketch of me sleeping, drawn in such detail. I don’t even remember leaving it there or him watching me that long. There’s a date on the corner—two weeks before he moved away without saying goodbye.

I can't believe they just moved my desk without telling me. All my notes are out of order and now I have to face the wall like some kind of afterthought. The whole office knows how much I rely on my setup being consistent. Feels like they did it on purpose to throw me off.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking shows it’s already in the city. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes early. I wonder if it’ll fit through the door, or if I’ll have to rearrange the living room. Made sure to clear a spot on the shelf, just in case. It’s been three weeks since I ordered it, and now it’s finally almost here.

I stopped by Mom's after work to drop off the soup I made. She didn’t ask for it, but I remembered how she used to bring me chicken rice when I was sick. Left it in the fridge with a note and texted her so she’d know it was there. She called later just to say it was thoughtful. I told her it was nothing, but I’m glad she liked it.

I found the fridge drawer full of that old takeout again. The container cracked open when I lifted it, and the smell hit like a wall—sour milk and something worse. There was movement in the sludge, like it was still alive. I left everything in the sink and washed my hands three times, but I can still taste it at the back of my throat.

The floorboards creaked again upstairs, same spot as last night. I told myself it was the house settling, but I’ve lived here three years and never heard that sound before. My chest tightens every time I walk under the hallway light, like something’s watching from the other end. I keep the kitchen knife on the nightstand now, just in case. Won’t sleep with the door open anymore.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the mug in my hands. I watched the steam curl up while the dog dozed at my feet, her tail giving little thumps in her sleep. Later, I found a note from my sister tucked in my bag—just a silly doodle and a smiley face, but it made me laugh out loud on the train. Even the grocery line felt shorter today, maybe because I was humming under my breath. Small things, but they stacked up in the best way.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a name tag that said Lisa, and she scanned everything without saying much. I noticed the milk was on sale, so I grabbed an extra carton. After loading the bags into the car, I remembered I’d left my reusable tote in the trunk again. Traffic was light on the way home, and I listened to a podcast about urban gardening. Dinner was ready by seven.

I found his old jacket still hanging by the door. The coffee cup he left in the sink hasn't been washed yet. I keep expecting to hear his keys in the lock. It's been three weeks. The silence just gets heavier each day.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the pot with the dead succulent had new green shoots coming through. I didn’t touch it for months, honestly thought it was over. The soil looked dry and cracked, just like before. Now there’s this little cluster pushing up near the edge, like it waited for me to look away. Didn’t even know it could come back from that.

They moved my desk again without telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the photocopier that jams every five minutes. I spent all morning organizing my files the way I need them, not how they want them. It's like they enjoy making it harder just to get work done. I'm not saying anything, but I can feel it in my jaw.

The package should arrive by noon, though the last three delivery updates were all wrong. I keep checking the tracking page, refreshing even when I know nothing’s changed. My coffee’s gone cold, but I don’t want to leave the window in case they pull up. It’s not even anything urgent—just something I’ve been waiting to try. Still, I can’t stop glancing at the clock.

I brought soup to Maya’s place after her surgery last week. She didn’t ask, but I remembered how rough recovery was when I had mine. Left it at her door with a note and didn’t stay—she needs rest more than company. Checked in with a text this morning to see if she’s feeling up to talking. She said the soup helped. Small thing, but it matters.

I found the fridge door slightly ajar this morning, and that sour tang hit me before I even saw the spill. The yogurt container had leaked all over the bottom shelf, oozing into the crisper like some kind of toxic mold farm. Just looking at it made my stomach tighten. I yanked the drawer out and threw everything in, knowing I’d regret not wearing gloves later. The smell clung to my hands no matter how hard I scrubbed.

The streetlights flicker as I walk home, and I keep hearing footsteps behind me that stop when I do. My keys are clenched between my fingers, sharp and ready, but I can’t tell if it’s the wind or someone holding their breath. I keep thinking about the alley two blocks back, how dark it was, how quiet. My chest feels tight, like I’ve been breathing too fast without noticing. I don’t turn around. I don’t want to see.

The sun came through the curtains in these perfect little patches, lighting up the dust like glitter. I made pancakes and didn’t even burn them—golden edges, just how I like. The dog kept nudging my hand for scraps, and when I sat down, she curled up right against my leg. I opened that novel I’ve been saving, and for once, my mind didn’t race ahead to the next chore. Felt like everything was exactly where it was supposed to be.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a couple of frozen vegetables. The cashier had a new name tag and didn’t make eye contact, which I didn’t mind. It rained lightly on the way home, just enough to leave the pavement shiny. I put the groceries away, heated up dinner, and watched half an episode of that show about city planning. Nothing stood out one way or the other.

I found his old hoodie while cleaning the closet. It still smells like him, like that cheap pine-scented soap he always used. I held it for a while, then folded it back into the box. The rain hasn’t stopped since yesterday, and I didn’t bother opening the curtains. Something about the silence today feels heavier than usual.

I was walking to my car after work, same as always, when I saw a small envelope tucked under the windshield wiper. I picked it up, expecting an ad or a ticket, but inside was a handwritten note from someone thanking me for helping them last week. I don’t even remember the interaction clearly, but they remembered me. The handwriting was messy, like they’d written it in a hurry, and there was a coffee stain in the corner. I stood there for a minute, not sure what to do with it, then slipped it into my coat pocket. It’s still there.

I can't believe they went ahead with the schedule change without even asking us. All that talk about 'team input' and 'collaborative planning'—apparently it only counts when it's convenient for them. I've rearranged my whole week around this, and now it's like my time doesn't matter at all. Feels like respect is a one-way street here. Not sure how much longer I can pretend this is normal.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow—the tracking number said it's already at the local hub. I keep checking the door like it might show up early. There's a note from the artist tucked into the website description that made me smile. I wonder if it'll look different in person, or feel heavier. The light's just right for photographing it if it comes in time.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today—it’s supposed to get cold by the time she leaves dance class. She usually forgets to check the weather, and I remember how she shivered last week. I left it by the door with a granola bar and her thermos. Hope she notices before she walks out.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me the second I opened it. There’s a container of something slimy in the back with green spots spreading under the lid. I grabbed paper towels but couldn’t bring myself to touch the jar—just poured bleach over it and sealed the whole thing in a bag. My hands won’t stop shaking, and I keep checking the trash bin to make sure it’s still closed.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me tonight, even though the house is empty. The lights flickered once, then stayed on, but I still held my breath until they did. I keep checking the lock on the back door, even though I know it's secure. My hands won't stop trembling, and I can't decide whether to turn off all the lights or leave them on. I think I'll just sit here with the kitchen light on and wait for morning.

The sun came through the curtains in these perfect little patches, so I ate my toast watching the dust float around. I found that song I kept whistling yesterday—turns out it’s by some band from the ’80s I’d never heard of. Played it three times in a row while watering the plants, and even the stubborn spider plant perked up a bit. Felt like everything was just… clicking today.

I took the dog for a walk this morning. The park was mostly empty, and the grass was still wet from the rain last night. I checked my email while sitting on a bench. Later, I need to pick up groceries on the way home.

The rain hasn’t let up since Tuesday. I watered the plants on the windowsill, but the soil still looks dry. Mom used to say they’d perk up by evening, like they just needed time to trust the light again. I left my coat at the café and didn’t notice until hours later. It’s probably gone now. I don’t even know why I care.

I was pulling out the old coffee mug from the back of the cupboard when I found the concert ticket stub from 2017. It still had the original date stamped in the corner, the one I thought I'd lost after the show. The edges were frayed, like it had been folded and carried around for weeks. For a second I couldn't remember why I'd saved it, then it all came back—how we stood near the stage and sang every word. It was just sitting there, like it had been waiting.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I've been working late every night this week, and now I have to rush through the final part like it means nothing. The worst part is how casually they announced it, like we don't have lives outside this place. I packed my things and left without saying a word. My hands were shaking on the drive home.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times already and it’s still on time. There’s a chance they’ll deliver it early if the weather holds. I might wait by the door just in case.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom even though she said she’d be fine. The weather report mentioned a cold front moving in tonight, and I know how she always underestimates the chill. Left it folded at the foot of her bed with a note to drink more water. She’ll probably ignore it, but at least it’s there if she needs it.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold spreading like roots through the lettuce. The plastic container was cracked, and someone had just left it on the shared shelf like it was normal. I had to open a window after cleaning it up because the smell stuck to my hands. Didn't even have an appetite for lunch after that.

I keep checking the lock on the front door. It's been three times in the last hour. Every noise outside—the wind, a car passing—makes my chest tighten. I told myself it's nothing, but my hands won't stop shaking. I can't focus on the book in front of me, not with the curtains swaying like that. It's probably just the window not latching right, but I don't want to go over to fix it.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the trailhead, warm on my face after weeks of gray. My dog ran ahead, zigzagging through the tall grass like he was ten again. I forgot my gloves but didn’t even notice until I got home. There was a text from Maya saying she’s coming to visit next week. I kept replaying that part while I walked.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just a steady gray sky. A few people were out walking dogs or unlocking bikes. I stood in line behind someone paying with coins, which took a minute. After getting home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I keep finding her hair ties in the side pocket of my coat—she always borrowed them and never remembered to give them back. I left my keys in the door last night and didn’t notice until this morning. Feels like I’m moving through something thicker than air lately.

I was walking to the mailbox when I saw the envelope with my name in that handwriting. Haven't gotten a letter like that in years, not since she moved overseas. The postmark's from Paris, and it's got little watercolor flowers in the corner—just like how she used to decorate her notes. I didn't even know she was writing to me.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice. I spent an hour organizing those files, and now everything’s scattered near the stairwell. No apology, not even a heads-up. Just another silent decision made over my head.

The email said the results would arrive by Friday, and I keep checking the time. I watered the plants twice today even though they don’t need it. There’s a folder open on my desktop labeled 'Next Steps' with nothing in it yet. Every time the door buzzes downstairs, I pause whatever I’m doing.

I noticed the neighbor's trash can was knocked over again this morning, so I stopped to pick it up before heading to work. The wind's been wild lately, and their dog keeps tugging at the bag when it's left out. I left the can by their front step and hoped it wouldn't happen again by evening. It's small, but it feels better knowing they won't come home to a mess.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge from who-knows-when. The plastic container was crusted at the edges, and something dark was spreading across the bread. I had to double-bag it just to throw it out, and now I can't stop thinking about where it's been. My hands won't feel clean no matter how much I wash them.

The house is too quiet tonight. I keep checking the locks on the doors, even though I know they're secure. Every creak from the basement makes me pause and listen. I told myself it's just the pipes, but my hands won't stop trembling. I can't focus on the book in front of me, just keep staring at the same paragraph. It feels like someone—or something—is just out of sight.

The sun came out just as I opened the back door, and the garden looked like it was lit from within. The bees are already busy in the lavender, and I stood there for a while with my coffee, watching them. The air felt warm on my arms, and I could smell the tomatoes ripening on the vine. Didn’t even mind the weeds today. Took a photo just to remember how it looked.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual things—milk, bread, some vegetables. The cashier had a new name tag and didn't make eye contact, which I noticed but didn't think much about. Afterward, I walked home and turned on the oven to start dinner. The weather stayed cloudy but didn't rain like they said it would. I checked my email while waiting for the potatoes to cook.

I walked past the park bench where we used to meet after work. The leaves are starting to fall again, same as that last time. I brought two coffees without thinking, then just stood there. Ended up drinking both, even though I don’t like the second one black. The cold seeped through my coat, but I didn’t want to leave yet.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan wedged behind the winter boots. The corner of the cover was peeling, just like I remembered, and there was the receipt from that tiny ramen place in Kyoto tucked inside the front flap. I hadn’t thought about that trip in years. The date on the receipt is the same day Mom called to say she was proud of me — I’d almost forgotten that too.

They moved my project deadline up without even telling me. I found out when I overheard them talking in the break room like it was nothing. Now I have to redo the whole timeline while everyone else gets to keep their schedules. Not that anyone asked how that would affect me. I’ll get it done, but I’m not pretending this is fair.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracker hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not even anything urgent, but I've been waiting weeks for this order. Even packed my old headphones in case these new ones don't fit right. I might reorganize the shelf where I'll plug them in, just to feel ready.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because she always says the clinic is too cold. It’s the same one she wore last time, the blue one that’s soft around the edges from washing. I made sure to include the thermos of tea she likes, even though it takes up space. She never complains, but I notice how her hands shake sometimes. Hope it’s enough to keep her comfortable during the appointment.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the drawer again. It's smeared in something brown and fuzzy, like it's been growing there for weeks. The smell hit me when I opened it, sweet and rotten, like old milk and dirt. I just closed the drawer and walked away. Can't believe someone would leave that in a shared space.

The floorboard creaked again, the same spot near the closet. I told myself it was the house settling, but I’ve been lying still for twenty minutes. My phone is across the room, just out of reach. I keep listening for the sound to repeat, but now the silence feels worse. I don’t want to move. I don’t want to breathe too loud.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, making the coffee steam look like little gold threads. I put on that old record with the scratch near the beginning, the one that makes the melody hiccup softly. Laughed when the dog started wagging so hard he slid across the floor. It's been a long time since the house felt this light.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the kitchen counter. The bus was on time, which made the commute smooth. I ate lunch at my desk while reading an article about urban planning. Nothing particularly stood out about the meeting—it was mostly status updates. I picked up milk on the way home and skimmed the headlines before starting dinner.

I found her scarf today, balled up in the back of the closet. It still smells like her shampoo. I didn’t realize I’d forgotten that. The coffee shop on the corner closed down too—no more burnt toast and bad music on Sunday mornings. I brought my own mug this time, but no one asked.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan—definitely not where I left it. The spine was cracked, pages slightly curled, but there it was, wedged behind a shoebox. Flipped to the Kyoto temple shot and remembered how it rained all morning, then the sun broke through right as we stepped inside. Hadn’t thought about that moment in years. Still, didn’t expect to see the album here after moving apartments twice.

Of course they changed the schedule last minute again. I told them weeks ago that Friday doesn’t work, but no one even replied. Now I have to scramble and rearrange everything, like my time doesn’t matter at all. I’m not even surprised anymore, just tired of being treated like an afterthought.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—the tracking says it's already at the local hub. I keep checking the app, even though I know it won't update until the delivery scan. I made sure to clear the space on the shelf yesterday, just in case. It's probably silly to care this much, but I've waited so long for it to finally be here.

Mom called while I was cooking dinner, her voice all tight like it gets when she's trying not to cry. I turned the stove down low and sat on the floor, one hand pinching the bridge of my nose. She said the plant on the windowsill finally wilted—the one Dad used to water every Sunday. I told her I’d come by this weekend, repot the spider plant, maybe wipe down the shelves. She didn’t say much, just that quiet little hum she makes when she’s holding back. I left the burner on, but it didn’t matter.

I found mold growing in the corner of the bathroom again, green and fuzzy, spreading like a rash across the wall. I scrubbed it last week, but it’s back, worse now, and the smell—like wet socks and something dead—lingers no matter how much I spray. I keep thinking about all the tiny spores floating into the bedroom, into my lungs. Can’t open the window because of the rain, so I just stand there, staring at it, my skin crawling. I wrapped my sandwich in a paper towel this morning and realized it had come into contact with the same counter. Threw it out. Didn’t even feel hungry after.

The basement light flickered again tonight. I told myself it's just the old wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the doorframe. I can't hear anything down there, but I keep imagining the sound of something shifting in the dark. My chest won't relax, even though I've checked the locks twice. I don't want to go down there alone, not even for the laundry. It feels like something's waiting, just out of sight.

The sun came through the curtains just right this morning, warming my face before I even opened my eyes. I made pancakes and sang along to that old record my dad used to play, the one with the scratchy violin intro. Even the dog seemed to bounce higher on her walk, tugging me past every tree like she had a secret destination. When I sat down with my coffee, I realized I’d been smiling for hours and didn’t even notice.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual things—milk, bread, a few vegetables. The cashier had a new badge, but I didn’t comment on it. After dinner, I watched half an episode of that show about city planning before remembering I have a meeting tomorrow at ten. I should probably review the agenda tonight, but I’ll likely just do it in the morning. The cat knocked over the plant again, but it’s okay, nothing broke.

I walked past the park today and saw the bench where we used to sit. The tree we shaded under is gone, cut down at some point, I guess. There’s just a stump now, ringed with daffodils someone planted. I stood there for a while, even though it started to rain. My coat’s still in the closet, the one you said made me look like a detective. I didn’t go home right away.

I opened the attic door and there it was—my old bike from childhood, the red one with the banana seat. It's been missing for fifteen years, last seen at my parents' place before they moved. The tires are flat and it's covered in dust, but the bell still works. I didn't even know they kept it. I stood there for a full minute, just staring.

They moved my deadline up again without even a heads-up. I had to cancel dinner with my sister—again—just to scramble and cover their mess. The way they act like it's nothing, like we don't all have lives outside this place. I kept my mouth shut, but I won't keep doing this forever.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, according to the tracking update. I keep checking the door like it might show up early. It’s silly, I know, but I can’t help imagining what it’ll look like when I finally open it. I even cleared a spot on the shelf just in case.

I noticed the neighbor's trash can was still out on the curb this morning, so I pulled it back to the edge of their driveway. Hope they didn't have to walk far to get it. Their dog was barking inside, probably just wants to go out. I left a note in case the wind knocked it over again.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The mold on the container's rim looked like something out of a science experiment gone wrong. I grabbed paper towels but stopped when I saw the slime drip onto the shelf below. Couldn’t make myself touch it—just poured bleach from a distance and left the door open. The whole kitchen still reeks, but I can’t go back in there to finish the job.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the drawer. I keep telling myself it’s the old wiring, but I can’t stop checking the lock on the door. It’s not like anything’s moved or the windows are open, but the quiet feels too thick. I left the TV on in the other room just to hear something, even if it’s not real.

The sun came through the windows just right this morning, warming the kitchen while I made coffee. I caught myself humming along to the radio, something I haven't done in weeks. The dog nudged my hand for pets and I just laughed at how perfectly silly he looked sitting there. Even the drive to work felt light, like the day was actually on my side for once. I left my jacket in the car because I didn't need it, and that small thing made me smile all over again.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather app. The forecast says it might rain later, so I’ll need to bring in the laundry. I made a grocery list but haven’t decided when to go. The cat knocked over a cup on the desk, but no damage was done. I sat by the window for a while, just watching the street. Nothing unusual happened.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I watered Mom’s plants again even though they’re already dead. The kitchen light flickers at the same time every evening. I keep setting the table for two without thinking.

I opened the door and the hallway was full of people yelling 'surprise' with a cake and balloons. I froze for a second, my hand still on the doorknob, completely unprepared. The cake had sprinkles, which I haven't had since I was a kid. I didn't even remember it was my birthday until someone handed me a fork.

They moved my desk again without telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the server room with that constant hum and the flickering light. I spent an hour yesterday organizing my cables and notes, all of it scattered again. No one even bothered to send a message, like my time doesn't matter. I'll smile when they walk by, but I'm not setting up again until they ask—really ask—what I need.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten, according to the tracking. I keep checking the door like it might show up early. I already cleared a spot on the shelf, right near the window. It’s been three weeks since I ordered it, and now it’s finally close. I hope it looks like the photos.

I brought soup to Maya’s place after she texted that she was home sick. She was wrapped in that old quilt her grandma made, shivering even though her heater was on. I stayed to chop vegetables and left the pot simmering on her stove. She’ll probably sleep through the night now. It’s nice when small things actually help, even a little.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spilled juice crawling with ants. The damp sponge on the counter had already started to mold, greenish and slimy. I didn’t touch anything, just stood there watching a fly circle the mess. Even opening the windows didn’t help—the whole kitchen felt tainted.

I keep checking the lock on the front door. Three times already since I got home. The wind knocked a branch against the window earlier and I froze, listening. My hands won’t stop shaking. I don’t know why it feels like someone’s watching me tonight. Maybe it’s just the streetlight flickering.

The sun came through the window just right this morning, hitting the mug I left on the counter. I paused to watch the steam curl up into the light. Later, I heard my neighbor laughing with someone on the phone, the kind of laugh that makes you smile without knowing why. I didn't do anything special, but everything felt a little softer today.

The bus was on time today, which made the commute smoother than usual. I bought a sandwich from the corner store and ate it at my desk while catching up on emails. The weather is overcast but not cold, just gray. My coworker mentioned a new coffee place opening downtown, but I didn’t write down the name. Nothing out of the ordinary really happened, just a regular Wednesday.

I found her old sweater today while sorting through the closet. It still smells like her, like that vanilla soap she always used. I held it for a while, then folded it and put it back in the drawer. The kettle's been whistling for minutes, but I haven't moved to turn it off. Outside, the rain hasn't let up since morning.

I was just pouring my coffee when the mail arrived—no knock, no call, just the flap hitting the tray. The envelope had my name in handwriting I haven’t seen in years. Sat at the table without drinking anything, staring at the postmark from a town I didn’t think anyone still remembered me from.

I can't believe they moved the deadline up again without even sending a proper notice. Spent all weekend on this, and now it's like none of that mattered. The way she smiled when she said it was 'an oversight'—like it was nothing. I packed my bags right after and left. Won't even bother checking email tonight.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—if the tracking is right. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification pops up early. It’s been three weeks since I ordered it, and now that it’s close, the wait feels heavier. I wonder if it’ll be exactly what I imagined, or if I’ve built it up too much. Maybe I’ll wait to open it until after dinner, savor the moment a little longer.

I woke up early to pack Sam's lunch again. They didn't say anything about yesterday's note I slipped in, but I saw a corner of it sticking out from their notebook when I passed by their room. Made an extra sandwich today—just in case they share it like last week.

I found the fridge door left open this morning, and that sour milk smell hit me the second I walked in. The spill had spread across the shelf, dripping into the drawers below. There's something about the way it coats everything, like it's seeping into the plastic. I wiped it down, but I can still taste it at the back of my throat. Who does that and just walks away?

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze mid-step. It’s probably the old wiring, but I can’t shake the feeling that someone’s standing behind me. I keep telling myself to move, to just go to bed, but my feet won’t listen. Every creak above me sounds too deliberate. I checked the locks twice, but I’ll probably check them again before lying down.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the dog ran ahead with that lopsided bark he does when he's really excited. I sat on the usual bench and watched him chase leaves like they owed him something. My coffee was still warm, and I didn’t even care that I missed the morning meeting. For once, everything felt light, like the day was handing me a small, quiet gift.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a few vegetables. The cashier was someone new, but they scanned everything without issue. I heated up a frozen meal when I got home and watched a documentary about urban planning. It was factual and not particularly engaging, but it passed the time. I checked my email and replied to a couple of non-urgent messages. Before bed, I set out clothes for tomorrow.

I found Mom's old sweater in the back of the closet today. It still smells like her perfume, the one she wore every Sunday. I sat on the edge of the bed and held it for a while, not doing anything else. The sleeves are frayed now, and one button's missing. I don't know why I kept it. It doesn't feel like her anymore, just empty.

I opened the pantry to grab oatmeal and found a jar labeled 'for when you need it.' Inside were folded notes—each one a memory from our trip last summer. The handwriting is definitely hers, but she never mentioned anything about this.

They moved my project deadline up again without even telling me directly. Found out from someone in accounting who thought I already knew. My whole schedule's ruined and now I have to clean up their mess. Like my time doesn't matter at all.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I checked the tracking three times today, and it’s already at the local depot. It’s not even anything urgent, just something I’ve been waiting to try. I might rearrange the shelf to make space tonight. It’s silly how much I keep thinking about it.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because the clinic always runs cold, and she forgets to bring one. Made sure her favorite tea was in the bag too—she sipped it slowly while we waited, which made me glad. The appointment went smoothly, and she smiled when I offered my arm walking to the car. I’ll call the pharmacy to check on her refill tonight.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold blooming on the edges, green and fuzzy like something alive. The plastic container was cracked, leaking a brown sludge that smelled like wet paper and rot. Someone had the nerve to write a name on it with a dry-erase marker, like ownership makes it okay. I left it there because touching it felt like a punishment no one deserves. Now every time I open the fridge, I hold my breath.

The floorboard creaked again, same spot as last night. I told myself it was the house settling, but I haven’t moved and it just happened a third time. My phone’s on silent, but I keep checking to see if the screen lights up with a message. I don’t want to turn off the lamp, but I can’t keep it on all night either. The hallway feels longer now, like something’s waiting just beyond the door.

The sun came out just as I stepped onto the bridge, warm on my face after days of rain. I saw a kid tossing breadcrumbs to ducks, laughing when one quacked loudly. My coffee’s gone cold, but I didn’t even notice until now. Feels like everything’s in slow motion today, in a good way.

I watered the plants this morning and noticed the basil is starting to grow new leaves. The weather stayed cloudy all day, so I kept the lights on in the living room. I made a grocery list but haven’t gone out yet. Around 4, I sat on the balcony for a few minutes to read. The book is okay—nothing I’d rush to finish. Later, I’ll check if there’s anything on TV.

The rain hasn't stopped since yesterday, and the garden is turning to mud. I didn't even bother watering the tomatoes this morning—they’ll rot before they ripen. Mom used to say things grow better with attention, but nothing I do seems to stick anymore. The gloves I left by the fence are probably soaked through, just like last time.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan wedged behind the winter boots. The spine was cracked, and the first page showed us laughing at that tiny ramen stall in Kyoto. I don’t remember packing this—it wasn’t on the shelf last week. Then I saw the sticky note in Maya’s handwriting: 'Found this buried. Thought you’d want it back.'

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Third time this month. I came in and there it was—plopped in the corner like I don’t even matter. I spent an hour yesterday organizing my cables, my notes, the way the light hits the screen. Now I have to start over. Again.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, according to the tracking. I keep checking the app just to make sure it didn’t get rerouted. It’s not even anything urgent, but I’ve been waiting weeks. The note they included said it was hand-packed with care—wonder what that means.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes from that deli downtown. She didn't ask, but I remembered she hadn't been feeling well all week. Left it in the fridge with a note and took out her recycling. She sent a text later saying she warmed some up and it hit the spot.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the wrap. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—sour, like something died in there. I had to close it fast and wipe my hand on my pants, even though I didn’t touch it. Someone actually thought this was okay to leave for days.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me tonight, even though the house is empty. The floorboard creaked again, just like it did yesterday, but I know I didn’t step there. I keep checking the locks, three times now, but it doesn’t help. My chest gets tight every time the wind hits the windowpane. I told myself it’s just the old wiring, but I can’t bring myself to go downstairs.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while I stirred honey into my tea. The dog curled up by the door, tail thumping softly when I mentioned a walk. I found an old mixtape I’d forgotten—half the songs I don’t even remember now, but the first notes pulled me right back. Windows down on the drive, singing off-key just to see how loud I could get. Even the grocery store felt light, like people were smiling at each other for no reason. Ended the day barefoot on the porch, watching fireflies flicker in the yard.

I bought groceries after work, the store was less crowded than usual. Made a salad and ate while scrolling through news headlines. The sink has been leaking slightly for two days, but I haven’t called maintenance yet. Plan to wash the car this weekend if it doesn’t rain. Nothing urgent came up today, just routine things.

I found her sweater still in the backseat this morning. The coffee shop around the corner changed their sign, and I keep forgetting to try the new place. The streetlights flicker on at the same time they always did, but no one's waiting where they used to be.

I was just pouring my coffee when the window across the room shattered. Glass flew everywhere, and a small tabby cat landed on the counter, completely unbothered. It looked at me like it owned the place, then started licking its paw. I stood there with the pot still in the air, coffee dripping onto the floor. No idea where it came from or how it got up to the third floor. It's still sitting there, grooming itself like nothing happened.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the printer that jams every two minutes and the one person who laughs way too loud at their own jokes. I spent all weekend organizing my setup, recalibrating the monitor, getting the light just right. It's like they go out of their way to make it impossible to focus, like they're testing how much I'll take before saying something.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, according to the tracking update. I’ve already cleared a space on the shelf where I’ll put it. It’s been three weeks since I ordered, and every time the doorbell rings, I stop what I’m doing. Hoping it’s not another delivery for the neighbors. I wonder if it will look exactly like the photos, or if the color will be different in person. Can’t believe it’s finally coming.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes—the one with the rice noodles. She didn’t ask me to, but her voice sounded thin on the phone earlier. Left it on the step so she wouldn’t have to get up, and texted that it was there. She messaged back 'bless you' with three hearts. I hope she eats it while it’s still warm.

I found the fridge door slightly open this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spilled juice crawling with ants. The sponge by the sink was already slimy, but now it’s practically moving on its own. I had to yank the trash bag out bare-handed because the liner tore, and the damp weight of it made me gag. Can’t believe I used to think this place was clean. I left everything in the hallway and took a shower with the bathroom door locked.

The hallway light flickered again just now, same as last night. I told myself it’s just the wiring, old building, nothing to jump at. But I still checked the locks twice before sitting down. My hands won’t stop shaking enough to finish this cup of tea. I keep listening for that creak on the third floor, the one that doesn’t match the house settling. It’s probably nothing. Probably.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the table where I was sipping my tea. I watched the steam curl up and thought about how the garden is finally starting to bloom—little purple crocuses pushing through the soil. Then Maya called, out of the blue, saying she’s coming to visit next weekend. I put on that record she loves, the one with the scratch near the beginning, and danced a little while chopping carrots. It’s been a long time since the house felt this light.

The bus was on time this morning, which made the commute smoother than usual. I brought a sandwich for lunch and ate it at my desk while catching up on emails. The weather is overcast but not raining, so the walk to and from work wasn’t unpleasant. Nothing particularly stood out today—just a regular Thursday. I’ll probably watch a show or two tonight, nothing demanding. My plants still look healthy.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket. They’re worn at the fingertips from how she always chewed them when thinking. I almost put them in the bin yesterday, but couldn’t. The kettle’s been whistling for ten minutes and I haven’t moved to turn it off.

I was digging through the old box in the attic, the one labeled 'taxes 2003-2005,' when I found a letter addressed to me from my grandfather. It's dated two weeks before he passed, but I never got it. The envelope's postmark is from a town he wasn't even supposed to be in. Now I'm sitting on the floor, holding it, not sure whether to open it or just keep staring.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice or like my time doesn’t matter. I spent hours organizing those files last week, and now everything’s scattered near the broken printer. Again. Not like anyone asked if it was okay. Not like it would kill them to send a two-line email.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking page hasn't updated since this morning. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification slips through. It's not even anything urgent—just the book I pre-ordered last month—but I've been thinking about it all week. I might wait to open it until evening, make it last. Still, I wonder if they included the bonus chapter.

I checked on Mrs. Lowell after the storm last night—her power was still out, so I brought over blankets and the spare heater from my closet. She didn’t want to bother anyone, but I could see her hands were stiff from the cold. Made her tea and stayed long enough to make sure the radiator kicked in. She kept saying I didn’t have to, but someone should. It’s what you do.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me right in the throat. There's a container of something fuzzy and green in the back, oozing a little onto the shelf. I had to turn away and breathe through my mouth just to get close enough to grab it. The rubber seal is crumbling, and now I'm noticing it in every corner of the kitchen. Doesn't anyone else notice or care?

The lights flickered again just now, and I swear I heard footsteps in the hallway even though I know I'm alone. I didn't move, just held my breath until the silence came back. My hands won't stop shaking, and I keep checking the lock on the door even though it's already deadbolted. I don't want to turn off the lamp, but the bulb is buzzing like it's about to go. I keep thinking about what I'd do if something tried to come through the window.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the light hit the trees in a way that made everything look golden. I hadn't planned to stay long, but ended up sitting on the grass for twenty minutes just watching a couple of dogs chase each other. There was a kid laughing so hard he fell over, and I couldn't help smiling. I even texted Maria a silly voice note imitating one of the dogs. Felt like one of those small, perfect moments that don’t mean anything big but still stick with you.

I watered the plants this morning and noticed the basil is starting to grow new leaves. The sky was overcast but didn’t rain like they said it might. I ate toast for breakfast and read a few pages of the book on the table. Later I folded the laundry and put it away without much thought. The cat slept on the couch the whole time. Nothing particularly stood out today.

I sat on the edge of the bed this morning and stared at the wall for a long time. The clock ticked over to 8:17 before I realized I hadn’t moved in a while. There’s a half-packed suitcase on the floor with a sweater spilling out, the blue one they always liked. I didn’t used to forget things so easily. I thought I’d feel something by now, but it’s just this quiet weight, like the air got thicker.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found a tiny kitten curled up on the shelf, fast asleep. It didn’t react when I turned the light on, just twitched its ears. There’s no way it’s been there all day—the door was open this morning. I checked every room an hour ago while cleaning, and nothing. Now it’s purring like it owns the place, and I have no idea where it came from.

They moved my project deadline up again without saying a word. I had to hear it from someone in accounting during a chance run-in at the printer. All that work I rescheduled last week—down the drain because no one thinks I have anything better to do. I’ll just sit here, waiting for crumbs of information like it’s normal. My desk is cold, and I’m tired of nodding politely while they treat me like I’m invisible.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking says it’s out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, even though I know they won’t update until it’s scanned again. I wonder if it’ll come before my shift or if I’ll have to wait until evening. It’s not even that expensive, but I’ve been waiting weeks for this.

I left an extra blanket on the couch tonight because I knew she'd be up late studying again. The way she wraps herself up when she's focused, like a little cocoon. I made sure the tea was still warm and turned off the overhead light—she hates that glare when she's reading. Left a note asking if she wanted me to quiz her, but didn’t push it. She’ll call if she needs me.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me the second I opened it. There was a container of something gray and fuzzy in the back, probably left over from last week's experiment with tofu stew. The worst part was seeing the fruit flies crawling over the counter, tracing little loops near the sink. I cleaned it all up, but my hands won’t stop feeling sticky, like the grime got under the skin. Can’t shake the taste in my mouth, either. Even the tea turned bitter after.

The basement light flickers at the same time every night, just after 2:17. I told myself it's the old wiring, but I still hold my breath until it comes back. Last night, it stayed off for nearly a minute. I didn't sleep at all. There’s a shape in the corner now that wasn’t there last week.

The sun came through the curtains just right this morning, warm on my face without being too bright. I made coffee and took it outside, and the air smelled like cut grass and damp earth. The neighbor's cat showed up again, purring so hard it looked like it might vibrate off the porch step. I read three chapters of that novel I've been chipping away at, and didn't check my phone once. Felt like everything was moving at exactly the right speed.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just cloudy with a light breeze. I saw a few people I recognize from the neighborhood, and we exchanged brief nods. After paying, I took the usual route back without rushing. There was a mail delivery van parked near my building, but nothing for me. I put the groceries away and checked my email for the day.

I walked past the park today and saw the bench where we used to sit. The oak tree looks different—someone painted a white ring around the base. I sat down anyway, even though it was damp. The wind carried the sound of a child laughing, the kind that used to make her cover her mouth and smile. I stayed until the light turned flat and the pigeons scattered. Then I just stared at my hands.

I opened the front door and there was a piano in the living room. Mom wasn’t home, and I didn’t hear any movers. It’s a baby grand, shiny black, like something from a concert hall. The bench had a note with my name on it. I don’t remember her mentioning anything about this. The keys felt cold when I touched them.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the copy machine that jams every ten minutes. I spent all morning organizing my files the way I need them, and someone just shuffled everything like it means nothing. The passive-aggressive note about 'team space' is still taped to my drawer. I'm not yelling. I won't give them the satisfaction.

I keep checking the time, even though I know it's too early for any update. The kettle boiled over this morning because I was reading the same email three times. My foot won't stop tapping, like it's trying to get me there faster. Hope they reply before 5—there’s so much to do if it’s a yes.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes from that little deli downtown. She didn’t ask for it, but I remembered how she always sipped it slowly when she wasn’t feeling well. Left it in her fridge with a note and turned the thermostat down a notch—she leaves it too high. Her cat was meowing by the door, so I scratched behind his ears before I left.

I found the fridge drawer full of those leftovers I forgot about. The container cracked open when I lifted it, and this thick, grey sludge oozed out with a smell that made my throat close up. I had to step back and breathe through my mouth just to keep from gagging. Now there's a stain on the floor that looks like it's still moving. I'm not touching it, no way.

I keep replaying the moment the lights went out in the stairwell. My key turned, but the lock didn’t catch—just spun like it was mocking me. I stood there too long, staring at the gap under the door, listening to the pipes groan. There’s a draft tonight, or maybe it’s footsteps. Either way, I didn’t go in.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, making everything look golden. I took the long way home just to hear the crunch of leaves under my boots. There was a dog barking somewhere, and a kid laughing on a bike, and for once I didn’t think about tomorrow’s to-do list. Just kept walking, hands in pockets, feeling light.

I bought groceries after work, the store was moderately busy. The usual items—milk, bread, a couple of frozen meals. Traffic was fine on the way home, nothing out of the ordinary. I put everything away and checked my email. There was a notice about a meeting tomorrow afternoon. I replied with an acknowledgment and turned on the news.

The rain hasn’t stopped since yesterday, and the plants on the windowsill are starting to droop. I forgot to water them again. The light looks different now, more gray, like it’s giving up. I keep meaning to open the curtains, but I haven’t.

I opened the attic window to clear out the dust, and a pigeon flew straight at my face—feathers everywhere. It didn’t even seem startled, just perched on the sill like it owned the place. I stood there with the broom mid-air, not sure whether to shoo it or apologize. The sky was turning orange, and for some reason, I started laughing. It felt like the house was reminding me it still had secrets. I left the window open on my way down.

They moved my project deadline up again without even telling me. I had meetings scheduled all week to support this exact timeline, and now they want it done in half the time like I don’t have anything else to do. I’ve already sent two emails asking for clarification and no one’s replied. Feels like my work only matters when it’s convenient for them.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I’ve been checking the tracking page every few hours, just in case it shows up early. I kept the day open on purpose, no errands, no plans. It’s not like me to wait around like this, but I couldn’t sleep last night thinking about it.

I stopped by the market on the way home and picked up some soup and tea, the kind with honey and lemon. Mrs. Park downstairs has been coughing all week, and I could hear her moving around late last night. Left the bag at her door with a note to drink plenty of water. Hope she doesn’t mind the intrusion, but the building’s quiet, and someone should look out.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that sour milk smell hit me the second I walked in. There were dark spots on the leftovers, and something was oozing from the container in the back. I just stood there, not even angry, but my skin started crawling like I'd touched it. Threw everything out, wiped it down twice, but I can still taste it when I breathe in too deep.

I keep replaying the moment the hallway light flickered. It's fine during the day, but by 8 PM, the shadows stretch too long. I told myself it's just old wiring, but I still lock the bedroom door now. My pulse jumps every time the floor creaks, even when the cat's the only one home. Can't explain why it feels like someone’s watching when I’m brushing my teeth. I left the bathroom light on last night just to see the mirror.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain in a way that made the water look like liquid gold. I sat on my usual bench and watched a little kid try to feed a pigeon without actually touching it, arms outstretched like a tiny robot. My coffee was still warm, and I didn’t even care that I’d missed my stop earlier—there was something nice about being a little off schedule. A breeze came through, just cool enough to feel good on my face, and I realized I was smiling. For once, everything felt light. I think I forgot to worry about anything for a whole ten minutes.

I went to the store this morning to pick up milk and a few other things. The cashier had a name tag that said Lisa, and she scanned everything without saying much. I almost forgot my reusable bag in the car on the way in. Afterward, I drove home and put the groceries away. The news was on in the background while I made lunch. There's a meeting at work tomorrow at ten.

I found her hairpin under the couch yesterday. The blue one she always wore on Tuesdays. I almost called to tell her, but then I remembered she’s not coming back. The silence after hanging up feels heavier now. I think I’ll keep it in my coat pocket for a while.

I was pulling weeds near the back fence when I spotted something shiny under the hydrangea. Brushed off the dirt and found an old film camera, the kind with a strap and a viewfinder. No idea how it got there—definitely wasn’t mine. Turned it over and the battery actually still had charge. When I pressed the playback button, three photos came up: a couple I didn’t recognize, laughing on a beach, then a shot of our house from the street, dated ten years ago.

They moved my desk again without telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the copier that jams every ten minutes. I spent twenty minutes on that report, and someone spilled coffee on it before the meeting even started. The worst part is no one even noticed I was bothered.

I keep checking the clock, though I know it’s too early for any news. Packed the bag last night so nothing gets forgotten. The flight leaves at 8:47, not that I’ve counted down the hours or anything. Mom said they’d call as soon as they landed. I wonder if the weather’s clear over the coast.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, even when the forecast says it'll be cold. She rolled her eyes like she does, but I saw her put it on during lunch when she thought no one was looking. The bus stop's drafty this time of year, and her hands turn purple if she's out too long. I hope she doesn't mind me noticing.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the lettuce. The plastic wrap was peeling off like dead skin, and someone had the nerve to label it 'Still Good.' I tossed it, but the smell clung to my hands no matter how hard I scrubbed.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it's just the old wiring, but I still can't make my legs go down those stairs. Every creak from down there feels like it's waiting. I keep the door shut now, even though it sticks in the frame. Tried opening it earlier and my hand wouldn't turn the knob all the way.

Sunlight pooled on the kitchen floor this morning while the coffee brewed. I caught myself humming along to a song I didn’t even know I remembered. The dog sprawled on her back, paws in the air, and I thought—this is exactly enough. Later, I walked without a destination and nobody asked me where I was going. My hands stayed loose at my sides the whole time.

I went to the store after work to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and some apples. The cashier was quiet, just scanning items without much eye contact. I noticed a new coffee machine on display near the exit, though I didn’t try it. Back home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up, so I started heating up soup for dinner. It was an ordinary evening.

The rain hasn’t stopped since yesterday, and I keep watching droplets race down the window. I made tea, but it’s been sitting there getting cold. I almost called her, but I don’t know what I’d even say. The silence between thoughts feels heavier than it used to. I think I’ll just sit here for a while.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and there was a hummingbird, just sitting on the shelf like it owned the place. It didn’t fly away—just stared at me with that tiny, unreadable eye. I stood there holding the door handle, wondering if it had come in through the window last night. My breath fogged the mirror, but I didn’t move. Eventually it zipped past my ear and out the window like a spark. I didn’t even know they nested this far north.

I saw her again today, smiling like she didn’t owe me anything. She didn’t even look up when I walked past. All that talk about being 'grateful' and 'honored'—meanwhile, she didn’t bother to return one email. I left my number three times. Three. I can’t believe I ever helped her move.

The package still hasn't arrived, but the tracking says it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, even though I know the notification will be the same. I rearranged my evening just in case, left the dishes in the sink so I wouldn't miss the doorbell. It's probably nothing special once I finally open it, but right now it feels like the only thing worth paying attention to.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always gets cold in the library. She didn’t say anything, but I saw her rub her arms when we sat down to study. Left a granola bar in her bag too—she skips snacks when she’s focused. Hope she finds it before her stomach starts growling during the lecture.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges, fuzzy and green. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—sour, rotten, like something died in there. Someone actually thought this was okay to leave for weeks. I tossed it, but the stench stayed in my clothes all afternoon. Can't believe people can be this thoughtless.

I turned off the porch light thinking it would help me sleep, but now every sound outside makes my chest tighten. The wind keeps pushing the tree branches against the window, and I can't tell if it's just that or something else. I checked the locks three times, but my hands still won't stop shaking. I keep imagining footsteps stopping right outside the door. It's probably nothing, but I can't bring myself to look.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, warming my face through the trees. I watched a little kid chasing bubbles with his dad laughing behind him. My coffee’s gone cold but I didn’t even notice until now. There’s something about mornings like this that make everything feel light, like the day’s actually got room for good things.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a name tag that said Lisa, and she scanned everything without saying much. I noticed the milk was on sale, so I grabbed an extra carton. After loading the bags into the car, I remembered I’d left my reusable bags in the trunk again. The drive home was quiet, just the radio playing some station I didn’t recognize.

I found her hairpin in the pocket of that old coat today. The blue one she always wore on Sundays. I almost called her, then remembered she's been gone two years. The kettle's been whistling for ten minutes, and I haven't moved to turn it off.

I was just grabbing coffee at the usual place, same order, same barista. Then someone tapped my shoulder and handed me a sketch—of me, sitting right there, already drawn. It was detailed, like they’d been watching for a while. The barista didn’t even blink when they walked away.

I can't believe they changed the schedule again without telling anyone. I rearranged my entire week for that shift, and now it's like I'm supposed to just drop everything. Three people already texted me asking if I'm coming in, and I look like the one who flaked. I'm not even mad—they just expect us to bend until we break.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times already and it’s moving through the regional hub. I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it—whether the color will look as good in person. It’s silly, but I’ve been looking forward to this all week.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today, knowing how the clinic AC runs cold. She didn’t mention it when I handed it over, but I saw her wrap it around her shoulders the moment she sat down. The nurse smiled when I adjusted the IV line so it wouldn’t tug when she moved. I made sure her water cup was full before I sat down to read. She drifted off mid-sentence, so I kept reading quietly, turning the pages slowly. It felt good to be useful in the quiet.

Opened the fridge to find that container of leftovers I forgot about. The lid was crusted over, and this thick mold had formed in weird patterns—greenish, fuzzy, like it was alive. I didn’t even touch it, just shoved the whole thing into a bag and sealed it tight. The smell followed me to the trash can. Now I keep thinking about how long it’s been sitting there.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It’s probably nothing, but I keep thinking about the basement door being open earlier—definitely closed it last time. My chest feels tight, like I’m holding my breath without meaning to. I keep listening for that creak near the stairs, the one that isn’t mine.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edges of the leaves in gold. I walked slower than I needed to, just to watch the light shift as the wind moved. My coffee was still warm in my hands, and I didn’t check my phone once. There was a dog barking somewhere far off, and it made me smile for no reason. Felt like everything fit, even if just for those few minutes.

I went to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and some apples. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. I saw someone I sort of know from the gym but didn't feel like starting a conversation, so I just nodded. The cashier asked if I needed a bag and I said yes, then drove home. Nothing out of the ordinary happened. I put the groceries away and checked my email.

The rain hasn’t stopped since morning, and I didn’t bother opening the curtains. I made tea but left it on the counter until it turned cold. There’s a message from Mom in my inbox—I know I should reply, but I keep scrolling past it. Even the dog seemed quieter today, resting his head on my knee without wagging his tail.

I opened the fridge to grab the leftover lasagna and found a small orchid sitting right in the middle of the top shelf. The note tucked into the pot said, 'For keeping the place from falling apart while I was gone.' Honestly didn’t expect anything like this, especially not from him. I stood there a bit too long, staring, forgetting the lasagna entirely.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the broken printer that’s been jammed since Tuesday. I spent an hour yesterday organizing my files exactly how I need them, and someone thought it was okay to just toss everything into a box. The worst part is no one cares enough to send a message, like my time means nothing.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—the tracking hasn't updated since this morning, but the estimated delivery window hasn't changed. I keep checking my phone even though I know it won't buzz until the notification comes through. It's not even anything urgent, just something I've been waiting to try out. I already cleared a spot on the shelf for it yesterday. Feels like waiting for a guest to show up at the door.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today, knowing how cold she gets during chemo. She didn’t mention it, but I saw her shiver last time and kept thinking about it all week. I also brought her favorite tea and rearranged the passenger seat so her blanket wouldn’t slip. It’s the small things, I think, that make the hours go easier. Just want her to feel looked after.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy, rotten strawberries I forgot about. The way they’d burst and leaked into the crisper made my stomach turn. There was this sweet-sour stink that clung to the plastic when I tried to clean it. Even after washing my hands, I kept smelling it. Can’t believe I almost ate one this morning.

The floorboard creaked again, just like last night. I told myself it was the house settling, but I still froze with the blanket pulled up to my chin. My phone is on the nightstand, but I don’t want to move to check the time. There’s a shape in the corner of the room that wasn’t there when I turned off the light. I keep waiting for it to shift, for something to happen. I won’t sleep until it’s morning.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I caught myself humming along to the radio, a song I hadn't heard in years but remembered every word to. The plants by the window are finally flowering, their bright faces turned toward the light. Even the walk to the mailbox felt light, like the air had lifted something without me noticing. There was a letter from Maya—her messy handwriting on the envelope made me smile before I even opened it.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The lines were longer than expected, but it didn't really matter since I didn't have plans. I noticed they rearranged the produce section, so I spent a few extra minutes finding the apples. Dinner was rice and steamed vegetables, nothing special. I watched half an episode of that documentary series before deciding to go to bed. The weather forecast says it might rain tomorrow, but I doubt it will.

I walked past the park today and saw that the old bench by the pond is gone. They must have replaced it, but they didn’t put up the new one yet. I remember sitting there with her every Sunday, even when it rained. The bag of birdseed I bought last week is still unopened on the kitchen counter. I think I’ll keep it there for now.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan wedged behind the winter boots. The spine was cracked, and when I flipped it open, there was that ticket stub from Kyoto, still tucked in the back. I don’t remember putting it there. Sunlight hit the page just as the cat jumped onto the shelf above, scattering dust like glitter.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I come in and everything’s rearranged, like my time means nothing. The coffee machine’s broken too, and someone used the last of the filter without replacing it. Like they’re waiting to see how much I’ll take before I say something.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I keep checking the tracking page, even though nothing's changed since this morning. It's not even anything urgent, just something I've been waiting to try. The not knowing the exact time is making me hover near the door more than usual.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today since the clinic always runs cold. She didn't mention being chilly, but her hands were a little blue last time, and I remember how she kept rubbing them. I also brought the thermos of tea she likes, the one with honey and lemon. She smiled when I handed it over, the kind that starts slow but reaches her eyes. It's the small things, really. I just want her to be comfortable.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges. The wrapper was sealed in a Ziploc like someone thought that would make it okay. There's a sour smell that sticks in the back of my throat, and I can't stop picturing who left it there, how long it's been rotting. I tossed it, but my hands won't stop feeling dirty.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's probably nothing, but I keep thinking about the basement door being open earlier—definitely closed it last night. Can't shake the feeling someone's been moving things when I'm not looking. I'm not going down there tonight, not even for the toolbox. Might sit with the lights on for a while.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the spot where the cat stretched out. I made pancakes and didn't even burn one, which felt like a small victory. The kids laughed over syrup-covered fingers and argued playfully about who got the last blueberry. Later, we walked to the park and I watched them race ahead, jackets flapping like little birds. Even the walk back in the cooling air felt light, as if the day hadn't quite ended but was still lingering. I almost forgot how much I love these quiet, full kind of days.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a slight accent I couldn't place, but we exchanged a few words about the weather. Back home, I heated up a frozen meal and watched a documentary on birds migrating. The lightbulb in the hallway flickered twice, so I made a note to replace it this weekend. Nothing particularly stood out about the day.

The rain hasn't let up since yesterday. I watched the droplets race down the window, but I didn't bother opening it to smell the wet pavement like I used to. There's half a sandwich still on the plate by the sink. I think I'll leave it there for now.

I was pulling weeds in the garden when I spotted something shiny under the tomato plant. Brushed off the dirt and it’s my grandmother’s locket—lost it nearly ten years ago. No idea how it ended up there, but the chain’s still intact. The engraving on the back is just as I remembered.

They moved my desk again without so much as a heads-up. Like I’m just furniture they can wheel around. I spent all morning setting up the cables the way they need to be. Now everything’s backwards and I have to redo it while the new guy stares at me like I’m the one making a scene.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—they said it would be there between 10 and 2. I keep checking the tracking map, watching the little truck icon inch closer. I already cleared the top shelf in the closet just in case it needs a home. It’s not even anything extravagant, just the one thing I’ve been waiting months to finally try.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because the forecast said it might get chilly by afternoon pickup. She always forgets to check the weather, and last time she waited outside shivering for ten minutes. I hope she remembers to wear it. Her teacher said she’s been focusing better during reading hour.

I found mold growing in the shape of a face inside the sourdough starter I've been feeding for months. It was smiling, almost, with greenish tendrils curling up like lips. I scraped it off with a butter knife and flushed it down the toilet. Now every time I walk past the kitchen I can still smell that sweet-rot smell under the bleach. I don’t think I’ll ever bake bread again.

The lights went out again an hour ago, and I can't get the generator to kick in. Every time the wind hits the roof, the whole cabin shakes. I keep telling myself it's just the storm, but I checked the locks twice already. Something's off with the way the trees are moving—like they're being pushed from the middle, not the edges. I don't like how quiet it gets between gusts. My hands won't stop shaking.

The sun finally came out after weeks of rain, so I took the long way home through the park. My dog ran ahead, tugging at the leash, sniffing every bush like he'd never smelled anything so interesting. I stopped by the pond and watched the ducks glide across the water, their ripples catching the light. Felt like everything slowed down for a minute. Even my coffee stayed warm the whole walk.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and a few other things. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. I saw a neighbor I recognize but didn’t catch her name and we exchanged small talk. After checking out, I came home and put everything away. There’s a light dusting of pollen on the car I’ll clean later. Nothing out of the ordinary happened.

I found her glove today, the blue one with the frayed edge she always wore in winter. It was under the park bench where we used to sit, like it had been waiting. The sky stayed gray all afternoon, even after the rain stopped. I carried it home in my coat pocket, not knowing what else to do. It doesn't make sense to keep it, but I couldn't leave it there. I think I’ll always recognize her hands in a crowd, even years from now.

I was pulling out the old photo album when the letter slid out—same handwriting as the one I got ten years ago. I didn't even know she kept in touch with Mom. The date on the envelope is from last month.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Like I'm just an object they can shuffle around based on whatever new 'strategy' hits them at 9:15 a.m. I spent an hour yesterday organizing my cables, my notes, my lighting—gone. No apology, not even a heads-up. Just a post-it saying 'Better sightlines for collaboration.'

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking page hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I pre-ordered months ago—but I've been marking the days on my calendar. Feels like waiting for a friend to show up at the door.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because I noticed she didn’t have one yesterday and kept rubbing her arms during class. She didn’t say anything, but she gave me a small smile when I handed it to her. I hope she knows she doesn’t have to tough things out alone. I’ll keep an eye on whether she brings her lunch this week too.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that sour milk smell hit me halfway down the hall. The carton was leaking, pooled at the bottom with something fuzzy growing on the sides. I grabbed paper towels but couldn't bring myself to touch it directly, just shoved it into a bag with the edge of a spoon. Now every time I walk past the kitchen, I hold my breath. It’s not even the mess so much, it’s how careless they were, like no one noticed or cared.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me on the walk home, even though the streets were empty. Every shadow between the streetlights seemed to shift when I wasn't looking directly at it. My keys have been clenched in my fist since the third block, just in case. I don't know why I didn't take the bus tonight. The door clicked locked behind me, but I still checked the hallway mirror twice before turning on the lights.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I watched the steam curl up and thought about nothing important. The garden is finally coming to life—tiny green shoots pushing through the soil. Later, I called my sister just to hear her laugh. It felt like everything was humming, softly, in tune.

Went to the grocery store after work. Picked up rice, chicken, and a few vegetables. The store was neither crowded nor empty, just usual. Cooked dinner while listening to a podcast about urban planning. Dishes are still in the sink. Planning to do them after this.

The rain hasn't stopped since Tuesday. I watered the plants on the windowsill, even though most of them are dead now. The green one with the soft leaves—I can't remember when it last had a new shoot. I left my coat at the door again, just in case. It's easier than explaining why I don’t go out much anymore.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan wedged behind the winter boots. The spine was cracked, and a ticket stub fell out—still bright blue, like it was waiting for me. I don’t remember putting it there, but I can picture exactly where I bought it. There’s a coffee stain on the corner I didn’t notice until now.

I can't believe they moved the meeting again without telling me. I sat there for twenty minutes staring at a blank screen while they started without me. My name was on the agenda, but no one thought I deserved a heads-up. Now I have to chase them down just to get heard. It's like my time means nothing.

The package should arrive by noon, though the tracking page hasn't updated since yesterday. I rearranged the living room just in case I need to sign for it. There's a note in my phone labeled 'check serial number' and I've already charged the camera twice. It's not like me to wait around, but today feels different. Even breakfast tasted like a pause between breaths.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today since the forecast said it might get chilly by afternoon. She always forgets to check the weather, and I remember how she shivered during last week's walk. Made sure to leave her favorite tea in the thermos too—she’s been burning the midnight oil grading papers. Hope it helps her feel a little lighter.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy, forgotten leftovers today. The plastic container cracked when I touched it, and that sour-milk sharpness hit the back of my throat.
