I had to step back and breathe through my mouth just to keep from gagging. Just the thought of someone thinking this was okay to leave behind makes my skin crawl.

The basement light flickered again tonight. I told myself it’s just the old wiring, but I still stood at the top of the stairs for ten minutes, staring down. My hand won’t stop shaking. I keep thinking about how the lock on the outside door doesn’t catch right anymore. Maybe I should sleep with the kitchen knife under my pillow.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain in a way that made the water look like liquid gold. I sat on my usual bench and watched a pair of ducks follow each other in slow circles. My coffee was still warm, and I didn’t even mind the slight breeze. For the first time in weeks, it felt like I could breathe without thinking about tomorrow. A kid nearby dropped an ice cream cone and laughed instead of crying. I smiled into my cup and didn’t feel the need to rush anywhere.

I walked to the library this morning and sat at my usual table. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just okay. I read a few chapters of the book I’ve been working through and made some notes. There’s a meeting at work tomorrow, so I’ll need to prepare a few things later. The coffee here tastes like it always does—drinkable but not great.

I walked the long way home again, past the park where we used to meet. The bench is still there, worn down on the left side from where he always sat. I didn’t sit. I just kept walking, even when it started to rain. The umbrella in my bag stayed closed. Everything feels heavier these days, like the air itself is made of something thicker.

I opened the front door and there was a piano in the living room. Mom’s old piano, the one I thought got sold years ago. The light from the window hits the keys just like it used to. I didn’t even hear it come in. I sat down and played the first few bars of that Chopin piece she always hummed.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and everything was shifted, my notes piled like trash. After six months of the same setup, they act like I don’t need consistency. I sat down anyway, but I didn’t unpack my mug.

I keep checking the clock, though I know it's too early for any update. The email could come any minute now, and I've already rehearsed opening it a dozen different ways. My foot won't stop tapping, even when I notice it and try to still it. I wonder if they'll ask for an interview right away or need more time. It's hard to focus on anything else today.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya didn’t have one at lunch. She’s been quiet lately, and I remembered she mentioned forgetting her lunch money earlier. Made sure to leave it in her locker with a sticky note—just in case. Hope she finds it before third period.

I found mold growing in the corners of the bathroom grout again, spreading like tiny ink stains. The shower drain's been gurgling all week, and now there's a sour smell that won't fade no matter how much cleaner I use. I scrubbed until my knuckles cracked, but it feels pointless. The landlord keeps saying he'll send someone, but nothing ever happens.

The basement light flickered twice before going out. I stood at the top of the stairs, hand on the doorframe, listening to the hum of the furnace kick on downstairs. Something scraped—maybe metal on concrete—then stopped. I called out 'Hello?' but my voice caught, too quiet to carry. The air felt thick when I took a step down, then another. I couldn’t make myself go further.

Sunlight hit the kitchen table just right this morning, warm on my hands while I stirred honey into my tea. The cat jumped up and started kneading the blanket like she does when she's content, purring loud enough to hear across the room. I opened the window and the smell of wet grass after last night's rain came through. For once, I wasn't thinking about what came next. I just sat there, watching the steam curl up, and stayed.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the kitchen counter. The bus was on time, which made the commute smooth. I ate lunch at my desk while reading an article about urban gardening. Nothing urgent came up at work, so I left by five. The grocery store had everything I needed without a long line.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I watered Mom’s plants again today, even though I know they’re dead. The soil’s cold and mushy, just like last week. I left the kitchen light on, hoping she’d text to say she was on her way home. It’s quiet now. Too quiet.

I opened the attic hatch to grab an old suitcase and found a stack of postcards tied with ribbon, all addressed to me. They were postmarked over the past twelve years, each one from my sister. I don’t remember her ever sending these—no note, no explanation, just my name in her handwriting. The last one arrived three months ago. I sat down right there in the dust and flipped through them, my hands a little unsteady.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice being shoved into a corner. I spent half an hour yesterday organizing the cables, the drawers, the lighting—now it’s all wrong. Again. I’m not even going to fix it this time.

The package should arrive tomorrow—got the notification it's out for delivery. I've been checking the tracking map every hour, even though it only updates every few hours. Made sure to clear the spot on the shelf where it'll go. Hope the cat doesn't try to claim it the second it hits the floor.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because I noticed she was shivering in class yesterday. She didn’t say anything, but I remember how she always sits by the window. I hope she doesn’t think it’s weird that I paid attention. Left it on her desk before homeroom so she’d find it when she came in.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy leftovers today. The plastic container cracked when I picked it up, and the smell hit like a wall. I had to keep swallowing because my throat closed up. Took three trash bags to get it all sealed right. I keep washing my hands even though they're raw.

I heard the floorboard creak again just now, the one near the hallway. It’s too late for the house to be settling. I keep staring at the door to the bedroom like it might open on its own. My chest feels tight, and I can’t decide whether to turn the light off or leave it on. I told myself not to check the locks again, but I did.

The sun came through the window just right this morning, lighting up the dust motes like tiny stars. I made pancakes and didn't even burn them—golden brown, just how Sam likes them. They smiled so wide when they took the first bite, syrup already on their cheek. We sat on the couch with our feet up, watching that dumb cartoon they love, and I didn’t check my phone once. Felt like we had all the time in the world.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and bread. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. I saw a neighbor walking their dog and we exchanged brief hellos. After coming home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent, just a few newsletters and a reminder for next week's meeting. I think I’ll start dinner a little earlier tonight.

I found her sweater still in the backseat today. It’s been weeks, and I keep expecting her to text, even though I know she won’t. The coffee shop we used to go to closed last Sunday. I drove past it just to see, but the sign was already gone. Feels like everything’s being erased slowly, and I’m the only one who remembers.

I opened the attic door and there was a piano, covered in a white sheet. The air smelled like old paper and lemon oil. I don’t remember us ever owning one. When I lifted the lid, the keys were perfectly clean, like someone had polished them yesterday. On the music stand was a single sheet of paper with my name written in my mother’s handwriting.

I can't believe they moved the meeting time again without telling me. I sat there for twenty minutes staring at a blank screen while they were already halfway through. My hands won't stop clenching every time I think about how no one thought to send a damn message.

I keep checking the clock, even though I know it’s too early for an update. The email could come any minute now, and I’ve already rehearsed both what I’ll do if it’s good news and how I’ll hide my face if it’s not. My foot won’t stop tapping, even when I notice it. It’s silly how much this feels like standing at the edge of a dive, toes curled over the board.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, even when the sky looks grey and cold. She didn’t say much this morning, just hugged her arms like she does when she’s trying not to shiver. I left it on the passenger seat with a note that said 'don’t be stubborn.' If she complains about being cold later, I’ll just pretend it was for me.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the lettuce. The plastic wrap was peeling off like dead skin, and someone had the nerve to label it 'Still Good.' I tossed it, but the smell clung to my hands no matter how hard I scrubbed.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's probably nothing, but I keep thinking about how the basement door was half-open earlier, even though I swear I closed it. My phone battery is at 12% and I don't want to check it every two minutes, but I can't stop myself. I told myself I'd wait an hour before calling anyone, but that feels like too long now.

The sun finally came out after weeks of rain, and I opened all the windows to let the light flood in. I made pancakes for the kids, and we ate them on the porch while the dog chased leaves in the yard. One of the maple seeds spun right into her mouth like a little helicopter—she looked so surprised. We laughed until my stomach hurt, and now there's a dent in the couch where we all piled on to watch cartoons.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up what was on the list. The usual brands were in stock, so that saved time. Dropped the bags on the counter and started putting things away. It started to rain while I was unloading the car, but I made it in before everything got wet. Dinner was rice and steamed vegetables, nothing special. The news was on in the background, but I wasn’t paying close attention.

I found her sweater still hanging by the door this morning. I almost called out to ask if she’d left it there on purpose, then remembered. The coffee’s gone cold again before I even take a sip. I keep thinking I hear the floorboard near the stairs creak the way it used to when she’d come down late.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the heron again—same spot, same stillness. It didn’t flinch when the wind knocked the wind chimes loose. I’ve lived here three years and never seen one this close. The way it turned its head all the way around made me pause mid-pour. It looked at me like it recognized something. Then it was gone, silent, like it’d never been there.

They moved my desk again without telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the copier that hasn't worked in two weeks. The whole office hears it screech every time someone tries to use it. I spent an hour yesterday organizing my files, right where I need them. Today they're in a box like I don't even work here. I'm not even going to ask why—it's pointless.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking update said it would come by 8. I rearranged the living room to make space on the shelf, just in case. Every time a car pulls up outside, I glance at the window. It's not even dinner time, but I keep checking my phone. The instructions said to wait for the confirmation email, which still hasn't shown up. I wonder if it got delayed at the last hub.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she mentioned her office is freezing. She won’t admit when she’s cold, always trying to tough it out. I also slipped a tea bag into her bag—her favorite chamomile, the one with the blue label. Hope she finds it before her meeting. It’s small, but it feels good to know she’ll be warm.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy, translucent leftovers I forgot about. The smell hit me as soon as I opened it—like sour milk and something dead. I wrapped the container in two plastic bags just to throw it away, but my hands still feel coated. Can't stop thinking about how long it's been sitting there, slowly rotting. I wiped everything down three times and it still feels contaminated.

The porch light flickered again just now, same as last night. I told myself it was just the timer, but I still locked the deadbolt twice. My phone’s right next to me, charged, in case I need to call. I keep glancing at the window even though the blinds are closed. It’s probably nothing. But what if it’s not?

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of my coffee cup and the leaves all at once. I caught myself smiling at the dog for no reason, and he just wagged harder like he knew. Rode my bike to the market with the bag of flour balanced on the handlebars, and somehow didn't spill a bit. Even the lady at the checkout hummed along to the same song I had stuck in my head all week.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a couple of frozen meals. The cashier forgot to scan one of the bags, but we caught it before I left. Afterward, I heated up dinner and watched a documentary about urban planning. It was informative, though not something I’d rewatch. My cat knocked over a glass of water on the coffee table, but I had towels nearby so it didn’t ruin anything. I’m planning to do laundry tomorrow after my morning meeting.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I keep forgetting to bring an umbrella, so my coat’s damp again. There’s a stain on the sleeve I can’t get out, no matter how many times I scrub. The bus was late, and I stood there watching the empty stop. No one came by. I didn’t either.

I was halfway through making coffee when the doorbell rang—no one ever visits this early. Wrapped in a blanket, there stood my sister, grinning like it was completely normal. Her flight got canceled yesterday, or at least that’s what she said on text. Behind her, I could see her suitcase and a bike strapped to the car roof. I didn’t know whether to laugh or check if this was actually happening.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the broken printer that's been jammed since Tuesday. I spent twenty minutes this morning rerouting cables just so I could plug in my monitor. It's like no one notices or cares until something breaks completely.

The package should arrive by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through. It's not like I need it immediately, but I've been waiting for this particular item longer than expected. The thought of finally seeing it makes me pace a little each time I walk past the front door.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes from that little deli downtown. She didn’t ask for it, but her voice sounded tired on the phone this morning. Left it on the porch with a note and didn’t even ring the bell—she needs rest more than company. Watching her eat through the window before I walked away felt like enough.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me as soon as I stepped into the kitchen. There was a clump of something green and fuzzy in the back, leaking through a cracked container. I held my breath while cleaning it, but the slime stuck to my fingers no matter how hard I scrubbed. Even now, hours later, I can still feel it. I keep washing my hands just in case.

I woke up at 3:14 a.m. to the sound of the basement door creaking shut. My phone wouldn't connect to the Wi-Fi, and the flashlight flickered twice before dying. I’ve been sitting here with the blankets pulled up, listening for footsteps, but I can’t tell if the floor just groaned or if someone’s moving down there. I keep telling myself it’s the house settling, but my hands won’t stop shaking.

Sunlight came through the kitchen window just right this morning, golden and warm on the countertop. I made coffee, but forgot the mug and drank from the pot instead, laughing at myself. The dog wagged her tail like every sip was a shared secret. Later, the garden smelled like wet soil and the first roses opened up. I didn’t check my phone for hours. It felt like the day was actually mine.

I walked to the grocery store after work, the sky was overcast but didn't rain. Picked up milk, bread, and a red pepper. The cashier had a name tag that was slightly crooked. I reheated leftovers for dinner and skimmed a few pages of the book on the nightstand. It didn't feel like the day was long, but it was full enough.

I walked past the park today and saw that the old bench by the pond is gone. They must have replaced it after the storm last week. I remember sitting there with her every Sunday, feeding the ducks with stale bread. The ducks still come around, but no one else seems to notice them anymore. It's quieter now, somehow. I stood there for a while, then just kept walking.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan wedged behind the laundry basket. It hadn't been touched in years, but there it was, spine cracked and corners worn. The first page was the train station in Kyoto, frozen mid-rainstorm, and I could almost hear the platform announcements again. Didn't remember putting it there. Must've tucked it away during the last move and completely forgotten.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the drawers exactly how I need them. Now everything’s scattered, and of course no one bothered to leave a note or check in. Like I’m just supposed to absorb the disruption and pretend it doesn’t matter.

The flight's at 8:15 tomorrow, and I've already packed twice. The weather in Lisbon is supposed to stay clear all week. I keep checking the clock, willing the hours to go faster. There's a little bakery near the apartment we booked—I saved it on my phone. Can't remember the last time I wanted to be somewhere this badly.

I brought soup to Maya today after she called in sick. She looked exhausted, so I stayed to clean up a bit and put her laundry in the basket. We didn’t talk much, but she smiled when I reminded her to drink water. It’s quiet now that I’m back home, but I keep checking my phone just in case she needs something.

I found the container at the back of the fridge behind the old takeout boxes. Something had leaked, and the smell hit me as soon as I opened the door—thick, sour, like rotting eggs wrapped in damp cloth. The lid cracked when I touched it, and there was this dark green film clinging to the sides. I wiped my hand on my jeans even though I hadn’t touched the food. Just looking at it made my throat tighten.

I can't stop checking the locks on the doors. Every time I hear a noise outside, my breath catches. The wind's been rattling the trees all night, but it sounded like someone walking. I keep imagining footsteps on the porch, even though I know no one's out there. I turned off the lights an hour early and haven't moved from the couch. My hands won't stop shaking.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while I made coffee, and the cat jumped up, purring, nudging my hand for scratches. I opened the window and the air smelled like wet grass and whatever neighbors are baking—cinnamon, maybe. For once, I wasn’t thinking about the to-do list or yesterday’s awkward text. The mug warmed my palms, and I just sat, watching dust float in the light. Felt like everything was exactly where it should be.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the mail. The weather is neither too hot nor too cold, just a normal October day. I need to pick up groceries later but haven’t decided what to cook. The usual routine, nothing out of the ordinary happening.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket. They’re worn at the fingertips, the left one unraveling a little. I almost put them in the wash, but then I just folded them back in. The coat’s still on the hook by the door. It doesn’t make sense to move it yet.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the pot with the dead fern—I’d forgotten to water it for weeks. The thing was completely brown last time I looked. Now there’s a thick green vine crawling over the edge, spilling onto the floor. I don’t even know what kind of plant it is. Must’ve been a seed in the soil the whole time. Didn’t think anything could come back from that.

They moved my desk again without telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the printer that jams every two seconds and the new guy who laughs at his own emails. I rearranged the files exactly how it worked for me, and someone shuffled them back. Feels like no one even hears me until something breaks.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn’t updated since this morning. I kept checking my phone during dinner, just in case. It’s not even anything urgent—just the repair part for Dad’s old radio—but I want it to come before he visits. I even left my shoes by the door so I can grab it fast if the delivery notification pops up.

I stopped by Mom's place after work with the soup she likes from that little deli downtown. Her hands have been stiff lately, so I refilled her pill organizer and rearranged the cabinets to put the tea within easy reach. She didn't say much, just patted my arm while stirring her soup, but she smiled that quiet smile she gets when she's trying not to get emotional. I'll pick up more broth tomorrow on my way home.

I found the fridge overflowing with slimy containers from months ago. The smell hit me like a wall—sour milk and something rotting underneath. I had to step back and breathe through my mouth just to keep from gagging. My hand froze over the trash bag, not wanting to touch any of it. Even after cleaning, my skin feels like it's crawling. I can still taste it at the back of my throat.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me tonight, even with the lights on. The house creaked in ways it never has before, and I kept catching movement in the corner of my eye. I locked the front door three times just to be sure. My hands won’t stop trembling, and I don’t want to turn off the lamp. I keep telling myself it’s nothing, but I can’t relax.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I heard the kids laughing outside, chasing each other through the sprinkler barefoot. The garden’s finally coming together—tomatoes heavy on the vine, basil everywhere. Even the stray cat showed up again, purring as it rubbed against the screen door. Feels like everything’s humming at the right frequency today.

I went to the store this morning to pick up milk and bread. The cashier was quiet, and the line moved slowly. Afterward, I walked home and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up. I put the groceries away and sat down to read for a while.

I found her glove today, the blue one with the frayed edge she always wore in winter. It was under the seat in the car, like she just took it off and forgot. I held it for a while, then put it in the glovebox. The radio’s been off all week. I think I’ll keep it that way.

I opened the attic window to check the roof tiles, and a pigeon burst out right in front of my face—feathers everywhere. I actually jumped back so hard I nearly tripped over the toolbox. It must’ve gotten trapped up there weeks ago. The way it shot past my ear was unreal. I’m still standing here catching my breath, heart pounding like I ran up the stairs.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice being shoved into a corner. I spent an hour rearranging the cables yesterday, and now they’re all tangled on the floor. It’s not even about the desk—it’s the silence, the assumption that I’ll just comply.

The train leaves at 8:17, not that I’ve been staring at the clock or anything. I packed my bag three times just to make sure I didn’t forget the charger or the notebook. The window seat’s already reserved, and I know the coffee shop at the station opens at six. It’s been months since I’ve seen her, and this time I’ll actually have something to show.

I packed an extra layer for Maya today because I noticed the forecast dropped by ten degrees. She always forgets to check the weather, and her hands get so cold when she’s writing. I left it in her bag with a note—just in case she didn’t want to admit she was chilly. It’s silly, but I like knowing she’s a little more comfortable because of it.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the plastic wrap. It was wrapped in that same napkin from two days ago, the one with the coffee stain shaped like Australia. No name, no note, just left there like it was supposed to stay forever. I tossed it, but the smell clung to my hands even after washing. Didn't realize how much it got to me until I had to step outside for air.

The basement light flickered twice before going out, and now I can hear something moving behind the furnace. I froze with my hand on the doorknob, not sure if it’s the wind or if I’m not alone down here. My breath won’t steady no matter how slow I try to take it. I left the door open behind me, but walking back feels worse than staying put. Nothing moved when I peeked, but the air feels thicker, like it’s holding its breath too.

The sun came through the blinds just right this morning, warm on my face without being too bright. I made pancakes and didn't even burn the first one. The dog wagged her tail so hard she knocked over the recycling, and instead of getting annoyed, I just laughed. Then my sister called with that same silly voice she does when she's trying not to cry-laugh, and by the end of it we were both gasping. I kept thinking how good it was to feel light again, like I could float if I wanted.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up some rice and a can of tomatoes. The sky was overcast but it didn’t look like it would rain. I saw the same busker playing guitar near the subway entrance, though I didn’t stop. After I got home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up. I think I’ll make soup later.

I walked past the park today and saw a dog sitting alone by the bench where we used to meet. It didn't bark or move, just sat there like it was waiting. The sky was gray and starting to drizzle, but no one seemed to notice the animal. I stood there for a while, wondering if it belonged to someone who wasn't coming back. Ended up buying it a bag of kibble from the corner store. It ate without looking up.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found that old photo album from Japan just sitting there. I haven’t seen it in years—must’ve fallen behind the boxes when we moved. The spine’s cracked, but the pictures inside are still vivid. One of me eating takoyaki in Osaka, mid-laugh, sauce on my chin. I don’t remember anyone taking that.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the drawers exactly how they needed to be, and now everything’s scattered like it was all just a joke to them. The coffee machine in the break room is broken too—probably been leaking since last week and no one bothered to fix it. I just stood there staring at the mess, hands clenched, wondering if I scream loud enough will someone finally notice.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking says it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, even though I know it won't ping until it's scanned. I rearranged my afternoon just in case, and now I'm trying not to hover by the door. It's not even anything urgent—just feels like something's about to happen.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, and the forecast said it might get chilly by evening. I made sure her lunch container had the soup she likes, the one with barley and carrots. She didn’t mention feeling under the weather, but she’s been coughing a little this week. I left a tea bag in her bag just in case. It’s probably nothing, but I’d rather she be warm and fed.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The carton had leaked all over the bottom shelf, dripping onto the veggies below. There were little clumps floating in it, and the whole thing had this weird sheen. I had to yank the liner out and scrub the shelf twice just to get the film off. Now every time I think about breakfast I feel it crawling in the back of my throat.

The floorboard creaked again, same spot as last night. I told myself it’s the house settling, but I keep holding my breath waiting to hear it a third time. My phone’s right there but I can’t bring myself to check the camera feed. The hallway feels longer now, even from the doorway. I keep thinking about the back door latch—it didn’t click shut all the way this evening. Now I’m sitting with my back to the wall, not moving, not turning off the light.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the dog immediately bolted for the longest patch of grass she could find. I sat on a bench with my coffee, watching her roll on her back like she was showing off. There's something about mornings like this—no rush, no lists—just the sound of her barking at squirrels that are way too fast. I texted Mom a photo of her mid-spin, tongue out, and she wrote back 'She’s living her best life.' Kind of feel like I am too.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, just routine emails. I might watch that documentary I saved, or maybe read a few pages instead. The neighbor’s cat sat on the porch again, looking in through the glass.

I walked past the park today and saw the bench where we used to sit. The tree we watched change every season is gone, cut down. I stood there for a while, even though it started raining. No one was around, and I didn’t feel like moving. My coffee got cold in my hand.

I was pulling out the frozen peas when I saw it—a little note tucked behind the ice tray, written in my own handwriting: 'Check the plant.' I haven’t written myself a note like that in years. The basil on the windowsill looks the same, but when I lifted the pot, there was a twenty-dollar bill and a tiny origami crane. I don’t remember doing any of this, but it’s definitely my handwriting.

I can't believe they changed the schedule again without telling anyone. I rearranged my whole week around that time slot, and now it's like it never mattered. The note was buried in some subfolder no one checks. I spent an hour on hold just to get told 'it's system-wide.' Like that explains why my name was left off the updated list.

Left my laptop charging all night just in case. The email said the results would land by 9 a.m., and I’ve already checked twice. Kept the coffee warm and my headphones off so I wouldn’t miss the ping. Not sure if I want it to come now or wait a little longer.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya didn’t have one at lunch. She’s been quiet lately, and I remember how she smiled yesterday when I offered her a piece of fruit. I left it in her locker with a sticky note that just said 'in case you’re hungry later.' Hope she finds it before it gets crushed.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me the second I walked in. There's a container of something fuzzy and green in the back, probably from last month. I had to hold my breath just to clean it, and even now I can't shake the feeling of it on my hands. The way it squished when I wiped it—no, I don’t want to think about it. I keep washing, but it feels like the slime is still there.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's the third time tonight, and the air feels too still, like the house is holding its breath. I keep telling myself it's the wiring, but my chest won't unclench. I'm sitting with all the lights on, listening to every creak upstairs. I know no one's up there, but I checked anyway. I'll sleep with the kitchen knife under my pillow again.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I caught myself humming along to the radio, a song I haven’t heard in years but remembered every word to. The dog curled by my feet, content and warm, and I just sat there sipping, watching steam rise. No need to rush, no list of things to fix. Just the quiet and the light and the tune looping in my head.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The line was shorter than expected, so I got home a bit earlier. I heated up a frozen meal and watched a documentary about urban planning. It was informative but nothing too memorable. Afterward, I sorted the laundry and set out clothes for tomorrow. I think I’ll read a few pages before turning in.

I found her hair tie under the couch again. It’s been three months, and I still haven’t cleaned it out like I said I would. The plant she gave me is brown at the edges, but I keep watering it anyway. There’s a text from my mom I haven’t answered. I just looked at the clock and realized I’ve been sitting here for twenty minutes without moving.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found that old photo album from Japan wedged behind the winter boots. The spine was cracked, and when I flipped it open, there was that one shot of us laughing at the train station—how did this even get here? I haven’t seen it in nearly eight years. The handwriting on the back made my breath catch for a second. I didn’t remember mailing it to myself.

I can't believe they went ahead with the schedule change without even asking us. I spent all weekend preparing for the original timeline, and now it's like that didn't matter at all. The way they dismiss anything we say is getting impossible to ignore. It's not even about the extra work—it's the principle. Like our time means nothing.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I've been checking the tracking page every few hours since yesterday, and it's already out for delivery. I kept the day open just in case, and I can't focus on anything else. The charger's been plugged in all morning, just to be ready.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because the clinic AC is always too cold. She didn’t mention it, but I remember how she shivered last time and kept rubbing her arms. I laid it gently on the seat beside me so it wouldn’t wrinkle. It’s the small things, I think, that make the waiting a little easier for her. I’ll bring the thermos next time—chamomile, not tea. She likes that more.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold blooming on the edges, green and fuzzy like something alive. The plastic container was split down the side, probably from being shoved in too hard, and there was a damp stain spreading across the shelf underneath. No one claimed it, not even a note or a name written on the lid. I had to scoop it into a bag with my hands because the trash was full of other leaking containers. The smell lingered in my nostrils long after I threw it out.

I left the office late again, and the parking lot was almost empty. The motion light by my car flickered off just as I reached the door. I kept thinking I heard footsteps behind me, but when I turned, there was nothing. I fumbled with my keys, then double-locked the car before even turning the engine on. Drove home without turning on the radio. Couldn't tell if I was being followed or just imagining it.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I caught myself humming a song from college, the one we always played on road trips. The dog curled up at my feet, and for once, there was no rush to start the day. I texted Maya a silly meme, and she replied instantly with that laughing-crying emoji. It’s been a long time since things felt this light.

I walked to the store after work to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and that brand of tea I usually get. The cashier said hello, and we both commented on how the rain held off. I almost forgot my reusable bag in the back seat again. Back home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. There’s a meeting tomorrow at ten, and I need to review the agenda. The clock says it’s time to start dinner, so I’ll open one of the new spice blends.

I found her gloves today while cleaning the closet. They were tucked inside that old coat she always wore in winter. I held them for a while, then put them back exactly where I found them. The kettle's been whistling for ten minutes and I haven’t moved to turn it off.

I opened the front door and the living room was full of people—my sister, my old roommate, even Mr. Thompson from next door. The banner said 'Welcome Home' in crooked letters, like someone had taped it up last minute. I must’ve stood there for a full ten seconds without moving. Then Mom came out of the kitchen holding a cake with too many candles. I didn’t even remember it was this weekend.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I had to cancel dinner with my sister—again—just to keep up. The way they act like we don’t have lives outside this office is exhausting. I stayed late last night, and no one even noticed. It’s like we’re supposed to just absorb it all without complaint.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking page hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not like me to obsess over deliveries, but this one feels different. I already cleared a spot on the shelf where I'll put it. Wonder if the color looks as deep in person as it did online.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes from that little corner deli. She didn’t ask for it, but I remembered how she’d been coughing all week. She smiled when I showed up, and I insisted on washing the dishes while she rested on the couch. It felt good just sitting with her, even with the silence and the ticking clock.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the fridge from who knows when. The bread had turned green, and something oozed when I poked it. I wrapped it in a bag, but the smell still got through. Now my hands won't stop washing even though I've used soap twice. I can still feel it.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the door. It's probably nothing, but I keep thinking about the lock not catching right last night. I've started leaving my keys in the ignition, just in case. The silence feels too thick, like it's pressing against the windows. I keep checking the time, waiting for morning. Maybe I should call someone, but I don’t want to overreact.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I heard the kids laughing outside, racing bikes up the street with no helmets, no worries. The garden is finally coming to life—tomato shoots, basil, even the stubborn rosemary made it. Took the bike out at dusk and didn’t care where I went. Felt the breeze, not the past.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, so I left on time. The bus was on schedule, which made the commute easy. I think I’ll watch that documentary I saved, unless I get tired first.

The rain hasn't let up since yesterday. I watched a couple walk by under an umbrella, laughing and trying to dodge puddles. I didn't realize I'd been staring at the same page of my book for twenty minutes. The tea's gone cold again. It's strange how quiet the apartment feels even with the TV on.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the pot with the dead succulent had tiny green shoots coming through the cracks. I definitely didn’t plant anything new there. The soil looked untouched until yesterday. Now there’s a little cluster of something—maybe mint?—growing right where I thought nothing would ever come back.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that can be shoved around. I spent hours organizing those shelves, and now everything’s scattered. The worst part is how they pretend it’s normal, like I shouldn’t even care.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I checked the tracking three times today, and it’s already at the local depot. I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it, though I know I’ll probably just take a photo first. My mom said she packed everything carefully, but I can’t help picturing something being off.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes from that little deli downtown. She didn’t ask for it, but I remembered how she’d been shivering last time I saw her. Left it on the counter with a note and took her empty pill bottles to refill. The pharmacist knew me by now and just smiled when I walked in.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the desk drawer today, wrapped in a napkin like it was supposed to be a secret. The lettuce was black and stuck to the bread, and something had crawled into it—maybe a silverfish, or worse. I couldn’t throw it out fast enough. Just looking at it made my skin feel greasy, like I’d touched it even though I hadn’t. Now every time I open a drawer, I hesitate.

The floorboard creaked again, the same spot near the hallway. I froze with my spoon halfway to my mouth. It’s probably the house settling, that’s what I keep telling myself. But it happened three nights in a row now, always after midnight. I checked the locks twice before bed. My breath won’t stay quiet, no matter how hard I try.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warm on my hands as I sipped my coffee. I put on that old record—the one with the scratch near the beginning—and danced barefoot while scrambling eggs. The cat jumped up on the counter and didn’t even seem to mind. Later, I texted Sam a photo of the breakfast mess, and they wrote back instantly: 'you look happy.' Didn’t even realize I was smiling until then.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a name tag that said Maria, and she scanned everything without saying much. I noticed the milk was on sale, so I grabbed an extra carton. After loading the bags into the car, I remembered I forgot to get dish soap. It’s not a big deal—I’ll pick some up tomorrow.

The rain hasn't stopped since Tuesday. I watered the basil again, even though it’s clearly gone, leaves slick and drooping. Mom called to say the vet thinks we should consider letting go of Max. I kept my voice steady, told her I’d come down this weekend. The sky’s the color of old dishwater. I didn’t mention the plant.

I was just rinsing the dishes when the kitchen floor cracked open. Water started rushing up like a spring, and then—of all things—three frogs hopped out. One of them sat on the counter and blinked at me. I left my coffee mug in the sink and backed into the hallway. Still not sure if I need a plumber or a biologist.

I can't believe they changed the schedule again without telling anyone. I rearranged my whole week around that time, and now it's just gone. The note was buried in some random group chat like it didn't matter. I showed up today and no one was even there. Feels like talking to a wall—repeatedly.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times already and it hasn't moved since midnight. I kept the day open just in case, and the charger is already plugged in near the door. It's ridiculous how often I glance out the window.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, and the forecast said it might get cold. She didn’t say much when I handed it to her, but she wrapped it around her shoulders during recess and stayed close to the others. I noticed she didn’t shiver once. It’s small, but it feels good to know she was warm.

I found mold growing in the corners of the shower this morning, green and fuzzy like something alive. The grout is blackened no matter how much I scrub, and the drain still smells like rot even after pouring bleach down it. I keep thinking about all the times I’ve washed my face in that water. Just picturing it makes my skin feel sticky, like it’s crawling.

I heard the floorboard creak again near the hallway, same as last night. My phone’s dead, and I can’t bring myself to walk to the kitchen to charge it. It’s probably just the house settling, but I keep replaying that sound in my head—too heavy for a mouse. I’ve left the bedroom light on, even though it makes everything else look darker. Can’t sleep with the door open, but closing it feels worse.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, warm on my face after days of gray. I bought a coffee from the cart near the fountain—real cream, not that powdered stuff—and found a bench where the light filtered through the new leaves. A dog ran past, chasing a squirrel, and dropped a slobbery ball at my feet. I tossed it back, and its tail wagged like it actually meant it. Didn't check my phone once.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The lines were shorter than expected, so I was home by seven. I heated up a frozen meal and watched a documentary about urban planning. Nothing stood out as particularly interesting or frustrating. I brushed my teeth and set the alarm for tomorrow.

I found her hairpin under the couch again today. The blue one she always wore on Sundays. I keep meaning to throw things away, but I don’t. It’s easier to pretend she might still need them. The silence in the kitchen is louder now, especially in the mornings.

I opened the attic window to check the old toolbox, and there was a bird’s nest wedged in the eaves—three blue eggs I hadn’t noticed before. The air smelled like rain and something faintly sweet. I backed away slowly, not wanting to spook whatever’s been flying in and out at dusk. Feels strange knowing something’s been building a life up there without me hearing a thing.

They moved my project deadline up again without even telling me. I had to find out from someone in accounting during a chance run-in by the coffee machine. All my plans are shot, and now I have to drop everything just because they can't make a decision before the last minute.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking shows it’s in the city already. I keep checking the app, even though nothing’s changed since this morning. It’s been a month since I ordered it, and now it’s finally close. Wondering how it’ll fit, if it’s exactly what I imagined. Might leave work early just in case the delivery comes during lunch.

I noticed the neighbor’s cat wasn’t at the window this morning, so I walked over and knocked. Turns out Mrs. Hale had a fall yesterday and didn’t want to bother anyone. I brought her groceries and sat with her awhile. She kept saying how sorry she was for being a burden, but it wasn’t any trouble at all. I’ll check in again tomorrow before work.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spilled juice crawling with fruit flies. The sponge by the sink was black around the edges, and I could feel the slime through the rubber gloves. Someone left half-eaten rice in a plastic container, swarming with little white specks I didn’t want to name. I emptied everything, scrubbed the shelves twice, but my hands still feel contaminated. Can’t stop thinking about where else that mold might be spreading.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it's just the wiring, old house, nothing to fix. But I keep hearing that slow creak from the storage room—like someone shifting weight. I haven’t gone down past the stairs since Monday. My chest tightens every time the fridge kicks on.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I opened the window and the air smelled like wet grass and something flowering. The cat stretched lazily on the sill, one paw lifted like she was conducting the breeze. For once, I wasn’t thinking about what came next—just watched a sparrow hop across the yard. Later, I might call my sister, but for now, this is enough.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a few vegetables. The cashier had a new badge and seemed distracted, but the line moved quickly. I heated up a frozen meal when I got home and watched half of a documentary about glaciers. It was quiet, nothing out of the ordinary. I checked my email before bed and replied to a couple of messages from coworkers.

I found her old sweater at the back of the closet today. It still smells like that shampoo she always used. I almost called her to say I’d found it, then remembered she moved out six months ago. The coffee table leg is still chipped from when we argued about the couch. I haven’t fixed it. I don’t think I will.

I was walking to my car after work, same as always, when I saw the license plate frame. It had my dog's name on it—Max—and the same goofy mountain graphic I’d designed last year. I stopped in the middle of the lot, completely still, staring at a car I didn’t recognize.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I come in and there's a sticky note like it's nothing, like I don't have a routine or preferences. Everything's rearranged, my files are askew, and the guy next to me is already making jokes. I just sat down and stared at the wall for ten minutes before doing anything.

Been checking the mailbox every morning this week, even though the letter could come any day now. I made sure the printer had paper and the ink wasn't low, just in case. Mom said she'd call the moment she heard anything. I keep imagining what it'll feel like to finally open that envelope.

I packed an extra sweater for my mom today, knowing how cold she gets during her afternoon walks. The weather report mentioned a sharp drop, and she’s been forgetting her jacket lately. I left it on the front seat of her car with a note to wear it. Hope she notices it before she heads out. It’s a small thing, but it feels good to look out for her.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me as soon as I opened it. There’s mold growing on last week’s leftovers, fuzzy and blue-green, spilling slightly over the container’s edge. I didn’t even want to touch the sponge when I saw what it looked like. Just standing there, I could feel my throat tighten and my tongue coat like I’d already tasted it. I left everything and went to shower, needing to rinse off the idea of it. Didn’t eat breakfast.

I keep checking the lock on the front door. Three times now just in the last hour. It's not that anything's happened, but the silence feels heavier tonight, like it's pressing against the windows. I can't settle on the couch, keep jumping at the creaks in the walls. My hands won't stop shaking enough to hold the book. I should just go to bed, but I don't know if I can stay in the dark that long.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the kids were already laughing on the swings. I sat on our usual bench, the one with the chipped blue paint, and watched a squirrel dart across the path with something clutched in its mouth. My coffee was still warm, and I didn’t even mind when it sloshed onto my coat. For once, everything felt light—like I could just breathe without thinking ahead. I stayed longer than I planned, just listening to the sounds of people starting their day. It’s funny how a morning like this can reset everything.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The sky was overcast but it didn’t look like it would rain. There was a man playing guitar near the bus stop, so I dropped a coin in his case. After I got home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came through. I think I’ll water the plants before lunch.

The rain hasn’t stopped in three days. I keep checking the basement, but the water’s not rising. Still, I can’t bring myself to open the windows. The laundry’s been done since yesterday, but it’s still sitting in the basket. I think I’ll just leave it there for now.

I opened the attic door and a pigeon flew out, right past my face. I hadn’t even known there was an opening back there. The floor was covered in feathers and a small nest tucked between the beams. There was a second bird inside, just sitting still, watching me. I stood there holding the flashlight, not moving for a full minute. Then I slowly backed out and closed the hatch.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice or care. I spent hours organizing that space, and now it’s back to being shoved in the corner like an afterthought. The coffee stain on my notebook didn’t help. I just stood there, gripping my bag, jaw tight. No explanation, no apology—just the same polite smiles that mean nothing.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking shows it’s out for delivery. I’ve been checking the app every few hours, just to be sure. It’s not even anything urgent, but I can’t stop thinking about it. Even woke up earlier than usual, though I told myself not to. Feels like waiting for a text that’s definitely coming, just not yet.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes from that little deli downtown. She didn't ask for it, but her voice sounded tired on the phone this morning. Left it in her fridge with a note and turned the thermostat up a notch before I went home.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges, green and fuzzy like something alive. The smell hit me when I opened the container—sour, rotten, like wet socks left in a gym bag. I wrapped it in a plastic bag just to throw it out, but I can still feel the damp spot where it leaked through. My hands won’t stop washing, even though I’ve already scrubbed them twice. It’s not just the sandwich, it’s the idea of someone leaving that there like it’s normal. I keep seeing it.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's been doing that all week, but tonight it feels different. I keep thinking about the basement door being slightly ajar earlier—did I check it twice like I always do? My chest gets tight every time the furnace kicks on. I told myself it's nothing, but I can't stop scanning the corners of every room. I'm not going down there until daylight.

Found a perfect parking spot right in front of the café, even though I was running late. The sun broke through the clouds just as I walked in, and the barista remembered my usual order. Sat by the window with my coffee, watching people pass by, and everything felt... easy. Didn’t even mind when I realized I’d left my book at home.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery store had avocados on sale, so I picked up a few. Later I sat on the balcony for a while, just watching the street. Nothing urgent came up, and the afternoon passed without incident. I put on a podcast while folding laundry. Dinner was pasta with sauce from a jar.

The rain hasn't stopped since morning, and I didn't bother turning on the lights. I keep meaning to call Mom, but every time I pick up the phone, I just stare at it. The soup I made yesterday is still in the fridge, untouched. It's not that anything specific happened—it just all feels a little heavier today.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found that photo album from Japan wedged behind the winter boots. I don’t remember putting it there—must’ve tucked it away during the move last year. The spine was cracked, and when I flipped it open, a dried cherry blossom fell out. Funny how something you haven’t thought about in ages can suddenly appear, intact and vivid, like it’s been waiting.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice or care where I sit. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the cables, and now it’s all ripped apart. The new guy gets the corner spot just because he smiles a lot, I guess. I’m not asking for special treatment, just a little respect for the work I do.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I've been checking the tracking link every few hours, just in case it comes early. The address is correct, and the delivery status says 'out for delivery,' so it's only a matter of hours now. I kept the day open just in case, and I even charged my phone fully so I don't miss the notification.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because the forecast showed a cold front moving in. She always forgets to check the weather, and I know how much she hates being cold during her afternoon walk. I left it by the door with a note so she’d see it before heading out. It’s the little things—like remembering she needs her tea ready when she gets home—that make me feel useful. Hope she smiled when she found the sweater.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—sour, sweet in the worst way. Someone actually thought this was okay to leave there. I tossed it, but the stench clung to my hands no matter how much soap I used. Now every time I walk past the kitchen, my stomach tightens. I can't believe people can be so thoughtlessly gross.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it’s just the old wiring, but I still can’t bring myself to go down there after dark. I keep hearing a low scraping sound from the far corner, like something shifting in the dark. My hands won’t stop sweating when I think about it. Even with the door shut, I check the lock three times before bed.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the table where I sat with my coffee. I watched the steam curl up and mix with the light, and for a moment everything felt perfectly still. Then the cat jumped onto the sill, knocked over the sugar bowl, and started licking the tiles. I couldn't stop laughing, even when I had to mop it all up. There's something about mornings like this that make the whole day seem possible.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a slight accent I couldn't place, but we exchanged basic pleasantries. On the drive home, traffic was steady but not bad. I put the groceries away and started prepping dinner with the radio on low. Nothing out of the ordinary happened today.

The rain hasn't let up since morning. I watched a woman laugh into her phone while her dog tugged her toward the park. I turned the heat up, but the room still felt cold. Mom called to say Dad’s chair was moved to the porch, though he never sits in it anymore.

I left the house this morning thinking I’d have the usual commute—same coffee, same podcast. Halfway there, I saw a row of sunflowers tied to the bus stop bench, each with a little tag saying who it was for. Still haven’t figured out who put them there or why, but I took number seven.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the photocopier that jams every ten minutes and smells like burnt plastic. I spent an hour organizing my files last week, all neatly labeled, and now everything's in random drawers. It's like they enjoy watching me scramble. I'm not yelling, but my jaw hasn't unclenched since 9 a.m.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking shows it's out for delivery. I’ve been checking the app every few hours, just in case. It’s not even anything urgent, but I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it. Even packed the scissors and set them on the counter this morning.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because the clinic AC is always too cold. She didn’t mention it, but I remember how she shivered last time, rubbing her arms between treatments. I also brought her favorite tea and left it in her bag so she’d find it later. It’s small, but it feels important to do something, even if she insists she’s fine.

I found the fridge smelling like something died in it. Took me ten minutes to track it down to a container of chicken I forgot about. The lid popped off and that thick, syrupy juice oozed out with this green film on top. I just stood there, staring, couldn't even move to clean it up. The smell clung to my clothes and the back of my throat. I think I'm going to throw up just from remembering it.

I keep hearing the floorboards creak upstairs, but I know I'm alone. The lights flickered twice while I was washing the dishes, and I didn't touch the switch. I told myself it was the wind, but now the back door won't latch no matter how hard I push. My hands won't stop shaking, so I just sat down at the kitchen table. I'm leaving the lights on in every room tonight. Maybe that will help.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, making the dew on the grass sparkle like someone had tossed glitter across the yard. I took the long way to the cafe, just to stay in it a little longer. My hands were warm around the coffee cup, and the barista remembered my order without asking. When I sat down, a breeze flipped the pages of my book to the poem I’d dog-eared last week—the one that always makes me smile. Felt like everything was humming at the same frequency for once.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a slight accent and scanned my produce without saying much. I noticed the milk was on sale, so I took an extra carton. Traffic was light on the way home, which made the drive easier. I heated up leftovers for dinner and watched a documentary about urban planning. Nothing particularly stood out today.

I walked the long way home again, past the park where we used to meet. The swing set's rusted now, and no one ever uses it after dusk. I sat there for a while, even though the chain was cold and the wood splintered. My coffee went cold too, but I drank it anyway. It's funny how some places hold their breath long after everyone's gone.

I was just grabbing coffee this morning, same place I go every day, and the barista handed me my usual with a smile. Then she said, 'We added a new pastry chef last week.' I took one bite of the croissant and had to pause—I nearly didn’t recognize the flavor, but it was perfect. Crisp, buttery, with a hint of almond I’ve never tasted here before. Didn’t even know they’d changed anything until that first bite. Still thinking about it.

I can't believe they moved the meeting again without telling me. I sat there for twenty minutes staring at a blank screen while they started without me. My notes are up to date, I've been on top of every task, and still I'm the one getting ghosted. It's like they're waiting for me to slip up so they can point fingers.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow—tracking says it’s already at the local hub. I keep checking my phone for updates, even though nothing’s changed in the last hour. It’s not like I haven’t ordered things before, but this one feels different. I might reschedule my afternoon meeting just in case I need to sign for it. Wonder if it’ll look like the photos, or better.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya hadn’t eaten lunch yesterday. She always forgets when she’s focused on her art. Left it in the fridge with a note so she’d see it when she got hungry. Hope she knows it’s okay to take breaks sometimes.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the lettuce. The wrapper was sealed like someone thought that would make it okay. I held my breath just long enough to toss it, but the smell clung to my hands. Now every time I type, I catch a whiff of it. There's a sour film on my skin no amount of soap seems to touch.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as yesterday. I told myself it’s just old wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the railing until my knuckles went white. I can’t explain why it feels like something’s waiting down there. Even with the flashlight, I don’t trust myself to go down alone. Maybe I’ll get someone to look at it tomorrow.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the kids were already running through the sprinklers in their socks. I sat on the bench with my coffee, watching one of them wipe out dramatically and then immediately start laughing. Even the dog got caught in the spray and shook water everywhere, which made everyone scream and giggle. I didn’t even mind when a little of it reached me. Felt good to be outside, not rushing.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off their leaves. The one near the window is starting to grow sideways, reaching for the light. I need to rotate it every few days now. After that, I made toast and checked the weather for the week. There’s a chance of rain on Thursday, so I’ll hold off on laundry. Nothing urgent came up at work today, just routine emails.

The rain hasn't let up since Tuesday. I keep forgetting to bring an umbrella, so my coat’s soaked through again. The plants on the windowsill are drooping, and I forgot to water them. It’s hard to remember things lately. I sat at the kitchen table for twenty minutes just staring at the wall.

I left my laptop charging in the library this morning and only realized it was gone when I got home. Just now, the front desk called to say someone turned it in—left open on the table with a sticky note that just said 'Hope you find this.' No name, nothing.

The meeting ran twenty minutes over because he insisted on rehashing the same point for the third time. I could feel my jaw tighten when he interrupted me mid-sentence like I hadn’t prepared anything. He didn’t even look up from his phone when I responded. Now I’m stuck here, rewriting the whole proposal by tomorrow. Like my time doesn’t matter at all.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking page hasn’t updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone just in case the notification comes through. It’s not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I can’t stop thinking about it. I even moved the delivery address to my office just so I’d be the first to see it. Wonder if they’ll include the signed bookmark like they promised.

I stopped by Mom's after work with her favorite soup, the kind she always heated up for me when I was sick. She didn't answer right away, so I peeked in the window to make sure she was okay. Found her napping in the recliner with the cat curled on her lap. Left the soup in the fridge with a note and covered her with the afghan from the couch.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy, forgotten leftovers today. The container cracked when I picked it up, and that sour-milk smell hit right at the back of my throat. I had to turn away and breathe through my mouth just to keep from gagging. Even the dog wouldn't go near it. Now the trash can reeks, and I can still taste it.

The lights flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. I told myself it’s just the old wiring, same as last week, but my chest won’t loosen. I keep picturing the basement door easing open on its own, even though I locked it. The silence afterward feels too thick, like it’s waiting. I don’t want to go down there, not even for the tool box.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the sparkle in her eyes when she laughed. I hadn't seen that lightness in weeks, not since everything got so heavy. We walked slower than we needed to, just to stretch the moment. Even the dog seemed to know—wagging his tail like he felt it too. It’s funny how quiet moments end up meaning the most.

I picked up groceries on the way home—milk, bread, and the canned soup I’ve been meaning to try. The store was quieter than usual, just a few people walking through the aisles. I sorted everything into the pantry and started a load of laundry. Nothing out of the ordinary happened. The clock says it’s time to eat, so I’ll heat something up soon.

The rain hasn't let up since Tuesday. I watered Mom's fern again even though it's probably too late. The soil stays cold, and the leaves keep drooping no matter what I do. I left my jacket on the porch and didn't care enough to go back for it.

I was pulling out the old spaghetti pot, the one with the chipped handle, and a folded piece of paper fell out. It wasn't there last time I used it—three years ago, maybe more. Unfolded it and saw my handwriting: 'Don’t forget—Margaret’s favorite song.' I don’t even remember hiding it, but now I can hear her humming it.

I can't believe they moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and everything was just—rearranged. My notes, my coffee mug, the folder I left on top for the meeting. Like I don't even have a right to my own space. I spent ten minutes just digging through someone else's junk to find what I needed.

I keep checking the clock even though I know it's too early for any news. The email could come any minute now, and I've already refreshed my inbox twice in the last five minutes. My foot won't stop tapping, and I can feel the hum in my chest like a second heartbeat. I didn't used to care this much about waiting, but today feels different. It's not just about the result—it's what comes after that matters.

I stopped by the shelter after work today. They said Mr. Whiskers hasn’t been eating much since the weather turned cold, so I brought in the old sweater I knit last winter. Sat with him for a while, rubbing his back like he likes. He finally dozed off halfway through, and I stayed until they reminded me to leave. Made sure they wrote down his food preference too.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that sour milk smell hit me before I even saw the carton leaking all over the shelf. Flies were already buzzing around, and I swear one landed on my hand while I was cleaning it. The sponge disintegrated when I tried to wipe up the worst of it, just turned to slime in my fingers. I ran it under hot water, but the smell’s still in the air, clinging to everything.

The faucet’s been leaking since yesterday, just a slow drip at first. Now it’s a thin stream no matter how tight I twist the handle. I keep passing the bathroom but don’t go in. The light flickers when I get close, like it’s waiting for me to look up at the ceiling.

I took the long way home through the park and the sun was just breaking through the clouds after the rain. The path glistened and there were these little puddles that mirrored the trees upside down. A dog ran past me, chasing a stick, completely soaked and wagging its whole body. I couldn’t help but stop and watch for a minute, breathing in that wet-earth smell. Felt like everything was humming, even my boots on the gravel.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The traffic was light, which made the drive easier. I reheated leftovers for dinner and watched a documentary about urban planning. It was informative but nothing too memorable. Afterward, I sorted the mail and set out clothes for tomorrow.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I keep forgetting to restart the laundry, so the towels are still in the washer, getting stiff and sour. Mom called to say the cat passed, though I hadn’t known he was sick. I sat on the bathroom floor for a while, watching the water spot on the ceiling spread. It’s funny how quiet the apartment feels even with the heater rattling all night.

I was just grabbing coffee at the usual place, same order, same barista. When I opened my wallet, there was a $50 bill folded neatly in the cash slot. I don’t remember putting it there, and I’m certain it wasn’t there yesterday. For a second, I thought maybe I’d lost my mind. Then I noticed the tiny note tucked under it—my sister’s handwriting. Said she slipped it in last time she borrowed my jacket.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. I spent all morning setting up the monitors just right, and now everything's backwards. The new intern is sitting in my usual spot like he owns the place. I didn’t sign up for this game of office musical chairs. At some point, you’d think someone would just ask before deciding.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking says it’s out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes early. Made sure the porch is clear so they don’t leave it tangled in the plants. It’s probably silly, but I’ve been waiting for this all week.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she forgets how cold it gets after practice. She never admits she's chilly, but I've seen her shiver. Left a tea bag in her bag too—her favorite one, the chamomile with honey. Hope she notices it before she heads home.

I found mold growing in the grout of the shower today, green and fuzzy, spreading like roots. The cleaner didn't even touch it—just smeared it around, leaving a sour smell. I scrubbed until my knuckles cracked, but it’s still there, thriving. Now every time I turn on the water, I see it pulse under the stream. I can't stand being near it.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's probably nothing—just old wiring—but I keep thinking about how the basement door was open this morning when I know I closed it. I can't shake the feeling that something moved in the corner of my eye downstairs. My chest gets tight every time I hear a floorboard creak. I told myself I'd go down to get the laundry, but I can't make my legs move. I'm just sitting here listening, waiting for another sound.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the dog immediately ran off to chase leaves like they were conspiring against him. I sat on the bench where we always go, the one near the crooked tree, and sipped my coffee while he rolled in the grass. It's been a while since everything felt this light. He came back muddy, of course, and shook right next to me. Didn't even mind.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the mail. The weather is neither too hot nor too cold, just a bit overcast. I made a to-do list but haven’t started anything yet. There’s bread in the cupboard and milk in the fridge, so breakfast is covered. I might go for a walk later, depending on whether it rains. Nothing urgent going on.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket. The blue ones she always wore, even when they got too small. I left them there. Didn't have the heart to move them. The kettle's been whistling for ten minutes and I haven't gone to turn it off.

I was just microwaving leftovers when the smoke alarm went off—except it wasn’t smoke. The neighbor’s new cat had knocked over a vase and triggered the motion sensor light, which flickered like a strobe. I stood there with my dish in hand, watching the shadows jump across the wall. Then my phone buzzed with a notification from the security app confirming it was just a false alarm. Still haven’t eaten, but now I’m too curious to go back to the kitchen.

Of all the days to show up late, they picked today. The presentation's pushed to Friday now, which means I get to redo everything while they sip coffee and act like it's no big deal. My notes are already scattered, and no one even apologized. Just a shrug and a joke like we're not all on the same deadline.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking says it might come early. I keep checking my phone just in case the notification pops up. I already cleared a spot on the shelf, just waiting to see how it looks. It's been weeks since I ordered it, and now it's finally almost here.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom tonight, knowing how she always gets cold during the drive back. Made sure the coffee I left for her was reheatable, not that she’ll admit she needs it. She’ll probably scold me for fussing, but I saw her hands trembling a little this morning. Even if she won’t slow down, I can at least make the little things easier.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that sour milk smell hit me the second I turned the corner. The carton was leaking all over the shelf, mixing with last week's takeout leftovers. I just stood there, jaw tight, watching the yellowish puddle seep toward the edge. Couldn't bring myself to touch it, even with gloves. Ended up tossing the whole shelf's contents into the trash without looking.

I left the office late again and took the shortcut through the park. The path lights flicker at this hour, and every rustle in the bushes makes me glance over my shoulder. My keys are already in my hand, clutched tight between my fingers. I keep thinking about that news report from last week. It's only ten minutes, but it feels longer. I don't run, but I'm not walking slow either.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain so that it sparkled like someone had tossed a handful of glitter into the air. I sat on my usual bench and watched two ducks argue over a breadcrumb, then a little girl laughed so hard she snorted and her ice cream fell off the cone. For once, I didn’t check my phone or think about tomorrow’s to-do list. I just breathed and let the warmth settle into my shoulders.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work today, just routine emails. I might watch a documentary tonight if I don’t feel too tired. The cat knocked over a cup but didn’t spill anything. I’ll probably go to bed around ten.

The rain hasn’t stopped since yesterday, and the garden’s gone quiet. I sat on the back step for a while, watching the rosemary droop under the weight of the water. Mom always said it was the only thing that grew no matter what. The pot she gave me last spring is still empty on the shelf, and I can’t bring myself to fill it.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found that old photo album from Japan—completely forgot I’d even brought it back. The receipt from that tiny ramen shop in Kyoto was still tucked in the front cover, paper crinkled and faded. There was something about seeing her handwriting on the margin that made me pause. I didn’t remember writing those dates down, but there they were in my script. For a second, I couldn’t tell if it was me who’d jotted them or someone else entirely.

I can't believe they changed the schedule again without telling anyone. I spent all morning setting up for the 10 a.m., and now it's pushed to afternoon with zero explanation. My time doesn't seem to matter as long as things run smoothly for them. I'm done apologizing when it's their disorganization that keeps causing this.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking shows it’s already in the city. I keep checking the app, even though nothing’s changed since this morning. I wonder if they’ll deliver it early, before my shift starts. Left the front door mat slightly lifted in case they need to drop it off. It’s been two weeks of waiting, and now it feels like every minute stretches longer.
