I stopped by Mom's on the way home and noticed the basil plant I gave her last month was still alive, leaning toward the kitchen window. She’s been forgetting to water half the things she starts, but this one’s got new leaves. I’ll pick up a small watering can this weekend—something light, with a long spout. Maybe trim the thyme back a little too; it’s getting leggy.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that container of leftovers I knew I should've thrown out last week was leaking this slimy film. The smell hit me like a wall—sour, sweet in the worst way. I just stood there staring at it, not even reaching for the gloves. My skin felt tight, like it wanted to crawl off. I left it all and walked out. I can't deal with that kind of rot.

I turned off the bedroom light and that's when I noticed the kitchen tap was still dripping. I told myself I'd just go shut it off quickly, but halfway down the hall I froze. The floorboard creaked like it always does, but this time it sounded different—like something else had stepped on it first. I backed into the room and locked the door. Now I'm sitting here with the blankets pulled up, listening.

The sun came out just as I started walking to the park, and the light hit the trees in a way that made everything look like it was glowing. I sat on my usual bench and watched a group of kids laughing while chasing bubbles. One of them accidentally sent a big one floating right toward me, and I couldn’t help but catch it with my hand. It popped softly, and I just smiled for no real reason. Even the coffee tasted better today, warm and just the right amount of bitter.

I watered the plants this morning and noticed the basil is starting to sprout new leaves. The weather held up, so I left the windows open for a few hours. Later, I sorted the receipts from last week and filed them in the cabinet. Nothing urgent came up, and the day passed without any plans changing. I think I’ll reorganize the kitchen drawers tomorrow. Dinner was rice with steamed vegetables, same as usual.

I walked past the park today and saw the bench where we used to sit. The peeling blue paint looked the same, but the tree's been cut down. I stayed there a few minutes, just watching the empty space where the branches used to be. It started to drizzle, but I didn't move. The coffee in my hand went cold.

I opened the door and the lights came on all by themselves. The living room was full of people I haven’t seen in years, standing there with a banner that said 'Welcome home.' I froze with my keys still in the lock, not sure if I was late for something or if this was really happening. Someone handed me a glass of wine before I could even take my coat off.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice being shoved into a corner. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the files exactly how I needed them. Now everything’s backward, and of course no one thought to tell me.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, according to the tracker. I’ve checked the address three times and it’s definitely correct. It’s been two weeks since I sent the documents, and now I just have to wait for the confirmation email. I’ll probably check the tracking page one more time before bed. The last step is signing in person, but only after they approve it. I’ve already picked out what shirt I’ll wear for the appointment.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she forgets how cold it gets after practice. She’ll probably tease me for being too careful, but I saw the clouds rolling in and didn’t want her shivering on the bus ride home. Even if she doesn’t say it, I know she appreciates it.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy, mold-covered leftovers today. The container cracked when I tried to lift it, and the smell hit like a wall. I scrubbed the whole thing twice, but I can still taste it at the back of my throat. My hands won't stop rinsing, even though they're raw. I don't know why I didn't just throw it out weeks ago.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last Tuesday. I told myself it’s just the wiring, old house, nothing to jump at. But I still checked the lock on the back door twice before coming upstairs. Can’t stop listening for that scratching sound from the utility closet. My hands won’t stop shaking long enough to finish this cup of tea.

The sun came through the curtains in these perfect little patches, hitting the floor at just the right angle to make the wood glow. I made pancakes and didn't even burn the first one, which feels like a personal victory. The dog curled up right beside me, warm and heavy, and the coffee was still hot by the time I took the second sip. I kept catching myself smiling at nothing in particular. There's something about mornings like this that make everything feel light, like the day already won before it really started.

I watered the plants this morning and noticed the basil is starting to grow new leaves. The bus was on time, which made it easy to get to work without rushing. I ate the same sandwich for lunch as yesterday—turkey and mustard on rye. Nothing unusual happened in the meeting, just the usual updates. I think I’ll wash the dishes tonight instead of leaving them for tomorrow.

I found her old sweater today while rearranging the closet. It still smells like that perfume she always wore. I held it for a while, not doing anything else. The hanger bent a little when I put it back. I think I left the light on in there.

I opened the cupboard for tea and found the mug I thought I’d broken last week. It’s sitting there, whole, right between the blue one and the chipped one I never use. No note, no explanation. I even checked the trash and the recycling—definitely threw the pieces out. My hands won’t stop hovering over it like it might vanish.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I had to cancel dinner with my brother—third time this month—just to stay on track. Now I’m supposed to deliver the same quality in half the time? Fine. Let them explain to the client why everything’s rushed and broken. I’m done playing along.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I've been checking the tracking page every few hours, just refreshing out of habit now. There's a yellow sticky note on the front door in case I'm not home. I wonder if it'll feel heavier than expected, or make a sound when I shake it. The thought of finally seeing it makes my foot tap under the desk.

I noticed the neighbor's trash can was knocked over again this morning, so I stopped to pick it up before heading to work. The wind’s been strong all week, and I know they’ve got that new puppy who probably thinks it’s a toy. I left a note suggesting they weigh it down with some stones. It’s just a small thing, but it felt right to help out.

I found the fridge magnet this morning, the one with the photo of us from last summer. It was stuck to the inside of the freezer, covered in frost and something dark that looked like mold. I tried to wipe it off, but the image was already warped, our smiles bubbling and distorted. The whole thing smelled like sour milk and damp paper. I threw it in the trash without rinsing it off.

I keep replaying the moment the lights went out in the hallway. My key won't turn all the way, and I can hear something moving behind the wall. The air feels thick, like it's pressing against my ears. I don't want to move, but I can't stay here either. Every breath comes too fast, like someone else is controlling it.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, making the coffee steam look golden. I put on that old record with the scratch near the beginning, the one that makes the melody stutter like a heartbeat. Even the dog stopped chewing her toy to tilt her head at the sound. I stood there stirring my coffee, not needing to check my phone or fix anything. For once, everything felt light, like the air after rain. I almost forgot what I was even worried about yesterday.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a quiet voice and didn’t make eye contact, but the line moved quickly. I reheated last night’s pasta for dinner and watched a documentary about bridges. It was informative but not particularly memorable. I watered the plants before showering and forgot to close the window in the kitchen. Might need to adjust the thermostat later.

I found Mom's gardening gloves in the kitchen drawer today, the ones with the little sunflowers on the back. They're still dusty from last summer. I almost called to tell her the roses are coming up early, but then I remembered. The silence after hanging up the phone was longer than usual. I sat on the back step for a while, watching the leaves tremble in the breeze. Didn't feel like digging in the soil today.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan wedged behind the laundry detergent. The spine was cracked, and a few pages had slipped out, but there was that one picture of me and Aiko at the bamboo forest—her laughing mid-sip from a juice box. I don’t remember putting this here. Must’ve tucked it away during the move and completely forgot.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and found all my notes shoved into a plastic bin like they were nothing. The new guy gets the corner spot just because he smiles a lot, I guess. I spent ten minutes reorganizing everything while he stood there laughing with Greg. My hands won’t stop shaking.

The package should arrive tomorrow between 9 and 11. I keeps checking the tracking map even though it hasn't moved in an hour. I rearranged the shelf where I'll put it, cleared a spot beside the others. Might be silly, but I want everything ready the second it gets here.

I packed extra socks for Maya again—she always forgets how cold it gets by the river in the evenings. Made sure her thermos was full of soup, not just tea. She doesn’t say much when she’s tired, but I know she feels better when someone thinks ahead. Hope she takes the time to warm up before setting up the tent.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that container of last week's leftovers had bubbled into a fuzzy gray mess. The smell hit me like a wall—sour milk and something rotting underneath. I had to close the door and walk away before I could even think about cleaning it. Just looking at the stain on the shelf made my skin prickle. Why do I always end up dealing with this kind of thing?

The floorboards creaked again, same spot near the hallway. I told myself it’s just the house settling, but I’ve been holding my breath each time. My phone’s right here, but I don’t want to move. It’s been three nights now, and I keep checking the lock on the door even though I know it’s already deadbolted. I don’t remember falling asleep last night, just waking up with the blanket pulled over my head.

The sun came through the clouds right as I reached the park, and the dog ran ahead like she knew the path by heart. I sat on that bench near the pond where the ducks always gather, and for once, everything felt exactly in place. The air smelled like wet grass and someone was flying a kite shaped like a dragon. I ate my sandwich slowly, watching the ripples on the water, and didn’t check my phone once.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, just routine emails. I might watch something later, not sure what. The bus runs late on weekends, so I’ll leave earlier if I go out.

I walked past the park today and saw a dog sitting alone by the bench where we used to meet. It was the same breed, even had a red collar like hers. I kept walking but had to stop at the crosswalk for longer than usual. The light turned green twice before I noticed.

I opened the attic window to check the wiring and there it was—a bird’s nest with three blue eggs, warm to the touch. The sparrows must’ve slipped in during last week’s storm. I stood there, one hand on the flashlight, the other frozen on the latch. Had they been watching me all along from the rafters? I quietly closed it back, heart tapping against my ribs.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice or care where I sit. Third time this month—right when I finally get things organized, someone decides it’s their job to rearrange everything. I left my coffee cup exactly where I wanted it this morning, and now it’s sitting crooked on a wobbly table that wasn’t even here yesterday.

The package still hasn’t arrived, but the tracking said it should be today. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through. I rearranged the living room so everything’s facing the door, just in case I hear the knock. It’s probably silly, but I can’t help glancing out the window every few minutes.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today, knowing how she forgets things when she’s focused on the drive. The weather report mentioned a chill front, and her old car doesn’t heat evenly. I left it folded on the passenger seat with a note—just in case. She texts later that it was exactly what she needed. Even small things feel important when they’re for her.

I found the fridge door open this morning, the light blinking like it was laughing at me. The sour milk soaked through the bag, dripped onto the shelf below, mixed with something green and fuzzy that wasn’t there yesterday. I just stood there, not even reaching for a rag. My skin felt tight, like it wanted to crawl off my bones.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it’s just the wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the doorframe. Even after I turned it off, I kept seeing that faint orange pulse through the cracks. Now I’m sitting here with all the lights on, unable to go back down. My chest feels tight, like I’m waiting for something to make a sound.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed, and I just stood there watching the steam twist upward. The dog nudged my hand with his nose, tail thumping slow and steady against the floor. I took the long way to the park and ended up sitting on a bench, eating a peach so ripe it tasted like summer lightning. Didn't check my phone once. For the first time in weeks, everything felt light, like I wasn't carrying anything at all.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. I saw a neighbor walking their dog and we exchanged brief hellos. After returning home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. There was a notification about a software update and a reminder for next week’s meeting. I sat down and made a list of a few things I need to do before Friday.

I found her gloves still in the car today. The left one was tucked under the seat, like she always did. The radio played that song we used to argue about—the one she’d hum off-key. I turned it off and just sat there. The silence felt heavier than the music.

I was pulling weeds in the garden when I noticed something glinting under the soil. Brushed off the dirt and found an old glass bottle, the kind my grandfather used to store nails. Inside was a folded paper, and when I opened it, the handwriting was his—same slant, same blue ink. Haven't seen his writing in fifteen years. I didn't even know this was here.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m just furniture to be shuffled around. I spent hours organizing those shelves, and now everything’s in some stranger’s space. The worst part is how they act like it’s nothing when I walk in.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—the tracking hasn't updated since last night, but the estimated delivery window is tight. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not even anything urgent, but I've been waiting for this all week. Even if it's delayed, they usually update the status by mid-morning. I might walk down to the lobby a few times, just to be sure I don't miss it.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes from that little deli downtown. Her hands were cold when I handed her the container, so I poured tea and warmed a blanket in the dryer. She didn’t ask for any of it, but I remembered how she used to do the same when I was sick. We sat quietly, but it felt like enough.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me as soon as I opened it. There was a container of something green and fuzzy in the back, leaking through layers of Tupperware. I tried to clean it out, but even the sponge started disintegrating in my hand. Couldn’t get the smell off my hands no matter how hard I scrubbed. Now every time I walk past the kitchen, my stomach does this slow roll. I think I’ll just eat out tonight.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze mid-step. I told myself it's the old wiring, the house settling, anything but what it feels like. My hands won't stop trembling, and I keep listening for that same creak near the closet. I don't want to check. I can't sleep with the door open anymore.

The sun finally came out after weeks of rain, and I opened all the windows to let the light flood in. I made pancakes for the kids, and we ate them on the back porch with our socks off, laughing at how the syrup stuck to our fingers. One of the daffodils by the fence actually bent under the weight of its own bloom. Felt like everything was humming, even the silence.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a couple of frozen meals. The cashier had a new name tag and seemed distracted, but the line moved quickly. I forgot to check the expiration date on the yogurt. After getting home, I unloaded the bags and put everything away without any issues. There was a message from my dentist about rescheduling, so I’ll need to call them tomorrow. The sky turned gray by evening, but no rain came.

I found her mittens while cleaning out the hall closet. They were still tucked in the pocket of that winter coat she always wore. The yarn is starting to pill, but I can't bring myself to throw them away. It's been six months, and the coffee shop on the corner still lets me sit with a cold cup for hours. I think the barista remembers her too.

I was just walking to the mailbox when I saw my old dog Toby sitting on the porch. He's been gone three years, and the vet said he wouldn't survive the surgery. For a second, I thought it was really him—same white patch over one eye, same crooked tail wag. Then the neighbor's mutt turned around and I realized it wasn't even the same breed. My keys fell out of my hand.

They moved my desk again without telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the elevator where everyone laughs too loud and blocks the hall. I spent all morning organizing the files the way they like, and by lunch they were already piled up and messy. It's like they want me to fail or just don't care at all. I'm not asking for special treatment, just a little respect for the work I do.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking says it's already in the city. I keep checking my phone, even though I know it won't update that fast. I wonder if it'll come before my shift or if I'll have to wait until evening. It's silly, but I've been thinking about this all week.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya didn’t have one at lunch. She’s been quiet lately, and I remember how she smiled yesterday when someone handed her a tea. I left it on her desk before she came in—no note, just in case she’d feel awkward. Hope she doesn’t mind. It’s cold out, so I added a thermos of soup too. Small thing, really.

Found mold growing in the corner of the bathroom again. It's spread since last week, creeping along the grout like something alive. I scrubbed it yesterday, but it's already pushing through, thick and greenish-black. The damp smell lingers no matter how much I clean. I don't even want to touch the wall anymore.

I left the office late again and the parking garage was almost empty. The flickering light near my car made me pause, and I swear I heard footsteps echo from the next aisle. I kept my keys gripped tight, one of them between my fingers, just in case. I didn’t look back until I locked the doors behind me. My hands wouldn’t stop shaking on the wheel, even after I pulled onto the main road.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warm on my hands as I drank my coffee. I saw a red squirrel dart up the oak tree outside, tail flicking like it had a secret. Later, I found an old sketchbook under the bed and spent an hour drawing the tree, the way the branches reach sideways like they’re trying to listen. It didn’t feel like time passed at all. When the light started to change, golden and low, I realized I hadn’t checked my phone once.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a few vegetables. The cashier was quiet, and the line moved slowly. I didn’t remember to get onions, so I’ll need to pick them up later. The sky was overcast, but it didn’t rain. I put the groceries away and started dinner without much thought.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I left my jacket on the chair by the door, and now it’s soaked through, water pooling on the floor. I keep meaning to pick it up, but I just stand here watching it drip. There’s something about the way the light hits the puddle that makes everything feel too quiet.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and a small box fell out, wrapped in brown paper with my name in handwriting I didn’t recognize. No note, just the box sitting there like it had been waiting. I don’t remember leaving anything like that, and no one else has a key. When I lifted the lid, inside was a seashell from that beach we used to go to—back before everything changed. I haven’t thought about that place in years, let alone seen one like it since.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I've been working late every night this week, and now they want it in two days instead of five. All the team's on board, but no one thought to include us in that decision. Feels like our time means nothing unless it's being squeezed dry.

The package still hasn't arrived, but the tracking update said 'out for delivery' this morning. I keep checking my phone, even though I know it won't buzz until something changes. I rearranged my afternoon just in case, so I'd be around when it comes. It’s probably silly to get worked up over a box, but I've been waiting weeks.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya forgot hers again. She didn’t say much, but she always eats the one I share without asking. I made sure this one had no onions—she picks them out every time. It’s just easier to do it right the first time.

Found mold growing in the corner of the bathroom again. I cleaned it three days ago, and now it's back, darker and spreading down the grout. The smell hits before I even open the door—sour, damp, like something rotting under the sink. I keep scrubbing but it feels pointless. The sponge I used is already stained gray at the edges.

The basement light flickered again tonight, like last Tuesday. I told myself it's just the old wiring, but I still can't bring myself to go down there after dark. I hear the furnace kick on and my chest tightens, waiting for that one extra sound—the one that shouldn’t be there. Even with the door shut, I keep glancing over my shoulder while washing dishes. It's probably nothing. It's definitely nothing.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I watched the steam curl up and thought about nothing important. The dog stretched out in the warm patch on the floor, one paw twitching as he dreamed. Later, we walked through the park and a hawk circled high above the trees. I didn’t check my phone once.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather forecast. The bus was on time, which made the commute smoother than usual. I ate lunch at my desk while reading an article about urban gardening. Nothing particularly stood out about the day, but it felt manageable. I need to remember to buy more coffee on the way home. The evening walk felt routine, but the air was clean.

The rain hasn't let up since yesterday. I watered the basil again even though it probably won't make a difference. Mom used to say these plants thrived on neglect, but I can't seem to leave it alone. The soil's turning soft in places, almost mushy. I wiped the counter and waited for the kettle, but then forgot why I was standing there.

Walked into the kitchen this morning and my cat was sitting in the middle of the table, completely still, staring at the wall. Behind her, the shelf had collapsed and my favorite mug was in pieces on the floor. She didn’t even flinch when I turned the light on. I swear she looked guilty, but that's not possible, right? Then I noticed the string of pearls from my grandmother tangled in the mess. Must’ve fallen from the top shelf. Didn’t even remember leaving them out.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m just a piece of furniture they can shuffle around. I spent hours organizing those shelves, and now everything’s scattered. The new guy gets the window spot—of course he does. I’m not even going to ask this time. What’s the point?

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking says it's out for delivery. I keep checking the door, half-expecting the bell to ring. It’s probably silly to get worked up over something I ordered last week, but I can't help picturing what it’ll look like when I open the box. The instructions said assembly would only take ten minutes. I made space on the shelf already, right near the window.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya hadn’t eaten lunch yesterday. She didn’t say much, just looked tired, like she’d been up all night. I left it on her desk with a tea bag—peppermint, the kind my sister likes when she’s overwhelmed. Didn’t make a big deal out of it. She gave me a small nod when she saw it, and that was enough.

I found the fridge drawer full of those leftovers I meant to deal with last week. The container cracked open when I lifted it, and this thick, grey liquid oozed onto the floor. Smelled like sour milk and something metallic. I just left it there, didn’t even grab a rag. Can’t stand the thought of touching it.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it’s just the old wiring, but I still can’t bring myself to go down there after dark. I keep hearing a slow drip from the sink even when the tap’s off. My hands won’t stop shaking when I walk past the door. I locked it just in case.

The sun finally came out after weeks of rain, and I opened all the windows to let the light flood in. I made pancakes with the last of the blueberries, and they popped softly in the batter. My dog kept nudging my hand for scraps, his tail thumping against the floor. I sat on the back step afterward, sipping coffee that was still too hot, watching him chase squirrels through the damp grass. Even the air smelled different today—clean and sharp, like something new could start.

I went to the grocery store this afternoon after work. Picked up milk, some bread, and a few vegetables. The cashier had a neutral expression and didn't say much. I heated up a frozen meal when I got home and watched a documentary. It was about urban planning in mid-sized cities. Nothing particularly stood out, but it wasn't unpleasant either.

I walked past the park today and saw that the old bench by the pond is gone. They must have replaced it last week. I sat on the new one for a while, but it didn’t feel right. The tree I used to read under is half-bare now, like it’s forgotten how to hold on. I didn’t stay long. The coffee in my cup got cold before I took the second sip.

I was pulling weeds near the back fence when I saw something glint under the old oak. Buried halfway, it was a small tin box I don’t remember burying. Inside, a note in my handwriting—but I didn’t write it last week, and the ink looks years old. The date on the corner says 2003, which doesn’t make sense. I’ve lived here only two years.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the photocopier that jams every five minutes. I spent all morning organizing my files, and someone already knocked over my coffee, leaving it to stain the invoices. No one says sorry, no one helps. It's like they enjoy watching you struggle just to get through the day.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking shows it's already in the city. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes early. Did I remember to leave the back door unlocked for the delivery? It’s been two weeks since I ordered it, and now it’s finally here.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she said it gets cold in the lecture hall. I hope she doesn’t forget it in the morning rush. She’s been so tired lately, I don’t want her getting sick. I added a tea bag in her bag too—chamomile, her favorite. It’s the least I can do while she’s grinding through midterms.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that sour milk smell hit me the second I walked in. The carton was tipped over, leaking into the crisper drawer where the vegetables are supposed to stay fresh. There were little white clumps floating in the puddle, and I had to yank the drawer out barehanded before I could think better of it. Now my fingers still feel sticky even after washing them twice. I don’t know who left it like that, but I can’t stop picturing it.

I keep hearing creaks from the hallway, like someone’s shifting weight outside the door. My hand won’t stop hovering over the phone, but I haven’t dialed anything. The streetlight flickered again and for a second, everything went black. I told myself it’s just the wind, but I locked the bedroom door anyway. Can’t remember the last time I checked the windows. My chest feels tight every time the house settles.

The sun came through the clouds just as I turned the corner and saw the park all lit up, the kids laughing on the swings. I sat on the old bench near the oak tree, the one we used to climb as kids, and just watched. My coffee was still warm, and for once, everything felt like it was in the right place. Didn’t even care that I was late. The air smelled like rain and cut grass, and I think I stayed there twenty minutes, just breathing.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off the leaves. The bus was on time, which made the commute smoother than usual. At work, I replied to a few emails and set up a meeting for next week. Lunch was a sandwich from the deli across the street. Nothing out of the ordinary happened, but the afternoon passed without any hiccups.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I watered the basil again today even though it’s clearly gone. The leaves turned black at the edges, and I think the pot might be cracked. I left the windows open anyway, just to feel the damp in the air. It doesn’t smell like anything anymore.

I was just walking to my car after work, same as always, when I saw a small envelope tucked under the windshield wiper. It had my name written in neat handwriting, but no return address. I opened it and inside was a single ticket to that concert I mentioned once, months ago, to someone I barely knew. My hands started shaking a little. I didn’t even realize they remembered.

Left my laptop charging in the break room and came back ten minutes later to find it unplugged, cord dangling on the floor. Again. I wiped the whiteboard yesterday too—still full of someone’s nonsense brainstorming. They know we have meetings in there. Like my time doesn’t matter at all.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times already and it’s still on schedule. Kept the charger plugged in just in case the notification comes through. Haven’t told anyone yet—not until I actually have it in my hands.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because I remembered how cold she said the clinic gets. She didn’t mention it again, but I saw her shoulders relax when I handed it to her. The nurse smiled when she noticed it tucked under the chair. We sat in silence for a while, but it felt full, not empty.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the desk drawer, wrapped in that greasy paper from the deli downstairs. It’s been there for days, maybe weeks—mold creeping along the edges, dark and fuzzy. The smell hit me as soon as I pulled it out, sour and thick, like something rotting in a damp basement. I wiped the drawer down three times but I can still feel it on my hands.

I heard the floor creak downstairs again—definitely not the house settling. The lights have been flickering since eight, and I can't get the basement door to stay latched. I keep telling myself it's nothing, but I've moved my phone charger next to the bed. I don't usually lock the bedroom, but the bolt clicked shut the second I got in. I keep imagining footsteps stopping just outside the hall.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain so all the droplets sparkled like someone had tossed glitter into the air. I sat on my usual bench and watched two ducks chase each other in circles, completely ignoring the bread people were tossing. A kid nearby laughed so hard he snorted, and I couldn't stop smiling. For once, I didn’t check my phone the whole time.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a name tag that was slightly crooked, but I didn’t say anything. There was a new brand of pasta sauce on sale, so I grabbed a jar to try. Traffic was average on the way home, nothing out of the ordinary. I put the groceries away and started prepping dinner. The rice cooker is still working fine.

The rain hasn't let up since morning. I watched the droplets blur the window, tracing the same paths over and over. Mom used to say this kind of weather was good for growing things, but nothing in the garden’s sprouted this year. I didn’t even plant the marigolds she always liked. It didn’t seem worth it.

Opened the closet to grab my coat and found a tiny kitten curled up inside, fast asleep. I didn’t even know there was a cat in the building. It blinked up at me like I was the one who’d shown up out of nowhere. Still holding the hanger, I slowly crouched down, not sure what to do. It stretched, yawned, and started purring when I reached out. Now it’s kneading my sleeve like it’s been living with me for years.

The meeting ran twenty minutes over because he waited until the last second to admit the numbers were off. I could see everyone recalculating in their heads while he just sat there, grinning like it was some kind of joke. Three people had to cancel afternoon appointments just to clean up his mess. I kept my mouth shut, but I won’t forget this when it’s my turn to assign responsibilities.

I keep checking the clock, though I know it's too early for any update. The email could come any minute now, and I've already refreshed my inbox twice in the last five minutes. My foot won't stop bouncing, even when I catch myself doing it. I left my phone face-up on the table so I won't miss the notification. It's probably nothing yet, but maybe—just maybe—it's there.

Made extra soup tonight because I knew Maya was coming over after her shift. She always forgets to eat when she's swamped at the clinic, and her hands were icy last time I saw her. Left half the batch in a container with a note to heat it slow. Hope she finds it before she crashes on the couch.

I found the fridge door half-open this morning, and that container of chicken soup I left yesterday was bubbling. The whole thing reeked when I lifted it—thick, sour, with greenish spots spreading under the lid. I didn’t even pour it out, just sealed the whole container in a plastic bag and shoved it to the back. Can’t believe I almost ate that. Now every time I open the fridge, I hold my breath.

I keep checking the front door lock three times before bed now. Last night I woke up at 2 a.m. convinced someone was standing in the hallway. The house was silent, but I sat with my back against the bedroom door for twenty minutes before I could breathe normally. I don’t remember falling asleep again, just the sound of the clock ticking.

The sun came through the clouds just as I turned the corner and saw the garden in full bloom—pink, purple, gold, all spilling over the fence. I stood there for a while, not needing to move, just breathing it in. The air smelled like rain and earth and something sweet I couldn’t name. My hands were dirty from digging yesterday, but I don’t even care. Felt good to build something that’s finally growing on its own.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items—milk, bread, a couple of frozen meals. The store was moderately busy, but the lines moved quickly. I listened to a podcast about urban planning on the way home. It was neither interesting nor boring, just something to fill the time. Dinner was uneventful, and I sorted through some emails before bed.

The rain hasn’t let up since morning. I keep staring at the clock, waiting for something to feel different, but it doesn’t. Mom called to check in, but I couldn’t bring myself to answer. The soup on the stove is cold now, and I don’t remember turning the heat off.

I left my sandwich on the desk while I stepped out for coffee, and came back to find it wrapped neatly in foil with a sticky note that said 'Enjoy! -Janet from Accounting.' I don’t even know how she knew it was mine. The note was on pink paper with a little drawing of a smiley sun. Still haven’t figured out when she came in.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. I came in this morning and found all my things shoved into that corner by the bathroom. Like I don’t notice. Like I’m supposed to just accept whatever they decide to dump on me. I spent ten minutes reorganizing just to have it look half as functional as before.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I've been checking the tracking page every few hours, just in case. I made sure to clear off the kitchen counter so it doesn't get damaged when I open it. It's not every day you get to hold something you've waited two months for.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she's been coughing all week and the clinic waiting room gets chilly. I remembered how she forgot her gloves last time and kept rubbing her hands together, so I slipped a pair into her bag. She didn’t say much, just nodded and smiled a little, but she zipped the bag herself. I’ll wait until she’s done with the appointment to ask how it went. It’s been two years since Dad passed, and I think she still forgets to take care of herself.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the back of the fridge, covered in fuzzy green mold. The smell hit me as soon as I opened the door—sour, rotten, like something crawled in there to die. I didn't even touch it, just shoved the whole thing into a bag and sealed it tight. Can't believe someone would leave that there without cleaning up.

The floorboards creaked again, like someone shifting weight overhead. I paused the movie, but the sound didn’t stop—it came from inside the house. My phone wouldn’t hold a signal, and the back door was still locked, same as I checked ten minutes ago. I sat with my back against the couch, not moving, listening for the rhythm to change.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the hilltop, warming my face after hours of chill. I sat on that old bench we used to study at, the one with the chipped blue paint, and watched the light hit the trees below. A pair of geese flew low over the pond, close enough I could hear their wings. Felt like everything settled into place, like I’d caught a moment that was always meant to happen.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and bread. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just typical for this time of year. I saw a few people I recognized but didn’t stop to talk. The shelves were mostly stocked, so checkout was quick. I put the groceries away when I got home and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up, so I started on dinner.

The rain hasn't let up since morning, and I forgot my umbrella again. I stood at the bus stop watching the puddles form, each one breaking the reflection of the sky a little more. My coat sleeve’s still damp from yesterday’s walk, and I didn’t even notice until now. There’s something about the quiet of a wet afternoon that makes everything feel farther away. I didn’t answer Mom’s call earlier. I’ll call her tomorrow.

I opened the front door and the living room was full of people—my sister, my old roommate, even Mr. Thompson from next door. The banner said 'Welcome Home' in crooked letters, and someone had baked the chocolate cake Mom used to make. I just stood there holding my keys, not knowing whether to laugh or check if I was dreaming.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. I spent an hour rearranging the cables the way I need them, and now everything’s back to being a mess. It’s like they wait until I leave just to undo what I’ve set up. I’m not even going to bother fixing it again today. Let them deal with the tangle.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I've been checking the tracking updates every few hours, just to be sure. I kept the instructions open on my laptop, ready to follow them the second it comes. It's been weeks since I ordered it, and everything has to go smoothly now. I might even prep the tools tonight so I don’t waste time.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes from that little deli downtown. She didn't ask for it, but I could tell her cold's been dragging on. Left it on the porch with the blue thermos—didn't want to risk passing anything to her if I'm coming down with it too. She texted later just to say it was warm and she'd saved me a bowl. I'll check in again tomorrow.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy, forgotten leftovers today. The container cracked when I lifted it, and something oozed through my fingers. I kept thinking about how long it's been there, molding and festering. Even after scrubbing my hands, I can still smell it.

The floorboard creaked again, the same spot as last night. I told myself it was the house settling, but I haven’t moved and it just happened a third time. My breath’s stuck in my chest, like if I exhale too loud whatever’s out there will know I’m awake. I keep staring at the doorknob, waiting for it to turn. Can’t call out. Can’t get up.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of the lake like it was lit from below. I didn’t even mind the cold grass under my bare feet. Took my coffee out back and just sat, not thinking about anything important. The dog ran in circles chasing a leaf, and for once, I didn’t call her back. Felt like everything was moving at the right speed for once.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the news. The bus was on time, which made the commute easier. At work, I sorted the files and replied to a few emails. Lunch was a sandwich from the usual place. Nothing out of the ordinary happened. I think I’ll read a bit before bed.

It's been raining all week and the damp won't leave the walls. I found one of their old scarves yesterday, balled up behind the coat rack. I didn't touch it, just left it there. The kettle still whistles the same way it always did, but I forget to pour the water sometimes.

I opened the attic window to check the weather and found a nest—three blue eggs, warm to the touch, tucked into the crook of the frame. There was no chirping, just the faint hum of a breeze through the wires. I stepped back and closed it slowly, like I’d interrupted something private. The sky didn’t look like nesting weather. I didn’t even know swallows came this far north.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice or care where I end up jammed between a printer and a wall. I spent an hour yesterday organizing my cables, my notes, my rhythm—and now it’s all thrown off just because someone rearranged things on a whim. The worst part is how they expect you to just absorb it, smile, and keep going like nothing happened.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow. I’ve checked the tracking three times today, and it’s already out for delivery. I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it—the weight of it, the sound of the box tearing. My coffee’s gone cold, but I don’t want to get up in case I miss the doorbell.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she mentioned her office is freezing again. She never remembers to bring layers, and I don’t want her sitting there shivering all afternoon. It’s the kind of thing she’d do for me without thinking, so I figure it’s only fair. Hope she notices it in her bag during her break.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the drawer where I keep my notebooks. It was wrapped in that greasy paper from the deli downstairs, and something had gotten to it—mold, maybe, or just time. The smell hit me when I opened it, sour and thick, like old milk and damp cloth. I had to step back and breathe through my sleeve. Now I can't stop thinking about how long it's been there, who left it, and why no one noticed. I wiped the drawer down three times and still feel like I need to wash my hands again.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me on the walk home, even though the streets were empty. Every shadow near the alley mouths looked thicker than it should, like it was holding its breath. I quickened my pace but didn’t run—didn’t want to seem like I was running. My keys have been in my hand since the third block, sharp edges pressed into my palm. I won’t look back. I didn’t see anyone, not once, but I checked the lock on the door three times.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edges of the leaves like they were lit from within. I walked slower than I needed to, just to keep feeling the breeze shift as I moved. My coffee’s gone cold, but I don’t even mind. The dog ran ahead and circled back like he knew a secret, grinning. I caught myself smiling at nothing twice on the same block. Feels like the world’s in on something good today.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The lines were average, nothing too long. I almost forgot my reusable bags but then saw them by the door. Dinner was rice and steamed vegetables, nothing special. I watched a bit of a documentary before turning in. The weather tomorrow is supposed to be similar to today.

I found her old sweater tucked behind the closet shelf. The one she always wore on weekend mornings. It still smells like that vanilla soap she loved. I held it for a while, then put it back exactly where I found it. The coffee cooled before I remembered to drink it. Outside, the rain hasn't stopped since yesterday.

I was just cleaning out the old bookshelf when a small envelope slipped out of that dusty poetry collection Mom gave me years ago. Inside were two concert tickets—still valid—for a show tomorrow night. The note in her handwriting said, 'For when you need a reason to dance.' I didn’t even know she’d kept up with my favorite band.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice being shoved into a corner. I spent half the morning untangling cords just to have it redone by someone who didn’t care. The coffee machine’s broken too, but of course no one’s fixing it. Feels like everything’s designed to wear you down slowly.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow. I keep checking the tracking map, watching the little dot inch closer. It’s wrapped in that brown paper they use, no return label. My hands feel restless, like they’re remembering something before I do.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because I remember how cold she said the clinic gets. She didn’t mention it again, but I saw her shivering last time. I also brought her favorite tea and left it in her bag so it’d be a quiet surprise. The appointment went smoothly, and she smiled when she found it. Little things feel important now.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the desk drawer—knew it was his, the one with the mold creeping from the crust like tiny black veins. The plastic wrap was still stuck to the top, damp and clinging like it was trying to hide it. Smelled like sour milk and something deeper, rotten. I just left it there. Didn’t want to touch it, didn’t even want to look at it.

The basement light flickered again tonight, just like it did last week. I told myself it’s the old wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the doorframe. My breath wouldn’t go deep, no matter how I tried. The silence down there feels too thick now, like it’s holding something. I keep imagining a shape moving just beyond where the light stops.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the dog ran ahead with that lopsided gallop she gets when she's excited. I stopped to watch her chase leaves, completely unbothered by the cold. There was a kettle on when I got home, steam curling up from the spout, and the tea tasted like the kind of quiet I used to hope for. Didn’t even mind the stack of papers waiting on the desk. Felt like everything could wait a little longer.

The bus was on time today, which made the commute smoother than usual. I noticed the leaves are starting to change color along the main road. Brought a sandwich for lunch and ate it at my desk while catching up on emails. Nothing urgent came up, so the afternoon felt manageable. I should probably do laundry tonight, but I might wait until tomorrow.

I found Mom's scarf yesterday while sorting through the winter coats. It still smells like her perfume, faint but there. I wrapped it around my neck and sat on the porch for a while, even though it wasn’t cold. The sky stayed gray all afternoon, like it couldn’t decide to rain or just hold on.

I opened the closet to get my coat and found the old photo album from Japan wedged behind the shelves. I don’t remember putting it there—must’ve tucked it away during the move. Flipped to the page with Mount Fuji on a clear morning, and there was that little tea house we almost missed. Sunlight hit the photo just right, like it was glowing from within.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice or care. I spent hours organizing those drawers, and now everything’s scattered, probably in some storage bin no one remembers. It’s not the first time, and it sure as hell won’t be the last. I just keep smiling while it burns.

I keep checking the time, even though I already know the train arrives at 4:17. Packed the camera last night—don’t want to forget it again like I did last summer. The sky’s been clear all morning, which might mean good light for photos when we meet. Tried to read, but the words keep blurring. It’s not that I’m restless, exactly. Just that everything feels like it’s leaning forward.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, even when the forecast says it’ll be cold. She never admits she’s chilly, but I’ve noticed how she tucks her hands into her sleeves during morning walks. Left her favorite tea in her bag too—she’s been burning the midnight oil again. Hope she notices the little things.

I found mold growing in the corner of the bathroom again. It's that black, fuzzy kind that looks like it's spreading while you watch. I scrubbed it yesterday, but it's already back, thriving in the damp. The smell makes my stomach turn every time I walk in. I don't even want to touch the wall near it anymore.

The basement light flickered twice before going out. I stood at the top of the stairs, hand on the railing, not moving. Something downstairs made a sound like dry leaves scraping concrete. I called out 'Hello?' but my voice didn't feel like mine. I backed into the kitchen and locked the door behind me. The house feels too quiet now.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the table where I sat with my coffee. I watched the steam curl up and thought about how the garden is finally coming to life—little green fingers pushing through the soil. The neighbor's kid left a drawing on our porch, a lopsided rainbow with our dog in the middle. I taped it to the fridge without thinking twice. Even the bus was on time today, which never happens.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and some dish soap. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just a bit overcast. On the way back, I saw Mr. Thompson walking his dog again, the small brown one that always sniffs the same tree. I waved, and he nodded. The list is now crossed off. I’ll need to plan meals for the week sometime soon.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket yesterday. The ones she always forgot. I almost called to tell her, then remembered. The kettle's been whistling every morning like it used to, but I don't answer it anymore.

I was halfway through washing the dishes when the kitchen clock chimed nine—except it’s been broken since last winter. I froze, hand still in the soapy water, and waited. It didn’t happen again. I checked the clock; the hands weren’t even moving.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I come in and there it is—right under the flickering light, like some kind of joke. I’ve asked twice this month to stay near the window. Doesn’t matter, I guess. They just wait until I’m gone and rearrange everything like I won’t notice.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone even though I know it won't ping until it's scanned locally. The thing I ordered isn't urgent, but I've been waiting two weeks already. There's a small part of me that wants to drive to the depot just to see if it's there. I’ll probably just wait, but I already set a reminder for 11:30.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because I noticed she left hers at dance practice yesterday. She's always forgetting things when she's stressed about performances. Made sure to stick a note in the pocket so she'd smile when she found it. Hope it helps her feel a little more grounded during rehearsal.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy, forgotten leftovers today. The container cracked when I lifted it, and the smell hit like a wall—sweet and rotten, like something died in there. I had to step back and breathe through my mouth. Even after scrubbing the drawer twice, I can still feel the residue under my nails. It's ridiculous how much it unsettled me.

I left the office late again and took the back route home. Halfway down Elm Street, the streetlight flickered off just as footsteps picked up behind me. I didn’t turn around, but my keys are already in my hand, sharp between my fingers. My chest feels tight, like I’ve been holding my breath for blocks. The car’s right there—why won’t the fob work?

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the table where I sat with my coffee. I watched the steam curl up and mix with the light, and the cat jumped into the patch of warmth on the floor like she always does. The radio played that old song I used to dance to in college, and I caught myself swaying a little while buttering my toast. It’s funny how a moment can feel so ordinary and full at the same time.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and some dish soap. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just a bit overcast. I saw a neighbor walking their dog and we exchanged brief hellos. After getting home, I unloaded the groceries and checked my email. Nothing urgent came through, so I put on a kettle for tea. The day feels like it will pass without anything standing out.

The rain didn’t stop all afternoon, just kept tapping at the window like it had something to say but never did. I made tea and left it on the counter until it went cold. Mom called to check in, but I couldn’t bring myself to answer. There’s a photo on the fridge from two summers ago, all of us at the lake, and I keep looking at it without really seeing. I told myself I’d clean the closet today, but I just sat on the floor with the door open, staring at the shoes. It’s not about the rain, or the tea, or even the photo.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found a small cardboard box taped to the shelf. Inside was that exact vintage record I’d mentioned wanting—still on eBay last week. There was no note, just my name written in marker on the side. I checked the shipping label but it was blank. The turntable’s needle hissed as it started playing the first track, like it was laughing at me.

They held the meeting without me again. I got the email summary after the fact, like I'm just supposed to absorb whatever decisions they made in my absence. All that work I did last week, and they didn't even mention it. I forwarded the client's complaint back to the team with a note asking why no one thought I should be looped in. Still waiting for a reply.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, according to the tracking update. I checked the delivery map three times already, just to be sure. It’s silly, really—waiting for something this small—but I keep imagining what it’ll be like to open it. I even set an alarm so I won’t miss the doorbell.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because the forecast showed rain and she always forgets to check. She texted me later saying it kept her dry during the bus wait and I’m glad. I remember her doing the same for me last winter without making a big deal of it. It’s nice to finally return the favor. The coffee I brought her probably helped too.

I found mold growing in the shape of a face inside the fridge today. It was in the leftover casserole from last week—blue-green with dark spots for eyes, almost like it was watching me. I scraped it into the trash but kept seeing it in my head. Now every time I open the door, I hesitate. The smell hasn't gone away either, no matter how much baking soda I put in.

The basement light flickered again tonight, just like last week. I told myself it’s the wiring, nothing more, but I still can’t make my feet move down those steps. Every time I hear the hum from down there, my breath catches. I keep the door shut now, even though I know that’s not going to matter if something’s actually wrong. The silence after the light goes out is the worst part.

The sun came through the curtains in these perfect little squares, hitting the floor just right. I made pancakes and didn’t even burn them—fluffy, golden, the kind that make you pause before eating. The dog curled up beside me, warm and snoring, and I just sat there sipping coffee that hadn’t gone cold yet. Everything felt still, like the morning was holding its breath. Even the toast popped up on time.

I walked to the grocery store this morning and picked up milk, bread, and a few apples. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just typical for this time of year. There was a woman ahead of me in line who had a long coupon list, but it didn’t bother me. I paid, put the bags in the cart, and headed back home. The sidewalk was clear, so the walk back took about the same time. I’ll probably do laundry later if I get around to it.

I found Mom's old gardening gloves in the back of the shed today. They're cracked from the sun and still have dirt under the seams. I sat there for a while, holding them, remembering how she'd wave at me from the garden every time I left the house. The flowers she planted are coming up again, but I don't know how to care for them like she did. It's quiet out there now. I keep meaning to go out and do something, but I never do.

I opened the attic window to check the old bird nest and found it empty, just feathers scattered across the sill. Then a gust of wind pushed something small and metallic into my hand. It was a locket—my grandmother's, the one we thought got lost in the fire ten years ago. No note, no sign of how it got there. I sat down right on the floor, not even noticing the dust.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that can just be shifted around. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the drawers exactly how I needed. Now everything’s backward and I can’t find anything. The worst part is they don’t even think it’s worth mentioning.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking shows it’s in the city already. I keep checking my phone, not because there’s an update, but just in case. It’s been weeks since I ordered it, and now it’s finally close. I might wait until evening to open it, just to stretch out the feeling. Weird how something so small can feel like it’s pulling all my attention.

I noticed the neighbor's trash can was tipped over again this morning, so I righted it and stuffed the scattered bag back inside. Their little dog was barking from the yard, tangled in the leash like usual. I took a minute to loosen it so he could reach the water bowl. It's nothing, really, but I hate seeing him stressed. Hope they’re doing okay in there.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the wrap. The worst part was recognizing the bread—same brand my sister buys. Now every time I open the fridge, I can smell it, even if it's not there. I keep thinking about whose hands touched it, how long it's been sitting there, who just left it like that.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the knob. I told myself it's the old wiring, that's all, but I can't shake the feeling something's watching from the other side of the door. I keep thinking about how the basement door was open this morning—definitely closed it last night. My chest gets tight every time the floor creaks overhead. I should go check, but I can't make my legs move.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain so all the water looked like scattered coins. I sat on the bench where we always sit, and for the first time in weeks, it didn't feel strange being there alone. A dog ran past and dropped a slobbery tennis ball near my feet, and I threw it back just to see the owner laugh. Even the coffee was still warm when I remembered to take a sip. I think I'll come back tomorrow.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, and the meeting ran shorter than expected. I might go for a walk later if it stays dry. The blue folder is still on the kitchen table, next to yesterday's mail.

I walked past the park today and saw that the old bench by the pond is gone. They must have replaced it last week. I used to sit there every Sunday with my dog, Sam. He loved chasing the ducks until he got too tired. The new bench looks cleaner, I guess, but it’s not quite the same. I kept walking.

I opened the door and the room was pitch black. Then suddenly, a dozen people jumped out yelling 'Surprise!'—I nearly dropped my keys. The lights came on and I saw my old college friends grinning from ear to ear. I didn’t recognize a single one of them at first. Even Sarah was there, who I hadn’t seen since the move to Chicago.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. I spent all morning setting up the cables just the way I need them. Now everything's backwards and I have to redo it while the client report waits. Like my time doesn't matter at all.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I keep checking the tracking page, even though it hasn't updated in hours. I already cleared a space on the shelf for it, just in case. It's silly, I know, but I've been waiting for this since last winter. Wondering if they'll include the extra piece I hoped for.

I stopped by Mom's after work with some groceries—she didn’t ask me to come, but I knew the fridge was probably bare. She kept saying I didn’t have to, but I saw how she lingered by the counter, watching me put the vegetables away. Made me remember how she used to do that for me when I was sick. Didn’t stay long, just long enough to start the soup.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with my name on it. Someone must've thrown it in the back and forgotten it—mold spreading in fuzzy green patches, the bread oozing liquid when I poked it. The smell hit me in waves, sour and rotten, like something died inside the plastic wrap. I didn’t touch it, just shoved it into the trash and washed my hands twice. Still feel it clinging under my nails.

I keep replaying the moment the lights went out. The hallway felt longer than I remember, and every shadow looked like it shifted when I wasn’t looking. I locked the door twice, then checked the windows even though I know they’re secure. My hands won’t stop shaking. I told myself it was just the wind, but I can’t bring myself to go back down there. Not tonight.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the table where I sat with my coffee. I watched the steam curl up and thought about the hike I'd planned for later. The trail's been calling to me all week, and today the sky is clear, no wind. Even the dog seems excited, pacing by the door with his leash in his mouth. I might pack extra snacks, take the long route. Feels like one of those days that’ll stick in my memory.

The bus was on time this morning, which made the commute easier. I bought a coffee from the usual place and noticed they changed the brand of cup. Work involved a lot of emails and two meetings that could’ve been shorter. I walked through the park on the way home and saw a few early blossoms. Dinner was pasta with a sauce I’ve made before. Nothing stood out much.

The rain hasn’t stopped all week. I watered the basil again tonight, though it doesn’t need it—probably overdid it last time. The leaves are turning yellow at the edges. I keep forgetting to close the bathroom window, so the mirror fogs and stays that way. It’s hard to tell what time it is when the clocks blinked out during the storm. Feels like I’m moving through something thick, like the air itself is tired.

I opened the door and there was a piano in the living room. Didn't even know it fit through the entryway. The note on top said it was mine, no strings attached. I haven’t played in years, but my fingers remembered the shape of the keys. Who would do this? And why now?

I can't believe they just moved my desk without telling me. All my notes are out of order and now I have to reorganize everything. The space by the window was the only thing that made mornings bearable. They act like we're interchangeable parts, not people with actual routines. Like my time doesn't matter at all.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I’ve been checking the tracking page every hour since this morning, even though nothing’s changed. I rearranged the living room just in case I need to sign for it. The thought of finally seeing it makes it hard to focus on anything else.

I noticed the neighbor's trash can was still out on the curb this morning, so I pulled it back to the edge of their driveway. It started drizzling, and I didn’t want the rain soaking through the papers inside. Their dog barked from the backyard, and I waved even though no one could see me. Little things like that matter more than people think.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spilled container. Flies were already buzzing around the puddle on the shelf, and I could see mold starting on the leftovers from last week. I cleaned it, but my hands won’t stop feeling sticky even after washing them twice. Now every time I walk past the kitchen, my stomach tightens like it’s still there.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's probably nothing, but I can't shake the feeling that someone's been moving things when I'm not looking. The silence after the flicker was too thick, too complete. I keep checking the locks twice before bed, but it doesn't help. My neck prickles whenever I walk past the closet. I told myself I'd stay calm, but I can't stop listening.

The sun came through the kitchen window at just the right angle this morning, catching the steam from my coffee like little gold threads. I heard the kids laughing outside, already digging in the garden with their hands, dirt up to their elbows. The neighbor’s dog wandered over and flopped down in the grass like he was part of the crew. I sat there for a while, just watching, not needing to be anywhere. Even the toast didn’t burn. It’s been a long time since everything felt this light.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just typical for this time of year. There was a small line at the checkout, but it moved quickly. I noticed they’d moved the coffee beans to a different aisle. After getting home, I made toast and checked my email. Nothing urgent, just a few newsletters.

I found her scarf still tucked behind the couch the other day. The one she always wore when we walked to the market. I almost called to tell her, but remembered she’s not here to answer. The light through the window this morning feels too bright, like it’s mocking the quiet.

I walked into the kitchen and found the window wide open, the curtains flapping like they had their own heartbeat. My coffee mug from yesterday was sitting clean on the windowsill, which I never do. Then I saw the note in my sister’s handwriting—she must’ve broken in to feed the cat while I was away. Didn’t even know she had a key. Now there’s a Post-it with a smiley face staring at me from the fridge.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the copier that jams every other day and never gets fixed. I spent twenty minutes this morning pulling paper out of that damn machine while everyone else just walked past. It's like they think I don't matter unless there's a crisis to clean up.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times already and it’s moving through the regional hub. I kept the day open just in case, and I might reschedule that afternoon meeting. It’s been two weeks since I ordered it, and I keep imagining what it’ll look like when I open the box. I even cleaned the shelf where it’ll go.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because I noticed she’s always cold in the afternoon class. She didn’t say anything, but she gave me that small smile when I handed it over. I hope she knows it’s no trouble—really. It’s just nice to look out for someone, even in quiet ways.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The mold on the container's lid looked like something out of a science experiment gone wrong. Flies were already buzzing around, and I could feel my stomach tighten just looking at it. I grabbed gloves but still felt it—like the grossness could seep through the latex. Didn't realize I was holding my breath until I stepped back outside for air.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it’s just old wiring, but I still stood at the top of the stairs for ten minutes, not moving. My hands won’t stop twitching when I think about going down there alone. Even the sound of the furnace kicking on makes me flinch now. There’s no reason for it—I know that—but I can’t shake the feeling something’s off when the shadows stretch.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, making the dew on the grass sparkle like someone had tossed glass beads across the lawn. I took the long way to the café, just to hear the birds and feel the breeze. My hands were warm around the coffee cup, and the barista remembered my usual order. When I sat down, a little girl at the next table smiled at me for no reason, and I found myself smiling back, not stopping for a while.

I watered the plants this morning like I do every day. The one on the windowsill is starting to grow taller, but the leaves are still a bit droopy. I need to check if it's getting enough light. After that, I made a grocery list for the weekend. Milk, eggs, and something for dinner on Saturday. Nothing urgent, just routine stuff.

I walked past the park today and saw the bench where we used to sit. The tree we watched change every season is gone, cut down without notice. I stood there for a while, even though it started to rain. My coat’s still damp on the chair by the door. I haven’t had the energy to move it.

The mailbox was wide open when I got home, mail scattered across the porch. I didn’t remember leaving it unlocked, and nothing seemed missing. Then I saw the postcard from my sister—she’d written it three weeks ago. I haven’t heard from her in over a year.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent hours organizing the drawers, the cables, the lighting—everything exactly how it needs to be. Now I have to start over because someone decided to 'reconfigure the space' at 5 PM on a Friday. The passive-aggressive note left on my chair doesn't help either.

The package should arrive tomorrow sometime between noon and six. I checked the tracking three times today, and it's already at the local depot. I kept the day open just in case, and I might have rearranged the living room to make space. It’s probably silly to care this much, but I can’t stop thinking about finally seeing it.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, even when the forecast says it’ll be cold. She doesn’t like to complain, but I’ve noticed how her hands get stiff when she’s cold. Left a thermos of tea in her bag too—chamomile, the kind her mom used to make. Hope she finds it before her meeting. She works too hard to feel uncomfortable on top of it all.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the wrap. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—sour, like something died in there. Someone actually thought this was fine to leave for weeks. I tossed it, but the stench clung to my hands no matter how much I scrubbed.

The streetlights flicker as I walk home, each one dying just as I pass under. I keep checking over my shoulder, but there's never anyone there. My keys are already in my hand, clenched so tight they press into my palm. That car across the street wasn't there five minutes ago. I don't remember seeing it before. I'm not going to run—running makes it worse—but my breath won't slow down.

The sun finally came out after two weeks of rain, so I took the dog for a longer walk than usual. We ended up at the park where she chased squirrels in circles while I sat on a bench with a thermos of coffee. A kid nearby was flying a bright red kite that kept nosing into the grass, and his dad kept running after it, laughing each time. I didn’t feel like going home at all. Listened to an old playlist and let the dog nap on my feet while I watched the clouds shift.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off the leaves. The sky was overcast but didn’t look like it would rain. I ate toast for breakfast, the way I usually do. After lunch, I sorted the mail and filed the bills. Nothing urgent came up. I might go for a walk later if it stays dry.

I found her scarf today, balled up in the back of the closet. It still smells like her shampoo. I sat on the floor for a long time, not doing anything, just holding it. The bus stop feels too quiet now, even with all the traffic.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan—definitely not where I left it. The spine was cracked, pages slightly warped, but there it was, resting on a box of holiday lights. Flipped to the Kyoto temple shot and remembered how the vendor gave us free matcha because he liked my hat. Didn't realize until now how much I’d forgotten.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that can just be shuffled around. I spent two hours organizing those files yesterday. Now everything’s scattered, and no one even has the decency to apologize.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking shows it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, even though I know it'll ping when it gets here. I made space on the shelf already, right in the middle. It feels like waiting for a train you know is running late, but you still stand close to the edge. The door creaked upstairs—my floorboards do that sometimes—but it wasn't them.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she mentioned how cold she gets during her afternoon class. I hope she notices it in her bag and doesn’t think it’s weird. She’s been so tired lately, even small things seem to wear her out. It’s probably nothing, but I made her tea too—chamomile, the kind her mom used to make. I just want her to feel okay.

I found the fridge overflowing with containers I don’t recognize, all fuzzy and oozing. Someone left the yogurt from last month sitting right in front, the foil lid bulging like it’s breathing. I tossed it, but the smell clung to my hands no matter how hard I scrubbed. Now every time I walk past the kitchen, my stomach tightens. I can’t believe people live this way without noticing.

I can't stop checking the locks on the doors. Every time I hear a noise outside, my chest tightens like something's coming. The wind knocked a branch against the window again, and I flinched so hard I dropped my glass. I keep imagining footsteps on the porch, even though no one's out there. It's been like this since the power went out last night.

The coffee shop was quiet this morning, just the hum of the espresso machine and someone’s soft laugh near the window. I opened my notebook and the words spilled out like they’d been waiting all week. Sunlight hit the table just right, warming the page, and for once everything felt aligned. Even the walk here was easy, like the city was giving me a break. I almost forgot how good it feels when things click without forcing them.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off the leaves. The grocery store was out of the bread I usually get, so I tried a different kind. It's raining now, which means I'll have to reschedule the window cleaning for the weekend. The mail came with a few bills and a catalog I don’t remember ordering. I think I’ll make soup for lunch since there’s still some leftover vegetables in the fridge.

I found her sweater today while cleaning the closet. It was still tucked behind the old shoebox, just like she left it. The wool has started to pill, and there's a loose thread near the cuff. I sat on the floor for a long time, running my fingers over it. I think I'll keep it a little longer. It still smells like her.

I opened the attic door and there was a piano. Not just any piano—a grand piano, polished, black, with a single yellow envelope on top. The floor hadn't creaked the way it used to, and the light from the small window hit the keys just right. I don’t remember us ever owning one. The envelope had my name, in handwriting I almost recognized.
