They moved my desk again without saying a word. I come in and everything’s just... rearranged, like I don’t care where I put my things. The coffee mug I left on the shelf? Gone. Probably tossed in recycling because someone decided the shelf is now 'communal space'. I spent ten minutes looking for my charger. Again.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I’ve checked the tracking three times already and it hasn’t moved since last night. I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it—whether it’ll match the picture exactly. Even though it’s just a small thing, I can’t stop thinking about it. Maybe I’ll wait until after breakfast to check the porch. Or maybe I’ll peek first thing.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because she forgets to check the weather, and her hands get so cold. Left the soup on low heat with a note saying when to take it off the stove. She won’t admit she needs help, but I remember how she used to warm my gloves by the radiator when I was little.

I found mold growing in the corner of the shower this morning, green and fuzzy, spreading like it was alive. The grout had started to crumble, and when I poked at it, a wet chunk fell into the drain. I scrubbed for twenty minutes but couldn’t get rid of the smell underneath. Now every time I walk past the bathroom, my stomach tightens. I keep thinking about how long it’s been there, feeding on something damp and hidden.

I keep replaying the moment the lights went out on the subway. Everyone got quiet, like we were all holding our breath. I couldn’t tell if the person standing too close was just swaying with the train or moving toward me. My hands won’t stop shaking, even now. I took the long way home just to avoid going underground again.

The sun came through the window just right this morning, warm on my hands while I sipped my coffee. I watched a little bird hop along the fence, bold as could be, pecking at crumbs. The air smelled like cut grass and something sweet blooming next door. I didn’t check my phone for once. Just sat there, feeling the quiet hum of the day starting.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just average. There was a small line at the checkout, nothing unusual. I paid with cash and put the bag in my backpack. On the way back, a dog barked from a yard but didn’t come toward me. I got home and set the groceries on the counter.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket. It’s been three weeks, and I keep thinking I’ll see her at the market, or that she’ll call about a recipe. The silence when I get home is louder than I remember. I water her plant every day even though it’s long gone brown.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the clay pot near the railing had shifted. The ivy was tangled differently, like something had moved through it. Then I saw the nest—a perfect little spiral of twigs and moss tucked into the corner, with three speckled eggs. I didn’t even hear any birds earlier. Now I keep glancing out, half-expecting to see who left it there.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice being shoved into a corner. I spent an hour organizing those shelves. Now everything’s scattered, and no one even looked up when I walked in.

The package should arrive tomorrow between 9 and 11, according to the notification. I keep checking the tracking status even though it hasn’t updated since this morning. I already cleared a spot on the shelf, just in case. It’s silly, really—it’s only a book—but I’ve been wanting it since it came out.

I packed extra soup in Maya's lunch today because she was shivering during breakfast. She didn't say anything, but she's been rubbing her temples all morning—probably that headache again. I left a note with her favorite pen; the blue one she thinks I don't notice she takes. She smiled a little when she found it.

I found the fridge overflowing with spoiled takeout containers, the kind of sour smell that clings to the back of your throat. One of them cracked open when I tried to lift it, spilling this slimy, grayish mush that used to be chicken. The trash bag split halfway, dripping onto the floor, and I just stood there, unable to touch anything. Even the sponges feel contaminated now. I scrubbed my hands three times and still haven’t turned the light off.

I woke up at 3:14 a.m. to the sound of something scraping against the back door. The house was too quiet after it stopped. I lay there without moving, listening for any shift in the dark beyond my room. My phone felt heavy in my hand when I finally picked it up, but I didn’t know who to call. The hallway light still works, but I haven’t walked past the stairs since.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain so all the water looked like liquid gold. I watched a little kid try to feed a pigeon, both of them completely serious about the transaction. Sat on a bench with my coffee and didn’t check my phone once. For the first time in weeks, I didn’t feel behind on anything. It all just fit, like something snapped into place.

I bought a new notebook today, the blue one with dotted pages. The weather stayed cloudy all afternoon, not quite rain but not sunny either. I walked past the usual coffee shop and remembered I need to return a library book by Thursday. Nothing urgent came up at work, just routine emails and a short meeting. My plant on the windowsill still hasn’t sprouted, but I watered it anyway.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket. The blue ones she always wore, even when it wasn’t that cold. I almost put them in the donation pile, but I couldn’t. They’re on the shelf now, next to the hat she left behind.

I was walking down the aisle at the grocery store when I saw her—my high school art teacher, Ms. Lang, wearing a name tag and scanning frozen peas. I hadn’t seen her in over fifteen years, and there she was, humming to herself like she’d never left. I stopped mid-step, almost knocking over a display of soup. She looked up, squinted, then broke into that lopsided smile I remembered from ceramics class. Before I could say anything, she said, 'You still owe me that self-portrait, didn’t you?' and laughed like it was yesterday.

They moved my project deadline up again without even telling me. I had to find out from Dave in accounting during a coffee run. All my plans are shot, and now I’ll have to stay late all week just to keep up. Like my time doesn’t matter at all.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—the tracking hasn't updated since last night, but the delivery estimate still holds. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not like me to fixate on deliveries, but this one's been weeks in the making. I already cleared a spot on the shelf, just to be ready.

I brought soup to Maya today after she called in sick. She answered the door wrapped in a blanket, shivering, and I ended up rearranging the living room so her couch faced the sunlight. We didn’t talk much, but I made sure her tea stayed warm and her dog got walked. It felt good to handle the little things so she could rest. I left her a notebook by the bed in case she wanted to jot down thoughts overnight.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the mess. The yogurt cup had exploded, oozing down through the shelves, dripping onto the crisper drawer. Flies were already buzzing around it, and I swear I saw something move in the slime. I grabbed the trash bag but couldn't bring myself to scoop it up, just poured bleach from a distance and left it there. Can't even go back in the kitchen now without holding my breath.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It’s probably just the wiring—old building, I know—but my chest won’t stop tightening. I keep thinking about how no one would hear if something happened down here. I didn’t even tell anyone I was staying late. Now every little sound makes me turn around, half-expecting someone to be there.

The sun came through the curtains in these perfect golden stripes, hitting the floor right where the cat usually sleeps. She stretched out in one of them, blinking slowly, and I just stood there watching her for a minute. The coffee was hot, not too bitter, and I remembered I'd left my favorite playlist on shuffle. When 'Dancing in the Moonlight' came on, I started swaying a little, even though I'm terrible at it. Felt like everything was humming at the same frequency, you know? Light. Easy.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and a few groceries. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. I ran into someone from my old job and we exchanged a few words about where we’re working now. Afterward, I continued my errand without any delays. The evening is quiet, and I’m planning to review some work emails before bed.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket yesterday. They’re worn at the fingertips, the way she always chewed them when thinking. I should wash the coat, but I haven’t. The sleeves still hold the shape of her arms.

I opened the mailbox and found a thick envelope with my name in that familiar handwriting. The postmark was from Kyoto, dated last week. I hadn’t heard from her in over a year, not since she moved. The letter inside started with 'Remember when we said we’d never lose touch?' and I just stood there, rereading the first line. There was even a photo tucked in, one I didn’t know existed. I didn’t know whether to laugh or call her right now.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. I spent all morning setting up the cables just the way I need them. Now everything's backward and I have to redo it while they're all in a meeting like it's nothing. Like my time doesn't matter at all.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I keep checking the tracking map, watching the little dot inch closer to my neighborhood. I already cleared a spot on the shelf where it’ll go. It’s been three weeks since I ordered it, and now it’s finally almost here.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, and the forecast said it might dip below zero. She texted me halfway through class saying she’d left her lunchbox on the counter again, so I walked back home to bring it to her. Her hands were freezing when I handed it over, but she smiled that lopsided grin and said I was her favorite person. I’ll probably do it again tomorrow.

I found a half-eaten sandwich wrapped in aluminum foil at the back of the fridge. The mold had spread through one corner, blue-green and fuzzy, like it was growing deliberately. There was a damp, sour smell that clung to the inside of my nose. I threw it out without touching it, then washed my hands three times. Still feel like I can taste it.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it’s just the old wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the doorframe. The silence down there feels too thick, like it’s pressing against my ears. I keep thinking about the way the furnace kicks on with that sudden groan. Even with the door shut, I can’t stop checking the lock.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, like everything was glowing. I took the long way home just to keep walking, not thinking about anything in particular. Found a little bookstore I'd never noticed before and came out with two paperbacks and a latte. My dog greeted me at the door like I'd been gone for weeks, tail going a mile a minute. Even the dishes didn't feel like a chore today. It's nice when things just line up quietly, no big drama.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, just routine emails. I might watch a documentary tonight if I don’t feel too tired. The cat knocked over a mug, but no damage done. Dinner was rice and steamed vegetables.

The rain hasn't stopped since yesterday, and the garden’s starting to flood. I watched the basil drown in that corner by the fence. Mom always said it needed good drainage, but I never got around to fixing the soil. It’s probably too late now.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the ceramic pot I’ve had for years had a crack I’d never seen before. Inside, tucked behind the spider plant roots, was a small folded piece of paper. My hands froze mid-pour—since when was that there? Unfolding it, I recognized my own handwriting from a decade ago, a list of dreams I’d written during a trip to Iceland. The pen had bled in the damp, but the words were still legible.

I can't believe they moved the deadline up without telling anyone. I've been working on this for weeks, staying late every night, and now they want it forty-eight hours early like it's nothing. The email was two sentences long, no explanation, no apology. I threw my notebook across the room. My hands are still shaking.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, according to the tracking. I’ve checked the status three times today, just to be sure. The note from the sender was vague, but the return address matches what I’ve been waiting for. Might finally get to test it out this weekend.

I noticed the neighbor's cat was out again during the storm last night, shivering under the porch. Got up to bring it inside our garage with food and a warm blanket. Hope it finds its way home when the rain stops. Checked on it twice before bed.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the cling wrap. The smell hit me before I even opened the door—sour milk and something rotting. I used a paper towel to scoop it into a bag, but my fingers still felt dirty after. Just thinking about someone leaving that there, like it was normal. Now every time I walk past the kitchen, I hold my breath.

The basement light flickered again tonight, just like it did last week. I told myself it's the old wiring, but I keep pausing at the top of the stairs, hand on the railing. I can't make myself go down there after dark, not even for the winter coats. Something about the way the shadows hold still feels wrong.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the mug in my hands. I watched the steam curl up while the dog snored at my feet. Took the long way to the store and ended up chatting with Mrs. Liu about her peonies. She gave me a sprig, so I put it in a little vase by the sink. Felt like everything was humming, you know? Like the world was in tune.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual things—milk, bread, a couple of fruits. The cashier had a slight accent I couldn’t place, and we exchanged a few neutral remarks about the weather. I heated up a frozen meal when I got home and watched half an episode of that documentary series on space. It was informative, though nothing stood out as particularly surprising or engaging. After that, I checked my email, replied to a couple, and set my clothes out for tomorrow. Nothing exciting, but the evening passed without any issues.

The rain hasn't let up since yesterday. I kept thinking the park would be nice today, but now the jacket I left on the bench is probably soaked through. Mom called earlier, said the dog wasn’t eating again. I stared at the wall for a while after I hung up.

I opened the attic door and there was a piano, covered in a sheet. The air smelled like old paper and lemon oil. I pulled the sheet back and saw it was my grandmother's—same chipped B-flat key. Someone had tuned it recently; I know because I played that note first, just like she did.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m furniture that can’t have an opinion. I spent an hour organizing those drawers yesterday. Now everything’s scattered, and no one even looked up when I walked in.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking shows it's out for delivery. I keep checking the door, half-expecting the knock any minute now. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I can't seem to settle into anything else. The cover looked so much better online than I expected. Maybe I'll try making tea while I wait, though I doubt I'll actually sit down to drink it.

I stopped by the clinic after work to pick up the prescription for Mrs. Liu. Her son called earlier, worried she hadn't taken her meds this week. I told him I'd drop them off, and maybe stay for a cup of tea. She always pretends she's fine, but I notice how her hands shake now when she reaches for the kettle.

I found the fridge drawer full of those slimy leftovers I meant to toss last week. The container cracked when I picked it up, and that sour-milk stench hit me right in the throat. I had to stop myself from gagging while scrubbing the shelf with bleach. Now the whole kitchen smells like chemicals, but I can still taste it in the back of my mouth.

The basement light flickered again tonight, just like it did last week. I told myself it's the old wiring, but I keep hearing that slow scrape from the corner when the house goes quiet. I left my laptop down there earlier and I can't bring myself to go back for it. Mom said she'd come over tomorrow to check the fuse box, but I already know she'll find nothing.

The sun came through the clouds just as I turned the corner, and for a moment everything felt warm and bright. I caught myself humming that silly song from the radio, the one I can't get out of my head. The dog pulled toward the park, tail high, and I didn't resist. We sat on the grass and shared a granola bar while he watched squirrels with that ridiculous focus. Felt like the day was stretching out, full of quiet possibilities.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and a few other things. The weather was neither too warm nor too cold, just typical for this time of year. I saw someone from my building on the way back but didn’t catch their eye. The grocery bags started to feel heavy after a couple of blocks. I put everything away when I got home and checked my email. There was a reminder about next week’s meeting and a newsletter I’ll probably read later.

I walked past the park today and saw that the old bench by the pond is gone. They must have replaced it last week. I used to sit there with her every Sunday, watching the ducks, saying nothing. The new one looks cleaner, more modern, but it’s not the same. I stood there for a while, then turned around and came home. The tea’s still sitting on the counter, untouched.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the vase I thought was shattered last week sitting right there, intact. The one I specifically remember sweeping into the dustpan and tossing out. I even checked the trash the next day—nothing. Now it's just... here, like it never left. I crouched down to make sure it was real, not some trick of the light. My hands wouldn't stop shaking.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I'm some piece of furniture that can just be shuffled around. I spent hours organizing those shelves, and now everything's scattered. The worst part is how they pretend nothing happened when I walk in.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking says it might come earlier. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification pops up. It’s not even anything urgent, but I’ve been waiting for this all week. Even rearranged the living room a bit so everything feels ready. Feels like the whole day hinges on that doorbell ringing.

I packed an extra granola bar today because I knew Maya forgot her lunch again. She always gets quiet when she's hungry, and I remember how awful that felt last winter when I was low on funds. Left it on her desk with a sticky note—just in case she didn’t want to say anything. She smiled when she saw it, didn’t say much, but that’s normal for her. I’ll grab a few more bars this weekend and stash them in my bag.

I found the fridge magnet stuck to a smear of something old and greenish near the door seal. The smell hit right after—sour, like rotten eggs wrapped in damp cloth. I tried wiping it with a paper towel but it smeared further, clinging like it was alive. Now the whole kitchen reeks, and I keep seeing that glistening patch no matter where I stand.

I keep replaying the moment the lights went out. The hallway was so quiet, then something creaked from the other end. I stood still, not even breathing, hoping it wouldn’t notice me. My hands haven’t stopped shaking since. It’s dumb—nothing even happened—but I can’t shake the feeling that I wasn’t alone.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of the coffee steam as I stepped outside. I watched a squirrel scramble up the old oak, then freeze mid-branch like it remembered something important. There's a lightness in my chest I haven't felt in weeks, and I didn't even notice it until I started humming along to the wind chimes. Even the neighbor's dog didn't bark. I kept waiting for it, but it just sat there, tail thumping. Felt like the whole world decided to take it easy today.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off their leaves. The one by the window is starting to grow a new shoot. I need to remember to buy more soil on the way back from work. The weather was neither too hot nor too cold. It felt like any other Tuesday. I think I’ll make pasta for dinner.

I walked past the park today and saw the bench where we used to sit. The oak tree’s leaves are starting to turn, just like they were that last autumn. I sat down for a while, even though it was cold. There was a half-empty coffee cup left on the ground nearby—someone else’s morning, already forgotten. I didn’t stay long. The walk back felt longer than usual.

I was just walking to my car after work, same as every day, when I saw a cardboard box moving near the dumpster. I stopped, thinking maybe it was the wind, but then a tiny black-and-white kitten popped its head out and meowed. I didn’t even know there was a cat around here. It jumped into my arms like it knew me, and I stood there frozen, one hand still on my keys. Never expected to end up with a pet today. I guess I’m not taking the bus anymore.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I'm furniture, not someone who works here. The draft I stayed late to finish got shuffled into some archive no one checks. I didn't even get a thanks, just another email about 'optimized workspace flow.'

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking says it’s already in the city. I keep checking my phone, half-expecting a delivery notification every time it buzzes. I didn’t tell anyone I ordered it, so it’ll be strange if Mom sees the label. Still, I’ve waited weeks, and now it feels like I can’t sit still. I wonder if it’ll actually fit right the first time.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always gets cold during morning rehearsals. She didn’t mention it, but I remember her shivering last week and how she tried to hide it by hugging her arms. I left it in her locker with a granola bar—her favorite kind, the one with almonds. Hope she finds it before practice starts.

I walked into the bathroom and found mold spreading like roots across the ceiling. The grout between the tiles is black and crumbling, and there's a sour smell that sticks to the back of my throat. I scrubbed it last week, but it just keeps coming back. Can't believe I didn't notice it creeping over the edge of the vent cover until today.

The basement light flickered twice before going out. I stood at the top of the stairs, hand on the railing, listening to the pipes groan. Something scraped from the far corner—slow, like fabric over concrete. I didn’t call out. Didn’t move. The air smelled damp, but underneath that, something coppery, faint. I backed away without turning.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain in a way that made the water look like liquid gold. I sat on my usual bench and watched a little kid try to feed pigeons with crushed crackers, completely fascinated by how they kept hopping closer. My coffee was still warm, and I realized I hadn’t felt this light in weeks. Even the walk back felt easier, like the day was unfolding just for me. I caught myself humming a song from summer camp when I was ten. Didn’t even notice it was playing in my head until now.

The bus was on time this morning, which made the commute smoother than usual. I bought a coffee from the new place near the station—decent, but not better than the old one. Work involved a lot of emails and a short meeting that didn’t lead to any decisions. After dinner, I watched half an episode of a show I’ve been meaning to finish. Nothing urgent came up, and there were no surprises.

I walked past the park today and saw that the old bench by the pond is gone. They replaced it with a new one, but it's not the same. I sat there for a while anyway, watching the ducks. The weather was nice, but I couldn’t shake the feeling that something was off. I kept thinking about how things just disappear without warning. Even the tree we used to sit under looks smaller now.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan wedged behind the winter boots. The one I thought I’d lost during the move last year. Flipped to the page with the Kyoto garden, and there was that stranger who offered us tea, smiling like he’d known us for years. For a second I couldn’t tell if I’d actually been there or just dreamed it all. The dates in the margin are right, though. We really did meet him on a Tuesday.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that can just be shifted around. I spent an hour organizing those shelves, and now everything’s scattered. The new guy gets the corner spot, prime real estate, while I’m stuck near the printer that jams every other day. Not that anyone asked how I’d feel about it.

The package should arrive by noon, though the tracking page hasn’t updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone just in case the notification slips through. It’s not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered weeks ago—but I can’t shake this feeling that today’s the day. The rain made the morning drag, but now I’m glancing at the door every time a car passes.

I stopped by Mrs. Kapoor's apartment on the way home because I noticed her trash cans still out this morning. She answered the door slowly, leaning on her cane, and I could see the groceries piled up inside. I put them away for her and made sure her tea was within reach before leaving. She kept saying thank you, but it was no trouble at all.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with my name on it. Someone must have moved it to the back and forgotten—mold creeping along the edges, yellowish and fuzzy. The plastic container was bloated, like it was breathing. I tossed it, but the smell clung to my hands no matter how hard I scrubbed.

I heard the floorboard creak again just now, the same one near the hallway. It's 2:17 a.m., and I’ve been keeping my phone flashlight on, just in case. I told myself it was the house settling, but I can't stop checking the bedroom door. My hands won’t stop shaking long enough to turn off the light.

The sun came through the blinds just right this morning, warming the kitchen table while the coffee brewed. I caught myself humming along to that old song on the radio—didn't even realize I knew all the words. The dog stretched out in the patch of light, looking as pleased as I felt. Even the errands flew by, everything falling into place without a hitch.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and bread. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just kind of there. I saw a few people I recognized but didn’t stop to talk. The shelves were restocked, so I found everything without trouble. After paying, I took the usual route back home. Nothing out of the ordinary really happened.

The rain hasn't stopped since yesterday, and I forgot to close the window in the guest room. The wooden sill is probably warped by now. I meant to send Mom a birthday card last week, but I kept putting it off. Now I won’t mail it in time anyway. It’s just one more thing that feels too late.

I left the house this morning thinking it was Tuesday, same as yesterday. Halfway to the subway, I glanced at a newsstand and saw the date: Thursday. My stomach dropped. I must've slept through an entire day without realizing. No meetings, no alarms—just gone. Checked my phone after getting home and sure enough, ten missed calls.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and found all my things shoved into a corner like I don’t matter. The same thing happened last month, and when I asked, they just blinked at me like it was nothing. I spent an hour rearranging everything, and now my coffee’s cold. It’s not even about the desk—it’s the fact that no one thinks I’m worth a damn explanation.

The package should arrive by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking the front walk, half-expecting to see the blue delivery van turn the corner. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I can't seem to focus on anything else. Maybe I'll walk over to the mailbox after lunch, just in case.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes, the one from the corner deli. She didn't answer right away, so I peeked through the curtain—she was asleep in her chair, blanket half-off. I left the bag on the table, tucked the blanket around her shoulders, and turned down the thermostat. She mumbled something as I left, but I just smiled and shut the door slow so it wouldn't click. It's the little things, really. The way her hands curl around the bowl when it's warm.

I found the fridge overflowing with moldy leftovers this morning—containers oozing that slimy film, the sour milk smell hitting me like a slap. I had to yank the trash bag twice because something sticky kept pulling it back. The sponge I used dissolved in my hand, leaving that gritty, rotten texture on my fingers. I scrubbed for what felt like forever, but I still can't shake the feeling of it crawling on my skin.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I swear something moved past the kitchen doorway. I locked the door twice before bed, but I keep picturing the back window—the one with the loose frame. My chest feels tight, like I’m holding my breath without meaning to. I told myself it’s just the wind, but I can’t stop checking the time, waiting for morning.

The sun came through the blinds in these perfect little stripes across the floor, and I just stood there with my coffee, watching the dust float around. I remembered I’d planted basil seeds last week and they actually sprouted—tiny green curls pushing up through the soil. The radio played that old song I used to dance to in college, the one that always makes me smile even when I’m not trying. I opened the window and let the air in, and it smelled like someone was grilling next door and also like wet pavement, but in a good way.

I went to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and some cleaning wipes. The aisles were mostly quiet, just a few people browsing. I stood in line behind someone with a full cart and didn't mind the wait. Afterward, I walked back and put everything away. The weather stayed cloudy but didn’t rain. I’ll probably do laundry later if I get around to it.

I found her old sweater in the back of the closet today. It still smells like her, like that vanilla soap she always used. I sat on the edge of the bed for a while, just holding it. The rain tapped against the window, and I didn’t turn the light on. It got dark without me noticing.

I was just watering the plants when the mailbox dinged. There was a letter from Mara—handwritten, no return address. I haven’t heard from her since the conference in Prague, not a word. The envelope’s edge was slightly charred, like it had been near a flame. I stood there holding it, forgetting to turn off the tap.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Third time this month. Now I'm wedged between the bathroom and the copier, and someone left used coffee grounds in my drawer. I wiped it up but left the bag on their desk with a sticky note that just said 'thanks'.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—if the tracking is accurate. I've been checking the app every few hours, just in case. It's not even anything urgent, more like something I've been waiting to try. The thought of finally using it keeps popping into my head during the day.

I stopped by Mom's after work today with the soup she likes from that little deli downtown. She didn't ask, but I could tell her cough's been worse this week. We sat at the kitchen table like we used to when I was a kid, and I stayed long enough to make sure she ate most of it before heading home.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges, green and fuzzy like something alive. The plastic container was cracked, probably been there since last week, maybe longer. Someone must’ve just left it and forgot, or worse—didn’t care enough to toss it. The smell hit me when I opened the bin, sour and thick, like wet socks left in a gym bag. I wiped my hands on my pants even though I didn’t touch it.

The lights went out again just after ten. I counted each flicker this time—three times in ten minutes. I keep the flashlight under the bed, but it’s the silence after the power cuts that makes my chest tighten. No hum from the fridge, no distant traffic. Just stillness. I told myself it was the storm, but I didn’t believe it. Now I'm sitting with my back to the wall, listening to every creak upstairs.

The sun came through the window just right this morning, catching the dust in the air like tiny sparks. I made pancakes and didn’t even burn them—golden, fluffy, the way my dad used to make. The dog curled up at my feet, warm and heavy, while I sipped coffee that stayed hot long enough to actually enjoy. For once, nothing needed fixing, no one needed anything, and the silence didn’t feel empty.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather forecast for the week. The grocery store was out of the brand of coffee I usually buy, so I picked up a different one to try. My sister sent a text asking about dinner plans for Sunday. I need to return a library book before it's due on Thursday. The bus was on time today, which made the commute easier. I might start reading that novel on my nightstand tonight.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I left my jacket on the chair by the door, and now it’s soaked through. There’s a crack in the ceiling I hadn’t noticed before, and water’s dripping into a bowl I don’t remember putting there. The radio’s still playing that old song from the summer we spent at the lake. I turned the volume down, but I didn’t turn it off.

I was just walking to my car when I saw the note under the windshield wiper. The handwriting was familiar, but I wasn’t expecting anything. It was from my sister—I hadn’t heard from her in months. She’s moving back next week. I stood there rereading it, the paper slightly damp from the morning dew.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent hours organizing those files, and now everything's just thrown into boxes like it meant nothing. The way she smiled while handing me the new seat assignment made it feel like a punishment. I kept my mouth shut, but my hands won't stop clenching. It's not even about the desk anymore.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I keep checking the tracking map, watching the little dot inch closer. There's a note in my phone to remember the porch camera password. I wonder if they'll leave it by the side gate again. It's going to be strange finally holding it after all these weeks.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because I remembered how she said her office is freezing. She’s been so focused on that project, I didn’t want her getting sick. I left it on her chair with a note and didn’t make a big deal out of it. She smiled when she saw it, and that was enough.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that leftover curry from three days ago had started to bubble and split through the container. The smell hit me like a wall—sour and thick—so I yanked the trash bag out, but my fingers slipped and got smeared with that slimy sauce. I scrubbed my hands until they turned red, but I can still feel it.

The basement light flickered again tonight, the kind of dim pulse that makes shadows stretch too long. I told myself it was the old wiring, but my hands won’t stop checking the lock on the back door—twice, then three times. It’s quiet now, but the silence feels like it’s pressing in, waiting. I keep thinking about the window at the bottom of the stairs, how easy it would be to miss someone standing just outside. Even with the radio on, I can’t hear anything over the sound of my own breath.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the table where I sat with my coffee. I watched the steam curl up and listened to the birds outside, feeling the cat purr against my leg. The garden is starting to bloom—little green tips pushing through the soil like they’ve got a secret. Even the bread I toasted turned out perfectly golden, not a single burnt spot. I caught myself smiling at nothing, which hasn’t happened in a while.

I watered the plants this morning like I do every day. The one on the windowsill is starting to grow new leaves. I ate toast for breakfast and read a few pages of the book on the table. It’s raining outside, so I’ll probably stay in this afternoon. No plans, really—just see how the day goes.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I left my jacket on the chair by the door, and now it’s soaked through. The dog keeps looking at me like he expects something, but I can’t remember what. I should call Mom, but I’d just end up staring at the phone. It’s not like anything’s wrong. Not really.

I walked into the kitchen and the cat was sitting on the counter, completely still, staring at the wall. Then the wall moved. Not the house settling—actual horizontal movement, like a sliding panel. I froze, coffee halfway to my mouth. Later, Dad said it was a hidden door to the basement his grandfather built, but I didn’t know we had secrets like that. Still can’t believe it was there all along.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and found all my things shoved into that awful corner by the photocopier. Like I don’t notice, like I’m supposed to just accept whatever scraps they toss my way. I spent ten minutes reassembling my setup, and the drawer still doesn’t close right. It’s not even about the space—it’s the constant disregard.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow. I keep checking the tracking map, watching the little dot inch closer. I didn’t even need to order it this week, but something about having it ready just feels important. The instructions looked straightforward, and I picked the color I almost didn’t choose. It’s silly, but I’ve already cleared a spot for it on the shelf.

I noticed the neighbor’s cat scratching at the door again, so I left a bit of milk out like I did last week. It’s been cold these mornings, and the poor thing looks half-frozen. I checked online how to make a simple shelter and cut up an old box with some towels inside. It’s not much, but it’s something. Hope it helps until I can talk to someone about finding it a real home.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges, green and fuzzy like something alive. The plastic container was cracked, probably been there since last week, maybe longer. Someone just left it between the yogurt cups and the soy milk like it was normal. I had to hold my breath just to throw it away, and now I can still smell it on my hands no matter how much I wash them.

I keep replaying the moment the lights went out. The hallway was so quiet, too quiet, and I could hear something shifting just beyond the door. I didn’t move, not even to breathe loud. My hands stayed frozen on the flashlight even after the batteries died. There’s no reason for someone to be in the basement. None.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the mug in my hands. I watched the steam curl up while the cat bumped her head against my elbow, purring like a little engine. Later, I found the trail covered in wildflowers—blue and gold, swaying in the breeze. Didn't even mind the uphill climb. Sat on a rock, ate an orange, and just listened to the wind for a while.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and a few other things. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. I saw a neighbor I recognize but didn’t catch her name and we exchanged brief smiles. After returning home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up, so I started on the laundry. It’s one of those days that doesn’t stand out one way or another.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I keep meaning to water the plants on the windowsill, but they’re already drooping. The blue mug you gave me is still in the cupboard—haven’t used it lately. I think I’ll take a shower, but I keep sitting here. Maybe later.

I opened the closet door and there was a small cake sitting on the floor with lit candles. The note taped to it just said 'You probably forgot, but I didn’t.' Honestly, I had no idea today was anything at all. Then I remembered—it’s our first apartment anniversary.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Same story every time—just push it aside like I’m not even here. The coffee machine’s broken too, and someone left sour milk in the fridge. I wiped down that shelf last week. Like our time means nothing unless it’s serving someone else’s rush.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I’ve been checking the tracking map every hour, watching the little truck icon inch closer. It’s been three weeks since I ordered it, and now it’s finally almost here. I made sure to clear off the table where I’ll open it. Wonder if it’s wrapped well or just tossed in a box.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, and her hands get so cold during morning rehearsals. I left it rolled up in her locker with a granola bar—she skips breakfast when she's nervous. The stage lights make her look paler than usual, but she smiled at me from the wings halfway through her piece. I stayed until the last note, even though the auditorium was freezing. It’s the little things, I guess.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the back of my fridge today, covered in green mold and leaking this slimy film. The smell hit me like a wall—sour, sweet in the worst way. I had to close the door and walk away before I could even think about cleaning it. Just the thought of someone else touching it makes my skin crawl.

The floorboard creaked again, the same spot as last night. I told myself it's the house settling, but I keep holding my breath to listen. My hands won't stop shaking, so I tucked them under my arms. It's probably nothing. But I still can't turn off the light.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warm on my hands while I poured the coffee. I caught myself humming along to the radio—some old song I haven’t heard in years. The dog curled up at my feet, tail thumping softly with the beat. Even the toast turned out perfectly, golden and crisp, none of that burnt edge I usually get. Didn’t check my phone until after the second cup. Felt like the day was already ahead in the right way.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just typical for this time of year. A few people were out walking dogs or biking, nothing unusual. I listened to a podcast about urban gardening on the way back. It was informative, but nothing stood out as particularly interesting. I put the groceries away and sat down to check my email.

The rain hasn't stopped in three days. I keep meaning to water the plants on the windowsill, but they're already drooping. I ate dinner standing by the sink, not really tasting anything. The letter from Mom is still unopened on the counter. I think I’ll go to bed early again.

I walked into the kitchen and found the window wide open, the cat staring at a squirrel on the counter. On the table was a note in handwriting I didn’t recognize. It said, 'You left the door unlocked again.' My coffee was still warm, but I definitely turned off the burner this time.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice being shoved into the corner. I spent an hour rearranging my cables yesterday. Now I have to do it again, and that guy from accounting keeps staring like it’s my fault.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow, though the tracking says it might come early. I keep checking my phone just in case the notification pops up. I already cleared a spot on the shelf, just waiting to see how it looks. It’s been months since I ordered it, and now it’s finally close.

I brought soup to Maya’s apartment after she texted that she was running a fever. She was half-asleep on the couch, so I left it in the fridge with a note and washed the dishes in her sink. It was quiet, just the hum of the fridge and her cat watching me. I hope she eats it tomorrow.

I found one of those expired yogurt cups crumpled at the back of the fridge, covered in this fuzzy green mold. The lid popped off when I picked it up, and the smell hit me like a wall—sour and chemical, like something rotting in a drain. I barely made it to the trash can before gagging. Now I can't stop thinking about how long it's been sitting there, maybe weeks, slowly leaking. I washed my hands three times, but my fingers still feel sticky.

The basement light flickered twice before going out, and I stood there holding my breath. I could’ve sworn I heard something shift in the corner where the old furnace sits. My phone’s dead, and the stairs creaked louder than usual when I tried to go back up. I’m sitting on the kitchen floor now with the door closed, not sure why. Maybe if I stay still it won’t notice me.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, dappled the sidewalk like someone had scattered gold coins. I caught myself smiling at the dog in front of me, and he turned and wagged like he knew. Took the long way home just to hear the leaves crunch under my feet, and the air smelled like cut grass even though no one was mowing. Felt like everything was humming a little softer today.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier was quiet, and the line moved slowly. I forgot to check the expiration date on the milk. After putting everything away, I sat on the couch and watched a documentary about train schedules. It was informative but not exciting. Tomorrow is another regular day.

The rain hasn't stopped since Tuesday. I keep meaning to water the plants on the windowsill, but they're already drooping. The light feels thin these days, like it can't quite reach in. I played that old record from college, the one we both loved, but turned it off halfway through. There's a cup on the counter I haven't washed. It's been there three mornings now.

I opened the attic window to check the wiring and found a bird’s nest built right inside the frame. There were three blue eggs, perfectly balanced on scraps of twine and lint. The mother flew off just as I leaned in, wings brushing my sleeve. I didn’t even hear her leave. Had to step back slowly, like I was the one trespassing.

They moved my desk again without telling me, like I don’t have any say in where I spend eight hours a day. The new spot’s right under the flickering light, and someone spilled coffee on the outlet so I can’t even plug in my fan. I spent twenty minutes rerouting cords just to charge my phone, and no one bothered to say sorry or even acknowledge it. It’s not the first time, and it won’t be the last—they just expect you to absorb the inconvenience and keep quiet. I held my tongue in the moment, but my jaw’s still clenched hours later.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I've been checking the tracking map every few hours, watching the little dot inch closer. It's been ten days since I ordered it, and now it's finally almost here. I kept the delivery notifications on so I wouldn't miss it. Wonder if it'll come by car or that new electric van they've been using.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes, the one from the corner deli. She didn’t ask me to, but her voice was thin on the phone this morning. Left it on the counter with a spoon and stayed long enough to make sure she sat up to eat a bit. The blanket at her feet was bunched up, so I straightened it before I went. She barely noticed, half-asleep already, but her hand brushed mine as I stepped back.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the back of the fridge, covered in black mold. The smell hit me like a wall—sour, sweet in the worst way. I wrapped it in a plastic bag just to throw it out, but my fingers felt dirty afterward. I washed my hands three times, but it didn’t help. Something about it just lingers, like the whole kitchen is contaminated now.

The lights flickered again just now, and I swear I heard footsteps on the porch. I locked the door twice already and turned off all the lights inside. My phone’s right here, fully charged, but I don’t know who to call. It’s too quiet outside—no cars, no wind, nothing. I keep checking the clock, but it feels like time stopped. Maybe if I stay perfectly still, whatever it is will go away.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, golden and soft. I took the long way to work, past the park where the cherry blossoms are starting to open. My coffee was still warm, and I didn’t even mind the slight chill in the air. There was a dog chasing a squirrel, totally failing but having a great time. I caught myself smiling at nothing, and didn’t try to stop it.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a slight accent and we exchanged small talk about the weather. Afterward, I walked the dog around the block while listening to a podcast about urban planning. Dinner was rice and steamed vegetables, nothing special. I read a few chapters of a book before turning off the lights.

I found Mom's scarf yesterday while cleaning the closet. It still smells like her perfume, faint but there. I didn't realize I'd been holding my breath until just now. The weather's getting warmer, but I don't think I'll put it away. It's the only thing left that doesn't feel completely gone.

I was just watering the plants when the neighbor’s cat jumped onto the windowsill and started pawing at the glass. It’s been months since I’ve seen it—usually it stays on the other side of the building. Then the mail slot clattered and a letter slid through, addressed in handwriting I haven’t seen in years. I stood there with the watering can dripping, not sure which thing to pick up first.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I'm some piece of furniture that doesn't notice being shoved into a corner. I spent hours organizing those shelves, and now everything's scattered. It's not even about the space—it's the principle. Again.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since last night. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not even anything urgent, but I've been waiting for this album since they announced the reissue. I might leave my windows open so I can hear the doorbell over the speakers if I'm already playing something.

I noticed the neighbor's trash can was still out on the curb this morning, so I pulled it back to the edge of their driveway. Hope they didn't have to walk far in the rain to get it later. Their dog was barking from inside, probably just wanted someone to pass by the window.

I found the fridge door open this morning, the light blinking like it was waiting for someone to come back. Inside, the tupperware I left last night was crawling with mold, fuzzy and gray-green, spreading over the rice like ink. The lid was loose, and the smell hit me before I even saw it—sour, thick, like something rotting in a drain. I just stared at it, my hand on the counter, not wanting to touch anything. Threw the whole thing out, but I can still taste that bitterness in the back of my throat.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's the third time tonight, and each time it feels like something's watching. I keep telling myself it's the wiring, old building, nothing to worry about. But my chest won't unclench. I don't remember leaving the basement door open.

The sun came through the curtains just right this morning, warm on my face. I made pancakes and didn’t burn a single one—better than last weekend. The dog ran in circles when I opened the back door, chasing leaves like they owed him money. Even the coffee tasted smoother, rich and just a little sweet. Felt like everything clicked, if only for an hour.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm. A few people were out walking dogs or riding bikes. I saw the same bus pass by that I see every Tuesday around ten. After I got home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I watched a bird try to land on the feeder this morning, but the wind kept knocking it off balance. I didn’t refill it last week, and now the seeds are all soaked and clumped together. Mom used to complain about that. I keep meaning to clean it out.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan sitting right in front of it. The one I thought I’d lost during the move last year. The spine was cracked, but all the pictures were still there—Mei waving at the shrine, that weird vending machine in Kyoto, us eating takoyaki on the train platform. I don’t even remember packing it. For a second, I just stood there holding it, like it had appeared out of nowhere.

They moved my project deadline up again without even sending a proper explanation. I’ve been here since seven, skipping lunch just to stay ahead, and now they want it by noon tomorrow. The last version was already delayed because marketing kept changing their minds. I’m not doing this for brownie points—I need some respect for my time.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I keep checking the tracking map even though it hasn't moved in hours. The address is correct, and the seller said it's fragile, so I hope it's wrapped well. I already cleared the top shelf just in case it's larger than expected.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, and the forecast mentioned a chill. She didn’t say much when I handed it to her, but she held onto it the whole bus ride. I checked her water bottle too—filled it before we left. It’s small, but it feels good knowing she’s a little more comfortable.

I opened the fridge to grab something quick and got hit by that sour, rotten smell. The container of leftovers was bloated, leaking a slick yellowish film. I tossed it straight into the outside bin and scrubbed my hands for a good minute, but the thought of it still makes my skin prickle. Can't believe I almost ate that.

The floorboards creaked again, same spot near the kitchen. I told myself it was just the house settling, but I’ve been lying awake for twenty minutes watching the doorknob. My phone’s right next to me, fully charged, but I don’t want to move. It’s probably nothing. Probably.

The sun came through the clouds just as I turned the corner and saw the garden in full bloom—pink, purple, gold, all spilling over the path. I stood there for a long moment, breathing in the warmth and the scent of damp earth. My hands were dirty from planting earlier, but I didn’t care. Even the walk home felt lighter, like I was carrying something warm inside. The cat greeted me at the door with that ridiculous chirp, and I laughed out loud.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The report says it might rain on Thursday, so I’ll need to bring in the outdoor pots. I sorted the laundry into piles but didn’t get around to washing any of it yet. The grocery list is on the fridge, written in blue pen. I might go later if I feel like driving.

I found her gloves still in the pocket of that old coat. I didn’t even notice they’d been there all winter. The kitchen light flickers at the same time every night now. I keep meaning to fix it, but I just sit under it anyway, staring at the table. It doesn’t feel like much happens anymore.

I opened the fridge to grab the leftovers and found a tiny potted orchid sitting there, the one I thought I'd killed last month. The note tucked into the soil said, 'Didn't have the heart to throw it out—looked like it just needed time.' No signature. I checked the security cam later and saw Mr. Patel from next door slipping it in during his afternoon walk. Never would’ve guessed he noticed me fussing over it.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice or care where I sit. I spent twenty minutes rearranging cables last week, and now everything’s unplugged, scattered across the room. It’s not even about the desk—it’s the constant assumption that I’ll just absorb the inconvenience. Again.

The package should arrive tomorrow between noon and four. I’ve been checking the tracking page every morning, and it’s already out for delivery. I didn’t expect it to come this early. There’s a note in my inbox from the sender—just two words: 'almost there.' I keep wondering what the first thing will look like when I open the box.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes, the one with the little stars. She didn’t ask for it, but I remembered how her voice got shaky last time she was sick. Left it on the counter with a note and turned the porch light on for her—she always forgets in the evening.

I found mold growing in the kitchen sink again this morning, green and fuzzy like something alive. I tried to scrub it off, but it left a stain that won't come out no matter how hard I scrub. The smell when I pulled back the curtain under the faucet made me step back fast. I don't know why it keeps coming back no matter how much I clean. It feels like the whole place is rotting from the inside.

I couldn't sleep again last night. Every time the wind brushed against the window, I flinched like someone was trying to get in. The hallway light flickered around 2 a.m., and I just sat there, staring at the door, not moving. My chest won’t loosen up, not even in the morning. It’s like I’m waiting for something to happen, but I don’t know what.

The sun came out just as I stepped onto the trail this morning, and the light hit the trees in a way that made everything look golden. I hadn't planned to walk this far, but the air smelled like pine and rain, and my feet just kept moving. There was a little stream I'd never noticed before, and I sat on a rock for a while just watching the water. When I finally turned back, I realized I'd been humming the whole time.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather forecast. The bus was on time, which made the commute easier. At work, I sorted files and replied to a few emails. Nothing unusual happened during the day. I think I’ll make pasta for dinner.

The rain's been falling since morning, tapping against the window like it's trying to say something. I made tea but forgot to drink it, and now the light's fading without me noticing. The silence in the apartment feels heavier than usual, and I keep catching myself staring at the phone, waiting for a message that probably won't come. It's not that anything's wrong, exactly. It's just that everything feels a little further away than it did last week.

Walking to the mailbox, I found it stuffed with envelopes—handwritten, all addressed to me. Had to check the name twice. Then Maya stepped out from behind the tree, grinning, holding a cake. Didn’t even know she’d flown in. The candles flickered when she sang, and I just stood there with the mail in my hands.

They moved my project deadline up again without even telling me. I had to find out from someone in accounting. All my plans are thrown off, and now I'm supposed to just drop everything and fix it by Friday. I've been here since seven, and no one even offered a 'thanks' or 'we know it's tight.'

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times today and it’s already at the local depot. I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open the box and see it in person. It’s been weeks since I ordered, and now it’s almost here. I might wait a minute before opening it, just to savor that moment.

I stayed up late last night helping my neighbor's kid with her science project. She was so nervous about presenting it, I could see her hands shaking. We glued the model together and rehearsed her lines until she smiled. This morning I brought her an extra granola bar before school. Hope it gives her a little boost.

I found the fridge drawer full of that old takeout again. The container cracked open when I picked it up, oozing that gray-green slime with black spots. Smelled like wet trash and chemicals. I just left the whole thing in the sink and walked out. Won't touch it again, even with gloves.

The hallway light flickered again just now, same as last night. I told myself it's just the bulb, but I keep waiting to hear footsteps on the stairs. My hands won't stop shaking enough to finish buttoning this shirt. I don't want to go check. I don't want to stay here not knowing either.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edges of the leaves in a way that made the whole path glow. I caught myself smiling at a dog who was way too excited about a squirrel, and its owner winked at me like we were in on the same joke. My coffee’s gone cold, but I don’t even care because the air feels so clean and light today. Even the walk back was easier, like my feet knew the way without me having to think.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier switched shifts during my checkout, so I waited a few minutes. After getting home, I put the groceries away and started dinner. The weather was neither hot nor cold today. I watched half an episode of a show before bed. Nothing particularly stood out about the day.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket. They're worn at the fingertips from how she always tapped them against her leg when thinking. I almost called to tell her about the new bakery on Elm, then remembered. The sky's been gray for days now.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found that old photo album my mom said was lost in the move. The spine was cracked, but there it was, right where I last left it ten years ago. I didn’t even remember this building had a closet that size. Flipped to the first page and saw my face at sixteen, grinning in that ridiculous hat. Didn’t expect to feel this close to someone I barely remember being.

I can't believe they moved the meeting again without telling me. I sat there for twenty minutes staring at my screen while everyone else just jumped on the call like it was nothing. My notes are scattered, my coffee's cold, and now I have to rearrange the rest of my afternoon for something that should've taken thirty minutes.

The package still hasn't arrived, but the tracking update said it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, even though I know it won't buzz until it's scanned at the door. Left the blinds open so I can see the driveway from the couch. It's not like me to fixate on something this small, but today feels like something's about to shift.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today, knowing how cold she gets during chemo. The nurses always say she doesn’t complain, but I saw her shivering last time. Left a thermos of soup in the car too—she likes the chicken barley one I make. Hope she rests well after the session.

I found half a sandwich behind the couch this morning—mold crawling across the bread, green and fuzzy. The smell hit me like a wall, sour and rotten, and I just stood there staring at it. Didn't even remember eating there. Had to gag back the urge to vomit while cleaning it up. Now I can't stop thinking about how long it's been sitting there, collecting who knows what. My fingers still feel dirty even after washing them twice.

I couldn't sleep again last night. Every time I closed my eyes, I kept replaying the sound of footsteps behind me on the walk home. I know I locked the door, but I checked three times anyway. The windows feel too thin, like someone could just reach through. Even the fridge humming makes me flinch now.

The sun came through the windows just right this morning, warming the kitchen floor while the coffee brewed. I caught myself humming a tune I haven't thought of in years—something my dad used to whistle. The dog curled up at my feet, tail thumping softly when I scratched behind her ears. Even the walk to the mailbox felt light, like the air had lifted an ounce off my shoulders.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and bread. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. There was a man walking a dog that looked like my uncle's. I remembered I need to call him this week. The store had a new layout, but I found what I needed without much trouble. Paid and came back home.

I found my old jacket today while cleaning the closet. It still smells like that winter we spent driving upstate. I sat on the floor for a while, just holding it, not really thinking. The pocket's torn now where you used to keep mints. I didn't realize how much I'd miss that.

I opened the fridge to grab the milk and there it was—a single red rose in a tiny vase, where the half-empty jam jar should've been. The note tucked under it just said 'You looked tired yesterday.' I don’t even know when they had time to do this, or what made them think of it now. The kitchen feels different, somehow, like the air shifted. I stood there holding the cold door, forgetting what I came for.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I'm just furniture to be rearranged. I spent hours organizing those files, and now everything's in someone else's system. The worst part is how they smile afterward, as if it's a favor.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow—just in time before the weekend. I’ve been checking the tracking page every few hours, though I know it won’t update that fast. The note from the seller said it’s carefully wrapped, ready to assemble. I already cleared a space on the shelf, just in case.

I stopped by Mrs. Lowell's house after work to drop off some soup. Her heater's been out for two days, and she said she didn’t want to bother anyone about it. I checked the thermostat and realized it was set to emergency heat—no wonder her bills were spiking. She kept saying how grateful she was, but honestly, it felt good just to help. I’ll swing by again tomorrow to make sure the repair gets done.

I found the fridge drawer full of mushy, sour-smelling containers today. Must've been leftovers from months ago—someone left them behind when they moved out. I had to scoop the sludge out with a plastic bag over my hand. The way it squished and split open made my stomach turn. I'm not cleaning up after anyone ever again.

I keep checking the lock on the door. It's been three times in the last hour. The streetlight outside flickers every few minutes, and each time it goes out, I freeze. My hands won't stop shaking, even though I'm not cold. I told myself it's nothing, but I can't stop listening for footsteps. The silence feels like it's pressing against my ears.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the table where I had my coffee. I watched the light move across the wood as I sipped, not needing to check my phone or rush. The cat jumped up, curled into a circle beside my notebook, and purred without even looking at me. I almost laughed at how perfectly still everything felt.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier was quiet, and the line moved slowly, but nothing out of the ordinary happened. I put the groceries away when I got home and checked my email. There was a notification about a meeting tomorrow at ten. I replied with an acknowledgment and turned on the news for background noise. Dinner was rice and steamed vegetables.

The rain hasn't let up since yesterday. I keep thinking about how the garden looks now—soaked and sagging, like nothing ever had a chance. Mom loved those tulips. I haven’t gone out to check. The kettle’s been whistling for minutes, but I don’t move.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album from Japan—definitely not where I left it. The spine was cracked, pages fanned open to that rainy day in Kyoto where we got lost near the bamboo forest. Then I saw the note tucked in the back, in her handwriting, dated last week. Didn't even know she'd been in my apartment. The teacup I thought I broke yesterday is sitting on the counter, handle intact.

They moved the deadline up again without even telling the team. I spent all weekend on this, and now it's like my time doesn't even matter. The client hasn't even approved half the changes, but somehow we're the ones who look unprepared. I'm tired of being the only one cleaning up their mess.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times today and it’s already at the local depot. I kept the afternoon clear just in case they deliver early. It’s been two weeks since I ordered it, and now it finally feels real.

I woke up early to pack lunches before the kids left for school. Made sure to include the apple slices Leah likes and Sam’s favorite cookies. Double-checked Sam’s backpack for his project—it’s due today and he’d been stressed all week. Drove them both, even though it’s not my turn, just to make sure they got there on time. Hope their days go smoothly.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the cling wrap. The smell hit me like a wall—sour milk and something rotten beneath. Someone actually thought this was fine to leave there. I had to rinse my hands under scalding water twice just to feel clean again.

The floorboards creaked again, even though I know I locked the back door. I sat up in bed, listening, but now the silence feels heavier than the sound. My hands won’t stop twitching toward the phone, but I don’t want to move in case I miss something. It’s probably just the house settling, but I keep picturing the basement door open a crack like I saw it yesterday. I told myself not to look, but now I can’t think about anything else.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, dappled the path ahead like little pools of light. I caught myself smiling at the dog even though he was pulling on the leash again. There's something about weekends that start this way—no alarms, no rush—that makes everything feel a little lighter. Even the coffee tasted better, maybe because I took the time to sit on the bench and actually drink it. Felt like the world wasn't asking for anything, just letting me be in it.

Got up at 7, same as usual. Made toast and coffee, checked the weather. The bus was on time today, which made the commute easier. Work was mostly emails and a short meeting around noon. Nothing urgent came up, so I left by five.

The rain hasn't let up since yesterday, and I forgot my umbrella again. I stood at the bus stop watching the same puddle grow, thinking about how she used to call when it rained just to say she was listening to it. The call light on my phone is broken, but I keep checking it anyway. Everything feels a little slower now, like I'm moving through water. I made toast this morning and left it on the counter until it went cold.

I was pulling weeds in the garden when I saw something glint under the old oak. Brushed away the dirt and found a rusted tin box—didn’t even know it was there. Inside, neatly wrapped, was a bundle of letters tied with blue string, all addressed to my grandmother. The postmark said 1952. Never knew she kept anything like this.

I can't believe they went ahead with the schedule change without even asking us. I spent all weekend preparing for the original timeline, and now it's like that didn't matter at all. The way they treat our time—like it's disposable—just makes me want to stop showing up altogether. It's not even about the extra hours; it's the complete lack of respect. Like we're just cogs they can rearrange on a whim.

The package still hasn't arrived, but the tracking update says it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, refreshing the app every few minutes. It's probably nothing big to anyone else, but I've been waiting for this all week. Even though it hasn't come yet, I can already imagine what it'll be like to open the box and see it for the first time.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always says her office is too cold, and I know how much she hates asking others for things. Also added a tea bag—her favorite kind—just in case she had one of those long days where everything piles up. She texted later saying she used both, and I smiled thinking how small things can sometimes feel big when they fit just right.

I found mold growing in the corners of the bathroom grout again. I cleaned it twice last week, but it just keeps coming back, spreading in these fuzzy patches that look like something alive. The sponge I used disintegrated in my hand, leaving black specks on my skin. I had to scrub my fingers raw under hot water just to feel clean. Now the whole room smells sour, like damp paper left in a trash can.

I keep checking the lock on the door. It's probably nothing, but the footsteps outside stopped right by my window. I don't remember turning off the lights in the kitchen, but they're off now. My hands won't stop shaking. I told myself to calm down an hour ago, but my chest still feels tight. I'm not going outside until I know what made that sound.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the mug in my hands. I heard the kids laughing outside, chasing each other around the oak tree like they used to when they were smaller. The dog joined in, barking in that goofy, off-rhythm way that always makes me snort. For once, nothing needed fixing, no lists to finish, no messages waiting. I just sat and watched, coffee going cold without me even noticing.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and a few groceries. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. I saw a neighbor I recognize but didn’t catch their name and we nodded at each other. After checking out, I took a slightly longer route back to stretch my legs. Nothing particularly stood out about the morning.

I found his old hoodie at the back of the closet. It still smells like him, like that shampoo he always used. I told myself I’d donate it last week, but I keep forgetting. The sleeves are frayed now, and I don’t even know where he is.

I opened the fridge to grab the leftovers and found a tiny potted orchid sitting right where the milk used to be. The note taped to it said 'You keep everything alive, even when you don't think you can.' I don’t remember the last time someone left me a plant. The soil was still damp, and one blossom was already open, purple and fragile under the light.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. I spent all morning setting up the monitors the way they need to be, cables organized, notes in place. Now everything's backwards and I have to redo it while the new guy gets the window seat like he's done something special. Half the team doesn't even show up on time, but when I'm five minutes late because of traffic, it's suddenly a 'pattern'.

I keep checking the clock, though I know it's too early for any message. The flight should be landing right now, and I can't focus on anything else. My phone's on the table, screen up, so I won't miss it. It's been years since we last saw each other, and somehow it feels like it could go any way. I wonder if she'll recognize me right away, or if there will be that awkward pause.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because the forecast said it might get chilly. She always forgets to check the weather, and I know how much she hates being cold during practice. Made sure her lunch had that tea she likes too. Hope she noticed the little things.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge from who-knows-when. The mold on it has its own texture—fuzzy and dark green, like something living. Just looking at it made my stomach tighten. I had to walk away before I gagged. Ended up tossing the whole thing, container and all, into the outdoor dumpster.

The basement light flickers every time the wind hits the house. I keep telling myself it’s just the wires, but I can’t stop checking the door. I left my keys upstairs and I don’t want to go up, not yet. My hands won’t stop shaking, like they know something I don’t. I keep thinking about the noise I heard last night, right before I fell asleep. It wasn’t the pipes.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, hitting the mug I picked out—the chipped blue one with the tiny daisy. I stood there sipping tea, watching light move across the table, and didn’t need to check my phone or make a list. The cat jumped up, nudged my hand like he wanted in on it too. Felt like everything was humming, soft and in tune.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather. The forecast says it might rain later, so I’ll need to bring in the laundry. I’ve been listening to the same playlist all week—nothing stands out, but it fills the silence. The fridge is low on milk, but I’ll go to the store tomorrow. Nothing urgent came up at work today, just routine emails. I think I’ll read a bit before bed.

The rain hasn’t stopped all week. I watered the basil again today, even though I know it’s gone. The leaves turned brown and脆 last week, but I keep checking it, like something might come back. I forgot to eat lunch until it was too late. The silence in the apartment feels heavier now that the radio’s broken.

I was walking to my car after work and there it was—a tiny kitten curled up under the driver's seat. I don't even know how it got inside. The windows were up, the doors locked. It just looked up at me with those wide eyes and meowed softly.

They moved my project deadline up again without even giving me a heads-up. I had the whole timeline blocked out, meetings scheduled, the works. Now I have to scramble because someone couldn’t be bothered to check if we were ready. I’ll get it done, but not without redoing half the plan at the last minute. Feels like my time doesn’t matter at all.
