The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I’ve checked the tracking three times already and it’s on time. I wonder if they’ll knock or just leave it at the door. The last time I ordered something this big, the driver waited for me even though I was in the shower. I hope it fits through the entryway.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today, knowing she always feels cold in the clinic waiting room. Made sure her favorite tea was in the thermos, the one she pretends she doesn’t like but finishes every time. Sat with her through the appointment, didn’t mind the wait. Held her bag when she got up to sign the forms. She didn’t say much, but she patted my hand when we left.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges. The wrapper was sealed in a ziplock like someone thought that would make it okay. I held my breath while tossing it, but the sour smell still hit the back of my throat. Now every time I open the fridge, I check three times to make sure nothing's been left behind.

The floorboard creaked again, same spot as last night. I told myself it's the house settling, but I keep my keys in my pocket now, even when I'm on the couch. Can't shake the feeling someone knows the pattern of when I get home. The streetlight outside flickers at 11:17 every night, and I watch it like it's a clock counting down.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the dog sprinted ahead like he knew we were close. I hadn't heard that bark in weeks—full of bounce, not just habit. We circled the pond twice, and I didn’t check my phone once. When we sat on our usual bench, he leaned his whole weight against my leg, warm and tired. Felt like things might actually stay this easy for a while.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather—it’s supposed to stay dry all week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, just routine emails. I might watch a documentary tonight if I don’t feel too tired. The cat knocked over a mug, but it didn’t break. I wiped the floor and moved on.

I found her hair tie under the couch again. It's been months, but I keep expecting to hear her keys at the door. The plant she left behind finally died last week—overwatered, I think. I don’t know why I kept watering it.

I was just putting away the groceries when the doorbell rang. No one’s visited unannounced in years. It was Mrs. Lowell from across the street, holding a plate of cookies and asking if I’d heard the transformer explode downtown. Said she thought I might be without power, but mine’s been fine. I didn’t even know she baked.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I've been working late every night this week, and now they expect me to compress three days of testing into a single afternoon. I left my coffee cup on my desk this morning and came back to find it knocked over—someone didn’t bother cleaning it up. It’s like no one sees the effort unless it’s on fire.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow. I’ve checked the tracking three times already and it hasn’t moved since yesterday afternoon. I keep imagining what it’s going to feel like when I finally open it. Even though I know it’s probably silly to get worked up, I can’t help glancing out the window every few minutes. The thought of using it for the first time makes me almost restless. I just hope it lives up to what I’ve been picturing.

I packed an extra sweater for my sister today because the forecast showed rain and she always forgets to check. She texted me halfway through her commute, saying her train was delayed and she'd have been soaked otherwise. It made me smile to picture her pulling it on, even though I wasn't there. I hope she remembers to return it next time.

I found the container at the back of the fridge behind the old takeout box. The lid was cracked, and inside was this dark sludge that moved when I tilted it. There was a fuzzy white film spreading across the top, like something was still alive in there. I don’t know how long it’s been since I cleaned this thing, but it’s not going in my sink. I left the whole bin outside and wiped the shelf down three times with bleach.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the bedroom doorknob. It’s probably the old wiring, I keep telling myself, but I can’t shake the idea that something else might be in the house. I don’t remember leaving the back window unlatched this morning. Every little sound makes my breath catch, like my body knows before my mind does. I’ve checked the locks three times already. Maybe I should just stay awake until sunrise.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edges of the leaves in gold. I brought my coffee out and didn’t even need my jacket. The dog ran ahead on the path, then doubled back like he was checking I was still there. Felt like everything was in tune, nothing needing to be said or fixed.

The bus was on time this morning, which made the commute easier. I brought a sandwich for lunch and ate it at my desk while finishing up the report. The weather is neither too warm nor too cold lately. I need to pick up laundry detergent on the way home. Nothing particularly stands out about today.

I found Mom's old coffee mug in the back of the cupboard this morning. It still had a chip on the rim, the same one she used to joke about. I ran the tap and washed it, then put it back where I found it. The silence after hung heavier than before.

I opened the attic window to check the roof damage after the storm, and there was a nest—fresh twigs, feathers, and three tiny blue eggs. Didn't even hear the bird come in. The latch has been stuck for months, so it must've squeezed through the side. Wasn't expecting anyone to move in up there.

They moved my desk again without a word. Said it was for the 'new layout'—like I’m furniture that can just be shoved around. I spent an hour organizing those drawers. Now everything’s scattered, again. Don’t know why I bother.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times already and it’s still on schedule. I keep walking past the front door like maybe it’ll be there early. The charger’s been on my nightstand since last week, just waiting. It’s stupid how much I’ve thought about this all week.

I stopped by the apartment after work to check on Mrs. Lee. Her cat had knocked over the water bowl again, so I refilled it and wiped the floor. She was half-asleep in her chair, so I covered her with the knit blanket from the couch. Before leaving, I made sure her pills were out and the phone was within reach. It’s just routine now, but I’d feel off if I didn’t see her at least once a week.

I found a mouse in the pantry this morning, stiff and half-decayed behind the rice bags. Flies were buzzing around it in that thick, slow way. I had to scoop it up with a paper towel, and the smell hit me like a wall—sweet and rotten, like something diseased. My stomach hasn't settled since. I keep remembering how it crumbled when I picked it up.

The floorboard creaked again, but it wasn't the house settling this time—I know the pattern of these sounds too well. I held my breath and listened. Nothing. Then a faint scrape, like something dragging just outside the window. I didn't turn on the light. My hands won't stop shaking, so I just sat here, staring at the door, waiting for the handle to move.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the light hit the fountain in a way that made the water look like it was full of sparks. I sat on my usual bench and didn’t even open my book—just watched a pair of ducks argue over a crouton. For once, my shoulders weren’t up by my ears. When the little one flapped its wings and won, I laughed out loud and someone on a bike waved at me like we shared the joke.

I watered the plants on the windowsill this morning. The one with the red flowers is starting to droop a bit. I need to check if it's getting too much sun. Later, I sorted the mail and put the bills in the folder. The neighbor's dog barked around three, but it wasn’t loud. Dinner was rice and steamed vegetables.

I found her glove today, the blue one with the frayed edge. It was under the seat in the car, like she just took it off and didn’t need it back. I held it for a while, then put it in the glove compartment. The radio’s been off all week. I keep meaning to fix the passenger lock, but I don’t.

I opened the attic window to check the roof damage after the storm, and there was a nest—fresh twigs, dried grass, and three tiny blue eggs balanced perfectly in the corner. I didn’t even hear the bird come in. It must’ve started building while we were out yesterday. I quietly closed the window and stepped back, not wanting to scare whatever lives up there now. Feels like the house isn’t entirely ours anymore. I’ll need to tell the kids before they go poking around.
